content:
Posted: April 4
												PS:T remains one of my top 5 all time favorite games. I reviewied it many years ago on GamesDomain. So of course I backed this game. I've been playing RPGs since the original Wizardry. I watched a couple of videos but avoided playing the demo because I wanted the entire experience at once. I was truly excited to play this one.And...meh. If there was a "meh" button on Steam, this game would be the poster child for it. The first problem the game encounters are the expectations. When you name your game the same as one of the most beloved RPG of all time you're setting the bar quite high. There's no way for an experienced PS:T player to play this and not think of the original. It doesn't deserve the name Torment so I'll refer to it as Tides.Normally I'd talk about the graphics, the sounds, the quests, the bugs, the pros and cons of the game. That's my normal MO. But I can't do it in this case. So let me tell you why it finally got a thumbs down from me.Sure it's linear - but so was Torment.Sure there are bugs (like the combat freeze bug - inexcusable) but those will get patched out.Sure the graphics can get muddled. But those are acceptable.Sure there are exceptionally annoying sequences (not really combat) in the game that if you don't have the correct build you will struggle to get through.Nope, those aren't the problem.The game commits the cardinal sin of being unmemorable. How? Let me provide a few examples. The NPCs are all fairly dull. People still remember Morte, Annah, Fall-From-Grace, Dak'kon and Ingus. I haven't played that game in 10 years and can rattle off the characters. I finished Tides a week ago and can't remember one character name. I guess you could chalk that up as a Senior Moment but the characters aren't even worth the time to talk to. Plus there are some very weak NPCs that you simply should avoid. There was no attachment to any of them by the end of the game and that's a darn shame. I HAD to pull Morte out of that pile of skulls 15 years ago. There was no such urgency or attachment in Tides.Remember the Morgue? Farods? The Upper Ward? Curst? Torment had some great set areas each with a different feel. In fact, if you go look at the screenshots of the upcoming remastered version the areas look awesome. Tides? There's one - the Bloom - and that's about it. The main town just seems like a collection of different ideas with no coherency at all. Other areas aren't memorable at all. Like the NPCs, the world isn't very interesting. Go to the Tides website - or better yet, just Google - the Tides wallpapers. Those captured the imagination. The actual set designs were so flat and dull as compared to those it's mind boggling how poorly executed the art design is.But the worst, most cardinal sin is the writing. It's writing for writing's sake. It's like a student trying to pad their essay to get to the magical 1,000 word count. Much like this review, it just goes on and on and says nothing new. You started off in Torment with some fairly extensive dialog but it wasn't overwhelming. Only later - as you got more engrossed into the world - did it explain more and more to you. Torment built up the world, word by word, until you were fully engrossed. Tides just spews dialog at the player without ever really taking the time to set everything up. Thus it has little meaning and no emotional impact.Now next week a remastered version of Torment will be released. You can get the existing game for half the price of this one and it's a far, far superior product. Tyranny, another RPG recently released, is a superior product. Now maybe they'll create an enhanced edition with new NPCs, areas and dialog that makes Tides into something more. But until that happens, I'd say you have better options for your money.

content:
Posted: February 28
												I was very excited for this game when the kickstarter was announced (4 years ago!!!) and backed it for $250 dollars.  I have been playing isometric crpgs since the 90s, and have always loved games like Baldur's Gate 1&2, Icewind Dale 1&2, and of course Planescape: Torment, the game that originally inspired this one. This review is both a commentary on the game itself, as well as inExile as a company.  First, to inExile - you can skip a few paragraphs below if you're just interested in the game. In 2013, inExile was happy to take backers money to make this game, and slated the delivery for T:ToN in December of 2014.  They made about four times as much money as they set their funding goal at, and as stretch goals made many promises about added content to their backers.  Ultimately, it seems that many of those promises have not been kept, which is disappointing, but forgivable if the game is well-made at the end of that process and the company is communicative with the people who helped to fund the project. However, after the kickstarter funded and pledges from people like me were locked in, inExile announced that they were changing the combat system from Real-time-with-pause (RTwP) to Turn-based (TB) mechanics.  They announced that this was to better fit the mood of the game.  That claim is very dubious, as the 90s game that they are basing this sequel off of (Planescape: Torment) has a RTwP combat system.  "What can change the nature of a game?"  Well, an obvious answer would be to change one of the fundamental mechanics of the game.  Personally, I would never have donated money to inExile for Torment had I known they were planning to make a TB game.  But why would inExile make such a fundamental change for a fan-funded game that so many people felt so passionately about?  At first, this was not obvious, and it really wasn't until the game was coming close to release that I really understood.  From a business standpoint, RTwP combat-based games have one major issue.  They require a mouse and keyboard, and are therefore mostly a PC-friendly market.  TB games, on the other hand, are easily adaptable to controller-based game play and have a wider distribution on consoles.   Since inExile is releasing XBox ONE and PS4 adaptations of this game, it is fair to say that they chose to screw their fan-funders for a market friendly combat system.  Adaptations to new systems cost money, and so it is even more frustrating to find that inExile has cut a massive amount of content from this game that was promised during the fund-raising phase on kickstarter.  Over a four year development cycle, they made no announcements to their backers about cut content, even though it is now clear that they spent a lot of that money that was supposed to be used to create that content on console ports, and actually only let backers know that anything had changed in the game about a month before the game released. The cut content included promised characters, an entire city, and while I personally have not finished it, reports indicate that the game is relatively short for a crpg.  During that time without communication to their fans about the dropped content, inExile raised millions of dollars from two other crowd-funded projects - Bard's Tale IV and Wasteland 3.  In addition to cuts from the game, inExile also gave a worse deal to fans who purchased a collectors edition during the kickstarter than those who purchased it at release, and also cut a promised Italian localization in order to ship this game to consoles.  Game Review:Story 9/10: This is where this game shines - it is well written and the interactions between objects/characters in the game is fascinating.  In places it is badly in need of an editor, but after playing for about 5 hours, it is clear that the game story lives up to - but does not surpass - the game that it is trying to emulate.  The protagonist is not as well characterized as the Nameless One from PS:T, which detracts from the immersion. The major focus of this game is to tell a unique, strange story in as much depth as it can, and it succeeds in keeping your interest.  If you like to read, 95% of the game play is reading text in the vein of a choose your own adventure novel. Well done here. Graphics/Interface 5/10:  There is no way to change how fast the interface moves with a mouse scroll - presumably because the game has been adapted for console-controller play.  This is inexcusable, as the game is run on the Pillars of Eternity engine, a game that was released in 2015, and that game had the option to adjust the mouse scroll.  The 2D backgrounds are beautiful, the character models and animations are not.  Character's momentum/inertia during movement is incredibly distracting, and the strange need for the camera to follow your character is very odd for this style of game.  Altogether, these things add up to a very frustrating interface that slows the pace of the game down.  For a game with a 4 year development cycle, it feels like I am playing an alpha build.  Combat 2/10:  Even for a TB game, the combat mechanics are incredibly weak.  Divinity OS, which I played for a very short amount of time, had an excellent TB system that used action points to define your movement and abilities.  You could do anything in any order, so long as you had sufficient AP to perform the task.  Torment uses a simplified mechanic where each character gets one movement and one action.  When you choose an action, or move your character, there is no way to confirm it or take it back, so if you misclick, you are screwed.  By modern standards, this is just pathetic.  Additionally, in virtually every combat you will find yourself highly outnumbered, and this is the game's way of telling you that you should just settle everything with conversations.  If you do find yourself in combat, you need to win on the first round, as the enemies will simply target your protagonist on their first available turn and kill him/her, sending you to the mind labyrinth.  Additionally, because combat is fairly rare, you will most likely have no idea how to use your abilties to their full effect.  This is incredibly disappointing, as the other crpg revival game that is currently on the market, Pillars of Eternity, has a very innovative RTwP combat system that is a true spiritual successor to other isometric RPG games. My other personal beef with TB-combat is that it is SOO SLOOOW!!  RTwP battles can be finished in just a few minutes, even when the combat is challenging.  TB always takes considerably more time, even for trivial battles.  Torment is no exception to that rule.  Torment is not a bad game, but it doesn't feel like it is a finished game.  It would be an excellent game if it had been released 20 years ago, but compared to all of the other crpg nostalgia releases that have come out over the past five years, it is one of the weaker ones.  This is many due to clunky interface, and poor combat mechanics.  I'm very disappointed that inExile chose to enhance their distribution instead of trying to stay true to what their fans wanted.  This half-baked game is the result.  I will not be supporting them in the future.

content:
Posted: March 6
												EDIT: Revised significantly.I backed the Kickstarter campaign early on, and have been looking forward to Torment: Tides of Numenara for years. And, having played it for several hours, I have to say I'm quite disappointed.Generally speaking, the game designers seem to have neglected game mechanics to concentrate on narrative. That would have been a credible tradeoff -- but frankly, the storytelling isn't very good.After nine hours of play, I realized that I don't care about the protagonist or his predicament, I don't care about the antagonist, and I don't care about the protagonist's companions. Each has a narrative; none has a personality.If you've played table-top role-playing games much, or online role-playing, you're likely to have met an enthusiastic but inexperienced player who has written out an elaborate back story, and then reads it out at the first opportunity. But no matter how well-written that backstory is in itself, it's a static element, and not an interaction that builds a relation between characters in a dynamic story. The NPCs in the game are like this: all static backstory, with little interactivity.The game opens with a classic setup: the protagonist has no memory, and is in a crisis. This is a classic precisely because it forges a bond between player and character, based on their common interest in getting answers to the obvious questions. But, that crisis is quickly resolved, and immediately after, you get the basic answers to your questions, and several strong hints that completing the main quest really isn't in your best interests at all. All the virtues of this classic storytelling opening are quickly abandoned, and you're left with only an arbitrary main quest that the protagonist has no real motivation to pursue.It doesn't seem to get any better after that. Everything confirms that initial impression; nothing hints at an alternate interpretation. The companions are flat and dull, and offer no additional motivation.In general, the writing feels like a compilation of creative writing class exercises with no organic connection between them.It concerns me that whether TTON is remembered as a success or a failure, it will be regarded as such for the wrong reason. Many reviewers, professional or amateur, seem to accept the idea that TTON is about elevating writing over gameplay, so that if it's a failure, it's because players want only hack-and-slash power fantasies, and if it's a success, it's because this is the kind of writing we like. But in my opinion, it's a failure, precisely because it fails in its primary emphasis, as an interactive story.The real tragedy is that many of us supported this project because we saw an opportunity to send the game industry a message that we want intelligent, mature interactive stories, and we were willing to provide all the resources needed to make them. That opportunity was squandered.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Beta review - 26.01.16You can't help comparing Tides of Numenera with its spiritual predecessor Planescape: Torment. For good or ill, this is not PS:T 2. Without Avellone, there is a noticeable shift in writing and the setting itself greatly differs from Planescape. I had worried that it would be a pale imitation, a weak creation that mimics but does not understand what made Planescape: Torment so great.I was wrong. I am not very far in the game, but after having talked to many NPCs and finished several quests, I feel like I have a good gauge of Tides of Numenera.1. The writing is superb. I still miss Avellone, but the new writers raise many interesting questions about legacy, always finding a new unusual facet to explore and introduce you to. It's not a shallow game, which comes as a great relief to me.2. The choices are introspective. The game not only asks what you would do, but why and how? It is very refreshing to be asked to ponder on my motives, especially compared to Pillars of Eternity, whose choices took a more results and action oriented view.3. The gameplay and combat looks promising. I can't say more, as the game is yet unbalanced and I only experienced 2 crisises yet. 4. Bugs and lack of optimization. Currently, the game lags pretty hard 3-year old gaming laptop. The loading times are exruciating. Smaller levels need 3-5 minutes, the big marketplace requires whole 10-15 minutes. Overall, I recommend the game, but only buy it right now if you have either an extremely powerful PC or a lot of patience for the loading times. I had the patience, but doubt that many other people will.

content:
Posted: March 2
												Torment: Tides of Numenera is an experience. It is a vast, sprawling world of strange and bizarre sensations. Filled with wonder and horror. It is a very wide and deep world that allows you to dig into all kinds of strange backstory and really learn the setting and the people and creatures inhabiting it.Frankly it is a very good argument to try out Monte Cook`s tabletop version. It is also a rather poor game, unfortunately.As i mentioned, the world, the canvas on which this game is painted can be explored, poked and prodded like no other game i can remember in at least the last ten years. That part is exceptional and memorable. The story itself is...good. Not great or amazing but good.But everything else from the graphics to the UI to the combat to the utilization of the PnP ruleset is lacklustre and uninspired and/or cut. I have seen the Devs argue about making the cuts for the benefit of the story, that they had to do it this way to make it fit properly. And i dont believe them. I would like to do so but the state of the game would be obvious, should have been obvious at least a year back and yet they said nothing. A month ago they did tell us some content was cut but did not mention all the other cuts that happened. Lies by omission may not strictly be lies but they certainly dont engender trust.Torment: Tides of Numenera is an elegy to halfassed shoddy work in almost every aspect but the world and story, which admittedly are the two most important parts of a RPG but that cant make up for all the other failings.Do i regret Kickstarting this game?...No, i dont.Would i have Kickstarted it even knowing what i do now?...Yes.But that is because this is exactly the kind of experience that i love. And even then i have to think it through before i answer in the positive.In the end Torment behaves like a game that was made by people that would rather write a visual novel. Four years and millions of dollars was spent on Torment and the game part of it show no evidence of that at all.To sum it up: Do you love Planescape: Torment`s story and weird worldscape? Then you might like Torment: Tides of Numenera too.Do you want to play a RPG game? Then i cant recommend Torment: Tides of Numenera.And ultimately i believe most people want to play a RPG game.

content:
Posted: March 2
												So full discosure, I was a huge fan of Planescape: Torment, as well as all the Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale games and kickstarted this game back in the day.Skip to the bottom for a TL : DRI really want to reccomend this game, based on my history with the genre and the devs, however I simply cannot, especially at the current price, and after the amount of time it was in development and the amount of kickstarter money that went into it, I can only say it was a massive disapointment in nearly every regard.- Giving credit where credit is due, the world is fantastic, and intriguing, unfortunetly this is not an original part of the game, they simply lisensed Monte cook's Numanera setting, though this was a great choice.- The main problem I have, is that despite the setting, there is no game here. It's a puzzle, and an easy one at that. There are mayble a half dozen mandatory combats in the whole of the game and most of them are more puzzly than combat anyhow, which would be fine if there was any sort of challenge persented.  The problem I have is not the puzzles themselves, but that simply taking a balanced party (one specialist in each of might, speed and intellect), which most gamers will do naturally, makes every challenge and crisis laughably easy  - Puzzles are good, not having to fight things is interesting, when the "puzzle" to avoid the fight is a single line of dialog with a percentage chance to pass or fail, and its nearly impossible to fail, ya dun farked up the game design son.- The other problem is, for a game that is supposed to be about player choice, your choices mean very little, and dialog options are more about solving a puzzle than adding any depth to the story or meaningful character development. Also there are a dozen insta-deaths in game, with no warning, for choices where you have done similar actions before. Great game design there lou.  I will admit, the ability to die in the intro, which I discovered by accident, was very amusing, it still comes from the pants-on-head school of game design choice - Because the choices don't do anything other than solve puzzles and the game is almost entirely linear, there is little to no replay value, unless you want to change a few lines of text in the credits screen, and not much change at that.- The graphics which aren't background are mediocre at best, however the backgrounds are gorgeous.- You can't use many movement type skills, which would be great for stealth, outside of combat, nor, as far as I can tell, can you seperate your party members to make sneaking about easier.-  You cannot survive the ending without screwing either the world or all of your friends, regardless of in game actions, and this is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t trend in story driven games that needs to end. On my first ending choice, I both screwed over the general populace and was remembered for my generosity and self-sacrifice... WTF? Another trend, the in game choices meaning nothing except for a few lines of dialog at side of the credits screen while the whole of the ending being decided by one choice at the end, is present here as well, though there are happily more choices than in Mass Effect 3.  None of these would be a problem if there were much of a game to play through, sadly there isn't.- The only "exploration" is holding down the tab key to look for items and interations, there are no optional areas apart from a "secret" room or two and the game is almost entirely linear, even the sidequests are all completed by just checking out all the locations and talking to people in the areas you go for the main story.- The game is only 15 hours long, I took 17.1 according to steam doing every sidequest + pixel♥♥♥♥♥ing for treasure and  save scumming for the endings, since once again, your ending is decided by a choice after the last boss, not your actions in game, so you an experience every major ending by simply loading the auto save before the ending choice. - To make a comparison, Pillars of Eternity has a larger world, longer playtime, just as much if not more (and arguably better) story and a much more entertaining and versatile gameplay experience and was made for less money and in considerably less time.TL : DR - Buy if you want an expensive, over-produced puzzle with high end indie quality and gorgeous scenery, avoid at all costs if you were looking for a AAA experience in the vein of the old Bioware Infinity engine games and buy Pillars of Eternity instead.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								As a 33 year old lawyer I consider myself somewhat of a "stealth gamer". It took my girlfriend 9 months to find out that I like video games... Due to a busy work schedule my Steam time is somewhat limited so I normally don't squander it writing reviews. But for this game I will make an exception. I was not familiar with the Numenera universe before playing the early access version of this game. (I still don't feel "familiar" after completing the early access version.) I consider myself a diehard planescape fan and couldn't suppress the feeling that the developers simply couldn't afford or wouldn't dish out the necessary funds to use the the planescape universe and make a "real successor" to Plancescape Torment.Boy, was I wrong!After playing this for 22.5 hours it went from my "I'll look into it" pile to my "dear god, no more delays" pile. The writing is simply stellar. The characters have incredible depth. The themes are mature and compelling. The developers have avoided the infamous genre pitfalls and clichés ("avenge loved ones, rescue princess, save the world"). Tides of Numenara is without a doubt the most original rpg I have ever played. I hope that the decision to make the game available across many different platforms will make it more available to audiences, who have avoided the rpg genre due to the above-mentioned clichés. In my view, this title shows that great art comes in many forms - even in the form of a video game.If you truly enjoyed Planescape Torment this is for you.

number of helpful: 186 of 247 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 11
Planescape: Torment, arguably the best RPG ever made. The game with cult following and, when it comes to story, nearly no contenders out there.A new challenger appears -  Torment: Tides of Numenera, the game from the people behind PS:T. Will it prove that the heights of PS:T can be reached, that people still can make games with unique setting and strong personal story? Will it be a spiritual successor to highly aclaimed RPG?Plot twist, it won't and here is why (in the form of the glorious WALL OF TEXT).Spoiler-free tl:dr version at the end.WritingWhat can change the writing of the game?Main PlotThe main plot revolves around The Last Castoff or better to say it doesn't. It revolves around the Resonance Chamber, a macguffin to fix it all, stop the menacing Sorrow and save all the Castoffs. The premise drops to much information (in the form of walls of text upon walls of text) and the game for the next 5-10 hours has nothing to add to the plot, aside from go there he/she knows. Everything from there on adds to the exposition of the weird things in the world. World building is important, yes, but it is essential to establish rules of the world and in T:ToN there are none. Psyonics. Timetravel. Constructs. Nanomachines. All of it is just there for the sake of being and all of it is presented , you can guess, through walls of text.After 10 hours of reading I asked myself, what was it I was supposed to do? The game presents no urgency, there is no menace. It contradicts what it tells you in the beginning. Then, there is a plot twist, which should have shifted the focus from Resonance Chamber and feel the urgency to act fast, but it doesn't. It is simply presented and the player suddenly has to care about it. And after 10 more hours there is another plot twist and more exposition as to provide the motivation of the villain (finally).The ending is presented in a style of Mass Effect 3: you did a lot of stuff throughout the game but it doesn't matter, choose an option. And it ends.CompanionsPS:T had a wide range of non-typical companions with unique personalities and ties to the protagonist in one way or another. A talking skull, tiefling, githzerai, a piece of armor and it is without saying anything about their personalities. Just the appearance.T:ToN has humans. All of them. And that tells you something from the very beginning. Their stories are bland, their unique quests are just "carry me around and at a certain point I'll tell you something" and that's basicaly it. Their arcs (if you can call their stories that) end abruptly and give no satisfaction.Writing itselfThe game has been advertised having word count higher than the Bible and that's not an exageration. Word count is too damn high. Everything in T:ToN drops a wall of text upon the player, for right and wrong reasons. The game lacks editors hand, who would have cut half of the text.Such word count would be okay if it delivered something superb, unique and interesting. Instead, it spills nonsense and amateurish purple prose.It does get better by the second half of the game, because the amount of text is significantly reduced, but by that time, you will be tired of it all.GameplayI may be bested in battle, but I shall never be waiting for 10 minutes for enemy's turn to endSkillchecks or Effort systemIn T:ToN attributes (Might, Speed, Intelegence) are presented in forms of pools. Each pool can be used to increase the chance to succeed in skillcheck (either in combat or dialogue). The player can replenish the pool by resting or using special items.Starts as an interesting mechanic and ends as a easy way to bypass and win at everything. Companion pool in 50% of events can be used in checks, items to replenish pools are everywhere making skillchecks a joke.CombatDevelopers wanted to improve the combat as opposed to PS:T. They failed.The combat is bad as in worse than in 99. Enemy turns take forever (literaly as AI can simply freeze and do nothing forcing to reload). There wouldn't be any problem if combat, as it was stated, was really optional. It is not. There are forced situations, which can be finished without killing anyone, but are nonetheless buggy and force to reload time and time again.Character classesThere are 3 classes and the only one you have to consider is Nano (aka Mage). Why? Because 60% of skillchecks are Intelegence bassed. Going with anything else results in failing checks and combat. And why combat is bad? Check above.ArtdirectionOur progenitor was funny like that. Substance for the next location was always a last minute decision.LocationsLet's go location after location.Sagus Cliffs - a place where everything is an attraction. Here you see a strange looking clock, there you see a strange generator, here a strange fountain with fish-like creatures instead of water, there a soundproof building and a place of diplomacy. It is so obsessed with little things that it fails as a whole.Valley of the Dead Heroes - a place of backer content. Though the most generic location, it has the most interesting quest - Endless Gate (which appears out of nowhere, sadly).Bloom - the only location in the game that feels consistent in what it is. The art is solid and supports the narative.Oasis - nothing to say about it, 'cause it has been cut.Calm - there's not much of it but it looks okay primary because of the fanthoms.Overall, in comparison to Pillars of Eternity, locations feel cheep and lowres.UIIt is atrocious. The inventory has no sorting. Trade screen has no appropriate buttons and has "it's not a bug but a feature" feel. Dialogue interface takes a lot of screen space but only 50% of it is text box. CYOA sequences have no proper scaling of elements and thus look like an indie project with low budget.All in all, as one man said, it looks like a Winamp skin.PortraitsJust plain bad. They had great portraits in alpha-beta build and changed them to low effort paint over photo. Moreover, none of the NPCs have portraits, though in alpha they were there.Bonus section. inXile's communication or lack of thereofIt was mentioned time and time again - cut content, which was promised during kickstarter campaign. It isn't the problem something was cut, such is the nature of game development, the problem is it wasn't properly mentioned until the exposure.Right now inXile is somewhat ignorant of the complaints regarding the final product. Technical forum is filled with unanswered threads and I gave up refreshing the page to see if the problems I mentioned are going to be addressed.tl:drProsthe design and pacing of The Bloom hub;multiple quests resolutions (sometimes more than 3);several interesting sidequests.Consbad and buggy combat system;bland companions;weird world for the sake of weirdness with little to no explanation, why and how everything works;mediocre main plot, which goes from "personal story" to "chosen one story";choices don't matter;abrupt ending akin to Mass Effect 3;atrocious consolidized UI without proper scaling;cut kickstarter strechgoals;VerdictA lot more can be said about each aspect of the game, but there isn't enough space.The game as a spiritual successor to Planescape: Torment gets a solid 2 out of 10 for failing to do everything it was destined to do: improve combat, tell a complex personal story, have unique companions and present reactivity, choice and real consequences.PS:T aside, it gets 5 out of 10 for trying to be original but failing to do everything else properly.

content:
Posted: February 28
												EDIT: This review has been edited a small bit from it's original state to indicate that there is, without a doubt, a fairly large group of people who will love this game and be very very happy with their purchase. I'm not part of that group, sadly. Read through to find out if you are.Backed this game. Was REALLY excited for it. I kept my spoilers to a minimum...and in doing so apparently missed my chance at getting a refund. Which, to be clear, I would have certainly done had I realized how bad of a shape this game was in.To start, there has been a MASSIVE amount of cut content. Not JUST Kickstarter Stretch Goals, as many people will insist, but also cuts to the core game. Cuts to the fundemental rules set the game is built upon (aka, if you're familiar with how the PnP Numenera game works, there are MASSIVE cuts to that rule set).Further, there are other major issues with the game. These include truly ugly character models/animations (although the rest of the game looks quite nice), an extreme imblance in the importance of different skills/abilities/classes/companions/etc (saying much more than that would be super spoilery, but, simply put, if you choose X, Y, and Z there can be no need to replay the game, as you'll have seen basically everything in a single playthrough, where as if you choose A, B, and C instead, you'll see about a 4th of the game's content, max, even if you're SUPER dilligent), unnanounced timed quests (aka quests you can fail by taking too long IRL to do them, with no indication that you need to do them in a timely manner), and relatively short playtime for a RPG of this price.Finally, some other things to note, smaller, less important things, but bothersome things nonetheless include but are not limited to voice acting for the female player character that is probably the worst I've heard from any game in years, certain static images (like loading screen images and such) being the wrong resolution regardless of the resolution you set (resulting in things like "loading tips" being off screen), the inability to lock the mouse cursor to a single monitor in multimonitor setups (even in fullscreen), the lack of a boarderless window mode, the fact that you can die in the text-only intro of the game and get a game over screen, and many, many other small problems (including performance issues...which this game should have even a little).Combine all this with what I feel are many poor design decisions that happened in the middle of development and had I know what was coming, I certainly would have asked for a refund back when I had the chance. Sadly, as this was a Kickstarter game for me (aka I got a CD key) I cannot get a refund through Steam, even though I've barely used it at all.To be clear: If you are looking for an in-depth CRPG with heavy RPG elements, a complete Numenera experince, or a mixture of both, you will likely be dissatisfied with your purchase. If, on the other hand, you're here EXCLUSIVELY for the story and want a Planescape: Torment like story experience, this IS the game for you, and you'll likely be VERY satisfied with your purchase. But I fall into the first camp, not the second camp. It should also be noted that if you want the game promised in the Kickstarter this is NOT going to live up to your expectations.All in all, this is not the game promised, it's a shell. It's not a CRPG, it's an incredibly detailed and intricate Choose Your Own Adventure visual novel with EXTREMELY light turn based combat on rare occasions. The broad strokes of the original premise are still there, but compared to other recent CRPGs (Pillars of Eternity, Divinity: Original Sin), the RPG elements are EXTREMELY lacking.So, should you buy it? Well, that's up to you. Some people WILL be VERY satisfied with this purchase. As for me, I wanted a complete Numenera CRPG. This is not that game. So I can't recommend it.

content:
Posted: March 19
												I was an early backer of the game, I usually back each and every CRPG that resembles old school RPGs. But TTON was my first big disappointment. I think mainly because of the hype that the devs built up, by promising a deep, multi layered inticate world. I really want to like this game, I am still trying, but even after only 9 hours, this title feels more like a choir than fun. My main problem is one of the selling points of the game, that you can beat it without killing anyone. I expected some sophisticated dialogue and skill system, but in reality, it is simply using Tide points to "solve" dialogue options that come up in every situation. Tide points are divided into 3 sections. Might, Speed and Intellect. The more Tide point you spend in an interaction, the higher chance you will succeed. The problem is, that Tide points can be used individually by any party member, so even a dumb brute can easily convince a fanatical deth acolyte to stand bck from his plan. For a brute, the options should not even pop up in my opinion. But like this, basically you can talk yourself through the game without ANY effort, in case you run out of points, you just need to rest and continue.Pros:-Interesting setting-Unique environment-Okay graphicsCons:-Tide system; you just talk yourself through the game in literally ANY situation-Combat is clunky and pointless-Main character is blank, you cannot even customize its look-Almost non-existent and bad voice acting-Uninteresting cliche companions with zero motive-Dull soundtrack-Tiny, cramped maps-Cyphers (so far) are more annoyance than use-Writing is tedious and overcomplicatedAll in all, given its hype and huge funding, the game underdelivers in almost every aspect for me. I keep going as long as I can, maybe I find the fun part of it, but so far it is more like a tedious graphic novel from a conceited literature student. For full price I definitely do not recommend it, on sale only if you are up to tons of reading and ONLY reading. (And by too much reading I mean compared to any other, enjoyable CRPG.)

content:
Posted: March 1
												~May contain Spoilers~Don't waste your money, wait until it goes on Sale!Torment: Tides of Numenera is not worth the advertised $50 price tag. Pro's:-The backgrounds are well done and have great detail. - Idea for the storyline is awesome.- Clean user interface.- Wide range of CyphersCon's:- Exceptionally linear storyline, with hardly any sub-plot.  - Choice and Consquence theme barely flushed out to its true potential.- Tides aren't maximized in a useful manner to benefit the player.- Could complete entire storyline and every quest available in less than 24 hours of gameplay. So not nearly enough quests or alternate storylines.- Inability to revisit old areas. Area's that are outside the city(s) are small and lacking, if they exist at all.- The game favors one style of play over another and the way to achieve that is primarily intellect usage. Can't play the dumb oaf because you'd be dead before the second chapter. - Species introductions and encounters are limited to the game area (chapter in main plotline) you encounter them on and no where else. - Character and player party npcs models are about as good as Neverwinter nights when it was first released. - No main character customization. Can't dye your hair, get tattoos, new scars or even decent looking armor. - The main plot line feels like its rushed, and that they couldn't end the game soon enough. - Not enough fluff. Whether that be useless quests, strange things to find, or weird♥♥♥♥♥♥ - There's practically no party banter and the personal quests aren't very engaging. - Character movement pathing is cumbersome and poorly designed. There isn't a multi-waypoint system to tell a character to move around an obstacle.  - Game mechanics in hostile situations are still buggy.- Player class is limited and unoriginal. Fighter, Rogue, Mage, like really? That hasn't been done to death.I really do hope that this developer will add more content, for free, as they introduce their updates. But as it stands, one day after release, this game is a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor excuse for the genre it represents. And considering that its supposed to blur the lines between what is magic and tech. This developer didn't reach far enough, to implement what could of been a great and engaging game. Instead I firmly believe, they spent the money from their backers on trying to make this game cross platform versuses making a solid game that could be converted afterwards. There are better games out there and some of them are nearly 20 years old, like Baldur's Gate.

content:
Posted: February 28
												Pros:- Mechanics: Game works very well mechanically, including options to interact with terrain is a certain feature I've craved for in isometric RPG's- Story and setting: Story and dialogue are very decent, characters seem memorable and interesting.Cons: - Cut Content: I don't thik I've ever seen a case, more brutal than this one. When the game was in early Alpha, it contained several additional features that are unavaible now at release, some being key to incorporating the true feeling of playing in the Numenera universe. The intro sequence and start was severely reduced and it doesn't seem that that content shows up later on, it's just... gone. 3 out of the 9 promised companions were also cut with the argument they want to focus their efforts on developing a deeper evolution for fewer characters than spreading their efforts out.Now the last and most dissappointing fact that was falsely hyped up (some would say promised) by the developers: only 3 foci... The essence and meat of the tabletop rpg Numenera is the plethora of foci you can choose from at character creation and the amount of starting diversity that offers you. When the alpha/beta started, one could only choose between 3 such foci, each one more or less designated to work with a certain type, so you can get a feel for the game. Back then, there was even a message that popped up as you were choosing, stating there will be more options in the full game. Well those promised additional options never made it in the full game for some reason and what's most annoying about this situation is that these issues were either never adressed or flimsy minor excuses were presented to justify these decisions.The only reason I could think of for all this content being cut/removed, is they want to add it as future DLC... Which 1st of all wouldn't work, because Isometric RPG's with a non-branching story don't go well with character options DLC, since most players will only play the game once. And 2ndly, the developers know they can't add cut content that was actually in the game at some point during the development as DLC, they probably know they'd get eaten alive for such silly and anti-consumer practices.Because of these confusing and silly decisions, I simply can't recommend the game to anyone.TL DR: Game is good, but lots of content was either cut for no logical reason, or never delivered despite being promised. Those cuts really hurt the game and don't give the Descriptor/Type/Focus system justice.

content:
Posted: January 20
Early Access Review
								I'm not a professional reviewer or anything but I'm 32 (golden age of gaming) years old and I've played and finished every single CRPG on the planet, some of them multiple times.  This game definitely has the potential to be among the best I've played.  The writing it fantastic but I have to say, what I like the most is how the game mechanics are setup.  Most games like this you would reload if your character fails at doing something or persuading someone, but the way Torment is set up failure can lead to something new and interesting and the best moral choice won't always lead to the best moral outcome.  I love that because it simulates real life decision making.  Nothing is black and white.Post Release Edit:I've just finished the game.  I definitely feel like there's a lot of room for replay because of all the branching choices. I still stand by my original words but I do feel mildly disappointed though I feel it's my fault.  Torment isn't really an CRPG in the traditional sense.  I feel it's more of a point and click adventure game with some combat elements (mind you I was a Jack so I got through many things without combat).  I was very excited to hear that the game was set 1 billion years in the future. I am a fan of all things sci-fi.  I love the bizarre and unknown and some of the concepts in the game (such as the Bloom) were genuinely cool.However the downside is being so far out made it also somewhat unrelateable.  I had a hard time caring for any of my companions. I also believe I've been spoiled by voice acting in RPGs. I don't mind reading at all but I honestly prefer to read what an NPC said rather than a novel-like narration though the skill with which it was written has my respect.  One let down was the lack of a world map.  I though perhaps I would get to visit some of these places I heard about in the game but alas they were only lore.  I was disappointed with the overall plot though there were some twists I didn't see coming. I felt like the billion year into the future plot was really interesting but I really wish it was more organized.  I felt like there were a lot of random elements and things that didn't really fit in well together. I also wish I could delve more into the backstories of some of the more interesting elements.  For example, I wanted to know a lot more about the Bloom than what was given.Overall, it's a good game though I believe Planescape Torment was better (though in all fairness I am a fan of that universe).  Perhaps it's just me since this is my first experience with Monte Cook, maybe if more comes out in this universe I'll grow to understand it better.

content:
Posted: March 5
												Having now completed what must be about 80% of the story, it seems like my initial concerns were well-founded.In a nutshell, this is a very nice rough draft.Where to begin? Let's start with the choices. Most of the time, they feel inconsequential. Granted, characters die, NPCs can be killed or made friends, but never did I feel like the death of a party member (I lost one person) or letting Qorro live changed anything momentous.Skills and abilities didn't seem to matter much mostly because there are only about a dozen fights through the whole game. The advancement system seems very compelling, and I was excited to progress. But then I never got a chance to use my new talents.Balance seems off, too. Either I found myself overwhelmed with up to a dozen foes with twice my hit points, or I was just talking my way through everything. I like that enemies could be spoken to during a crisis, but that only happened twice, maybe three times. The worst part about being outnumbered wasn't the frustration of difficulty, but how slow and repetetive the battles got. I'm looking at you, corpuscular maws.Plus the game feels short, the pacing is tedious (if well-narrated), the voice acting is confusingly sporadic, crisis instructions were vague at best, and most of the game is the script to a cut scene that budget didn't allow to be rendered.It's got great ideas. It has a fun world and character advancement system. It just doesn't do anything with them that makes any of it exciting. Had I spent $15, I wouldn't complain (or replay). At $45, I have to warn others to wait for a discount or a better option from another developer.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've put in a decent chunk of time in to the Torment beta over the weekend and while its obviously clunky and unfinished I had a great deal of fun with it.There are so many people you can talk to in Sagus, the first city, that you can easily spend over 5 hours just going around and annoying people with endless questions. Best thing about it is that pretty much every single bit of dialogue is well written and all of the characters have some sort of compelling story to tell, if you can get them to share it.For example there's a cannibalistic cult that lives in the depths of the city and rather than the usual RPG business of having you kill them Torment actually managed to convince me to not just leave them alone but concede that they might have a good point...However, while the story really is amazing, possibly just as good or even better than Planescape: Torment's the combat, graphics and performance still need a lot of work done to them.The combat right now is best described as generic low-level DND combat with the one big difference being the various items and background objects you can use (the titular Numenera) if you have either the necessary skill or knowledge to activate them without blowing yourself up in the process. I'm guessing things will become a whole lot more interesting once you get a few more abilities under your belt but since you're mostly stuck as a low level character during the beta it was fairly meek.The performance is also a bit of a sore spot. Its not uncommon to have your game freeze for a couple of seconds mid combat or while interacting with particularly complex background objects or even when simply accessing your inventory or any menu besides the dialogue one.In other words, while Torment has an amazing story that's well worth exploring, it is still very much so a beta and as such I'd recommend you buy it either because you want to support the developers or because you want to soak in the story. Just don't buy it expecting a finished game because it most certainly isn't one just yet.I've also done a video where I go far more in-depth about Torment so if you're looking for more info I welcome you to take a look:

content:
Posted: February 27
Early Access Review
								"What does one life matter?"Apparently, it is a question where the answer would only make sense to each individual's code of beliefs and ethics. And sometimes, for a rare few, there isn't any answer to be had at all. But much like "What can change the nature of a man?", it's not the answer where the satisfaction is derived, but the journey to that answer through self-discovery.This game does exactly what Planescape: Torment has done way back in 1999, that is to say, it has achieved a narrative that is thick with philosophical metaphors, witty dialogue and wonderfully delightful characters. Like Planescape: Torment, it takes every known cliche, knocks it down and rebuilds it in a manner that most ordinary folks wouldn't have ever imagined, let alone foresee it.As such, this game is really not for the faint of heart, at least when it comes to reading. The text is heavy and littered with many proses and vocabulary that are somewhat archaic in format. Throw in some in-universe colloquial slang, and many players would easily be put off by the game within the opening moments, but that is essentially the charm of the game. Soldier on and you will be rewarded with an immersive experience that probably surpasses even Pillars of Eternity.So, what does one life matter? It doesn't, but you make it matter anyway, because it's your story to tell, and perhaps, that is actually all that really matters.

Early Access Review
								Being a regular player and GM in the world of Numenera, this game could only please me. It really feels like it's coming from where it claims it's coming (or something like that). Moreover, this fantastic universe of weird stuff and strange people is taken over by cool devs from a nice studio with the goal of reproducing the experience Planescape : Torment was while not forgetting to enhance it. So it's like a dinosaur of the oldschool rpg world but with a facelift, featuring a marvelous -but super weird- universe, dialogues where you can actually go pretty deep (not in all cases, but i don't care if i can't discuss the meaning of life with the guard patrolling the area), sceneries where you can actually feel the work which is provided by the devs, and a crisis system which is refreshing the good ol' pen'n'paper turn based system without disorienting the nostalgic ones, giving a sense of returning to the roots of the style which made some of us lovers of all this game can represent : a good videogame, a good adaptation of the pen and paper rpg Numenera, but also a great storytelling in which your choices feel decisive.Prepare yourself for tons and tons of dialogue though, so if it's not something you're searching for or if you simply think you'll not be able to stand it after a while, i would suggest you to go your own way on another wonderful steam page !PS :Early access is early (no♥♥♥♥♥♥Game is buggySpaghettiEdit 10/06/2016So many bugs corrected, it feels great and the new hud is less laggy than it was before. Generally speaking, everything is smoother. I'm glad I can restart a game without having to deal with game breaking bugs (negative fettles which never disappeared, i'm looking at you right now). I read some people talking about how the game is thinking too highly of himself, looking for complexity and deepness at times it's not needed and I understand exactly what they mean as I find this irritating as well, but that is not the vibe this game gives in my opinion.

Posted: January 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Where to begin... I am an old school Planescape: Torment fan, and a D&D tabletop player/DM. Let's set a few things straight about this game:1) Best Writing Ever! Amazing story, characters and settings with personalities of their own.2) Uniquely awe-inspiring environments with unforgettable experiences around every corner.3) A massive project filled with love, both from the Devs and the Fans!4) The Spiritual Successor to Planescape: Torment, and I could not be any prouder!5) Just to clarify: This is not D&D, nor is it technically part of the D&D universe... but it's also technically could be, in a way. Afterall, Planescape: Torment took place in Sigil, and that city could take you anywhere in the universe... I wish not to debate meta/universe lines or copyrights, so I will just leave it as that. No it doesn't explicitly have any connection to the previous game, but the feel, wonderful bizarrities and incredible writing feel right at home.      Thus far, the game has been amazing. It has the updated graphics and sounds (plus voice acting!) that were needed to drive the series forward. Planescape: Torment is held dear to the hearts of many, and this game shall not disappoint! 12/10 Can't wait for the full release!If only it weren't so late... I want to play FOREVER!P.S. The in game bug-reporting system is great! I need to make a torment account, but I will surely be giving useful information to help squash bugs before release. I have only had one bug at the beginning, one of my guys couldn't move during combat. I hit the space bar or something to skip the turn and it fixed it. Didn't cause a major issue.

content:
Posted: March 5
												The most difficult decision before writing this review is wether I would recommend it or not.Not recommending it would probably gather me more votes but that's easy way out.If you are considering buying this game and expecting a "traditional" rpg with character options, interesting combat and encounters like Baldur's Gate I&II, Neverwinter Nights, Divinity series or Dragon Age: Origin you'll probably be disappointed. You might be pleasantly surprised by the setting though. So what is this game then?It calls itself the spiritual successor of Planescape Torment, a beloved, text-heavy old rpg which is a lesser known but much loved game in the genre.In nearly every conversation I've had with another gamer who said he liked rpg's I've probably said: “Yeah, that's cool, but have you ever played Planescape Torment?” If he/she said “yes offcourse!” and I was drunk I probably hugged him or her. I should stop asking that question … If you enjoyed Planescape Torment you've probably backed this game so this review is rather pointless but you like reading wall's of text, clicking a button afterwards and influencing the world around you so, be my guest, and keep on reading. Is this game something for me then?I honestly don't know. It might be if you like exploring locations, talking to npc's, reading item descriptions and diving, head-on, into a world you haven't seen before.The one thing I can assure you that you have never played a game like this one before.Wether that's a good or bad thing is up in the air though. Like everything in life, the game is a mixed bag. Sometimes it shines and sometimes it stinks. Currently (06/03/2017) the game still has several annoying bugs, combat is repetitive, cumbersome and will test your patience. It delivers on the text heavy style of its spiritual predecessor but unfortunately the story, although well told, isn't as good. Where Planescape left the downtrodden path of most rpg's where you're the focal point of the world who has to save the town/country/the world/planes of existence/ reality itself from a certain evil and his macguffin. Planescape told a personal story of a man trying to find the bane of his own existence, Tides manages to rehash the standard rpg story from the get go. You're a castoff, on the run from or towards, depending on your point of view, of a big evil who threatens you and every one of your kind and the key to all this is, you guessed it, a certain macguffin that you need to repair. Thankfully the creators, for the most part, told this story in a interesting setting and  there are several memorable gems in the dialogues with npc's and companionsWhy a positive score if you're mostly negative?In a world without Planescape this game would have blown me away, in a world with Planescape it only rattled my cage. It was an interesting ride and if you, someday, want to play something that's more different then most rpg's then atleast put this game in your wish list.

Posted: March 3
												I tried very hard to like this game, since Planescape:Torment was one of my favorite games growing up and I've been waiting 18 years for a new "Torment" game. But unfortunately, after about 30 hours, I have come to the conclusion that this is not a worthy successor. The characters are bland, the story is contrived, and some of the voice acting is so bad / irritating that I had to turn the voice-over volume to zero.The combat is a slog with basically no strategic curve, and the maps are hilariously cramped.You can easily tell that this game suffered from major budgetary constraints, technical limitations, and last minute cuts -- and that kind of ruins the immersion for me.This game is basically "Wasteland 2" with worse combat, UX, and maps. AND WL2 didnt really do any of those things particularly well to begin with.

For a game with focus on dialogues there are too few real options in dialogues besides asking questions.

number of helpful: 97 of 136 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12
												Just my two cents...A decent and intriguing game in its own right (I'll rate it at 6.5/10.) I backed it early and got it for half-price, and I can't say I didn't get my money's worth. Most people have singled out the combat as its major weakness, but while I found the animations/interface a bit sluggish/awkward and the character models rather ugly, overall it's still acceptable to me.However...(1) It's NOTHING like Planescape: Torment. This is not necessarily bad per se, but I (and many others, I think) jumped to back this PRECISELY because of the Torment link. To claim that this is a "spiritual successor" to that game is not only inaccurate, it's deceptive and cheap. While this doesn't really affect my enjoyment of the game, it does significantly put me off backing future inXile titles. (I think it's safe to say that I likely wouldn't have got this if it was just called Tides of Numisomething rather than TORMENT: Tides of Numisomething, and it wouldn't have been a major loss on my part too.)(2) Considering the amount of money it raised, I find this game underwhelming compared to other games with less budget and development time. It's not as impressive as I hoped/thought it would be, nor as fun as other games out there (and I say this as someone who LOVES isometric turn-based games.) I certainly won't be speaking of it in the same breath as Planescape: Torment.(3) Some of the things that were a major disappointment for me were the lack of character portraits (the few in the game depicting your character and party members were just awful); the lack of evocative music (which was one the things that made Planescape: Torment so memorable for me); the lacklustre story and NPCs (NPCs were also what made Pst memorable for me); and finally, poor pacing and balancing (by the time of the third act, my Stats were high enough that ability tests were trivial and I was all of a sudden swimming in cash but had nothing I wanted to buy.)Bottom-line: I mildy enjoyed this game while it lasted...but, for the amount of tme invested, I think you can get a lot more enjoyment and value out of a good novel. On this basis alone, I really can't recommend it. Wait for the sale.

content:
Posted: March 28
												I backed this game on Kickstarter and had high hopes for it, and I did play it all the way through, so that's saying quite a lot.However, I feel like it missed the mark, or else, our hopes were all set too high.First, the game is buggy. Very buggy. Freezes are not uncommon. Graphic corruption is not uncommon. Freezes are often persistent, such that you have to just skip that chunk of the game to get around them. (For example, if entering a certain area causes the game to freeze, it will generally do so every time, so the only workaround is just to not go there.) The 1.0.2 patch didn't help that for me -- if anything, it made it worse. Also, there are little "bugs" like the wrong gender in dialogue and things like that, but there are a fair number of them, so it does interfere with your immersion.Second, the game is surprisingly short. That's likely why I actually got around to finishing it. It just didn't take all that long. For a game of its type, for what I paid for it, and for the reputation of its franchise, that was a bit disappointing. [Steam tells me that I played for 38 hours, and that includes restarting areas multiple times due to freezes, and walking away from the computer for hours at least once.]Also, there's a lot of dialogue, but it's not very fluid and doesn't evolve much. Conversations feel pretty "gamey", and you can generally explore every conversational thread -- none will get cut off because of another thread you followed. It feels ... old school in that respect, and not in a good way.And then, there are just a lot of bad UI choices. For example, when you use an ability, it plays a sound effect if you succeed and labels a button "Continue", but if you actually click that, which I kept forgetting to not do, you'll actually skip over the screen that tells you the results of your action. (It's surprising how often that happened and how much I didn't really care.) As another action, on a complex battlefield, if you want to use an attack or ability on an ally or enemy, you must pick them out on the battlefield, even if other characters occluding them make that nearly impossible to do. The game is *aware* of who you select using the character portraits in the initiative list, but won't use that information. Why not? Also, many items have a "Use Item" button that does nothing because instead the game wants you to click back to the main game screen, click on the little backpack on the left side, and then select them there to use them. Why not make both work? If the button doesn't work, why display it?I didn't hate the game. I did enjoy parts of it a fair bit. But the tone is often grim-just-to-be-grim and the fact that it didn't really draw me in made that feel less "adult" and more just egregious, or even childish. Also, I would have liked to see not only more content and a larger adventure, but more locations. There are hardly any in the game. Oh, and this probably matters to very few people, but I largely backed this game because I'm a huge fan of the Numenera role-playing game, and the system implemented in the video game is *not* the same at all. It barely qualifies as "inspired by". They should have made more effort to stick to the actual system where possible if they were going to market it the way they did.In the end, I think people who own the game will enjoy it, but I'm not likely to recommend people run out and buy it. I'm going to go tackle Pillars of Eternity next, and I'm expecting to get more out of it.

content:
Posted: March 9
												I got banned from the Torment Steam Community Discussion board for posting this review there:I grew up a huge fan of all the infinitiy engine games. I backed Pillars. I backed Torment. I thought the new golden age of cRPGs was upon us. It had to be, these games had record funding.And they were incredibly poorly planned and managed. We saw some of these issues, much less significant, with Pillars - where ambitious stretch goal were delivered but hastily developed, not fully realized, insignificant to the grander scheme, and tacked on feeling - but it's even worse with Torment.Much of the base game that was planned was cut. Entire stretch goals that we earned were cut. These cuts, while not only making the game significantly more shallow with significantly less replayability, are the antithesis of this RPG system. Go on, count how many companions shipped at launch, the laughable amount of focuses, literally no factions as we were promised, no crafting system. No orchestral sound track. Compare the stretch goals, which is literally what people were paying for, to the final delivered product, which is what we were given. Imagine yourself being Italian backer and being promised an Italian localization that wasn't delivered- Because that happened.Kickstarter is allowing developers to deliver whatever they want. And that is something I'm never going to support again. If there would be a platform that binds the developers with a contract to fulfilll their promises and design targets, I would reconsider it but Tides, along with so many incredibly successful kickstarted games simply aren't delivering what they're promsing. What we paid for.InExile has had zero transparency about the entire thing, and will only acknowledge it after the fans make it into a scandal. Zero accountability. I am sorry I backed Bards Tale 2 and now I understand why they kickstarted the next Wasteland before this launched and blew up in their faces. Who knows how many dollars from this sinking ship they put into those more marketable games?

content:
Posted: March 2
												So as the thumb shows. I don't recommend this and just to point this out. I did not back this on kickstarter and bought this purely on an "looks like a neat RPG" motive. I don't know Torment Planescape or have played it. I'm essentially new to this kind of "world" or... whatever it is people are comparing this to.So why do I not recommend Tides of Numenera?It's not a simple, short answer. I wish it was. It'd make it easier.Unlike other people who don't recommend this on the basis of "can't create your character appearance" I don't really mind it very much, but I will admit whoever drew the male and female 'main character' avatar pictures... should be fired. They're horrible, I've seen better ones in far worse games.It would have been nice if there was a place in-game where you could 'edit' your avatar's appearance (and that horrible picture), but like I said I don't find it too big of a problem. I pester npc's no matter my appearance. This is simply a QoL (Quality of Life) thing that 'would' have been nice to have, but does nothing to impact my opinion on the game as a whole.Now the 1st third of the game is in Sagus Cliffs is great. It's fun, it's interesting. Once you leave Sagus Cliff's to continue the story... it slowly, very slowly but surely gets worse.Adding onto the fact that if you do not have 3 companions with you after leaving Sagus, you're screwed as you'll never get another companion afterward. Why? No idea a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ design decision I figure, and you CAN lose your companions so if you lose them, you don't get a replacement as you'll never return to the first city to grab another one, which in turn makes combat (if you get into it) annoyingly hard.EDIT: Thank to a few people who commented on my review. I've discovered you 'can' swap companions, but somehow in my playthrough I was never able to. Why? Apparently an item that allows you to swap them, was in all likelihood bugged for me and prevented this. Given you can't access the companions in later areas, it seems this bug I had with swapping them should have been dealt with 'before' release given it is particularly critical. (If albeit rare as I seem to be the lucky minority)And combat as it is in-game is like putting your hand in an active garbage disposal. Painful. Combat isn't fun, it isn't "intuitive" It's annoying, it's painful... it's tormenting. The game calls battles a "crisis" and it is one, for you because you're going to go through your own crisis trying to "win" these battles in a horribly made combat mechanic. So if you DO buy the game... avoid combat like you'd avoid getting the plague. You'll save yourself a lot of headaches.The 2nd part of the game (before getting to the end-game city) is strange, and not in the 'oh this is neat' strange. It's a "What is this?" kind of strange, with admittedly bits of the first kind. The 2nd part is mostly there so the dev's can say "Hey, look at these names. They backed us." Beyond that, it really serves no purpose in the game.The last part of the game is... almost as awesome as the first, but it wears off quickly and it gets replaced with annoyance. The third part of the game feels rushed, like some invisible force is whipping your character to do things right away and while you don't have to (and if you buy the game anyways) you should go slowly. Makes it a bit more enjoyable.But therein lies the problem. The first part of the game will take you 10 hours to get through it. The rest of the game... 8 hours and that is doing "ALL" of the side quests as well, exploring the cities, talking to npc's, etc.And it's not even worth replaying the game in a different way. It'll all lead down the same path no matter what. (Yay for youtube)Nothing changes very much beyond how much your companions "like" you, and how other npc's might, and it takes a lot to get them to dislike you. (All npc's generally dislike you to start with, so your screwed there either way)The companions, they aren't very... interesting. Actually no, I'm lying. Only 1 companion is interesting, and this is "AFTER" they cut 3 other companions to 'expand/flesh out' the six they kept. Apparently they didn't put much effort into five of these companions, so they probably should have just kept the other 3 anyways.  The companion who is the most interesting (in my opinion) is Rhin. A girl misplaced in the world that you can save/adopt. Compared to all of the other companions who are interesting for a span of five minutes. Rhin is a companion you'll likely find far more interesting than half the maniacs who want to join you. However, she's a child and thus isn't made for combat which makes her even more interesting in my eyes. Eventually through the course of the game she eventually sees your character as a surrogate parent of sorts and then you'll come to a decision in the end part of the game... that just kicks you in the gut. This choice is: You can have her stay with you or return to her real family as you discover a way to send her home and if you (like me) really really like having her around. It's a painful choice to make.  The rest don't have this kind of impact. The rest are screwed up beyond any measure of saving or bothering to learn about.Playing it, it feels like the dev's were doing good in the first part, but then said "screw it" and rushed up the rest just to shove it out the proverbial door and if the steam forums show anything.♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off almost everyone who have backed the game because of cut content, changed goals, etc.Which even though I didn't back this. I feel it's a horrible move by the dev's given that while they have the choice. They should have brought it up to those who backed the game, the people who PAID them to create this game and paid for the "cut content" that isn't in the game. (Especially when people paid the 'stretch goals' for specific content and the dev's just told them it won't be there. (That's downright lying)Sure there are "creative problems" and issues they have to be worked through or past but they aren't allowed to make those kind of choices when the people who paid money for specific content are told "Yeah, you paid for it to be in game but... we feel it's not a good choice to put it in. Sorry."In business, this causes a business to go OUT of business as the investors abandon it for another business that'll do as it promises. Speaking of cut content... I'd say this decision was a bad move given how short the game is past the first part of the game, but chances are it was "cut" so it will be later added as paid dlc.If it doesn't I would be surprised.In the end, with the bad business practices, relatively short gameplay (with it's price as it is at the time of this review), no replayability, downright abusive combat mechanics, I can't recommend this game to anyone until it's priced around $20 (or regional equivelant)I'd give this game a 5 out of 10. It's average, in the end that's all it is. Instead of buying this, go watch a let's play on youtube. You'll find it more enjoyable and if combat happens. At least you won't be the one harmed by it.
