Posted: March 14
												This game to Planescape:Torment is what Atack of the clones is to Empire strikes back.....In core its alright story driven rpg,however as succesor to Planescape Torment it fails.It feels like fanmade torment tribute game,not something that was backed by kickstarter and made by profesional dev company.The great thing about PS:T was the originality in world setting or characters : no knights in shiny armour,barely any armour at all in fact,only a few swords to be found etc. and even though the world  setting in Tides of Numenera  is fresh and original nothing else really is.Nameless immortal character with amnesia exploring own past while trying to stave off some kind of shadows ....Also combat,even though its surely not the main focus of the game,is even less enjoyable than in PS:T and thats saying something i managed to skip most of it through persuation ,intimidation etc. Also when figting large amount of enemies i had time to make cup of tea while waiting for my turn.the good things about it:-One companion which i felt atached to (Rhin ftw)-Enjoyable side quests-Interaction with objects-World setting - nice design,fun to explore,cool lore.-Solving problems can be done in several waysthe not so good things:-Every companion minus Rhin-Boring prolonged combat makes you want to solve everything peaceful way -Expected more content-Main storyline is shallow and unoriginal-Glaive jack and nano is just different name for warrior rogue and mage -crashed several times during combat (played on the release so might be fixed now)If you want good cRPG ...thumbs up (even though Pillars or Tyranny are still much much more better choices)If oyu want experience something on level of Planescape Torment go play .....Planescape Torment,because this is not it

number of helpful: 122 of 180 people (68%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 9
												First thing first: TToN is not an RPG. It's a story-driven adventure game and should be judged as such. Its progression type is actually that of a point-and-click game: you get a hub, you find the correct order to click things, you uncover the plot and then move to the next area.This is all fine in my book, but should be kept in mind.Sadly, the game has a bunch of glaring downsides: The visuals are imaginative, but poorly-executed The balance is atrocious (as others have mentioned, most challenges in TToN are basically non-challenges and have no reason to be there) The whole game feels clunky in a bad way Glitches abound Non-plot Meres seem to be pointless It's obvious that the game was written by many different writers with different styles.Does this all make the game unworthy of playing? No. Unworthy of its price tag? Yeah, perhaps.Trying to remember PST without nostalgia goggles, I'd actually say that TToN does a good job of capturing the spirit of the now-franchise. You get the sense of a huge and wondrous world with plots and events criss-crossing each other—and there you are, thrown in the thick of it, your head spinning from the weirdness that surrounds you. This feeling is strongly enhanced by the fact that the game rarely repeats the assets—meaning that most characters and situations you'll encounter will have unique models, scripts, and so on. The lack of junk content makes the world feel rich and true.TToN actually builds upon PST's methods, trying little neat tricks to make everything seem... I wouldn't say "more natural", but rather "more engaging". You get dialogue options that are only available once. You get failure states more interesting than successes. You get hidden timers that make certain events change and unfold. You can never be sure. All these things are great improvements over PST.Another thing that captures the spirit of the old game to a T is the soundtrack. Reserved, non-grandiose, yet full of genuine tingling sorrow, it seemed perfect.Honorable mentions to some other elements of the game: The Bloom is dark and imaginative, rivalling the best moments of the whole PST setting; a brilliant concept that was well-executed The "Ashen Imitation" quest (the one with the same girl being reborn over and over) intrigued me greatly The replacement of monetary rewards with Oddities (pointless items that exist only to be sold—so they're basically shins, but flavourful) Some writing is quite captivating (The Genocide) or funny ("coital cluster") Companions have a lot of dialogue and react to A LOT OF things happening in the game How Perception and other unasked-for checks are done, making you feel super smart every time they trigger Some Crises are very engaging (like the one where you need to retrieve the Cortex) The quiet, fanfare-less moment when you find Chile ErritisA WORD ABOUT COMPANIONSThey're okay. The game features: Two well-executed typecast fan service characters (the "naive little girl you need to protect" Rhin and the "charming rogue with a tragic backstory" Tybir) A rather bland companion who's important to the plot (Matkina) Two characters who seemed very bland apart from the beginning (Callistege and Aliger) A brilliant character who only shines if you use a particular skill—a skill that I actually found detrimental to the rest of the game since the explication of characters' thoughts destroys the whole point of fiction in all cases but Erritis'sThey're less original than in PST, but way more fully-realized. However, for some inexplicable reason they are also all human.THE ELEPHANT IN THE ROOMNow, like I said, I do recommend this game. For all its downsides, it's more than worth your time if you just want to immerse yourself in the Ninth World and play an adventure game of epic scale.But—and there's no way to put in lightly—the main plot sucks.I'm not talking about the writing, although I did find the major plot scenes to be among the less well-executed. But that, once again, would be forgivable... if the game didn't spend its second half to destroy the great premise of the first half.You start as a person in a startling, but not unique, situation: you are a shell of a body, cast off by your creator who jumps vessels to stay immortal. You are not special in any existential way—however, you are technically the best candidate to oppose The Changing God/Sorrow, since each new body he makes is better than the previous ones, so you're the best among your brethren. Sounds like a great "fit for this story, but not The Chosen One" setup.Oh, only you are The Chosen One, because your skills and body are unique—no one else could have triggered the events of the ending. And the tutorial guy is actually The Changing God, your creator. Oh, no, he isn't. The brilliant yet narcissistic and ruthless Changing God, so excuisitely built up at the beginning? He shows neitehr brilliance nor ruthlessness—he's actually a lost and sensitive guy who started this whole mess to revive his sick daughter. Only he's not trying to revive her. And he's actually dead, because... reasons. Why was he even running from death so hard? What was his personality like? We don't know for sure, he never gets much of a spotlight. And that looming thing that's hunting him, called the effing SORROW? Nope, no metaphors, it's an ancient guardian or something. There to protect the Tides, that are a gameplay mechanic, but not really explained to you. Did you use Tidal Surge? Did we tell you it was bad, even though we never told you how and it had no repercussions? Yeah, now decide stuff in an ending that fully revolves around dilemmas and entities that were not explored in the game at all.Basically, it's a mess of "Fahrenheit" proportions. In the third act, new entities get shoved down your throat one after the other, every new screen is a revelation that turns the plot on its head... leaving you confused and the game, robbed of focus.THE TRUNK OF THE ELEPHANTWith all its oddness and quirkiness, down below PST was a very simple, almost Hollywood-like story of redemption. The question it asked was Shakespearean in its simplicity: Is there a fate worse then death? And the bittersweet yet fulfilling answer was, Yes. It was a game about accepting death, plain and simple.TToN's premise is actually at times more imaginative than that of PST... but what is it about? The ending devolves into a tangle of personal motivations, of who went where and who did what—but there's no central issue, no subject the game would explore and revolve around. It's just... abut people.It's like a castoff: pretty and able to surpass its creator in certain areas, but ultimalety empty.And that, my friends, is a bloody shame.

content:
Posted: March 6
												It's not very good.This has been one of the most anticipated Kickstarter games of all time, what with it's prestigious legacy, and it falls short.To be brief and fair, I'll not compare it to it's spiritual predecessor overmuch, and will instead judge it on it's own merits as it's own game.Torment: Tides of Numenera feels like a game that was in the oven for so long that it was held in stasis, while an entire generation of new, great cRPGs (the Divinities, Tyranny, Pillars of Eternity...) came and went. It's been in developement for four years, and yet it still feels like a rough draft that pales in comparison to what other luminaries of the genre accomplished with less.  It's on the short side for a cRPG, but I'll not hold it against Torment: I rather like shorter cRPGs, as Tyranny showed.The biggest problem I have with this game is how rough the interface and controls are. Movement is somewhat floaty and imprecise, interactable objects and characters can be tricky to click on, character icons can overlap and block environmental interactables, there is no fast movement/exploration option, the UI feels slow and clunky to resolve... It lacks polish is most every regard. One of the best ways to explain that lack of polish is in the sound design. There are many effects in the game without any accompanying sound effect, making for a weird feeling of incompleteness. The sound desgin that there -is- is actually quite bad, with many zones being hampered by repetitive, grating, loud and annoying sound effects. Coupled with the lackluster and sporadic voice-acting, after a while I just started playing without sound.Many people have complained that there is very little combat - and they're right. I can't remember participating in much more than a dozen combat encounters overall, but I won't chalk that up as a negative. One of the few innovations Torment brings to the table is the introduction of the Crisis System, a sort of turn-based gameplay that is mostly used for combat, but also for some interesting non-combat interactions, even in the -midst- of combat. Through the Crisis Sistem, you can interact with objects and other people even while in combat, which makes for an interesting, if not very refined experience. I had no problems at all with the very low number of combats throughout the game, especially because combat itself is not very enjoyable, what with that cardinal sin of 3D RPGs - slow and clunky animations. Torment utilizes Monte Cook's Numenera System and scenario. This is an entirely subjective point on my part, but I have never enjoyed Numenera, and this game has not changed my opinion. The mechanics of it are quite weird, and they exacerbate the particular mania of many a player.Specifically, especially in the lower levels (or 'Tiers'), you have to burn your attribute points in order to increase your chance to succeed at any particular task. Early on in game, you fail at most everything, missing all your attacks (I had a pitiable performance in the very first combat encounter in the game whereupon I missed all of my attacks for so many turns that combat ended, the boss literally taking pity on me and leaving) and must trade even your slightest chances to succeed later to have an ever slighter chance to succeed now. This curves rather awkardly - later on in the game once you've stacked enough Stats Pools and Edge, you steamroll through any and every test and check. There is not happy middle ground. In the end, it's pointless, because you can just savescum to succeed in most every check - and I'd argue that this system encourages you to.In addition, there are Cyphers, which are items that produce powerful, reliable effects - but are consumable, each Cypher having only one use, with very few exceptions.Having to burn your own Stat Pools to have a bigger chance to succeed, and almost all your powerful attacks being one-offs, feeds into that particular gamer paranoia of not wanting to use up your limited items or resources for the fear of needing them later. I know I'm not alone in this, and I finished the game whilst hardly using any Cyphers at all or burning Stat Pools beyond my Edge. Finally, there's the Numenera world itself - the Ninth World to be exact. It's a literal mishmash of random sci-fi and fantasy elements from dozens of different sources, what with the debris from different worlds and realities piling up in a giant junkyard reality, with nobody knowing anything about how anything works and just cobbling everything together from alien junk. The aesthetic is all over the place, from wooden shields to pilot jackets to H.R. Geiger walls to future guns. There is no consistent design, everything seems equally plausible, there are no real rules. It's hard to be invested in such a scatterbrained world.The story is- fine. Functional. The companions aren't bad, but they feel like holdovers from the Planescape Torment era. Nowadays we're used to much better written and relatable companions, from Obsidian to Bioware. It's just not good enough for the present age.In short, Torment: Tides of Numenera is a middling cRPG at best, unworthy of your hype, or your money. Avoid it unless on sale.

Posted: March 24
												This game was early backed for me as a gift.  I tinkered with the early-release for a while but was never really wowed by it.  Once release came, I decided to devote some real effort to the game.  I ran through with different options and different NPC's in group.  Ultimately I have to say, it was really a pretty big let down.  When you compare it to the RPG's its supposed to harken back to, it lacks depth, it lacks immersion, it lacks complexity.  Sure, there are lots of ways to 'handle' the various situations that arise.  But it almost always comes down to either having a skill or rolling a skill.  Which can be influenced by effort.  Honestly, I had more fun going back and replaying Dark Sun: Shattered Lands than I did playing this game.  And the excuse of not including certain milestones in the final product because it would have 'taken away' from the game?  Yeah... no.  This came across as a 'take the money and run' endeavor.  Save your money and get something else.

												Have you ever been offered chocolate cookies but after the first bite found it was raisins? Felt betrayed."I am one with the tides, the tides is with me..." - Castoff Chirrut Imwe - Admit it, they look alike.Expected more, but was disappointed.Encountered a great amount of bugs that made it dreadful. Battle mechanics was cheezy and does not pull you in. Some people say its not the main focus but should be more interesting.The story is rich and great but there should be a balance and events to get you back in.One thing I hated the most was the bugs on quests that shows complete but your journal never updates, then it freezes.It is so easy to avoid conflict. Once you have edge up you would never fail a task. Companions were interesting at first but then they get all over the place real quick as you go on and felt forced/rushed.The tides has a few impact on the game, unless you went Silver/Blue.It felt really incomplete. I hope in a year or so they implement all things they promised and more. Then I'll recommend it.

Posted: March 2
												There have already been some excellent full reviews of the game here on Steam, so I'm just adding in my summary:Pros:- At times very good story writing (I agree with other reviews that TTON plays more like a visual novel than a RPG)- Amazingly interactive world. A breath of fresh air and quite a lot of fun...even though it did seem a bit disjointed at times.Cons: - The combat and character mechanics absolutely killed this game for me. I ran a playthrough with the sole purpose of avoiding ANY combat but at times it is unavoidable. I can't remember the last time I was so upset with fight mechanics in a game from this genre. - Very little replayability. Without a large pool of companions to choose from and the shallow character generation (only 3 foci) I doubt I'll ever re-roll.

content:
Posted: April 16
												What does one promise matter? Deception.A tragic tale of modern CRPG where all the dreams about a true successor of the greatest CRPG of all time shattered like broken glass. Torment: Tides of Numenera has everything going for it to be the definitive modern CRPG to remind people that this genre doesn't lack behemoths. And what a disappointment it is, 4 years in development, having collaboration from Mask of the Betrayer's original designers, PS:T's Colin McComb and Chris Avellone, over 4 million dollars funded on Kickstarter, comes a video game proved that inXile Entertainment forgot what made PS:T a true masterpiece.For a game that boasted itself as "having more words than Bible", T:ToN surprisingly has very few memorable moments and characters, its writing relies on unnecessarily long and flowery descriptions that seems to try too hard to shout "look at me, appreciate all these Pulitzer-inspired writing prompts" to readers. There's no fault in bringing a lot of text in CRPG, because it's one of the definitive features of the genre, but the problem is T:ToN has very few interesting things to say, and one thing won't get more interesting no matter how you keep describing it. It's a wordy game for the sake of being wordy, it sometimes feels like a very long pretentious short book that was made for people who don't have a huge vocabulary. As someone whose native language isn't English, I can read the translated version of Witcher saga from Andrej Sapkowski which has arguably equal amount of vocab but way comprehensive than T:ToN.You have a lot of questions, NPCs have a lot of answers and descriptions, but only a few of them is worth listening to. The story itself doesn't have any real climax or tension, one plot twist revealed near the end of act 2 is way too predictable, none of the companions is memorable or relatable in any mean except Shin, and the story only gets somewhat interesting when you reach The Bloom. It's 2017 and we're comparing role-playing games through words count? Why is the successor of Planescape: Torment is more boring, forgettable and lack any suspense when compared to Tyranny - a side project from Obsidian? Morte blew all of the companions in this game out of the water which is incredibly stupid because important character arcs is the trend of writing in modern video game yet T:ToN failed short in it. It's too proud of its pretentous messages and forgot that there are confusing readers being left behind in its mess of a narrative, a dumbfounded hollow of writing in CRPG that missed all the marks, lacked any emotion and didn't give us anything worth remembering.Everything else about Torment: Tides of Numenera screams lack of professional game design. The UI is stupidly designed, NPCs don't have portraits (yet several important ones have it in battles?), available portraits span from terrible to horrible, crisis has a decent concept yet in reality, is tedious because inXile has no idea how to make compelling combat sections, so they throw roaming/respawning/a huge number of enemies into your way as obstacle. Effort mechanic leans to Intellect skill checks too much, there's no reason to play Nano unless you tend to fight your way (which is not a great idea since all battles in this game are crap) or you want to cripple yourself. The Tides' impact is incredibly hard to notice. The Cyphers span from being completely useless to overpowered. Mark Morgan's 50-track OST doesn't have any remotely memorable tune. The Meres get old quick with more and more overexposition.Torment: Tides of Numenera was supposed to be the "dream game" for CRPG followers, instead, it's a game where hipsters try to pluck through the narrative then come back and ♥♥♥♥♥ slap people "because you don't like reading in video games". T:ToN is a badly made video game and a mediocre book with millions of unheard words that better stayed silent.

number of helpful: 36 of 41 people (88%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 16
												I don't do speed runs, I don't ignore side quests yet the first run through took only thirteen hours to complete this game. (I have no wish for a 2nd run through)  I'd like to say this was down to my brilliant RPG skills cutting through the Gordian Knot but given it took me 23 hours to complete Tyranny (not known for it's length); no, this game is short and I'm feeling short changed.I'd make some combat about how weak the combat system was, but I really didn't see enough of it to be qualified to comment.  I think I had a grand total of 5 fights (or crisis) all game, what little I saw did not impress me.  In most RPG's you see more fights before getting out of the tutorial.  All that really sticks in my mind was how slow it was, if there was an option to speed up the enemy animation I didn't find it, those few fights I did have really dragged.  Without combat, what was there?  Puzzles?  What was there was so simple I'm not sure they were meant to be a puzzle or not.  The game was mostly running back and forth, clicking on NPC's and ploughing through the turgid dialogue.  I think the writers used every word in the dictionary except brevity, very little of it was useful to completing the plot.  At no point did I need to engage my brain in this game.  Humour?  Nope.  I got more laughs from watching Clockwork Orange.  The real killer though wasn't it only took 13 hours to complete.  No, the clincher is; at no point in those 13 hours do I remember enjoying the game.

Posted: February 28
												EDIT: Review below.I am enjoying this game.BUT I have to give it a negative review because of the scummy business tactics used by inExile.No matter how good this game is , it is most certainly not a 5 year long , $5 million game.Where did the time and money go ? Other projects? Mismanagement? Who can truly say at this point.But the crux of the story is that this is NOT the game detailed and outlined on their kickstarter.(no where near it).It's ok to cut a few stretch goals to finish in the proposed time. But cutting down even the core content after years of delay? Inexcusable.EDIT: The Good: -incredibly strange and unique world.-story is alright so far, it's fun and enjoyable to work through.-Side quests and characters are so interconnected that plot threads feed the living world quite well.- Background detail is sufficient.- Background music is good.The Bad:-Combat is a boring slog, it doesn't come up often though which just means 1/3 of the characters skills and uniqueness is pointless in this game.-UI : The game is clearly rushed in terms of UI/UX polish.-AI: Path finding is Bugged as hell. Often lose a character because they get stuck running into other characters and objects.- AI: Combat AI is pointless, never had a fight which is interesting from a tactics point. Considering the few amount of fights in the game I was hoping they would all be very unique.-Settings: For a game built on the Pillars tech, it sure lacks settings and options.- Virtually Silent: this game has no sound bar the one time I heard voice acting , and the very subtle background noises now and then.CONCLUSION:A decent RPG but no where near what the "Big Name Reviewers" are promising. But it if you have a hankering for new weird locations to read about and explore.If you are looking for a decent CRPG experience then look at Pillars of Eternity instead.This game lacks a serious amount of polish and design. The story is good and the amount of detail sufficient but the gameplay elements are very lacklustre. If the game was never "about combat" then why bother spending your limited time and resources fleshing out a combat mechanic?Game could've been so much more , but threw away too much in pursuit of a "great story".

Posted: March 5
												Heavy handed. Boring and disappointing. I can deal with the repetitive combat. It's isometric RPG, and while some games can still pull that through, that's quite a high bar to not recommend this on. I can forgive the stale and forgettable companions. Creating a Bioware class side kick is difficult, something even the best RPGs fail to do. I'm not asking for another Minsc or HK-47. After all these years I've waited for something akin to Morte, Nordom, Vhailor, Dakkon, and Grace to resurge (no, I didn't like Annah, and Ignus was a filthy traitor), not finding any of character even close to likeable is disappointing. But this is not Black Isle's baby. It's just a self proclaimed 'Spiritual successor'. I would have at least contended with something akin to Pillars of Eternity. Pillars was okay. Felt more like Ice WInd Dale than Baldur's Gate or Planescape Torment.But then I reached (to spare you spoilers) a mid point crucial moment, and met a mentor like person who supposed to 'teach' you things, I felt the heavy heavy heavy hand of the writers imposing their point of view on you. It's not necessarily 'poor writing' but it isn't good for gaming, especially this sort of gaming, where player agency is paramount. You are presented with a fantastical world, and I've gobbled up all the text. I've read through every minutiae of description on baubles that you sold off as junk, just because they spiked the imagination. But after all that, if what you are faced with is some pedantic idiot spewing pseudo philosophical gibberish in their proclaimed role as the Obi-Wan Kenobi, then screw this game. It's not RPG; it's not even Choose your own adventure. It's just the writers masturbating to their own writing; it shares its genealogy with the worst of Eurotrash, High minded, looking down on the player, force feeding mindless philosophy. It's not Planescape Torment. It's a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor imitation, and I regret backing this during kickstarter.

content:
Posted: March 3
												Four years after its record-breaking crowdfunding campaign, and more than two years after its planned release date, Torment: Tides of Numenera has arrived. Fans of Planescape: Torment had long looked forward to the game’s release, excited by the opportunity to play an isometric RPG with a focus on thoughtful story-telling, compelling characters set against a bizarre backdrop. Today, those fans are decidedly underwhelmed. Let me be clear, this game is not awful, but it pales in comparison to many of its ‘isometric rpg renaissance’ peers, and comes across more as an awkward imitation of the original Torment than a loving tribute. While the backdrop of the ‘Ninth World’ echoes the oddness of Planescape setting well, the games are otherwise very different.Where the 1999 game’s plot was engaging, surprising and satisfying, Tides of Numenera’s is thin, obvious and quite forgettable. Where the Nameless One kept company with a floating skull, a demoness and a mechanical box-thing, the Last Castoff will journey with people that many orthodontists would find to be a bit dreary. It is not just the game’s writing that leaves much to be desired. The action – rare as it is – is maddeningly slow and repetitive. The character generation system – which initially seems to offer a great deal of choice – has very little impact on the game. Even the vaunted ‘tides’ morality system, which appears to have the potential to add depth to your character’s choices, has little more than a cosmetic impact on the game.Reader, if you are hoping to recapture Planescape: Torment’s unusual approach to adventuring, this game will be a terrible disappointment... but dry those tears. A few month ago, rival game studio Obsidian Entertainment beat InXile to the punch, releasing a bizarre isometric RPG of their own. While Tyranny’s setting is far less similar to Planescape than Tides of Numenera's, it entertains in a very similar way. Characters include a haunted suit of armour and a mind-absorbing maniac named ‘The Voices of Nerat.’Skip this, get that. Don’t let InXile get away with phoning in such a promising idea – especially after the crowdfunding efforts, the two year delay and the big selling job.

content:
Posted: April 15
												I was not a backer of Torment: Tides of Numenera, however I am a great fan of original Planescape: Torment and text-heavy RPGs. I waited for TTOM (I'll use this abbreviation) for a long, long time and it is one of the worst disappointments I have ever faced in gaming.So now, dear friend, let me shortly summarize how incompetent InXile was while creating this mess.1) Writing. Many people here complain on terrible combat (that's true) or broken promises (that's true), or at best complain on awful companions (also true) but whitewashing the writing of this game. As I have written above, I am a fan of original Torment and text-heavy RPGs in general. But if TTOM is what devs nowadays understand as "deep, high quality writing" then I'd prefer to play hack n slash, because surviving the writing style of this game was... torment.Planescape: Torment had a lot of wonderfully written, moving, wise, meaningful text. Torment: Tides of Numenera looked at this and the only thing it understood is "a lot of ANY text is good". The final result: the game is filled to the brim with verbose, overdescriptive, exhausting, pretentious, and worst of all - completely redundant, meaningless, non-engaging writing. TTOM is proud of describing the most trivial **** in the most bloated, pseudo-intellectual way possible, and breaking rules of "show, don't tell" in every way. And trust me - I read a lot of books, so I'm not averse to a lot of reading - I simply hate meaningless writing which confuses quantity with quality. Maybe I would be less angry on writing in TTOM if next to this nonsense it actually bothered to be emotional in some aspects. But it has completely failed to move my heart and soul. In this game you will get 100 000 words describing how characters look, yet very very few words which even attempt to make you feel what those characters feel.2) Story. Another catastrophic failure, on a level completely separate from the horrible writing style. Planescape: Torment had story which was simultaneously personal, moving, emotional, philosophical and coherent. In this game, you spend 90% of it to "find x to get information on artifact y", waiting for hours for your questions to be answered - for some kind of reveal - only for this reveal to be super disappointing. Within first 15 minutes of  the game, you ask yourselves a lot of plot questions ("What is Sorrow" etc) - none of them are really answered in a ridiculously rushed, chaotic mess of an ending. Main story of TTOM is hilariously desperate to be "philosophical" but it doesn't have anything genuine to say, so it indulges into pseudo-intellectual babble about Tides, while failing to build empathy towards any of its characters. 3) Companions and charactersInXile originally promised us 9 party companions, then delivered only 6 while saying "we needed to cut out those three to make remaining ones really good". I have no idea how bad those characters were before, then, because the final result is party of completely bland, uninteresting NPCs you don't give a **** about... with one exception - hilariously, that exceptional character was written by an outsider "guest" writer, not devs themselves. Other than this one character, I failed to care about anybody in TTOM universe, including main character.4) Nonlinearity, morality and endingsMy character was follower of compassionate, Golden Tide, so he got two extra lines of description on one of the static, ugly ending slides.5) Difficulty levelI don't really wanna to indulge in mechanics of this game here, let me just say that it is so "brilliantly" balanced and designed that after first few hours you will be capable of passing almost every single skill check with 100% success rate - at least that's how it worked for me, although I am not alone and others had similar problem. No tension or difficulty at all. 6) Awful combatCombat mechanics in TTOM are quite probably the worst I have ever experienced in any RPG, with the possible exception of Arcanum. Combat here is rare, but when it happens it is incredibly slow, bugged, frustrating, non-strategic mess. Encounters you face are absurdly designed - for example, the moment you begin combat your enemy insta-kills your weakest character and cripples three other party members. Generally 90% of enemies you face have higher initiative than your party, so good luck with strategy when everybody you encounter jumps on you from all sides.7) Nonexistant soundtrackI can't honestly say TTOM's music was "bad" because I have barely heard anything of it over the course of game. For some reason 90% of it is quiet, bland ambient.8) Broken promisesInXile has promised us: few more locations (especially Oasis M'Ra Jolios and Ruins of Ossiphagan), three more companions, crafting, player's stronghold, lacunae, separate Labyrinth mechanics, dozens of Focuses and many other things. It not only failed to deliver them, it failed to inform us of them.So, that's my opinion on Torment: Tides of Numenera.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								UPDATE: I've been playing the final game now, but not on PC. FIRST OFF: My gaming PC broke like a week before the game published. I had no ready cash to sink in to a PC, so I bought it (again) on PS4. So I cannot comment on the technical side of the game on this review. On PS4, it works better than expected (I didn't expect much, to be honest). It's a bit sluggish and not super amazing looking. But honestly, it's not like anyone played Planescape for graphics, either.IN SHORT: Very text heavy RPG, basically a novel of ginormous size that you can wander through and read all the accompanying lore. There is very little combat, and all of it can be avoided. There is a number of systems at play in game that are not very well explained and take a long time (in some cases) to figure out. Despite some items having a lot of lore attached to them, they are often just random throwaway stuff that you're just meant to sell away.SLIGHTLY MORE NUANCE: Torment Tides of Numenera, I am glad to say works as intended. It has a story that is mostly about thematic depth, interesting conversations, very interesting lore, and more text than you can possibly imagine. This is probably a guinness world record, isn't it? It also, at least on first glance, seems to have quite a lot of options that make difference. It's hard to say if this is actually true unless you play the game several times over. But at first playthrough it seems to be hinting at quite the number of decisions. I am not saying the crisis system is the best system ever, but it does bring an interesting de-emphasis to combat. You don't need to fight a damn thing in this game, and often you should be thinking: should I even fight? In conclusion; if you liked Torment: Planescape, you will like this game. Unless like so many, you are blinded by nostalgia. The fact is that most gamers are nostalgic to a fatal degree and can't grasp that some things will never have the same impact once you've experienced them once (like playing a truly story driven RPG first time, like Planescape). It doesn't mean Numenera is worse than Planescape, it means you are different. I think Numenera is better than Planescape, but mostly because of presentation and technical things. Planescape was horrible game when it came to combat, and the whole DnD aspect dragged it down badly. The strange world of Numenera lifts this game up, and the systems don't in general get too much in the way of the game. However, I haven't finished this game yet so I can't say for sure that the story is as good. I might update this review once I finish the game, or I might not. Who cares? This is just my opinion anyway.Like I said, I recommend this game for those who want a story driven, text infused, very slow paced game with mostly optional combat in a very surreal world.

Posted: April 9
												I have mixed feelings after playing this game. I bought it hoping for a proper RPG game and it delivers in some aspects, but it doesn't in most of them:+multiple ways of solving riddles (there are usually 2 ways to solve a quest)+different endings (you get a summary of how different lifes went on after the end of the game)+story (quite interesting)+"colors system" which shows you if you did chose the "righteaous/curious/YOLO" path-"you can complete the game without fighting", no, you can't and this statement is just an excuse for poor combat/lack of.- story (it feels like a copy of Baldur's Gate II though, where you are a "child of a god" as well and another child wants you dead)- poor combat (since it's there anyway, it's actually an important aspect of the game because it should force you to build your team, but in the end, it doesn't matter so much which characters you pick and what offensive skills you chose for them)-------- In polish version, a voice actor that is a legend due to his voice acting in Baldurs Gate was advertised to work on the game, but afterall he reads only the intro, which IMHO was cheating on the customers.I was not a fan of PS:T, was hoping for something closer to BaldursGate/IcewindDale therefore I'm dissapointed but I admit that nobody was advertising this one as a competition for these titles.Spoiler:- Skip offensive skills on you character, invest in stuff that helps you questing (intelligence, persuasion, knowlege, anamnesis(or whatever it is in english).- The only usefull spell I found on nano is "summon living fire" which always draws all NPCS during combat, letting you save HP- Just get Callistege and Erritis, give them the ring that lets them share states so callistege can buff erritis and erritis kills everything

content:
Posted: March 9
												Torment: Tides of Numenera, the successor to Planescap...wait, no.Torment: Tides of Numenera, the spiritual succ...nope!Torment: Tides of Numenera, the thematic successor? (What the heck does that even mean...?)What is this game? Here's a better title:Numenera: The Fluffy Tides Make You Fall Asleep (a poor attempt at Star Wars: The Force Awakens.)Who's in torment? It certainly isn't the Last Castoff. The Tides may as well not even exist, or be referred to like something as gravity for that matter. They have no impact on game play, nor are they an ethical system, or what people think of you. Legacy is just another name for "extra screen at the ending."So we're left with this idea: take the template from Planescape:Torment, look at it, then throw it away.-Switch up the setting, since they can't get the license. (The setting is amazing by definition, not by opinion.)-Create a boring protagonist who has the character of a blank RPG sheet -- minus the stats, since there are only 3.-Forget everything from P:T that made the characters deep with their personal conflicts, faults, and philosophies, and forget putting tropes upside down on their heads in a fantasy D&D setting. Instead, create people who are simply there and have almost nothing to do with anyone (save maybe Matkina?)-Get Chris Avellone to write the only entertaining character, Erritis, instead of putting him in charge.--"Oh but if you give Rhin to X, she becomes tall and..."--zzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz.-Waste Mark Morgan's time and have him create over 40 pieces of forgettable pieces of music.-Get, in some cases, highschool level artwork to have "meres" or memory experiences that change other castoff's memories or time or whatever (?), because that worked so well in Pillars of Eternity. So you can change your tidal affinity. Which does nothing.-Re-invent "turn based combat" by providing dozens of weapons and armor -- armour that only you can wear -- but half the time during "Crises" you're going to be talking, or running through a group of enemies to solve the problem in a non-combat way. Essentially the strategy of running around like an armoured up A-Team truck, because a selling point will be to "go through the entire game without fighting." Thus, making combat for people who play Glaive, or of players who want to actually play a game, a chore. Thanks, endless amounts of teleporting Bloom--Predatory Echoes. (If I wanted to play a visual novel, I'd get one with sex, nudity and actual drama. Thanks, senpai.)-Lie about in the marketing how Glaives can attack twice in a turn (note:provided your first turn killed an enemy, and you bothered to get the skill to attack again.)-Get oddities from long sidequests that literally do nothing but clutter up your inventory-Have a scrolling inventory of useless items -- 2 rows of 14 items at a time-Pick up Cypher Sickness when completing a quest if you didn't choose a Jack. If you are a Jack, die.-Bombard us with narrative fluff in an already padded out story of figuring out how to fix a Resonance Chamber, whatever that is, 95% of the time.-Beat your daddy by telling him he doesn't exist, because he's actually an AI program. I'm not kidding.People who were expecting Planescape: Torment? Get used to entire weird worlds of disppointment.People who want drama and philosophy and conflict and layers of meaning and memorab-- look elsewhere.Pros:-I'd say the writing is on a level only slightly better than Pillars of Eternity. And Good Lord is there fluff; you'll be going through this text faster than any other Infinity Engine style game, choosing the option where you get to use your Effort.-You can tell all your hipster friends you like narrative heavy games, because you're a smart video gamer."What does one life matter?" After 4 years and 5 million bucks of delayed, dropped content, I don't know, Colin.  If that's your response to "what can change the nature of a man", well, I guess we all knew what we were getting into beforehand.Like Star Wars, The Force Awakens, this is a fan made game trying to use a winning formula, only worse: they didn't understand why the original worked.

content:
Posted: March 3
												As someone who have played the original source material (Numenera RPG, the tabletop one) before. This one is hard for me. inXile did put a breath of life to the Ninth World fantastically. The world, the background are weird and odd, but carry the abstractly beautiful aesthetic that is a throwback to the old games like Myst, Oddworld, and The Longest Journey. However, the story, dialogue, and bad adaption of tabletop system kills the fun for me.Story is good, but not really something to write home about. Maybe I did set the bar too high, but it did not leave a strong lasting impression. It will entice you to follow it, but sometime I get bored and just quit the game. Instead of wanting to get to the end on my own, it feels more like a carrot on a stick. Also I do not like most of the companions as a person. That maybe a good or bad thing because I do not know how others do find them. I feel that they are really unlikable, almost Anti-Mary Sue like unlikable. I do not see anything good in them at all. Everyone except for the Lost Child who Talks to God, and the Furtive Jack who Murders. One thing I really appreciate about this is inXiles decision to separate the continuity from the source material because lately it has been cancerous lately not so subtly pushing political agenda, but also to let the uninitiated have an easy time understanding this weird little world.Dialogue carries the worst sin in this game. For the denizens of the Ninth World, they sure do speak and behave like typical Hipsters and the Millenials of San Francisco of today. Not all of them, sure. But when I came across one, the magic is shattered and the wonders fade. The other times, it just feel odd. I understand that this is the future world where everything is eerie and weird, but I just cannot seem to relate. Star Trek and other Speculative Fictions also do boast weird alien cultures, but it is done well. Not in this case though.The gameplay. Where should I begin, this will be a long topic. First, how about lack of character customisation though your mileage may vary with this one. Planescape: Torment is an old game, lack of customisation is excusable for the game of that period. I feel this is a missed opportunity, even though 'your appearance is a plot point', so why the so called plot point cannot follow the player customisation. Why the devs do not let players have fun express themselves properly through the 'Role-Playing' game. I seriously do not want to be some guy with bad tan and a bad hairdo.Second, the severe lack of Foci option. You only have 3 foci which is not really much, the source material has about 30 which I believe can be easily translated. Why I cannot be a Jack who WIelds Two Weapon or Wields Power with Precision, or a Nano who Explores Dark Places.Third, the introduction of HP, stunted starting pool, lack of Edge in the beginning. The Cypher system is simple enough to translate to video game format without much difficulty, yet the dev decided to 'adapt it to video game' and the work did screw up the balance and fun of the system. For the uninitiated, the source material has no HP. Any damage you sustain goes into the appropriate pool (mental assault hits Intellect, a hamstring hits Speed, a slash hits Might), if the appropriate pool are depleted then it goes to the next appropriate. If one pool is depleted, you are in big trouble with a penalty to every action. If two pools are depleted, you are near death as in utterly covered bruises and bleeding or something along that line, can take no action and can only crawl. Three gone, you are dead. No need to introduce HP at all. Your starting pool are higher (average out at 9-10), and you begin with appropriate Edge or two of your chosen class so that, say a Nano can use Onslaught with for free without having to run to inn every time he depletes his pool (and put himself in a bad situation). Also you have 6 Tiers and recover your pool through recovery pool, not magical inn rest that cures everything including AIDS.This will be direct questions to the dev: I poked around the inner workings, I just want to ask why? I saw that you were going for a 1-1 translation of the game, so why everything ended up half-baked. Dangers of Kickstarter of having to listen 100 opinions pushing you 100 directions as a designer so you have to compromise to satisfy everyone but in the end let everyone down? Also the 'hand-crafted' combat encounters is too heavy handed, let thing flow, give some space for players to work with please.Everything feels like a giant half-hearted of a letdown in attempt to please everyone. Not every customer wants what they say they want, you are game designer, developers. You should know these situations well where if you let a customer just use you as a tool which is precisely commanded through feedback, then the end result is going to be bad.No more please. Never again.Message to the devs ends hereTo summarise. I would not recommend this. It is fun, charming, lovely, but ultimately a massive letdown and you see a fleeting grand vision of what could have been a magnificent masterpiece, a disappointment you cannot let go like an ex with a tragic breakup.

number of helpful: 132 of 207 people (64%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 4
												Disclaimer: I do NOT reccomend the game at its current pricing. Furthermore, after much thought, I do not reccomened it for what it claims to be. This is no Planescape: Torment and it is not a worthy successor. Nevertheless, there is something worth the time it takes to play, even if it is deeply flawed. Below is my first formal attempt at a review, which I have tried to do indepth and professionally as possible.At the conclusion, there will be a numerical score with a breakdown for my reasoning behind it.---Background---I backed this game for a sum of forty dollars the week it was announced. I discovered the kickstarter just as I was finishing Planescape: Torment, the last of the great CRPG classics that I was cleaning out of my backlogue. Starting with Baldurs Gate, I have gone through that entire series, the Neverwinters, the Icewind Dales, Arcanum, and had also played entirety of the newer roleplaying games of both high and low prominence, such as Mass Effect, Dragon Age, Jade Empire, Inquisitor, Knights of the Old Republic, and was also following the development of Wasteland 2, Pillars of Eternity, Age of Decadence, and so on and so forth.I was one of the cautiously surprised wave surfers of the "age of incline" or the "new golden age of RPGs." And Planescape: Torment had just become the crown jewel and the capstone of that period of my life before the new era began.Should a developer or InXile affiliate read this, I have a personal note. This was my first Kickstarter I ever participated in, and I was very hesitant to lay down that much (or any) money for any project. While my tier was low as far as backers go, it was a lot of money for me, considering that I was funding my own education at the time and came from a poor background. So I placed a lot of value in this game. During the years it took for T:TON to be developed, I went through multiple rough patches where suicide seemed to be the answer. Yet thought that persisted in my mind when I came close to doing something drastic was that I would never see the return on this monetary investment, and I didn't want to die after wasting thirty five ♥♥♥♥ing bucks. So yeah. I'm not claiming T:TON saved my life. It didn't. I had other reasons or pulling through in the end, but it was one of many minor things that kept me going.---Development, Production, and Publishing---Hype was generated through regular Kickstart updates and YouTube videos with lofty promises, but I have always been a pessimist and I decided early to not buy in. Many did, however, and ended up donating even more.In the months to come, major cuts of important goals were promsied, but never mentioned. These were things that people donated for with expectation of their deliverance. It would have been forgivable if they had been straightforward and transparant about it, but they were not. A backer had to discover it and confront them before it was admitted.An apology is owed to the backers. This is a shameful incident. Luckily, they managed to salavage (from whatever unknown difficulty and strife was responsible for these cuts) a decent game that delivers an excellent story.They acceped a publishing contract with Techland  who, if I have the story correct, was responsible for the decision to port it to XBox-One and PS4, and footed the bill for the ports. The game was promised to be optimized for PC. In the end, it was not.Of note, the Italians were also screwed over and never got a translation, as they were promised.In the end, the hype:delivery ratio would make Todd Howard proud.---Review---Artistic Visuals:  First off, the enviromental visuals are utterly fantastic in my opinion. The otherwordly vibe of official Numenera artwork and universe is captured perfectly. Every single location in the game seems irreplacible unique and incomparable to other settings. This is most definitely a worthy introduction to the surreal beauty of Numenera. +2GUI: In stark contract, the GUI is minimalistic most of the time, and overwhelming at other times. Thankfully, this game is not one that is reliant on the GUI to be playable. During exploration, it is very clean. Perhaps a little too clean. During dialogue, the box is far too large. It is visually appalling and sometimes even detrimental to the actions being described, as characters and objects are often cut off and sometimes not visible at all.A classic CRPG feature is pressing a 'tab' to highlight all objects. Here it is absolutely overwhelming. Every name is enshrined in a massive decoration that is unecessary, while everything else is covered in an icon indicating its purpose. It doesn't simply highlight, it adds a whole new layer of buttons and symbols, along with respective text labels for all of them.There is also no way to see where a scene transition is going to take you without consulting your map, which is on a separate screenThe CYOA UI of Meres is nice, but I've heard of some bugs at higher resolutions. -.5 Combat: I'm not going to go into depth here due to the character limit, but it is mediocre at best and flat out atrocious at worst. It is not a focus of the game, but it is still a feature. A bad feature. -.8 Writing: Varies wildly. Most tertiery background characters and minor antagonists recieve the most depth, while most companions are lacking in enough dialogue to make them feel human. The main characters, such as the Changing God, the Sorrow,  and the Last Castoff are tragically the worst written. Rhin, Erritis, Tyber, Inifere, and the Bloom are the best characterized.It frequently devolves into adjective porn and purple prose. More edits should have been done. I have a large vocabulary and was able to understand everything in the game without consulting a dictionary, but there were some cases of uneeded verbosity. However, what is actually being written, is indeed literary. Reminiscent of Gene Wolfe in particular, and yes, even PS:T. +3.3, -.7 Story/Plot: It is definitely not on par with PS:T, but it isn't entirely dissociated from it. It is excellent for the era it was released in. This is a cut above Pillars of Eternity, Wasteland, Sword of Dragonspear, etc. On par with Age of Decadence, with better writing. However, it tries to be too different AND too similar to PS:T at the exact same time. The epynonymous "torment" element is particularly lacking. +4, -.2 Choice and Consequence: Average. It delivers what should be expected of all story heavy RPGs. Not as hyperreactive as promised, however. +0, -0 Pacing: Sagus Cliffs is the only decently paced area in the entire game and the ending feels rushed due to cut content that would have filled the gaps. -.3 Levels: The non-linearity and linearity is unbalanced, again, due to cut content again. But the content of them is rife with well designed quests, and non-quest exploration that is rewarded and engaging. Size varies, but feels right in the end. The Bloom is fantastic. +2, -.5 Mechanics: Stat Pools are laughable and easily abused, but are drained enough to need management. There is a bias towards being a nano and getting their mind reading abilities, but overall, the games skills are balanced and are checked often. They add a lot in the end. -.4, +.5 Bugs: Minor ones still present during writing of review, but nothing that will ruin your game. But some annoying ones none the less. -.2---Score: 6.9/10 PS:T's score: 9.5/10---Go in with zero expectations and you'll be pleasantly surprised. It has an amazing world with a capitvating story. Expect what was promised, and you'll be very disappointed. This is one of the better examples of the RPG 'renaissance,' but a crude imitation of its inspiration, riddled with inconsistent quality, a bad development history and broken promises. I felt like it was worth my time, but I did not feel satisfied due to how much better it could have been. Buy it on sale.

number of helpful: 53 of 74 people (72%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ah, Tides of Numenera. This game has great potential. It -can- become a truly great game. Perhaps one of the all-time greats.But we are not there yet. The game as it stands in December 2016 is a 10-hour buggy mess with a crappy combat system.So how come I recommend it do you say? Well, here's why. It -does- have great potential. The story is engrossing, the world is strange, mystical, and refreshing, the skills and abilities are cool and, for the most part, work really well. The combat system is an exception. It doesn't work well, and doesn't feel slick and dangerous, like combat should.Without going into spoilers I want to say that the main story so far looks really well put together. There are many throwbacks to Planescape: Torment, but this is definitely its own thing.The three-stat system, and how you use stats for skills and conversations all work really well.There's a lot of bugs in the current build, and hopefully by the time you read this review, they have ironed out the worst of them. I expect a lot of this game. I count on inXile to deliver.

												Did you always want to gently massage the rim of a giant alien's sphincter in order to climb up it? Listen to endless people drone on about Legacies and whether their life matters or not in paragraph after paragraph of wordy, description-heavy text? Go bake a cake while the game plays itself, as masses of enemies march around endlessly in unavoidable Crises? Read stories and look at pictures which looked like they were made by highschoolers with a too-high opinion of themselves? Succeed in every skill check because you're awesome, they're awesome, everybody's awesome? Congratulations, Torment: Tides of Numenera is just the game for you.For my part, next time I'm in the mood for this level of entertainment, I'll just wash the dishes. At least that gives a certain sense of accomplishment.

content:
Posted: March 5
												Sadly I am joining the ranks of users dissatisfied with this game.  I gave it a good 8 hours but when I realized that I was forcing myself to continue playing in the hopes it would improve I decided it was not worth my time.  I'm sure there's a great story here, but I don't want to have to slog through text block after text block to uncover it.  I like playing my games, being involved in them moreso than just selecting another dialogue option.I believe the lack of combat gameplay really hurt this game - in other CRPGs the combat/dungeon crawling provides a break from the text and allows the player to experience the world.  This is very lacking in this game.  There is very little combat at all and the existing combat is all staged - it feels less interactive and more like an alternate form of dialogue.I guess that's my overall impression of the game: it's a videogame that feels like its designed to be read and not played.There are so many ways a videogame can be used to show something, immerse the players, but this feels like someone telling me a story as opposed to showing/letting me experience it. The introduction has you falling to your (believed) death - but, instead of having a quick cinematic showing you falling from a great height and crashing to the ground, there is a 10 minute narration about the fall, oh look there's a forest over there, oh were you being chased by something? oh wait is that the ground....wait for it....still narrating...finally, you hit the ground.  And the graphic display for this?  A black screen with white streaks that I think are supposed to be wind.Each character you meet has blocks of descriptor but I have yet to encounter a single character portrait concept art.  There is a section of the dialogue box that looks designed to hold a portrait but it remains a blank grey canvas.  Even when you speak to your companions there is no close up portrait of them.3 million plus words is not a selling point!  It's a sign that a better editor was needed.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								First, let me say at the time of writing this, this game is early beta and it shows. There's quite a few bugs, it's not very stable even with high end computers, and you can tell there's some basic features that haven't been implemented. Thankfully, this build of the game has a convenient and ever present feedback button that makes reporting the bugs and other issues much easier. Second, in spite of that knowledge, I'd like to recommend opting into the beta because this game is just that promising. It's still too soon to say with any certainty if this game will be just a good game or a great game, but I will say that what I have seen is special. Everything from the setting to the writing to the mechanics is just brimming with potential, and even with the game only being partially realized I can say that it is worth checking out and that you should keep your expectations high.

number of helpful: 94 of 146 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24
												Badly mismanaged development leads to a crudely foreshortened final act. This is a decent game but far too short for the price.The botched final act is why I left a negative review. All that time looking for a way to fix the resonance chamber but it just floats into the room after half an hour offscreen with a Mazzof who was still covered in Bloom vomit. In general the areas are quite claustrophobic, with some cut entirely. You can see the loose ends of cut content in many places.Also the setting is too much random, disconnected atomised trinkets, with little or no cohesion. The frustration from that is exacerbated by the overly adjective-heavy writing. Sometimes less is more. Plus, I don't find an endless series of literal Deus Ex Machinas a satisfying narrative device.The character portraits are apparently photos of faces that then got surrounds painted onto them - Aligern's face is set square to the camera while his body and head are at an angle. Not only that but I saw some much better alternative portraits, which Inexile made, which looked far better than those used ingame, for Tybir, Callistege, Aligern, Matkina. The ones in game are expressionless; that's arguably fitting for Matkina and Aligern and Erritis, who are cold, depressed and vacant respectively. But the alternative portrait for Callistege is so superior - it expresses her personality very well. Reminds me of an exgirlfriend of mine.Also, what's with the lighting being so flat?However, Rhin is not only good, but is something I've never seen in an RPG before. very unusual concept. It's a decent/good game but it's so obviously worse than what it should have been, it pisses me off.

Early Access Review
								Now I've been through the early access version meticulously (expected bugs included) and in spite of the few glitches, it's obvious what a completely awesome and amazing story this is.I totally and gleefully look forward to the finished version.Lifting the legacy of Planescape Torment is, in my eyes, quite an impossibility. I've kept coming back to that game like a favourite story since it was released, but I almost think they might succeed. In creating a setting so different, and yet so similar, I feel like I'm being given all the same philosophical, ambiguous and metaphysical strangeness, but in a new world without it being just old stuff reiterated. The atmosphere is different, the characters, the tone. And yet somehow, it's recognisable as a successor. Long story short, this is the kind of story that I will likely keep coming back to in the future too.I can't wait to see the finished product.10/10

Generally is just really miss the pacechanges from crpgs - going from hardhitting dialogue the has you all wrapped up in stories, characters and places, to fast paced pause-based combat.I so wanted to like this. So much. I just find the game somewhat tedious, and would much rather just read the story as a book.Edit: Pillars of earth :D

content:
Posted: March 1
												I'm giving this a thumb down with really a heavy heart.And this be a high(ish) tier KS backer bleeding heart, for that matter. And that's the crux of the problem, I think.By no means is Numenera an objectively bad game, but I think it unfortunate that the KS campaign is probably the best excecuted area of the whole project. I admit I could not manage my expectations because PS:T is forever a favourite. Someone coming to this game with lesser vested interest will probably really like it.The writing is quite good, with interesting and even touching little destinies. I mean: why did I feel so sad for a "stillborn" robot, for example?? The story is a definate highlight. I also think visually the game is pleasing.But I really, really hate the combat. It's not particularly good as far as turn based go, IMO - and because the emphasis more or less has to be on "social" skills and checks to get the most out of the gameworld, I've found myself quite on the plain side as far as fighting prowess go.Here the promised but not delivered death labyrinths would have been handy, to add a silver lining to the fumbling combat.I find the turn based solution poor and inorganic - not to mention that BG-style pausable tactical combat could be played as turn based by enabing auto-pause. Why not deliver both worlds, when this has been the case in the classics of the genre inXile is paying homage to?Do I regret backing? Not exactly. I did not get what I hoped for, but at least inXile got my good-will when it needed it the most. I wish to be optimistic that this title will serve a basis from which inXile can improve many a tantalising idea that did not get the depth it would have deserved. But I doubt that I would pre-pay them on faith again.

content:
Posted: February 28
												When I first ran the game on release day and clicked on the options menu, I noticed all the text in the settings menu was blurry. When I entered the actual game, I saw that the in-game text was also blurry. Since I wasn't sure if I was the only person with this problem, I posted in the forums to see if other people were having it, and to my surprise the blurry text turned out to be there for everyone (although there are varying opinions about how bothersome it is).After some debate about it in the forum, a developer message responds:"Thanks for letting us know. We're aware of this behavior - this is not really a new issue with Unity, many games using UGUI seem to exhibit it.Prior to release we weren't able to find an ideal solution that didn't also introduce other issues. We'll investigate our options further for future updates."You can find the thread about the blurry text problem here:https://steamcommunity.com/app/272270/discussions/0/133258092255625842/Unfortunately, I can't play a game that is so focused on text dialog if it has a blurry text problem. Since Steam can provide refunds for any reason, you should be able to buy the game and then judge whether the blurry text problem is annoying enough for you to justify returning the game. If this problem ever gets fixed, I'll update my review, but for now the game is going to sit on my digital shelf since I kickstarted the project and have no option for a refund.

												I recommended this game, butit is definitely not for everyone. Planescape: Torment was like reading a book in game form. As the Spiritual successor Torment: Tides of Numenera (T:ToN) is the same. So if you aren't into dialogue heavy games then this is not for you.The writing is very good though. It is interesting. Sometimes it feels to me like there is some trying hard to be different and exotic, but mostly it's excellent.Combat is done fairly interestingly. You "spend" your stat points to perform actions, or boost them. Then use consumables or rest to restore them.Ciphers are special consumables, you can only carry a limited amount, or you get penalties, and they are one use only. But you get enough that I don't really get the "I'll save this for when I need it" hoarding.Annoted my logbook.

This is a missed opportunity where a lingering thought of "what could have been" remains in the end.

												I would have loved to rate this positivly, but the game isn't worth it.  I think they made a mistake going with the numenera system.  While the setting is fantastic, the system is absolutly geared towards pen and paper, high role playing, not CRPG.  As such, story and campaign wise, it would have made for a great P&P game, but it falls flat in this medium.  It is to easy.  I went back to play Planescape: Torment, and died twice trying escape the first level.  There is no tension here, and some pretty poor decisions in the NPC interactions (dialogs are *pain*) turn what should have been an enjoyable, well though out and well written (it is very well written) world into  a chore.I'm really sad about this, I have played Numenera with friends, I love the setting, the writting is good, the art is fantastic, but this is a bad video game.

												I want to like this. I want to recommend it. But I can't.At its core, a Torment game should be a visual novel.Except the writing in this game is terrible. There's no details, save when you  use Anamnesis, but even then it's vague.They should have taken a page from Shadowrun: delve into the writing. Don't just tell me about the world, show me it in words that grasp the entire human vocabulary.And the world. InXile's representation of Monte Cook's world manages to take the exotic, the alien, and the innately fascinating, and turn it into something mundane.This is science fantasy. This is Clake's Third Law.Distilled, pureed, and rendered homogenous. Instead we're left with a lackluster swipe at fame, an attempt to emulate the greatness of Planescape torment without understanding what made it special.As an early backer, I'm disappointed.As a fan of Planescape: Torment, I'm saddened.As a person whom yearns for the days of old-style CRPGs, this title solidifies the fact that we're not going back. It is no longer possible to do so.

												This would be one of the first game reviews I publish, mostly because I have ixed feelings on it. I enjoyed the game but I'm going to not reccomend it in order to balance all the other positive reviews it's getting. Working my way through almost all the side quests and exploring I finished the game in 15hrs. Due to the limited number of available party members I feel the replay value is not that great. Hence, 44EUR is too high a price (30 would be more reasonable.) The game is interesting but somewhat incoherent. The concept of several layers of reality is neat, but what that means in effect is that the thread of interesting plots/characters is lost against the mish-mash background. This leads to clicking around an area 'just because' rather than any central drive or natural curiousity. By the end I didn't feel like I had a real understanding of the characters involved, or what their motivations mattered.

Posted: March 17
												For reference: I have played through Planescape:Torment 3 times over the years.I had played this game for 110 minutes when I started to doubt whether there would be fun or an interesting story sometime soon. So I went and checked the, at this time outragiously good, reviews and suggestions and so on; And after pondering a view hours, hovering the mouse over the play button, wondering whether I should refund the game or not, I eventually went with the later. Unfortunatly at that. After 7 hours of playing, fun still nowhere to be found. The story is dull to say the least. The companiens, except for the little girl, are forgettable placeholders. All the characters are purposefully ugly. Their flawed nature is supposed to be the point I guess but still... There is no romance option. The combat system is annoying at best and again begs the question why devs constantly try to reinvent the wheel.I personally enjoyed but one quest so far; The one with the psychics in the bar.I am aware that one could argue that I might have seen nothing of the game after that time but still though. I'm not playing games in the search of eventual fun.For the equivalent amount of money you could have bought the original game, both icewind dales and would still have something over to grab a hard copy of Anno 1602 from some green case stack.Originally I swore to myself to never buy a Unity game again. Should have stuck with it.

number of helpful: 61 of 95 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 5
												Too much text, not enough gameplay. They say good dialogue is what made Planescape great. They're not wrong, but what they didn't understand is that what kept the original from being a true masterpiece was the lack of decent combat gameplay. I remember playing it and by the end thinking "man, what a great story, great characters and intriguing world... now if only it had the combat gameplay mechnanics of Baldur's Gate, it would have been the best". Instead of correcting this, they made it worse. I can't play this 10 minutes without getting bored and rushing through dialogues and without the dialogues, there's nothing left. Show, don't tell. I find it ironic that whenever you ask a character a second time to repeat the trivial information he spent so long to describe he manages to summarize it in a few sentences only. These summary, more often than not, should have been the first and only answer.The fact that you can't engage in combat with anyone also diminishes the impression of freedom and choice of action and reinforces the impression that you're really just a spectactor here, and the game just wants you to go about speaking to people and solve their fetch quests. Whatever your choices in Baldur's Gate, you knew you could always attack the npcs. Here? The game really just wants you to listen to its lore... I don't recommend it. This is for hipsters stuck on nostalgia saying that PT was about something else than gameplay. PT was great but it's never been the classic game than Baldur's Gate was. It could have been so much better with a better combat mechanic and simply MORE COMBATS. I understand PT strived to be the ANTI Baldur's Gate, and had its heart in the right place by having you focus in stats like charisma, intelligence and wisdom instead, but it went overboard with it, as it ends up way less balanced than BG and having little replay value. Fights is what give replay value to these games. Fights can go in so many directions, although less so in turn based combats, but that's another issue (at this point I'm just desperate for anything else than listening to NPCs narrating a fantasy's short story, so I'll take turn based, even with its obvious flaws). Dialogues options, on the other hand, is just a matter of reloading and finding out what happens if I click on one answer instead of the other. They are "nice to have", but they're not the meat of these video games.Unfortunatly they chose poorly in this sequel by focusing even LESS on gameplay. I guess it costs less to produce. 50$ for this is ridiculous. It's worth 15$ at the most. Will not be purchasing from InXile again.

content:
Posted: March 2
												I've pledged this Kickstarter, I was following this since the beggining. The game I've receive is not what was promised, it's just an lazy animated book, filled with meaningless text 80% of the time. What's the point of interact with a blue floating orb that emits light, if the only thing I'm presented is a text saying "it's a blue floating orb with light pouring from it"? Yes, I can see that, are you just trying to increase ingame word-count? You can't take pride of 3+ milion word-count if almost all of those words are just wasted text.It's  just a little bit of Numenera (the world), if you already read the Ninth World Guidebook you'll be disapointed because this game can't make justice to this amazing world.It's not Cypher System, in the worst way, as the developer just got a system that made a paradigm shift in RPGs and returned it to the status quo. The system uses your stat pools as "HP", the developer just ignored this and created out of thin air a HP stat. There are just 3 foci, instead of dozens that you have in the original Cypher System. And even with all those changes, if you make a Nano and go full INT, the game turns so easy that's almost like you're cheating. Just to show how poorly implemented the system is: you can 90% of time use your companions stat pools in your personal checks. It doesn't make any sense. You're not that good at lying? No problem at all, because this other nano is a lying machine and will make sure you deceive everyone around you with his talking skills, even while he is not taking any part in the talk!Very lazy texts, unpolished UI that screams "CONSOLE GAME", forgettable NPCs, boring combat system. It's an abomination to call this a "spiritual successor" of Planescape: Torment. It isn't, and by far.Stick to Pillars of Eternity if you're dying for a CRPG, it's a better product than this mess.

												Torment Tides of Numenera is what happens when individuals who dont understand creating fun games try to copy one portion an old game that was fun for multiple reasons.  It falls miserably short.  TLDR version Backed game, played beta.  Did not enjoy stat pool version of combat still beat early crises even with difficulty apparently "too high".  Streamlining occured for "reasons", combat no longer important pools made more simplistic so people couldnt kill themselves with difficulty.  What we get  is a talky often incomprehensible game with the illusion of choice but no real part in the plot.  Planescape torment had plot, but it also had player choice that felt like it actually matter.  Torment tides simply does not.  Exploring portions of setting and sidequest is more interesting than learning why the main character is who he is or why he exists.  THATS NOT GOOD NEWS

												Had high hopes for that game. Finished it thoroughly, read all the text, talked with everybody, etc... and there's nothing special to remember. The single quest with Baron in Witcher 3 is twice better than this whole game. Which is sad, actually.Not even close to the Old Planescape, of course.Combat is bad (you can skip almost all of it, but that does not make it better), UI and inventory are clunky, companions are bland, but what is the worst - all the walls of text you trudge through, are not exciting. They are boring. Ah, and one more - your decisions actually does not really matter. The whole Tide system is for nothing.The game is not a total disaster, but for the money and time that was invested in it it's more of a joke. A sad joke.

Early Access Review
								I searched for a game that offered a compelling story and enthralling universe. I found Torment: Tides of Numenera and instantly purchased it. This game, which is set to be released at the end of the month, is beautiful. I became fully immersed in this game, just as I did with Shadowrun Returns (+xpacs). Give this game your attention and patience, and you will certainly become hooked and intrigued. The game is not combat-centric and I really enjoy that. It works for the Numenera universer, the storyline, and the pacing of how things develop.Highly recommended.
