content:
Posted: March 2
												Before this game I got and quite enjoyed such recent "oldschool isometric RPGs" as Pillars of Eternity, Divinity Original Sin, Wasteland 2, Age of Decadence and Tyranny. They had their ups and downs, but Numenera is regrettably the worst of them. In some ancient past I revered Planescape as much as the next guy. Don't remember much details now though, so no comparison here.Nonexistant gameplay leaves you with what tries to be an ineractive book. Though full of interesting ideas, the writing is actually bad. This is not a book, this is a simulator of a journalist in a madhouse: Hello there, what's your name, from which dimension you think you came today, which one of your split personalities is causing problems you think? Ok, yeah, the next one please, hello, what's your name. The game is ridiculously easy: three types of easily restockable resources will get you through every dialog check and battle in no time, you just keep minimal reasonable balance when upgrading your characters, no real planning needed.Interface is fine, but with overwhelmingly enormous infodumps why not make these super helpful hyperlinks like in Tyranny. And yeah, you have this large placeholder in the bottom interface panel, where logically you expect to see your dialog partner portrait, but it just stays empty every single time. Characters and situations are often interesting but resolve too mundane, sideqests are mechanically short and primitive. I find it depressing that characters often have rich and tasty backgrounds but don't do much in actual game. Main quest is really great, for me it's the best thing there is in this game.I have only finished the first large hub, it's 1/3 of the game I figure, so I cannot really tell about reactivity - have not seen much of it yet though.Tides mechanics are funny not in a good way: they are supposed to change NPC reactions in dialogs, but I have no idea if it really happens. Seems you need second playthrough to evaluate this mechanics.There is this 'use environment' mechanics in fights, but I did not bother, simple attacks solved all 5 or so fights.Visuals are bad, Wasteland 2 was much better (when it was finally done properly), leave alone the gorgeous beautiful Divinity Original Sin. Art design may appeal to some, but it left me cold (though I expect second hub Bloom to be better). Thanks for Linux support though, love to have it.I'll update the review when I finish the game. But from where I stand now you can do much better reading Gene Wolfe's "The Book of the new Sun" cycle than playing this game, it will scratch your itch, I guarantee you.

number of helpful: 32 of 45 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												Update:There are a dozen things that I should be doing right now, after having neglected life for the last two days in favour of playing/finishing Torment, but I felt that I should update my review.The beginning, much like the original, starts off slow, and is not a good indicator of the plot pacing throughout the rest of the game. As I continued to play beyond the early access content, I couldn’t believe how amazing this game is. The general narrative, dialog, and characters (even minor NPCs) are developed incredibly well, so much so that I felt like I was playing through a well-written novel.There are numerous ways to compare it to Planescape: Torment (including several in-game nods), yet Tides of Numenera is very much a creature of its own. Given the setting change, I didn’t think that it would be able to hold a candle to it’s predecessor—it does, and then some. It’s hard not to feel involved in the plights of your party members, and the worlds/areas are so unique and rich that I found myself excited to explore.I like that most of the quests don’t provide much hand-holding, the story in this game is such that it wouldn’t be anywhere nearly as immersive if I didn’t have to use my brain to remember who I’d spoken to and what was discussed. I can see that being extremely frustrating for people who prefer to zone out while gaming, along with the quantity of reading required. The game is also -not- combat-centric as most RPGs are, so some may find that lacking.My only complaint is that I wish the game were longer, because I didn’t want it to end.

content:
Posted: April 22
												I can't get myself to finish this game. I suppose I'm about halfway through, but everytime I try and play it again I quit within 10 minutes due to boredom. I love RPGs and have played many of the classic ones, including Planescape Torment. I'm not averse to reading, but what I read has to at least mean something. Much of the dialogue in this game is lengthy descriptions that ultimately don't say anything, they are just words for words' sake. I'd much rather read a good book than have to wade through Tides' wordy dialogues. What else is there to the game? There's a bit of combat which is neither interesting nor difficult. There's a plot which is not very engaging, in my opinion; It's revealed to you in the beginning who and why you are, so there's hardly any mystery left in the game. Also, while you do level up in the game, it doesn't feel like you are getting any stronger; dialogue skill checks are absurdly easy to pass even in the beginning, and combat is so rare and far between and easy that it doesn't seem necessary to level up. I guess it comes down to the lack of anything to look forward to in the game. I can't look forward to trying my new cool high-level skills in a difficult boss fight, can't look forward to the reveal of the mystery of the story, can't even look forward to saving the world. Just wade through the dialogue and wait for the game to finish. A shame really, as I was really looking forward to this game. It's just not engaging at all. It'll probably be the first RPG I own that I'll never finish.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
Early Access Review
0. Conclusion I'm not a native speaker, but I like reading English novels. I loved every piece of the stories in the game, and actually, quality of the stories was the only thing that made me keep playing this game. However, if I had wanted just good readings, I would have bought a book. Every feature in this game is not that desirable except stories, and if I have to point out things, I think I should talk about  2.animation  3.combat  4.voice acting. I saw some people saying that this is a story-driven game and the other things are not needed, but this is not 'Planescape: Torment' in 1999. If an essential feature of the game can be developed as a firm structure, and it can enrich the whole game without hurting or shortening stories, I don't see any reason to prevent it.1. StoryFor people who like reading novels - (10/10)For people who don't like or are not familiar with reading - (5/10)If you like reading books, you'll be satisfied just for good stories. I like novels, movies, and TV shows which focuses on sophisticated stories, and I haven't seen any stories like T:TON. Describing the stories of this game with my sloppy words will only debase the true value of it because there are not many writers who can describe 'a world unlike any other' better than this team. So here's an example of the stories in the game, some words from a person whom you get to meet in the game."A spoken lie lasts but a breath, and those who hear it can answer with the truth. But a written lie lingers long past the lives of those who know it to be false. enduring until it can lead a whole race astray."However, I think not everyone will like this game because it contains too many reading materials. It was hard to read all these vast amounts of texts, and it was much harder than 'Pillars of Eternity'. Actually, You'll have to spend 85% of your time for reading, and 95% if you choose to avoid or resolve the crisis(combat). In my case, I liked it cause I liked those stories, but I think it could be a huge threshold for those who don't like or are not familiar with reading.2. Animation (6/10)


Torment: Tides of Numenera 
A Screenshot of Torment: Tides of Numenera
By: Gamebot




1) silver of mirror : a red line comes out.2) side mirror : A torrent of golden light flows through you.3) oval mirror : The pulsing blue star expands as you watch. Pale clouds of blue light surround your heads.4) center mirror : it shows your unaltered reflection, the crease between your eyebrows.When I was choosing each action, I expected they would show me some animations, or at least some glow on each mirror. However, all I could see during the whole sequence was the exact same static picture without any changes or movements. It's basically a picture book which I have to read multiple pages of scripts separately. It doesn't feel like a real world. I'm not saying they have to make some fabulous fantastic actions. Is it really that hard to make one bit of red or blue shining line, or at least some glow? I can't imagine that devs are somehow apathetic or lazy. This scene really made me think if there had been anything wrong with development progress.This is just one example of many things. I couldn't see any animations when 'the clock mission' started, and 'master foreman'(enormous robot) didn't even blink even when I was talking to him(But he was still talking and shouting). If it is a really hard part and can't be changed technically, I can accept that. But small effects in the important scene can't be hard and can't hurt stories. I can't understand why they didn't do anything about them.I don't think these issues are just some minor bugs or mistakes. If devs don't change their whole perspective, we'll have to read scripts on the lifeless and static picture book for most of the time.3. Combat (7/10)As you all know, 'Wasteland 2' and 'Divinity: Original Sin' had similar combat system. For instance, if you have 12 action points in 1 turn, you get to move(2pt), heal/buff/debuff(3pt), attack(5pt) and spare 2 points. In T:TON, simply put, you can use only 1 action(use item/skill/attack) and 1 move in 1 turn. Combats actually work like this.[Initiative]Enemy1 > Enemy2 > Team1 > Team2 > Enemy3 > Team3  TURN 1→ E1 Attack E2 Attack T1 Attack T2 Attack E3 Attack T3 Attack →E3 Dies   TURN 2→ E1 Attack E2 Attack T1 Attack T2 Attack   T3 Attack →E2 Dies   TURN 3→ E1 Attack  T1 Attack T2 Attack  T3 Attack →E1 Dies The reason I didn't include moving is because it doesn't actually matter in combat. First, cost and benefit(distance) of the moving is fixed. Second, moving rarely affects to the attacks because it has fixed cost. Third, moving is not about strategic decision making in the field, rather about choosing whom I will attack on this turn, like a card game. If you want to hit enemyX, you can just go to X and hit X, and there're no limits or disengagements or anything. Forth, I've tried many combats by using several saving files, so I can assure you that the enemies are not that smart. There's nothing special you can strategically gain from moving. In conclusion, It's basically not different from typical card games.At first, I thought 'sacrificing stats to increase hit chance and damage' was a brilliant idea. However, since maintaining stats are not that hard, it doesn't actually matter that much, at least for now. There are some alternative options like intimidation, persuasion, or using numenera, but they're nothing but another type of attacks. Some could say it's inevitable cause it's based on the board game Numenera, but they were monotonous and tedious combats for me anyway.I simplified many things for the explanation, but it's not that different from the big picture. I don't think little tweaks could fix this matter.4. Voice Acting (?/10)I think voice acting is important in animation movies and games. Think about any animation movie and imagine that you have to watch it without any voices. I always couldn't understand why they don't put voices in RPG. Funny thing is, they always show us an advertisement with voice actors performing their breathtaking lines, but in actual games, we can't hear anything on 80~90% of the scripts. I don't know much about voice actors, but even Youtubers make videos of full voice version. When I heard they raised over 5,000k, first thing got in my mind was a little hope that devs could show us full voice version of Torment. But I couldn't hear any signs or promises yet.[Pros]1. Vast amounts of good stories, if you like reading novels. (10/10)[Cons]1. Vast amounts of good stories, if you don't like or are not familiar with reading. (5/10)2. Lack of animations on the important scenes. (6/10)3. Combats are too simple. fundamentally similar to a card game. (7/10)4. Lack of voice actors, at least for now. and couldn't see any promises. (?/10)(My first review was a horrible gibberish, and I understand why so many people were angry about my review. I admit everything you said. I'm a system breaking illogical dishonest faggXt hipster who is also  a stupid idiot. However, this time I've done my best to arrange my thoughts and to provide information. I don't expect everyone would agree with me or like my thoughts, but I wish this could help a person who comes next. )

content:
Posted: April 17
												First game I'm reviewing on Steam.  My favorite all-time game is Baldur's Gate 2 and I loved Planescape Torment.  I was stoked for this game and backed it when it was first made public.I am not very happy with what I ended up with.  The ending (in particular) was very poorly done and felt incredibly rushed and disjointed.  A lot of times I felt like the designers challenged themselves to come up with as many outlandish characters and dialogue as they could without worrying about whether things would actually work.  And there was no depth.  The locations presented with shallow with barely any interactivity.Basically, this is a short, somewhat poorly written illustrated interactive fiction story.Connections between situations were tenuous and I barely cared about what was happening.  I thought there were some interesting points to the background story but the bit of good material was squandered in a rush to make the situations work.  And, again, the ending.  The ending was a mess.  And the antagonist!  I don't want to spoil anything but it would've worked better if it had stayed silent and menacing.  Instead, I felt like a kid at a cheap magic show:  excited at the idea until the table and poorly made boxes fall apart to reveal the trick.Not recommended.  The designers felt like they were trying to be too clever in order to replicate PT without any depth or satisfying conclusion.

Posted: March 10
												I backed this game on KS ... it was actually the reason I even got a Kickstarter account! I had extremely high hopes and that might be part of my problem with the game now.  Planescape was - for me - the best computer RPG ever. Memorable setting, characters, stories ... Torment tries to carry on that tradition and in my opinion fails. It's not about the graphics, it's not about some of the strange design decisions (combat ... amongst other things). It's about writing. Writing made Planescape such a great game and Torment is lacking in writing. It tries to reach Planescape, but it fails. A lot of overblown dialogue, trying to sound meaningful, hiding the fact that it is not under big words and extravagance.Memorable characters? Have not found many yet ...The setting? I could get into Planescape because despite the world being strange, I could relate to it.This one here? Too much ... trying to hard to be strange.Interface feels clunky in many ways, too. Granted, old RPGs had that problem, too. But it does not have to be that way. Why should I live with "old" graphics, "old" interface ... etc? It's 2017 now...

Early Access Review
								This game is in BETA still! This positive review reflects my opinion about the direction of the game knowing it's still going through beta iterations.The writing is nearly finished, and boy is the writing and story great so far! Unlike most Early Access games these days, this is not an EA release where you can play through the whole game right now. Your progress is gate to a specific point in the story so DO NOT buy this expecting to play a full length $44 game right now.The original Planescape: Torment's strengths were its amazing storytelling and loyalty to the pen & paper rules of AD&D/Planescape setting. So far my experience with Torment: Tides of Numenera shows that it will follow those same footsteps. I'm a HUGE fan of the pen & paper Numenera game and currently GM two different campaigns. I love that InXile has preserved the Tabletop rules and that they play very well in conversations and in-game combat.

content:
Posted: March 13
												Torment: Tides of Numenera is the long awaited spiritual successor to Planescape: Torment. After a successful kickstarter campaign, and several delays, the game is finally out. But how well does it hold up?What sets Torment apart from most other CRPGs is the amount of reading you have to do. There's not a whole lot of combat in this game, and what is in there can usually be avoided through dialogue or skillchecks.Graphics & soundTorment tries to emulate the look of the old infinity engine games, but with a more modern coat of paint. The result are some beautiful, and very imaginative looking environments, that look both familiar, and unlike anything I've seen in another game. The art style is consistently strong, and the environments are varied. From the sky docks of the city, that evokes a fantasy/steampunk feeling, to the fleshy interior of the Bloom, there's a lot to like about the environments.Sadly the character models don't fare as well. While they are not hideous, they do look dated, with a low polygon count, and relatively stiff poses. It's not something that really distracts from the game, but they could still have been done better. The humanoid models are also visually uninteresting, with little that really stands out about them. Where the game that inspired this had a large cast of very distinct looking characters, here they mostly look the same. Non-humanoid characters do fare better, and there are a couple of interesting looking creatures in this game, but once again, the quality of the character models do disappoint a bit.There's not a whole lot to say about the sound in Torment. The music works as background music, and often feels directly inspired by that of Planescape, but after having played the game, there are no tracks that really stick out in my mind. The voice acting is overall not bad, but not spectacular either. Most of the dialogue is not voiced, but what is voiced does the job well enough.Setting & storyThis is where Torment shines. The game is, as previously mentioned, set in the Numenera setting. The setting offers a mix between fantasy & sci-fi, but in a more coherent and logical way than games like Wizardry or Might & Magic. There are remains of ancient high-standing civilizations everywhere, with younger civilizations building on top of older. This means that during play, you run into both fantastical beasts, and robots, ancient constructs, and modern architecture. It's an interesting setting, one I wish to explore further after having played through the game. In terms of story, you start the game falling from the sky. You're not sure why, who you are, or where you've landed. Unlike classic amnesia stories, there's a reason for this that makes perfect sense in setting. You're the creation of a god, or are you the god reborn in a new body? You're not sure, but as you move through the world you find out more about this god, about the struggle it faces, and about its conflict with its children. I'm not going to spoil it further, but it's a mostly well told story, although it ends up feeling rushed towards the end. The main story also ends up feeling a bit too linear, and once you've left an area, you can never go back. The way the progression is structured, the game world actually ends up feeling really small.Like many other CRPGs of this type, there are also plenty of side quests to be done, many smaller stories that are being told around you, and that you can influence. There are no rats in the basement quests in this game, or go and deliver this box of cupcakes to that person, all the quests have their own stories, that are generally well written and interesting. There are also several different ways to solve most quests. You might talk your way through them, fight your way, use specific objects in the world, or a combination of the above. And they often have different outcomes that sometimes end up haunting you further into the game.Each of your companions also have their own quests, and a large amount of dialogue, that lets you learn more about them. This is against quite well written, but I do feel that some companions are far more interesting than others. None of the ones I've used have been boring, but some could have used a bit more work. Still, if you're the kind of person who loves to get to know your party members, Torment has you covered. Sadly Planescape does trounce Torment: Tides of Numenera quite soundly when it comes to party members. There are more of them, and they are also more interesting.GameplayThere's a lively debate surrounding this game's predecessor, about what counts as gameplay. Just the combat, or does the dialogue choices you make also count as gameplay? Depending on which side of the line you fall on, Torment either has very little gameplay, or still a fare amount of it. There are a lot of dialogue choices to be made in Torment, and they can have wide-ranging consequences. One system that I really liked from Torment is the "efforts" system. When you're performing a task that requires a skillcheck, you've got a base chance based on your skills & stats, and then you can spend "efforts" into improving your odds of success. These efforts are treated like a resource that replenishes  when you rest, and it's a really nice system, which allows you to be the judge of what skill checks you think it's important to succeed in. Efforts come in 3 categories, might, speed & intelligence, and each character has its own pool of efforts to spend from these categories. I did find intelligence to be the far superior category to build my character around though, as there are more skill checks that requires intelligence than there are from the other categories.As you level up you can also gain "edge" which gives you free efforts to spend in each skillcheck. So basically if you were to make an intelligence skill check and have 2 in edge for intelligence, you've already got 2 free efforts spent in each skill check  using intelligence. This is both a nice idea, allowing you to become noticeably better through the game, and almost gamebreaking, as you've got so much edge towards the late game that running out of efforts becomes a non-issue.Combat is the game's weakest point. It uses a turnbased system that feels like something out of a pen & paper RPG. The efforts/edge system is in use here as well, and it works well enough, but sadly none of the combat encounters feel very well designed, and the slow animation speed makes them drag on for longer than they should. You're also never given enough options for it to feel really tactical.Final thoughtsI'm a bit torn on Torment. On the one hand, the writing is great, the story is interesting, the setting hints at something amazing, I like the dialogue system and the effort system but on the other hand, the game feels too linear and towards the end rushed. The combat system also feels underdeveloped, though luckily you can easily avoid most combat. Despite numerous delays, the game still feels like it could have used some more time in development.Do I recommend Torment? Yes, I do, if you enjoy dialogue heavy CRPGs, but it's not a glowing recommendation. The game has some very strong point, but also some weaker points that holds it back from greatness. But if you've already played Planescape: Torment & Pillars of Eternity, and want to play another party-baed CRPG, Torment: Tides of Numenera is not a bad choice. Just don't expect it to be as good as Planescape: Torment.

content:
Posted: February 28
Product received for free
												So after about 32 hours with the game and its Review build (release build) I feel confident to say that i absolutely love this game... so lets dive into why.Video:


YouTube™ Video: Torment: Tides of numenera - Logic Review 

			Views: 4,304		

			gameplay starts at: 4:05 Torment: Tides of numenera is a clasic style CRPG from developer inExile coming out of early access into full release. Review copy supplied free of charge.		

Text:There is one caveat regarding Torment... If you do not enjoy reading, you will almost certainly not like this game, because there is a LOT, and i mean a LOT of reading. Dialogue, Interactions, Descriptions, Activities, inner monologue - everything primarily communicated through text, and then - maybe - through visuals.Which means that the primary point of critique is the story... so is it any good?yes. Yes. YES. The combination of excellent writing, very well fleshed out characters, a unique and mind-bending universe and an endless parade of cool interactions with people and and objects make the setup for the story great... and the story, side-quests and objectives you have are all also VERY Good.But not only due to good story: Your choices are important, your actions are critical and choices made before, affect a lot of things later in major ways. Sometimes in ways you wouldn't imagine, but even minor changes will make massive differences. There is a just a LOT of things that you do to shape your gameplay, and that provides a lot of replay value and a lot of general gameplay value. VERY good.Now, having set that stage: There are a few issues. The game is still not as bug-free as I would like and is missing polish in certain areas: primarily the UI. So its not a perfect game, and would benefit form a good Quality of Life pass by the developers. Just small animations issues, minor bugs and UI inconsistencies that break immersion for no particularity good reason. The Visuals are also a bit of a mixed blessing - While the art design, direction and composition are all amazing and the sound design (including the limited Voice over work) are very good... the character customization and visuals are very restricted and not that great and the level of animation, effects and interactive elements that are more than text... are also not that great. It's not a major issue to me personally, but your mileage may vary.Combat is the last part and here i have a few issues with the way the game does a few cool things, but ultimately - it feels very limited. The various stats, items, usables and so on are often available in combat to perform cool actions and your characters can have a wide range of abilities, but because of the massive story / dialogue focus, the game doesn't reward "working towards" combat focus - so you end up with a character that can talk down a demi-god, but still needs to use a cudgel to fight a literal sentient nightmare.  While the combat requires thinking about actions, much like the rest of the game, it doesn't have the same effect where possible consequences are exiting - merely the end result of smacking something in the head.Thankfully - combat is infrequent unless you actively seek it out, which makes it very good indeed. Talking your way out of a sticky spot is a viable strategy and that is very much applauded.Overall Torment is a fantastic CRPG, and i wholly recommend the title for anyone that enjoys RPGS. Unless you don't like reading, because... yeah... tons of that.

												Q: What can change the nature of a man?A: Not this game.20 hours in and this game is not keeping my interest. This game so far is feeling like a poorly done reboot.  The sound design is lackluster and later becomes grating and repetitive.  The music is forgettable.  I find myself not caring about the protagonist or any of the potential party members. number of helpful: 18 of 22 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13
												I can't reccomend this and I can't willingly motivate myself to keep playing this game. There is more than enough well written reviews of this game so I won't bother repeating a great deal of what has already been said about the short falls and issues. *Have since played another 3 hours on a friends account and its only reinforced my initial perspective...The main reason I'm dropping this game already, less than 5 hours of play in, is because it just doesn't hit the mark to stand with the legacy of Planescape Torment. The atmosphere and asthetic elements are just not right, too much flashy sci fi styles spilling into the gameworld of TTON (lasers, facial augmentation machines etc). The asthetics are just off; there are points in the city which will feel similar to the city of Sigil from Planescape Torment but there is too many other graphics and designs that just don't fit. The combat is horrible; slow, contrived and a constant feeling of playing through scripted battles (removing real rpg aspects we enjoy; grinding, leveling, stats, looting). The Tides/Skill interface is clanky and slow; bringing nothing really significant to the game that I felt validated a need for this system at all. From the start onwards the dialogue is just dull and fails to immerse me into this world. I found no vested interests in my characters plight or the party members who joined me, besides Rhin. The character creation system is interesting but felt like it makes next to no difference in general with how events and quests play out (and come on, no option to chose a potrait - stuck with some bland face that looks like it came from a 1970's Sci Fi novel cover). I think that by focussing on being a dialogue/text heavy game too much the developers have ultimately failed to incorporate typical RPG elements that made the original game so good - we've got this unbalanced result of a game that has turned into a very linear. almost point and click adventure game. Big dissapointment.There is moments, glimmers of good writing and creativity, where this game shows some potential I found in a few of the side quests. But these moments are over shadowed by the points I made above. Look forward to modders ripping this game apart and rebuilding it into something the Torment community wants. I feel for the backers who got screwed over here but hopefully update patches can fix some of these issues. Save your cash and buy the Enchanced Edition of Planescape Torment or check out many of the other recent RPG's like Tyranny, Pillars etc

number of helpful: 35 of 53 people (66%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8
												Objectively, this game is OK, at times even enjoyable. Not great, but I completed it, so it is engaging enough. Without the "help us to recreate a Planescape: Torment experience" I would give it a 70% rating and might have considered to get it in a steam sale. Yet, the story of this game is a different one, in every aspect a disappointing one.When I heard that a group of creators of the original P:T wanted to revive the spirit that so many modern cRPGs have lost, I was excited. Games with character, games that challenge players instead of just catering them, games that depart from the average and breathe life into unknown worlds, are being replaced by endless sequels without ambition or spirit. So here they are, promising to take a giant and build something on his shoulders, with enough funding for that shiny new Ferrari and free of the shackles of pleasing publishers and the market of "casual gamers." I hold the developers in high regard for their experience and achievements in the past, but in my opinion they have completely lost track here. If they really think that Tides of Numenera is fulfilling their own ambitions to live up to the sublime immersion and storytelling that is P:T, then they have lost much sense over the years. The game is neither ambitioned or bold, it is bland and tries to scrape by with the least effort required. It is not polished or rich in content; it feels more like an unwanted step child locked into the cellar than a love child.There are many thoughtful reviews out there that capture the good and bad to the game, I just want to add a few personal observations.- Numenera is a great choice for a Planescape setting replacement, it enables similar storytelling elements to P:T. I feel that it was worth the 35$ of backing just to discover this gem of pen and paper gaming. However the game mechanics adaptation is not good, once you reach three or four edge points there is no challenge in any task. I hardly used any of the 26(?!) intellect pool points for any of the tasks in the later game, and you can solve anything with intellect. The fighting mechanics are also unbalanced, and there is no room for developing combat tactics, you simply don't need them (health feels too low, though).- Seriously, where is the content?? I finished the game in 50 hours after reading every description and looking at every nook, but I was really expecting 200++ hours of gameplay. Only two major locations (which you cannot revisit)? About 10 fights in the whole game, 80% of which you can simply talk your way out of? Your "mind labyrinth" consists of four almost empty rooms connected by a bridge? 6 companions, half of them as dull as a rock? You can choose from exactly three character foci? You only have 3 item slots? Animations look horrible, only about 20 lines of text are narrated? The inventory implementation is buggy, I mean how hard can it be?  These are not design choices, it is simply laziness. Where did all the time go, where did all the money go? This game is 10~20% of P:T or BG2, and takes away the enjoyable parts without reason. Where other games have seven chapters, this feels like one and a half. When you are not inspired you should at least put some sweat in it.- There was supposed to be some personal stronghold that you can furnish and develop. I was hoping for a De'Arnise Keep on steroids, and got ... nothing. Is the mind labyrinth supposed to be it? That would be just pathetic. Just take the your pocket dimension from Throne of Baal and add more adventure to it, but no. - Fights. I can understand that people don't like random fights, and want to put some more meaning in them. However, I liked walking up to some random basher for XP and money in P:T, even when the combat mechanics were not great. I'm not even talking about the highly enjoyable fights in BG2. I did not expect this game to be Icewind Dale, but ... where is the combat? They are only a few completely scripted scenes you walk into with companions bumbling about, and with heavy-handed non-violent solutions that are always feel like the better choice. The turn-based system reduces the tactics to an absolute minimum, and most of the skills are useless or not required because of the unbalanced combat mechanics. I don't really care if the combat is turn-based or real-time, as long as it's enjoyable. Nothing was enjoyable here, so maybe the lack of fights is even a good thing.- Where is the promised impact to the world? I was looking for some effect of my choices, but the color of the tidal emblem seems to be the only thing that is changing. I was hoping for a system similar to KotoR, where you can alter the outlook of your companions, but this time with effects on the whole world. I did not feel anything to that effect.- The Meres are a great idea, but the execution is lackluster. The game hints that they can change the course of the story, even change other characters. However with a few exceptions there are no effects on the game world, and even then the effect are just dialogue options. I envisioned great replay value and interesting interactions between your choices, but got some inconsequential mini-stories that don't even yield XP. Still, whoever introduced this was up to something, way better potential than the similar narration element in Pillars of Eternity.In conclusion, I cannot help but notice that the game started out great, with lush background art and high ambitions, with the first Mere showing that your choices can matter, only to reveal a shack cobbled together behind the facade. It feels like all developers suddenly lost interest in extending their ideas beyond the beta contents or even completing the game. I would be very interested to learn why this breakdown happened, but it seems they want to focus on PR babble of a "spiritual successor" of P:T that fulfills all promises. Just admit that the money was still not enough to deliver what you envisioned, or that the creative spirit has left you. Looking at the stretch goals and seeing what you made of them just makes me sad. At least I am motivated again to replay the Icewind Dales, Baldurs Gates, and of course Planescape: Torment.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								The beta is a bit rough, but it's the first beta build so that's just going to happen.  That said, it was still very playable and enjoyable.  What really struck me about the game was the sense of otherness that the main city oozed out of each and every one of its pores.  Even after investigation I don't know what half of the ancient machines that scatter the city do, but they're all beautiful and intriguing.Remember those question based character creation segments in a lot of older RPGs?  Well this game found a way to take that concept and make it not suck.  Basically how you solve the games initial set of problems determines your class and early stats in a way that feels organic.  You're literally discovering yourelf.  Don't worry, though, if you don't like the results, you get a chance to change them to what you want to play before jumping into the game world proper.I don't have a solid review of the game's combat, because I didn't really fight anyone per se.  I wanted to see if you could solve everything without dealing a single HP of damage, and for everything I stumbled upon that was an option!The strongest point of the beta is probably the writing.  It was a delight!

content:
Posted: March 26
												I keep finding myself in disagreement with the "majority" of RPG fans, so maybe I'm not as much an RPG gamer as I thought to be.This game feels like that part of an RPG, for which the developers didn't get funding, but re-e-eally wanted to squeeze in. The obvious drawback here is that it doesn't contain any other compelling parts... The writers worked real hard trying to bind the storylines to one another and cross-reference everything with everything, but I feel that it cost them that much more effort for barely any benefits - looking back, I still would describe most of my time in the game as dull, even if I acknowledge the craftsmanship.The major "plot twists" were nothing but obvious, and the ending brings back memories of Mass Effect 3. I shiver at the thought of ever attempting a second playthrough, and from now on will be even more suspicious of any review hype-train that claims a game "earned its place in the old-school pantheon"...P.S. The sporadic and therefore tediously long combat sequences regularly froze on enemy movements; exchanging items between your companions lead to duplicates, cyphers placed in inventory slots, inability to sell items etc. As is tradition, the closer I got to the ending, the more bugs surfaced when attempting anything but the "most predictable path". So, I guess if you're sensitive to that sort of thing, I'd probably hold off on the purchase.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								As someone who has more than 300 hours into Pillars, I can say that I am not too excited for Tides. Pillars easily carries the most coheisve and dramatically presented narrative in a cRPG since Baldur's Gate 2, yet while Tides holds it's place in my library, I earnestly do not expect it to hold up as well. inXile games tend to carry a very unfinished and unpolished feel to them, which is often overlooked due to quality writing that propells the games from start to finish. Wasteland 2 is an excellent example of this: great story ... but incomplete "product" ... and the hours I've spent with the Early Access of Tides, I get the same impression. Recent changes have shown a clear trajectory towards simple delivery of a complex story, confirmed by developer responses on the forums to questions regarding removed features (such as a truncated introduction that has been stripped of any ingenuity and unique inspiration that it had during earlier versions). Many suspect this is due to it's concurrent console release, but I suspect there is more to it: as development has unfolded, I believe the inXile scrapped elements that weren't working, which has left visceral gaps in what remains.Still, inXile's writers are top notch and I will play this game through to the end, but I do not expect it to have much of the replayability that PlaneScape: Torment, Baldur's Gate/2, or Pillars of Eternity possess.

content:
Posted: April 2
												I actualy had to take a several weeks break from the game before writing this review. Also I fell like I need to be honest, that I did NOT finish the game. The reasons will be described.I cant do the usual +/- scheme review because this game is... different. So I'll just write my thoughts down.First of all, I am a huge fan of PS:T and BG games. I also played all other games from Bioware but they didnt left such a deep mark like the first two.When they announced the successor (I know ''spiritual''...) to my all time favourite PS:T I was rejoiced. I remember spending my teenage years, not playing, but living the Nameless One's story in front of my computer screen. The feelings and emotions of despair and decay the game could invoke vere first and only I ever felt from a computer game. The writing was amazing, the design was perfect, the atmosphere cant be described, you, who played it know what I am talking about here.But I was sceptical. I knew that PS:T 2 is impossible to make, so I waited with backing and preorders until the very release. I gave it a try... and liked it. No in the hindsight, I regret buying it.- First of all as non native english speaker I had trouble with the VAST ammount of extremely long text that has NO purpose other than being long and to fill up the blank and boring gameplay. I dare to say that my english is on a good level, but I had trouble focusing and remembering all those vast lines of non-important text that was thrown at me at every step.Stick with me here, I am not by any chance some barbarian who doesnt like to read and just want to hack-and-slash through the game. I am a huge fan of all fluff and trivia in games and always read them. But this is just TOO MUCH. Also you may notice varying quality of texts, like if multiple authors were put together on one book- The atmosphere and setting is something I hated from the first minutes ingame. I couldnt get into the world and feel like a part of it even though I very much tried to. It is all just so flashy, shiny, colorful and bright compared to PS:T. Everyone in the world seem to be desperate and tortured to some degree, yet the world doesnt feel tortured and grim. It is all like a huge carnival, only the clowns were missing. - In comparison to games like Baldurs Gate 2 and PS:T the NPCs are absolutely boring, flat and if they dissapeared I wouldnt notice. You dont make any connection to them and few days after finishing the game you dont even remember their names. Jaheira, Morte, Dakkon, Minsc. Those childhood companions of mine, I'll never forget. I didnt play this game for several weeks and I recall only boring albino, some dark haired pirate and glowing imbecil. This review is VERY personal that is why I dont talk about gameplay mechanics at all. They were mentioned by others.

Early Access Review
								Torment is a worthy successor to Planescape. A new universe to play around with keeps things fresh while some familiar RPG mechanics stay similar to other games, and the lore is expansive to say the least. With the option to complete pretty much any crisis (the battle scenes) peacefully given the right skills and lucky rolls, pacifist runs are possible. Using the environment to your benefit in these crises is very satisfying when it works, too. Be aware that as an early access game there are quite a few bugs, some that can break things to the extent that a reload is required, so save frequently!I can't wait to play the full game!Gameplay:

content:
Posted: January 18
Early Access Review
First some background:"Planescape: Torment" has been my favorite CRPG of all time since I first played it at its release in 1999. It figuratively and literally turned the genre on its head. All the basic assumptions people take away from most CRPGs had been practically inverted wholesale. I was a fan of the source tabletop setting released in 1994, long before the game hit the shelves, so I had looked at the video game with a very critical eye, and found every moment of its game play engaging, and its story, theme and characters utterly unique.I was hesitant, and ultimately decided against supporting the kickstarter, mostly as I realize now due to my lack of understanding of the Numenera setting. Unlike Planescape, which had the underpinnings of D&D to start with, I was never able to wrap my head around how the Numenera setting worked. It just never clicked for me.Initial Impressions:I knew I’d pick this up when it released, even if it was just a chance of catching some of that old Planescape:Torment nostalgia.I also admit, I only have 3.0 hours, yes three, into this as I'm writing it. (I may update this review after I have more time with the actual release version).However, I've played the first 10-20 minutes of the game probably 6 times, each with completely different outcomes: In some I died prior to even getting into a fight In others I was able to talk down my foes I used environment objects to help me overcome my enemies  I’ve pretended to be someone I’m not In others I was painfully truthful to my own detriment.From what I've seen, which I completely admit is a small sliver of the whole, this not only matches my expectations of what a spiritual successor to P:T would be, it exceeds them.  The settings are equally fantastic in the truest sense of the word. The characters I’ve seen so far, are almost as good as the initial characters you meet in P:T. If the rest of this game matches the first 15 minutes, this will easily slide up to match Planescape:Torment as my favorite cRPG.Where Planescape: Torment asked: “What can change the nature of a man?” Torment: Tides of Numenera asks: “What does one life matter?”And as in P:T, I believe looking forward this just may help you answer that question in the same way,through game play, story, and character development.

number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31
												I'm so so torn.  I spent about 44 hours playing this game through to completion.   There were parts I really enjoyed...like wandering around Sagus Cliffs, the first main city of the game.   Exploring, talking (great writing BTW), etc.    But there was much more that I felt was rushed, not fully fleshed out, etc.  It's clear they spent a lot of time coming up with a weird, quirky story with lots of characters to talk to.  But the game just wasn't "fun".  What I enjoy about a CRPG is a great story, plus great exploration, plus a little strategy in a tough combat.  There's no point in leveling up if things aren't progressively difficult, require some strategy, planning, luck, etc.  Things were NEVER difficult or tense.  The while "spend as many points as you want on a check, and just refill by sleeping" was only annoying at the beginning before you found a place to sleep.  Leveling up is really kind of pointless...all you 'really' need is more points in your talent pool of choice.  I so so wanted this game to be great, and from a weird story perspective, it IS great....like a good pick a path book.  But everything else about it is lacking from leveling, to exploration to combat, to acquiring gear, etc. all felt like RPG lite lite.  I remember people complaining that the strategy and leveling of the Shadowrun Kickstarters as being a little "RPG lite"....this is too.  Before anybody says "well if you just want combat, this game isn't for you", remember, I don't "just want combat".  I want good combat, challenges, leveling, story, companions, etc.......like you got in the original Torment, Baldur's gate, etc.   This got the story and companions right but missed on everything else.  This would have made a great book.   For those reasons, I can't recommend this game like I would PoE, Wasteland 2, Divinity Original Sin, etc.

content:
Posted: March 8
												The zone "The Bloom" is well-designed with some very good content. This was the only place in the game where I got Torment vibes, and even Mask of the Betrayer vibes. Very well done by George Ziets, who I think saved this game from being utter garbage.But I cannot recommend the game for one zone alone, even if it makes up a good chunk of the game.Nothing outside of The Bloom grabbed me. I didn't like any of the companions I met and I didn't even really care for the fate of my own character. InXile did not manage to make Numenera as personal and intimate as Planescape: Torment.Add to that a slew of bugs, loads of slow loading screens, and weird performance issues (I run the game off an SSD on a high-end rig with a GTX 1080, good OC CPU and plenty of memory).I expected a lot more from a game that has been in development for 4 years, both content-wise and technology-wise.I have no idea why the gaming press loves it so. They are an enigma worthy of a Torment game.

Posted: March 3
												Backed this game, waited 4 years for it and now I'm uninstalling. Might come back to it later but for now I've lost patience with it. A few things that have annoyed me so far: - atrocious character running animation. People say the switch to turn based combat was due to catering for consoles but I strongly believe it was due to their technical incompetence. If they can't even get a running animation to look realistic and not detract from the immersion, I don't even want to think how real time combat would look. This is something that seems to plague Unity games for some reason.- trailer that spoils the game. I already knew much of the story from watching the movie that plays automatically when you land on the store page. "Oh yeah the publisher paid for this and added it in" - don't care, you're spoiling your own game! Speaking of - why the hell do you even have a publisher after we gave you 4 million dollars? - had to turn up the colour vibrancy for my monitor - only got to Sagus Cliffs but it's SO BLAND. Completely washed out colour scheme. Too dull.- lack of combat - I ended up hoping I'd run into some bandits in the city, something to fight, anything. Even though I knew from the encounter before that combat is just bad and not satysfying at all. Just something to punctuate the long reading sessions, as the writing is awesome but overwhelming.Needs some action and a bit of that character progression feeling - I did level up but I didn't get that feeling. Overall feels a bit unrelatable and I bet most of it comes from the limited combat. Feels more like Myst than a cRPG.So right now I'm reinstalling Pillars of Eternity. Just realised I never finished it, I had 210 hours on it but I lost the saves.

content:
Posted: March 4
												SUMMARYGreat premise, awful execution. Do not buy.There are way too many things wrong with the game at this stage. I don't understand how inXile spent $4M+ and several years at this, yet managed to produce something that feels so incredibly rushed, and has one of the worst implementation of the first ~2 hours of gameplay of all RPGs I've played.If you're looking for a good CRPG buy Tyranny instead.FIRST IMPRESSIONSStart a new game, there's some voice acted intro text, and then all you see is greyscale hexes and black. You look at it for a moment and wonder if the game broke, until you realize there's a pretty gray character lying on the hexes too and that you can move. The game describes this pure black thing next to you - that on your screen looks like a deep hole with no detail at all distinguishable - as a bowl of sorts. The game describes how you can see the details of the bowl as a light source moves around. None of this you can see on your screen, just see a static black thing that sorta has a shape that could be a bowl, but it has no depth to it at all, just pure black. 5 minutes in the game looks rather dull and really unimpressive.You run around a bit in this very linear bit going through dialog trees where you're supposed to make "choices". The dialog is phrased as if you knew what you were supposed to be doing, and then you're given several options to choose from. Many of these options refer to game mechanics there is no way for you to understand at this point, and you just get frustrated and think the game could just as well throw dice as there is no way for you to even make an educated guess as to what happens from the options or how you're supposed to choose.Then it turns out these "choises" you made was the character creation, and the game just keeps dumping more and more references to game mechanics without providing any explanation to them. One option gives you "+15% willpower", but you have literally no way to figure out what "willpower" does. You have options to be, among other things, "Clever" or "Intelligent", each comes with bonuses suitable for a character of the type I wanted to build, but additionally really unintuitive negative points. It also feels like the game is misleading or lying to you about some effects, as I think I've heard it mention effects that then don't get shown in the details once you try to look at them. Tell me, do you want to be Clever, or Strong-willed? I have no idea, as there's no way to know what these mean in-game when you make the decisions.At worst the game throws ~5 consecutive tutorial "Did you know" -dialogs at you so you already forgot what the first one said before you even get to the last one or get to use any of this information.GAMEPLAY ISSUESThere's an ability to read people's thoughts or something. You get some rare insight into what people think mid-dialog, but after getting about 20 such insights the game gave me exactly 0 options to use the info.Lots of dialog and flavor text is shown mid-game in popup texts that pop up and vanish without any interaction from you. Unlike in other similar games there's no combat log or anything where you could go back to check what that text said. You can use a pause key, sometimes, but never when you'd really need it as during scripted sequences the pause key does nothing. Why would you implement a "pause" key that doesn't pause the game?All initial items for you and the first few party members are "only usable by X".Dialog options seem to arbitrarily vanish after activating them once, there doesn't seem to be any logic as to which options just change to "tell me that thing again" -type things, and which ones just vanish.It's possible to accidentally pick up items that give you a penalty if you have too many of them. You cannot drop them, you can only sell them, or swap them in the party, or use them, if you can. If you can't use them, don't have any empty slots in your party, and nobody to sell them to, you get a penalty and there's apparently no way around it except loading the game before you picked it up.The game incorrectly refers to the ground as "Earth", when they are clearly not on our planet.After the couple of hours the game has mentioned cyphers, tides, esoteries, etc. which I still don't understand the slightest bit.Party members seem to follow you with an annoying delay instead of in formations. This probably leads to unfortunate combat setups.UI/UX ISSUESCamera feels somehow wrong by default, it feels a little less annoying when disabling the autofollow.A blue dot is a bonus, two blue dots is more bonus, two red dots is a penalty. These are shown with some unclear text explanations, much before the game explains what these really mean.Applying attribute points is done in a screen where you have two arrows on the left and right of a number for the attribute, clicking the arrows changes the value, which changes the amount of space the number takes and moves the buttons from right under your mouse cursor, when you're trying to click them. Similar issues are all over.I'm playing on full HD resolution, with "full" anti-aliasing, yet there is not a single edge that doesn't look jagged. The inventory management screen has rough edges everywhere on the UI, your character is rendered with clear rough edges, as are all the items, and much of the text.There are some really random obviously wrongly positioned effects sometimes hovered *almost* on top of your character portrait that don't seem to make any sense and then just go away when there's a scene transition.In the inventory screen there are two places where your weapon is shown, right-clicking on one shows "details", right-clicking on the other does nothing. Why? Who knows. I sure don't.Right-clicking on things sometimes opens this "detailed" view, which describes stats and shows flavor text on items. However, this is quite unclearly structured and it still often fails to tell you what is going on, and doesn't clearly indicate with graphical design e.g. what part is flavor text. You can't further hover over/click on unclear concepts to find out more about them.Dialog trees look very boring compared to e.g. Tyranny. The colors are dull, there's nothing to hover over, there seems to be no extra information other than just the text for you to say and what the other people respond with.FINAL NOTESI was super excited to try the game out finally after all this time, and now I'm really heavily disappointed. I helped kickstart this years ago, I spent $135 (+S&H) thinking I'd help inXile create something amazing. In the first ~2 hours of gameplay I hated almost every moment, though I saw that under the incredibly rough surface there is probably something worth looking at. However, as the game simply pisses me off constantly, I don't want to play any more of it until inXile fixes at least some of these issues.Did inXile do exactly 0 internal testing before releasing this? Did nobody complain about these issues? How, after multiple years of development, can the first moments of the game be so incredibly weak?After playing games like Pillars of Eternity and Tyranny, this game feels like garbage in way too many areas. The devs should play Tyranny, and then play their game from scratch, and then fix all the things they find were clearly better in Tyranny.Most of these issues should not be big things to fix, add information here and there, a few tooltips, fix a few UI decisions (fixed width vs. variable width, etc.), and so on, if inXile had any interest in it. However, with what I heard about some big quest-line issues with Wasteland 2 (which I also kickstarted) never being fixed, I doubt inXile has huge interest in fixing these issues.Unless inXile fixes these issues and they're sorry for messing up, I don't think I'll ever be able to support their kickstarters again, or buy their games for over $10.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								You're sitting in a room, alone.  Before you hover images, passing in rapid sequence, but conveying a comforting sense of the entirety of a whole.  You sift through their details - an odd protuberance in an unexpected place, a comforting voice passing through the air behind you - and ponder.  While you draw no closer to these images physically, your mind and will are progressively and inexorably more deeply involved in the events you observe, these same events you even direct, to some extent.  You notice that, in reflections of reflections, you weigh heavy questions.  They pass through lesser used corridors in your mind, and prompt at once both introspection and alarm.  You realize then that you just spent the greater part of an afternoon, and the equivalent of the price of a quality meal for two, on a simulacrum, still in its fledgling state, of worlds only known to a glimmering few, and you yearn to know - to feel - more.If you've read this far, congratulations.  You'll see more like this, lots more, as you wade, wander, and weigh your options through this newest world of Torment.After starting over twice, and a good, what, 30 hours at this point?  I finally found an in-canon expositor who at least helped me, the human playing this game, understand that numenera is a plural noun indicating objects, not a singular proper noun indicating a place.  I know what two of the five tides regard, and my latest protagonist is happily balanced among all of them.[Edit] So, I am apparently a ponderously slow exploratory player, and I'm okay with that.  I do believe the reason the series is named Torment is because it's (almost) impossible to die.  That seems fitting, for someone who took almost 50 hours to get through the beta.  Pro tip: don't leave town.Having resolved 16-odd quests, and with 2 remaining, now I'm seriously jonesing to get on with the rest of this.  I can only guess that, as a secret-finder and prose-reader (I really LIKE the Meres!), I'll probably lose ~200 hours of my life in this game.  I can't wait for the hideous stench of the Bloom to fill my nostrils... ugh, wait, maybe I can? [/edit]Highly recommended for your Bartle's exploratory types!  Feel free to look elsewhere for bullet-time, spraying gibs, skimpy outfits, collisions, porridge, wanton violence or wontons.  You're on earth, a billion years in the future, and you've got all the time in the world to read through tomes of narrative, linking slender chains in your mind, piecing together yourself, and all the whys of all the voids, within and without.Grand. Fictional. Terrifying. Alluring. Fun. Interesting. Human.

												Just what Blackadar said. I'm a hardcore RPG player since 1996 and I have been waiting for this game with a great enthusiasm. Also I didn't like the numenera universe, but I guess this is just my personal preference.I'm a real fan of Brian Fargo, I really like the way he does things and I will continue supporting him, but I sure hope that the next games he does, would be more like Planescape:Torment instead of Torment:Tides of Numenera, more like Fallout 2, than Wasteland 2.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								In advance I will say that this game is still in beta and requires some polishing, but it promises incredible potential to pull you into its world.Torment: Tides of Numenera is intended to be the spiritual successor to Planescape: Torment, which has been said to be one of the best RPGs created and I am inclined to agree. The settings, writing and characters were all rich in detail.I am happy to say that, so far, TToN is shaping up to also be a masterpiece to be remembered.At first the settings will seem alien to you and you'll feel slightly confused, but gradually everything will make sense if you open your mind to concepts that would otherwise seem impossible to comprehend under normal circumstances.You'll end up wanting to explore every corner of every area, finding secrets, speaking to the locals or simply examining strange, otherwordly technology in the hopes to gain some sort of advantage through them.Many of the quests will not give you a sense of what is the right and what is the wrong decision, leaving it up to you to decide what the best course of action is based entirely on your personal interpretation and opinion and even then you might be wondering "was that truly the best choice there was?"An example containing spoilers: At some stage you will find a creature in a bar, lamenting the fact that he lost contact to the rest of his civilization, whose purpose it was to guide others. The most obvious choice would be to use your powers to rid his mind of the sadness enveloping his thoughts. After you do so his sadness turns into cold determination as he sets out, not to guide people, but to dictate over their lives with an iron fist. (Or that is how I interpreted the turn of events. Correct me if I'm wrong.)Would I recommend the game as it is now? Yes, if you can accept the fact that it is not finished, but you want a glimpse of what is to come. Otherwise just wait until its full release.

content:
Posted: March 6
												My issue with this game is as follows:1. Combat. Seriously, forget the turn based part of it, where the heck is it?  XP through kills = pretty much non existant. I can't say how the whole game is, but I'm pretty far into it, I've been in 4? 5? fights, and only 1 gave me any symblance of XP (You might say, well that's good cause it means you don't have to choose combat as an option! But I ---wanted--- to fight. I designed a glaive character, went out of my way to go into battle, and did everything I could to annoy people. Heck I ran into three thugs that were all "Hand over the girl or else!" I picked or else, and it just throws me a dialogue "You did 20 damage fight ende dinstantly." Like what?! WHERE IS MY BATTLE?! What happened to the axe wielding scar covered madman slaughtering innocents in the street that I played as on PST?)2. The illusion of choice, isn't as well casted as the previous PST (in the previous one I did playthroughs with 2 or 3 fights, and playthroughs with everyone in every town dead that you could kill. Lots of variety!). Each decision I make seems rather "flat" ? In a good choice RPG, decisions will keep piling up on top of each other, each quest you complete, each choice you make in dialogue, it all stacks up. This one? Not so much. There were a few quests that required some chaining behaviors, but mostly their "choice" system was just the occassional 'oh you could have gotten +1 str if you played it this way. Too bad, suckah!' Combined with the fact you don't really get a lot of fights, this can feel a lot like reading a book and having to roll dice every now and then to see if you're getting all the pages or an angry troll is going to rip a few out before you can read them and much less like you're shaping the RPG with your choices.3.  The plot is slow and drags into errand boy in several sections, and the characters were interesting, but I didn't get to feel I connected to any of them. I wanted more out of my Main Char Side Char relationships, I wanted to feel like my scruffy gang of 3 was really impacted by my existence. I didn't get that at all. Things that I really enjoyed about the game: 1. It wasn't a good hit for me, but I did like the skill point system stretch they did with effort. It was interesting and forced me to think about a lot of decisions I normally wouldn't have had to .2. The artwork was, as it was in the previous game, really good. The landscapes were constantly changing so much so that even in the same town I could feel the differences between area one and area two.3. The character backgrounds were interesting, which made point 3 of the cons that much more frustrating. Now these are all just personal opinions, and I would only not recommend the game because there are a lot better RPGs out there that do what T: ToN tried to do in terms of execution, but better, and they're cheaper. If you've played every RPG on the market though, consider my thumbs down a thumbs up.

content:
Posted: April 7
												Torment is the long awaited "brother" to the original Torment that so many fans adore, yet it fails to deliver what most fans expected, which is a long and solid game with an captivating story and a world to experience and explore.It is graphically ok ( It uses the unity game engine ), the player get's rather little options to customize his own character besides genre and 3 different classes , and a lot of the promised content from the early kickstarter campaign is absent in the early version of the game which allready shows when you create your character.There's a lot of dialogue, but your own character is more on the listening side of the story and it seems your background and player type does little to change this ( which other older Interplay games did like Baldurs Gate , Fallout , Icewind dale and so on ) so the story is pretty straight forward and honestly seems to give little in the terms of replayability ( perhaps a couple of times at most).Combat is ludicrious bad and almost absent in the aspects of strategy, once you find a tactic that works you will probably use that for the rest of the game. You do get certain "items" that helps you in combat, but most of the game is so easy you can have a large surpluss of these items without ever the need to use them.The game did seem to have in the start certain "consecuences" of resting if you had a few quests active, as some of them had time limits ( to my knowledge only one ) , but strangely enough that part seems to dissapear completely from the game later on it seems. Again poor quest planning is probably behind that part of the game.Other aspects of the game is that the story is decently written, but again nothing really special that will make you think about the game again when you hit the bed after having completed it. There's really none of those cuestion other great games gave you like "what if I had" and then go back and try that other option to see what would happen to the world...Music and sounds where not bad, but to be honest I felt they could have been better , some areas certainly dont give you the feeling that the sound comes from there...And the game is ludicrious short... My first playthrough (and I tend to try to get every little quest and content ) was around 41 hours and honestly speaking it felt like there's rather few "maps" and things to explore. The dialogue makes up for most of those hours and youre going to spend a lot of time reading.It's not an outright bad game, but in terms of what it could have been since it's the spiritual successor to Planescape Torment it should have been so much more...After having crowd funded Inxile a couple of times I have lost faith in them and are going to wait for their games to be released before bothering considering buying them ( like the upcoming bards tale )...

content:
Posted: March 5
												This is a tough one. tl;dr I *would* recommend the game, but it comes with a few caveats in particular: don't buy it at the present price. they're having a laugh.The details.The bad1. As a backer I was *really* disappointed with the difference between what was proposed in the kickstarter campaign and what actually ended up in the final product. I tried to keep an open mind when playing but it still did leave a sour taste.2. The companions are mostly... kinda uninspired. In PS:T you could choose 5 companions out of 7 and I always stuggled deciding who not to take in my party. Here you could choose 3 out of 6, so you think it would be harder, but I had no such trouble - especially since you can't have Aligern and Callistege in a party together so that rules out a bunch of party combinations.3. The character models are kinda... bad. In particular I often found the Last Castoff's running annimation pretty goofy looking.4. A lot of the character options seemed pretty cosmetic (backed up by some videos I've watched). Tides, foci, descriptors... just don't seem to have very much impact on how the game actually plays out.5. The UI felt incomplete to the point where I tried to avoid using it.6. It's simply not as good as PS:T although it's not a bad effort.7. It felt like there was a real lack of item progression in the game, and the effects that the various damage types did were never very clear to me. I think I changed my gear like... twice.8. The price, IMO it's well not worth what they are currently asking for it ($74.95NZD at the time of writing).The good----------1. The Mark Morgan music is on point again. Like that guy is fantastic. 2. The world is well imagined, I loved following through asking about everything and seeing the backstory piece together during the game.3. The companion Rhin is great, whoever wrote her (kidding I know it was Patrick Rothfuss) is a champion.4. The level backgrounds were bautiful.5. Did I say I really liked the Numenera setting? I hope they or other groups write games set using the system in the future.Now I know there's more bad than good but I honestly felt the good passed the bad in terms of my overall enjoyment of the game. However if you haven't played Wasteland II or Pillars of Eternity definitely go and play those first because they are both better games. If they haven't satisfied your itch then I would definitely say give Tides of Numenera a go after those, and the price coming down a tad.

												Ok. I've finally finished this game.What can i say about it? It's bad in almost everything. 1. Combat system is trash. Don't even dare to take any class except nano focused on conversations + invest all edges into intellect pool because it is used in most cases. Strengths pool is just a joke really. You'll never use it in combat.2. Character progression is quite new but it appears to be very stupid.3. Cyphers - well... you don't need them in 99% of cases. Remaining 1% is experiments and permament bonuses4. Abilities - most of battle-related are useless. As nano I used only 3 attacking abilities 1 of which had friendlyfire and was quite useless in most cases. Social are better. Pick mind reading one - it will help you skip most of texts and also there ate quite funny thought appear sometimes.5. Story is quite interesting but there are too many extra texts. You'll be bored after the 1st location. Well, I was trying to read them all at first but then I just skipped everuthing not related to main quest. It looks like most texts were written by people called "copywriters". They are experts to write empty texts around some simple plot so that search engines treat web site better. I was able to half-blindly end the game with the best ending for the worlds (IMHO). It looks like your choices does not affect the ending the way they should.6. Companions are quite different but most of them are empty. I liked only Rhin. Callestige is amost good too. Also she is quite useful in dialogs and fights7. Locations are mostly small. I'd say very small. Remember baldur's gates, neverwitnter nights, icewind dale - all had great variety of beautiful locations. And now forget about it. Not in this game. Funny thing: Necropolis has lots of chambes with some names on plates. As i saw most plates had different appearence. It seems that it took too much time to make that chambers and other locations were sacrificed...8. World is something that you'd like to know about but every important thing wrapped in tons of text. Well, I've surrendered and just rushed to the ending.If you're looking for a good RPG with good story - pass this one. It's short and mostly empty.If you're looking for a good RPG with interesting tactical fights - run away or you'll want to kill developersIf ou like to read tons of texts and not afraid of half-emptiness in text - you're welcome! Remember to pick Nano and increate intellect pool and edge. You'll have the story almost without fights.

												I'll keep this short.I'm a Kickstarter backer.  After we gave inXile $4million (more than 4x the original goal) and waiting 4 years (more than 2x the original proposal), we're left with something that's barely recognizable from what was initially promised.  Worse, we had to wait longer than Steam beta players to play the product we made possible.  Worse STILL, we got to watch inXile♥♥♥♥♥♥around and spend our money on their other projects for years on end, and then finally tell us they had to turn to Steam beta to finish funding their project.  The one that was funded for $4mil.As for the game itself, I'm utterly underwhelmed.  Graphics are bland, effects are unimpressive, writing is okay-ish but could've really used a decent editor to tighten things down (more is not always better), and story didn't really hook me.  Bizarrely, there's no way to customize character appearance beyond gender.  I realize they were going for a retro experience, but this is 2017.  In fact, all in all, there's very little that makes this game feel superior to anything released in 2007.  I wish I hadn't bought it.
