content:
Posted: March 6
TL;DR Tides of Numenera is a good game; it only seems bad when you put Torment: in front of the title.So - another game from the anointed messiahs of old-school CRPG development, and this one is supposedly the 'spiritual sequel' to the hallowed Planescape: Torment, no less!On its own merits, Numenera is good game. I backed it on Kickstarter at the lowest level (which was about £10-£15 if I remember right), and for that price I got great value for money and lots of enjoyment. I think I would wait for a sale rather than pay the release price though.The world is a weird and wonderful one, with lots of nooks and crannies to investigate, colourful characters to meet, and bizarre hightech powers and weapons to wield. Most of the inhabitants of the city of Sagus (where most of the game takes place) are ignorant of the technology behind all this, so all the fancypants electro-swords and brain-cooking zapper pistols are often seen as magic. The result is a pleasing steampunk scifi sort of vibe.Combat is unfortunately a rather dull, clunky, turn-based affair - but thankfully as I broke from my usual habit of playing a tanky sword and shield guy and went for a silver-tongued brainiac nano (the game's wizardish class) I often found that fights could be ended early (or more often avoided completely) thanks to my gifts of the gab. This also made my psychic powers stronger so the occasional fight I did get into wasn't too hard with some help.Companions are an amusing and varied mix of archetypes, if a bit shallow,(apart from my little buddy Rhin :) ) with good flavour voice acting on a small amount of their and other NPCs' conversations, which add a little richness to what is otherwise large amounts of silent text. Lots of reading to do in this game which I enjoyed - descriptions and speech are well-written but brief enough so as not to interfere with moving things along. Graphics are decent enough and quite pretty in places, although characters' faces do tend to look a bit like clothes mannequins.Overall the story and setting were engrossing enough to have me playing enthusiastically until the credits rolled. BUT WAIT - This game isn't being judged entirely on its own merits. Instead of just being called Tides of Numenera, this game is called Torment: Tides of Numenera. And that's the main reason lots of nostalgic people like me funded this game (and a real can of worms).What struck me most about the original was the main character - the Nameless One. Gravel voice, scars and tattoos, ghoulish looks. He begins as a fairly cliched amnesiac , but as the story develops we find that he has lived many lives - soldier, scholar, mystic and many more. He has been a terrible villain, but later a hero. Worshipped and feared, hated and loved - he has commited terrible atrocities, manipulated and sacrificed loved ones and friends, but he has done great deeds of heroism, kindness, and selflessness. I get that in Numenera the Last Castoff is intentionally a blank slate so that the choices players make shapes his character, but what was so clever about Planescape was that the Nameless one could be a fully rounded prewritten character by the end of the game, whilst still being shaped by the player's choices. And these choices still made sense within the larger context of the Nameless' character because they are drawn from aspects of all the various forgotten experiences he has had, as well as what the player has done. He could finally be redeemed, or be a villain far worse than the final boss, all because of the choices of the player. The Castoff on the other hand, is a non-character. Voice acting has a generic hero sound, and he has no experiences because he was literally someone else just before the game begins.The supporting cast of NPCs in Planescape was likewise so much more memorable than Numenera. Morte, Annah, Fall-from-Grace, Dak'kon, Ignus. That weird cube-man who had Homer Simpson's voice. The Lady of Pain, Deionarra, the Night Hag, the Silent King. That hive-mind of super-intelligent rats! I haven't played that game in years and I can still remember them all. I think the only character I will remember in any detail from Numenera is Rhin. Plus perhaps the Changing God only for his name, and the BigBad Sorrow mostly because of a huge expositional dump of information at the end of the game.Planescape had a grimy, grim, at times nightmarish atmosphere. Numenera approaches this later in the game (the Bloom is the best area by far), but never manages to reach those heights before or after."What can change the nature of a man?" - the thought-provoking question and motif that appears throughout the game and is relevant to so many of its facets, and to its main character in so many ways. There is no simple answer to it.Numenera's limp counterpart is "What does one life matter?" - the answer being "it matters loads, because you are the Chosen One who must defeat the Big Bad."Tides of Numenera is a good game; it only seems bad when you put Torment: in front of the title.

Early Access Review
								Put around 10 hours into the beta, it was seriously out of pure boredom because I would usually never go near games like these unless they were well and truly finished. I'm thinking, hey, they plan for a Q1 2017 release, how unfinished can it be? Very unfinished is the answer. No way in hell they're releasing in the first quarter of 2017.. but if they do, it's going to be quite the mess. 1. Interface is clunky, with text being cut off, even through character creation, you're picking abilites you don't know anything about because if you hover the ability the text shows up cut off! Infuriating. If you exit an area and hover over the exit, nothing happens, you have to view the map to see where you're actually going. Not to mention that your entire party freezes once you click on the exit, unless one of your dudes is stuck behind a bystander way back there somewhere..and then you're treated to an epic loading time, yes even on an ssd setup. 2. The first group fight in the game, had to savescum 4 times before I could pass it without a fight. Why? Because the fight always ended with either A. The enemy had the turn but didn't do anything. B. I had the turn but couldn't attack.3. The entire thing runs like poop. I turned off AA, magical clothing and it still ran like poop. This is not pretty enough to run terribly on my system. I blame Unity. 4. While I completed their inspirational game PS:T several times and yes, it did not have a strong focus on combat, it feels like this game has contempt for combat. It's all sluggish, uninspired and boring. In my 10 hours I had 3-4 real fights and they were all terrible(when they worked) Abilities feel meaningless, just point click and bash to get it over with. 5. Six times I had to exit the game and restart it because my group refused to move when entering a new area. Save, exit, reload and they moved again. I haven't even mentioned all the text bugs or the graphical bugs such as equipping a shield and your dude is wearing it through his stomach..To me this is an Alpha version of the game, isn't beta supposed to be working but with minor bugs? Would I suggest buying it? Yes, if you got in on the early backer discount and have a lot of patience.. otherwise no.

Posted: March 14
												I backed this a million years ago because I like cRPGs, and I particularly like TALKY cRPGs. In that sense, this is a well realized game, with a fairly good story and a system that seems geared towards providing non-combat solutions to most encounters. I've dumped all of my leveling up into being a good talker/thinker, and dug some of the non stabbing related solutions that afforded.That being said, holy hell this game is a buggy mess. If you ARE unfortunate enough to get into combat, there seems to be about a 1 in 5 chance every combat round for the game to hard lock, I've come out of combat encounters with my party completely frozen in place, and there is an incredibly annoying humming sound anytime you have a buff (which you will have permanently after a couple of hours of playing the game. that last isn't a bug per se, but I feel it speaks to a lack of outside eyes (ears?) on this product.What's here is pretty good, but I'd recommend you give these guys a couple months to finish their game up, and play it when it's more stable.

number of helpful: 17 of 23 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13
												I like this a lot more than public opinion seems to hold! It's probably overpriced, the combat is mostly terrible, and as an RPG it's not really as complete or as generous as Original Sin and will probably be handily outdone by Original Sin 2.BUT! I think this has been really underrated as a spiritual successor to Planescape Torment. The original game's visuals and combat (of which there is way too much, compared to this) have not aged well at all, and its writing, however beloved, is very "90s D&D."By comparison, the writing in this is very enjoyable in a broader SF context -- the biggest complaint I could leverage is that they occasionally run out of ways to describe Dune-like interactions with otherworldly devices -- and there's less conspicuous philosophizing, which is more to my tastes. The worldbuilding in general is very nice; the graphics are only good enough, but the visual design of every area is distinct and memorable (lots of great blues and purples), and it's really to the benefit of the game's narrative thrust. The scope is relatively narrow and linear, and the side quests are basically typical CRPG fare in that you can play for completion and try to get the best outcome from everyone, but the game stays interesting from start to finish and there's a lot of creativity from one minute to the next. Individual NPC's are regularly more interesting and three-dimensional than major characters in the average BioWare game. It's also pretty bug-free and polished on the whole, although the balancing is pretty weak by the end.Torment 2017 is also pretty affectionate towards the source material of Torment  1999 and manages to be thus without seeming derivative -- the bar in the first main hub town, the references to the "endless battle," and so on are all distinctly P:T-esque.Definitely play any of the newer Divinity games first, but this is great and unique and deserves better than the response it's gotten.

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22
Negatives: Very bad endings, your "legacy" is literally two sentences on a slide in the epilogue.  To achieve what you want you almost always have to use trial-and-error via reloading saves. This of course breaks any (small) immersion the game may have and is frustrating.  Does not feel like a complete game, it's clear that the developers did not have time to finish several of the main characters and story concepts.  There is a ridiculously large amount of text, but it's often not very interesting and some of it frankly does not make much sense (from a logical or philosophical perspective).  Furthermore, even with 1.2 million lines of text, several of the major story points/twists are pretty clear already in the first city you explore.  Almost all the story is told through text, it would be better if more was shown through the environment, interactions, animations, or even cut scenes. Instead, the game basically tells you what is going on instead of showing it or letting you play it out.  The "Crisis" mechanic does not work very well in that it's not exciting, does not feel like a crisis, can be failed based on unknowable factors (requiring more trial and error, save-scumming).Positives:Some of the areas, items, and characters give us an interesting look into this odd and unusual fantasy, sci-fi world. Some minor characters and item interactions are funny and surprising.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Beta review 26.1.2016Why all the hype? In short Torment is isometric cRPG. The game aims more for reactivity, choices, replayability and story telling than other RPGs. This game is successor to Planescape Torment which was released 1999. According to wikipedia, PST has been pretty frequently rewarded after year 2000. For example, 2008 IGN listed this as n. 8/10 franchises that should be resurrected, praising game for having "best writing and characterization seen in gaming". Planescape has also been frequently listed top xx all games ever done and to play, last of them being PC Gamer stating 2011 Planescape Torment being 19th greatest PC game ever done. Clearly, there's a huge demand for this successor.Background of Torment: Team behind the game is more or less "all star" group, having been part of creating following titles: The Bard's Tale series, Wasteland 1 & 2, Fallout 1 & 2, Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, IWD 1&2 and NWN2 expansions. (Well, Avellone left before change of year 2016 ) Also, creator of Numenera setting is involved with project as well. Mark Morgan (Fallout 1,2,NV, Planescape etc.) is composing music for Torment. The game raised 4 million USD in Kickstarter, later increrasing the amount to 5 million and it's still growing. As far as I know, this is currently a world record for a Kickstarter project related to games. The game has already delayed like one year and will be released this year, propably after summer? If I remember correct, Kickstarter was was chosen as a method to fund the game to get rid of some problems gaming industry does for developing of games.So, a lot of promises, expections, hopes and doubts. Lets see what first version of Beta seems to provide us so far and what kind of thoughts it delivers to me:- Torment is clearly closest to Planescape, just like developers have said. There's a lot of text to read and it is written really well and the use of words is colourful, really making your imagination running. The languange however is not anything simple, which might become problem for people who dont speak English as first languange or have fluent English otherwise. (For this, before buying, I would recommend to check Let's Play videos or something where you can see a bit of it). Dev has mentioned that this game will have about equal amount of words than Planescape had or possibly even more. (Devs have however stated that the game will be translated into: French, German, Italian, Polish, Russian and Spanish during early access.)- Reactivity seems to play big part of the quests and world in the game. Quests seem to have multiple solutions, starting from not even taking the quest, ignoring after taking it and other solutions where you do something. Naturally, you can't solve quests in all different ways in one playthrough. 5 dimensional tide system also seems to provide replayability as they do different things for the world. You even have different prologue parts before waking up in the world of Torment. Choices in game also shifts these tides as well and might cause NPC's in world to react in different ways etc. I havent investigated this  tide thing yet.- First version of beta is buggy: Developers ask for feedback in the forum or via the feedback system provided in the game. It's nice to see that developers are actually reading the forum and recommendations, suggestions and other ideas of people in the forum, also commenting them occasionally. (To make it clear they dont do what people tell them to do, they just take the best parts or ideas that suit for their vision of the game). Also, they havent developed f.e. stores, proper UI or many items for it. I'm sure that the combat system will get some tweaks as well.- Setting: Numenera is odd world for a person who is not familiar with the setting before playing this. That's why the lore might feel a bit crushing at the start, but if you look around and do things, you get more familiar with it in short time. In short it's scifi world but has a touch of more usual cRPG aspects, which makes you feel more like in home if you are familiar with genre. There's a lot of advanced technology, but knowledge and how odd devices and such are used is limited. I'm not explaining theme more here, but there's a lot to wonder and be curious about (like a fountain of purple fishes flowing instead of water?)Overall: I think the game seems really promising so far. I'm curious about what I will learn about Numenera, the story, characters etc and what kind of choices can I make. I hope the full game will show more strong philosophical aspects as well (like PST did), which, at least the question "What does one life matter?" seems to be hinting about. I also got now and then Point And Click feeling :D Also, I havent had problems with performance of the game (other than first area). If you would like to see all different outcomes of quests etc. I would say playing this beta could be like 40 hour thing to play. Otherwise it's about +10 hours.This game seems to be for: People who want to read (a lot) and think, diving into atmosphere and environment of Numenera with their imagination. People who enjoy cRPG titles, especially Planescape: Torment. People who don't mind that you can't archive everything in one playthrough. People who enjoy traditional, narrative roleplaying things, pnp and such. (However, dont expect and hope that this game is Planescape Torment 2 - Successor means that the heart of PST is there in terms of writing, reactivity etc. but the game's setting, rules etc have nothing to do with PST..)This game is not for: People who dont speak fluent English. People who expect more fast paced gaming and action. Also, people who find idea of reading a book horrible. People who think that fighting in RPG is mandatory rather than one possibility among others.Good thing is that this game will also be released DRM free.

number of helpful: 19 of 27 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7
												"All flavor, no meat" is the best way to describe Torment 2 :ToN. I should point out that I am one of the original backers from 4 years ago and loved the Original Planescape Torment - having played it a dozen times at least. The original Torment was reviewed by the New York Times which felt that it should be elevated to the status of literature due to the depth, beauty and originality of the writing - and I completely agree - the writing was that good. http://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/27/techn ... tions.htmlNot so much the sequel, Torment 2 - Tides of Numenera. I am not sure where to begin with all the problems this game has.1) Poor NPC introduction and character development. During this game I really reached a point of not really caring at all about my fellow companions. Mainly because there wasn't really anything compelling to care about. If you look at the original game, each companion is introduced to you from a space that matches who they are. Morte you meet in the beginning after you awaken in the dusties mortuary. Fall-from-Grace in the Brothel Of Slaking Intellectual Lusts, Anna-From the Shadows you meet in the Beggar Kings domain surrounded by shadows and thieves, Nordrom is found in a tainted Modron construct and so on... They are all incredible well-voiced and have distinct opinions and personalities as well as extensive backstories that you have to dig out. They also are linked to you through a unified theme - that of being broken and/or creatures that defy their own nature. In ToN I felt the companions were just kind of there - not much to the backstory nor are they all that important. 2) Way too much flavor without substance. There was just an exhaustive amount of shallow flavor interactions with this game that didn't have a whole lot to do with the main story. Although this feels like more a result of the universe - the Numenera - which is everywhere. The whole point of the Numenera is you never find out who made any of it or what its original purpose is/was - which can be fun in small doses but this game is lousy with that sort of thing. It just becomes one exhausting and unfulfilling interaction after another - wondering if this strange thing is important (usually not).3) Show don't tell - this has been said many times and it is spot on. This just doesn't feel like an RPG - more of a story we are being told and we have to click the screen a bunch to get to the next part. I lost count of the number of times the writing devolved into telling us what we should be experiencing and what we should know instead of showing us what is there to see and letting us figure it out. The original Planescape has been called literature - and I agree - it definitely hits that bar. ToN is barely bad storytelling - and at the juvenile level at best. The excuse I keep hearing from people is - "Well the original had a lot of writing - maybe you just don't like that" and my response is "Please shut up if you can't tell the difference between good writing and bad"4) The combat is terrible, boring and confusing. It actually ends up being a blessing that combat is so rare in this game (although it shouldn't be if the game was well made), because it is really unsatisfying. Thankfully mostly you can skip it. 5) It is derivative in the worst kinds of ways. It felt like they just copy pasted aspects of the story from the original and pasted them onto this story. The overall feeling is a story that feels pieced-together and does not flow organically. So basically there is a lot more but it comes down to this -it's pretty clear that the real genius behind Planescape Torment was not present on this project. I am done with Brian Fargo and InExile Entertainment. Wasteland 2 was just as weak and tedious story-wise as this title and its clear they don't have the writing chops to offer anything worthy of the titles and legacies they are pilfering. This game will not do well. I hope you guys felt it was worth it to waste your resources on porting instead of making sure you had a solid product with great writing.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								(Beta Review: 28Jan2016)Where to start?To be a spiritual successor to Planescape: Torment is to fill some gargantuan boots- but the team behind this game is doing it.Fleshing out the weird that is the Numenera setting is no easy task, either, and still- this team is doing it.So. Should you buy this game?Yes. Abso♥♥♥♥inglutely. The creators involved in this game and the Numenera setting are *brilliant* and I want them to continue creating beautiful things. The more people I can convince to give them money the more likely they are going to continue to create more awesome. If you play this game, you will want this, too. If you are not into seeing things that are unfinished- if you can't handle bugs and rough edges, then maybe wait for a few patch passes- give a little time for the technical bits to have another coat of polish before investing. But if you're in it for the writing- and if you loved Planescape: Torment you *know* you are in it for the writing- then I've a feeling you'll be able to put the bugs behind you.Okay, okay, you want something besides feelings? If you love attention to detail and rolling your eyeballs across hundreds of thousands of words-Play this game.If you love thinking about how our choices make us the people we are-Play this game.If you have ever played a game and thought- "Dyah- I wish there were more dialogue options"-Play this game.If you love your swords and sorcery with a side of petulant AI and brain-eating-amphetamine♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥worms-Play this game.What? You don't like any of those things?Play this game anyway, you might learn something. (Seriously? Not even one of those things? Really? Worms didn't do it for ya? Whatever.)Yeah. So stop reading, go buy it (or get your key if you were a kickstarter backer) and go play. It is an absolute delight.

Posted: February 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Just played a bit of it, but I can already enumerate some points. First, I died before I could even start the game. How? In an awesome way, but I won't give you spoilers. I just say that I was too "eager to throw myself away". And that's one big lead to let you know how unpredictable is the scenario of this game. Since the first lines of the narration, you`re already choosing your destiny and changing whatever you don't know you're going to change, and that's simply terrifying and gratifying at the same time. About the "Planescape: Torment premise", well, I might say the whole package is all in it, even if many thing are not implemented and "well developed" yet, you can "feel" it`s all there.  I can give a couple of examples from what I`ve already experienced: alien-ish and complete freakish ambientation, great character development, "things" so bizarre simply apread all over places for you to interact and figure (what the hell) is it about, dense and metaphysical dialogues that give you the creeps and "haunt" your decision-making. Aside of that, you're simply thrown into the world without knowledge or making sense of anything. It's strange. The most common word not for the begining of the game but for the whole of it. I'm sincerely SUPER excited for what's coming next (patches and updates) and still exploring and understanding everything we already have. It's not something simple to make a game whose main premise is to continue the legacy of one of the greatest RPG's ever made. It's really a BOLD proposition, but I have to say, the guys in InXile are treading the right path towards this goal.

Posted: March 30
												Not sure what went wrong here, excellent storytelling and top-notch writing but the game just doesn't hold together - feels fragmented and then suddenly rushed at the end with the story themes all clashing at once. Although, it possesses many of the hallmarks of an excellent sci-fi novel, it's ultimately disappointing as an RPG. The sub-quests, sub-plots and mini-stories are interesting and feature thought-provoking themes whilst adding substance to the world, but they seem to overshadow the main storyline and sap away some of the game's momentum. Even the MacGuffin (resonance chamber) wasn't really interesting or urgent enough for me to feel like it motivated the main character or companions. After walking in the footsteps of the Changing God and meeting all the other Castoffs, well, I just wasn't sold that my "one" life really mattered as the protagonist in the game - maybe that answers the question of the game's premise.

content:
Posted: March 6
												Perfect world-building, good storyline, very interactive (but zero real player agency and probably not much replay value).Main problem: it's obviously rushed. It feels as if at some point they decided to stitch all the finished fragments and systems of a much larger game into something smaller and passable enough to sell. That, among other things, screwed up the pacing and rendered half of the systems obsolete.The end result has merits, but it is not very graceful.Too bad. Could've been an excellent game; instead it's merely decent (not a crime, but even if you disregard the hype the wasted potential is glaringly obvious).Clearly needed another year (or two). A large addon, maybe? Some sort of director's cut? Sadly, that's not likely to happen.

												I'm not sure that there is a word for the feeling of desperately wanting to recapture a pleasant feeling that you had once upon a time but because you and the world have changed that innocent feeling is no longer possible.  In any case, that is this game.  I know that, from a stand point of pure unbiased opinion that this game is probably pretty good.  But I cannot stand it.  It is like being trapped in a particularly annoying novel where you hate everything about it from the characters to the plot to the completely bizarre world.Game play is boring, controls are simple and simple and in a world of complex high end controls simple just doesn't work.  The isometric view sucks for control as about 90% of the time you are at least partially obscured on what you are doing and you have no means of telling what you are seeing.  This makes combat a chore and really irritating to boot.The plot is simple, and while that is not automatically a bad thing, its boring.  I find absolutely nothing interesting in the characters they've provided and the idea of trying to make a story out of these sad two dimensional cardboard cut-outs is just too annoying to work with.The game is a failure.  And that makes me sad.  So much potential and work squandered on so much lack luster nonsense.

content:
Posted: February 12
												I really wanted to write a positive review for this game but I just cannot. I am an avid CRPG fan, with multiple completions of BG1, BG2, IWD, IWD2 as well as more recently, PoE, and Tyranny. While I did not play planescape torment, I believe my major criticisms are not due to the theme of the story, which is actually something I enjoy, but rather due to the major design and technical errors found in the game. I finished the "First Chapter" in about 12 hours. With that, here are some positive aspects to begin. Good writing if longwinded and obtuse about the actual consequences of what you read. There is a lot of magic jargon and special words to keep track of. It could use something like what Tyranny did where you can read the lore behind a word in a brief summary.  Good setting and artwork. It is strange; it is not dwarves, elves and humans in space. It is a weird sci-fi fantasy, cyberpunk blend with a ton of psychedelics thrown in. The environments are interesting to look at and are varied, but sometimes get in the way of actually accomplishing what you want to do. The systems have great potential for depth. For example not only do I get extra insight through text because I am a mind reader, but occasionally I will receive extra damage because I read peoples mind who do not like that.Now for the much longer negatives. Too many loading screens - they are not too long but dear god will you see a lot of them Too much backtracking which is tedious due to the screens. Consequences for having too many onetime use items, but not enough situations to actually use them A completely unfinished companion  Rhin  Clunky movement and control, which is not smooth. Fast travel must be unlocked through progress in the main story line - AND it does not even sometimes place you in the place where you can visit the rest of the area  Caravanserai I am looking at you!  No rest outside of two areas in the main city. Almost too many options for leveling up. Seriously. You have to choose between, like four things every time, and it is unclear what is important. Poor skill balance. A few skills are super useful and easy to progress with while others are challenging.  Little VO compared to PoE or BG2. Only a few of the companion conversations have it and it feels like it is difficult to know when you have new ones available. No indicator when you have no choices available to speak with NCPs. What I mean is the text does not just go gray or dark when you have already asked INSTEAD you get the version of it where the word AGAIN is inserted into the sentence. Which is difficult to notice. Sometimes that will yield more information but most of the time not. It’s stupid, because every cRPG to date has solved this problem. Gray out when it is the same make it blue to indicate you can ask again and get a new response.  The cypher look like they should interact and there is even dialogue in game that suggests that they do YET I have not seen any evidence of the sort. Many items called oddities SOME of which are critical to solving optional quests.  Like the starfish eyeball thing for the pyramid puzzle in order of truth section  Very unclear which ones are important. Chapter one is pretty short ~6 hours without side quests, 12 hours with a large amount of side quests (Can't say I did all of them but I tried to)  Unclear combat mechanics. Its turn based which is fine, but then there is a large of amount of information, which is unclear. How do I find out how much armor the enemy has for example? Boring skills and abilities that are not balanced. Okay I get it I can get a bunch of skills that can increase my chances at pass a specific check. Each increase is 15% - That is not exciting and seems too quickly turn into automatically passing the check automatically. Unbalanced rewards sometimes just hitting the right dialogue with one NPC without doing ANYTHING gives you free stats equivalent if not better then leveling up. In addition, sometimes a quest, which took 35 minutes to do because of how difficult it was to track down all the stuff, gives 40 xp. Stupid. Stupid. Stupid  The movement and interaction feels almost sluggish. Crashes occasionally has weird graphical glitches as NPC bodies sliding around and Steam overlay freezing over parts of the game. Unclear consequences of some actions. As I am not sure which tide I will get sometimes - which is fine... but I am also unsure how each tide effected the conversations I had.I really hope they improve the game in the next parts because while I enjoyed spending my weekend with it I am saddened that it is unfinished and has so many glaring problems. Some might say the obfuscation is what makes the game challenging and interesting. I tend to agree and I try to solve every puzzle myself beforehand. However, it cannot be expected that many people interested in the story are able to commit 30 minutes to solve a minor side quest, or know to look up the solution online (the latter might not even be possible in all cases)If you are a diehard cRPG fan like me, you will probably still enjoy it, if you are just getting your feet wet in cRPG's go play Pillars of Eternity or Baldurs Gate 2: Enhanced Edition.EDIT: Played the game for about 5 hours after the release to see what happen after the beta content. The vast majority of my criticism still stands. There is more voice acting later and new dialogue options that appear but still suffers from many of the same problems as before. I was most disappointed to find out that Rhin remains largely unviable in combat - although can be useful in completing objectives. I still dislike the combat even more so when there are literally 20 enemies that must take their turn. It feels very slow. Again. More loading screens - for example SPOILER in the valley section you must travel between different rooms of which I think ~15 are quest revelant but there is loading screen on each one. I think I must have spent a good hour today on loading screens. The writing remains strong if somewhat obtuse. Nearly every character speaks in riddles while lecturing on metaphyiscs which is not neccarily bad but may not be for everyone . Going to finish it during the week and will provide a full review.

content:
Posted: March 12
												EDIT: After going through a second playthrough, I have some added thoughts. I stand by the original review and it have not changed it or removed anything, but have added some final thoughts.Alright... Let's start with the negatives. There are a few. There are quite a few bugs, most of them minor annoyances (EDIT: See the end for how these minor annoyances became a lot more major.). But I have through one complete playthrough and well into the second one encountered two quest bugs that make it impossible to finish those quests. In the first case it was annoying, but didn't really ruin anything for me. The second one, however is a pretty big deal and almost causes me to turn on this game. I have decided not to continue with that playthrough until this is fixed. I should note that I had no problems at all with the same qeust on the first playthrough. This is not acceptable in a game that has had such a long ( and open) development time. There are minor technical issues here and there but I have not experienced anything bad.With that out of the way - This in an incredible game when it comes to story, plot, characters, atmosphere, lore and worldbuilding. It is well worthy of its claim as successor to Planescape: Torment. The protagonist is slightly less interesting than in P:T but the progression and decisions make up for it. There is an army of characters and quests, mostly very well done and varied.If you're not ready to read, and lots of, then this is NOT the game for you. The sheer amount of written dialogue and descriptions is staggering and very well done.If you're expecting action then, again, this game is NOT for you. There are few combat situations and most potential combat situations can be avoided through conversations and skills. It's a plus in my eyes but some may disagree. As a matter of fact there is no actual combat situation - it's referred to as Crisis and can be resolved in many ways, including but not limited to combat. The combat system is turn based and old-school gamers will be very familiar with the good and bad of such. I like it but it can be on the tough side.The character progression is fairly traditional and easy to learn but may not be for everyone. It's the ol' fashioned 'get a bunch of XP and level up' but with the added wrinkle that there are four levels / tier. You can only do so much every level but gain new abilities at every tier. The characters are pretty weak to begin with and get more versatile and powerful with time - no big surprises there.Long story short, this is a very good game worth the wait (I kickstarted it back in 2013) but it sure as hell isn't for everyone. It's an incredible world and story with a lot of great content but it absolutely will not appeal to those seeking a fast pace and/or action. This is a game that takes its time and rewards patience and immersion. That's my thing, may not be yours.But is sure isn't perfect.Finally (this will be a personal gripe, by all means stop reading if you're satisfied so far) I cannot, for the life of me, understand a looooooot of the other reviews for this game. I see an awful lot of complaints about the lack of action and combat and complaints about the amount of text. I don't mean to be rude, but it has been purdy clear from day one that this would never be a game drowning in action nor lacking in reading and lore. So I stress, again, if you're looking for action this just isn't the game for you.EDIT: I went through and finished a second playthrough. Using some player knowledge of the quests, I managed to completely avoid any such bugs and could do (and finish) all the quests. I still think this is a very well written and thought out game, story, plot etc. I also still think it will never appeal to everyone, but then people forget that nobody bought Planescape: Torment on release and it took years for people to understand what a remarkable game that was. In my personal instance, I alone in my group of friends bought and/or thought it was special. That's the good news.There's just no way around it, this is a buggy mess. I've lost count of the number of issues I've experienced but they've ranged from tiny annoyances to game-breaking in a sense. I had to effectively restart a playthrough from scratch becuase of a quest bug. Late game I had to relaod the same encounter repeatedly because my character was knocked down for -1 round, which so completely baffled the program that I was stuck. I've had a situation almost at the end of the game where I was basically stuck because I was given a 110% chance at succeeding at a task. But the thing about bugs is that they can be fixed and I have a feeling inXile could have really used a few more months, but wouldn't have dared to delay once again. The positives of the game, as far as I'm concerned, still far outweigh the negatives. But I repeat once more that this game will never appeal to everyone.

number of helpful: 28 of 46 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10
												Admittedly I haven't got very far into TTON yet, but what I've seen so far hasn't impressed me a great deal.I am a huge fan of Planescape Torment, though I've never claimed it to be a perfect game. PST suffered from an overabundance of trash fights, but made up for it by having some of the best video game writing I've ever seen. As a successor to PST, TTON fails in many areas. Every character in PST, from party members to random NPCs on the streets of Sigil, were extremely memorable. In TTON, characters usually serve only as lore dispensers, lacking interesting personality or anything particuarly interesting to say. The issue of lore dumpy, boring characters is compounded by generally poor writing. There is an overabundance of "purple prose", that is text excessively extravagant, that often feels like it was just added to increase the length of a lore dump. PST was also fond of extravagant description, but Chris Avellone managed to work within the setting so that the rich descriptions of the crazy planes immersed you in the setting, rather than frustrating you with another long lore dump.The combat falls flat, much like its predecessor, though one improvement over PST is that there are far less "trash" fights, so in that at least, it is an improvement.  The combat is extremely slow, and the whole "one move and one combat action" system feels incredibly restricting. Divinity Original Sin had far better turn based combat than this (and most other recent TB games)The stat system feels like a system that works in a P&P, but not a CRPG. You see all skill/stat checks regardless of your stat levels, and "spend" your stats to increase the chance of a successful attempt. This removes replayability, as all you need to do is save before a stat/skill check and reload until you pass, compared to say Fallout 1/2 and PST where extra options appeared based on your current stats. A super smart character gets no extra options over a dumb one, just an easier time passing the checks.Overall, I am disappointed with this release. It might be salvageable, but it would take a lot of work.

number of helpful: 14 of 20 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												Damn I wanted to like TToN so much, I didn't though.Pros:+Beautifull landscape art+Very interesting setting+Rhin (companion)Cons:-Ugly character art, made worse by ugly or nonexistent character portraits-Pointless character developement system: *Combat skills feel pointless because there's so little combat, of which most is avoidable anyway*All other skills feel pointless after few levels, because you end up automatically passing every single skill test with minimal effort / points used-Simplistic, unengaging combat (Crisis)-Uninteresting companion characters (most of them)-Bugs. I've found two bugs in vendor screen taking all my money, one side quest I couldn't complete, and one crisis in main quest line I had to load/save a dozen times to get through because of a crucial companion being unable to use his skills due to an UI bug.-Complete lack of anything that would make this an engaging computer game. It's more like a book with graphics you need to click on to read more, and couple of very simple puzzles to solve.I suppose it all boils down to the writing though, and how you like it. I'm a constant reader, and I mainly read science fiction and historical novels from a lot of authors, all of which usually contain a lot of world building and lengthy descriptions, and I loved PST. In TToN I still got completely exhausted by the amount of text one has to wade through. Sure the world *is* interesting, and some of the quests are too. However, there's just so much text explaining just how interesting and clever and filled with hidden meaning and lost secrets everything is, even when said item, NPC or concept is pointless and never mentioned again, I can't be bothered to read it all. I got tired of it. I mean, there's pointless stuff you can collect and sell, and those all have lengthy descriptions. Every NPC has a wall of text to wade through, just so you can be sure that the NPC in question is a pointless sidenote that doesn't even have a named sidequests tied to it. I mean, it took me like five hours to finish my first quest in the game, because I felt like I had to talk to all of the NPC's in Sagus' Cliffs (several of them twice), to be sure I was making an educated decision. Five hours is two movies worth of writing, or half a book, without any kind of conclusion or advancement of the plot. After being exhausted by this sort of gameplay, where the "game" was actually just me clicking my character between NPC's and reading their comments for hours, I really couldn't believe it that the game then even took the graphics away, and made me do text adventures (most of which seemed totally disconnected from the story.)I'm sorry about writing a review without finishing the game, but I suppose that speaks for itself. I'll maybe return to TToN in couple of months and try to struggle through it.

												I can't give this a thumbs up.  I backed it, I'd like to give it a thumbs up, but I can't. - Combat is tedious - I'm yet to see these "hand-crafted encounters with changing objectives, and interactions" that they spoke of in their backer emails.  Currently I'm in a location filled with nameless enemies with whom you can't negotiate, or avoid, with literally 0 terrain, just a flat gray path.  So, good work guys, I guess you can give 0 ♥♥♥♥♥ while handcrafting something too."A New Take on Combat. With the Crisis system, combat is more than just bashing your enemies. Plan your way through hand-crafted set-pieces which combine battles with environmental puzzles, social interaction, stealth, and more." - the Devs, I guess talking about some different game. - My character's current equipment is a mesh cloak and a skin coloured jumpsuit, they look like a loosely wrapped supermarket ham. - For all their record  backing, they sure did the minimal voice acting - it actually surprises me every time an NPC bothers to say a word.If you're feeling like an RPG, and haven't played Divinity yet, do that.  It is turn-based, actually strategic, with far more interesting interactions with NPCs.  Plus, they have this newfangle thing called 3D graphics, which were developed sometime between Baldur's Gate and now.  Turns out you can make pretty interesting environments, and when you have to do a combat encounter next to a wall, you can just turn the camera around.I'm giving this one more go, because I backed this and really want to like it.  But its is definitely circling the Vortex of Uninstalling.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Now that the full version is out, some of my thoughts:Wonderful writing, great world design, gorgeous art design, great science fiction feel to the game and the atmosphere is well done.Can't wait to play more of this wonderful, engrossing rpg, if you want some wonderful writing or a beautifully crafted gameworld and a future science fiction setting then pick this up asap!I have played above 20 hours of the final version and I have only gotten in 1 fight so far. Like Planscape Torment before it, you can beat most of the game without fighting if you want. The game gives you alot of ways to play the game!Now excuse me as I get pulled back into this wonderfully crafted game that so far has reminded me of a cross between the setting and writing of Planscape Torment and the atmosphere and feel of HBO's Westworld with the science aspects this game brings to the table.The only negatives are that the first hour is slow and not the best (But boy does it get going after this!) and also that the combat is not that great (when compared to something like  Divinity Original Sin), decent but not super amazing. Thankfully you can play most the game without fighting if that is what you so desire. The combat is good enough but won't blow you away, this is how I felt about the combat for the Shadowrun crpgs.Well done Inexile! You made a guy like me very excited to be back in this universe again after all these years (1999 since Planscape Torment I think?).Now get reading and get ready for an adventure you might just not be ready for!Best writing of the crpg resurgence for me (Pillars and Wasteland 2 where the best writing previous of the insurgence of crpgs) but a bit behind Divinity, Wasteland 2 and Pillars in the combat department. Still, so far this is a wonderful game that has a very unique setting, amazing writing and a world that has been crafted with so much love and care.I am so glad crpgs are back, it is wonderful to have something to play that focuses on characters, writing and the game world, instead of just action, shooting or top of the line graphics like so many modern games these days.WRITING = 9.5/10WORLD DESIGN = 9/10SOUNDTRACK = 8.5/10COMBAT = 7/10NON-COMBAT GAMEPLAY = 9/10

content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								I really loved Planescape Torment. It had a rich, creative world with a very grown up story that was ahead of its time. The graphics really added up to the game and created a rich atmosphere.Now to Torment: Tides of Numenera. To be honest, it is nothing like Planescape. I haven't really seen anything were I can say this is on par with its role model.Even if you do not judge it by that high standards, it is mediocre at best. For example the graphics. It just doesn't look good. And I am not talking from a technical standpoint, but from an artistic. In terms of colors it lacks harmonic environments, it looks dull. Compared with a newer game like Pillars of Eternity which manages to create something special with every map, it is weaker in every way. No atmospheric lightning, the maps are nowhere near that detailed.Also through other means like sound they do not manage to create the imagination of a living, breathing city.As for the combat, it is boring and slow. I don't know why they made the decision to go turn based. I see no reason, it isn't even very tactical.But remember, this is still Early Access and maybe the game has greatly improved in the past month - who knows. And that brings me to my last point:I am really disappointed by this Early Access. There is no real involvement of the buyers. No updates, no information. If anything, this is a good example on how you should NOT do an Early Access. I am sure I am not the only buyer that is disappointed how this is going. It really looks like they just wanted to grab some early money without any real responsibility towards the buyers.

content:
Posted: March 9
												I am a backer of this title and consider Planescape: Torment one of the greatest PC games of all time. It is with a heavy heart that I find myself writing a bad review for this game. The problems are numerous:1. The story is dull and uninteresting. I find myself pushing forward thinking it must surely get better soon.2. The characters are lacking in personality. Near the beginning of the game, you are introduced to two characters who eventually choose to split up and force you to choose which one to follow. It occurred to me at that point that I don't really care which I follow because the characters are so lacking in personality that it is impossible to distinguish one from the other without resorting to judging by looks and character class.3. The writing is bad. I don't mean "writing" as in "the plot" (though that's not good either); I mean the dialogue and other text you read throughout the game. This is a game that relies heavily on the writing. The prose needed to be good; it isn't. The writing should be at least good enough that you don't stop to think about whether it's good or not. Instead, it is so bad that you wonder if it was written by amateurs.4. This game feels less like a video game and more like a "Choose your own adventure" book. Quite often, things that deserve a cut-scene are merely described to you using that bland prose I complained about in #3 above. Why am I reading about a flash-back memory instead of seeing it as a cut-scene?5. I'm bored. Yes, I'm barely getting started, but I don't recall ever being bored of a game this quickly, especially one I had been looking forward to and eagerly anticipating for several years.Pretty much the only redeeming quality of this game is the setting. The setting is fantastic; I could imagine many great epic stories taking place in this world. Unfortunately, the story they tell in this title is just bland and boring.Having said that, I have to admit that I have barely put any time into the game yet and its possible it will get good soon. If it does I will update this review. In the meantime though, I am bored and don't really feel like playing it.If you do choose to get this game, just be aware of what you are getting into. This is not a classic RPG and doesn't actually resemble Planescape: Torment in any way. This is more along the lines of Sid Meyer's Sorcery! and other text driven games. You will spend most of your time reading descriptions of events that you are not actually seeing on screen and interacting with dialogue menus.

Early Access Review
								Tried to play an alpha. All I wanna say: I'm very impatient for the moment this game will be released. Whoever liked Planescape will be pleasantly surprised by the diversity of choises you can make. Also I'd like to tell that after 15+ years of wait...it was totally worth it. Pros:+The context dialogues consist of 10+ options and all your choises lead to some kind of consiquences that differ one from another! +A decent storyline, which kinda reminds of Planescape, when you dunno who are you, what happened to you and someone is after you.+Pleasant graphics which also remind of good old times spent in Planescape.+Soundtrack.+Atmosphere.+Easter eggs! (not spoiling, try to find them yourself :P)Cons:-Still in alpha.-Pretty slow development.-Decent english skills required to understand what is going on (they plan to make several localisations later though)P.S. The only reason I'm not playing it right now- is that the game is not finished yet. I want to wait till it's released, take a vacation, turn off the phones, tell everyone to leave me alone for 2 weeks, close myself in my house and pass this game non-stop :D

content:
Posted: March 25
												Torment: Tides of Numenera is a not a bad game, but the whole “spiritual successor to Planescape: Torment” is a lie. The only thing these two titles share is a horrible combat mechanics.On surface it looks like P:T — there is a lot of nicely written text. Sadly, it is mostly used for lore and certain interesting stories, when companions and main plot desperately needed more attention. Rich world lore conveys a false feeling that something deep is going on, but then illusion dissipates. Huge amount of text feels redundant, because it is rarely used for things that matter. Game fails to create a connection with the player, it is hard to become involved in the Last Castoff's story when everything feels so artificial and shallow. After Sagus Cliffs, locations are rushed, NPC have next to nothing to say, quests devolve into constant fetching off something from neighbouring location. Meres feels like something that should not even be in game, they are so primitive and unpolished it hurts. Companion-related quests are very short and simple, and in some cases (Rhin and Callistege) also disappointing. Story closure is the final spit in the face, it is one of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥ “here is your buttons, press one and receive corresponding enging” deals.In the end, game leaves a very bitter aftertaste, like a waste of time and, worst of all, hope.

content:
Posted: March 16
												I haven't finished the game and I'm writing this review now because I'm not sure that I will. It's a decent game, but when you set yourself up as the successor to Planescape: Torment, you have to live up to high expectations, and Tides of Numenera just doesn't. The concept and world are amazing, but the implementation is just unfinished, making the experience feel like you're just scratching the sruface. First, here's what the game does right. I really liked the original story. It's a bit of a slow burn, but most of the writing is good, and they included all the interesting and bizarre little details, side-stories, and dark humor that really nailed the same narrative feel as PS:T. Also, the promise of being able to take multiple approaches to situations has been delivered. They also definitely brought it with the art. The various game locations I've seen so far are varied and exciting, and in the era of 3D dominance, they still manage to make an isometric game look attractive and visually engaging.However, the flaws really prevent this game from coming together into an immersive experience. The idea of the tides affecting how everyone in the world reacts to you was barely there, really just adding up to a few throwaway dialogue lines of, "I had heard you were that type of person..." It never seemed to actually affect outcomes. Also, there are no real factions like the ones you could interact with and even join in Torment. I "joined" one of the groups in the game through dialogue, but it has had no effect at all as far as I can tell. No one treated me any differently, I got no stat bonuses or penalties, it didn't seem to help or hurt the group's standing in the world, and I later I even met people who were members of that same group and they had no idea who I even was. Again, there was a lame line about how the various branches of the group didn't have much contact with each other. The skills, abilities, and effort setup felt needlessly complex, and some of the mechanics were never fully explained. I never figured out how to tell the difference between a one-handed and a two-handed weapon except by equipping it, and I'm still not sure why weapons were divided up into heavy and light. I don't need a lot of hand-holding or a huge tutorial, but as far I can tell, this info wasn't available for me to see anywhere at all. It sucks having to buy a weapon just to see if my character can use it with his shield, then having to sell it back at a loss when it turns out it's two-handed. Maybe I missed something. Finally, I encountered a bug that would cause combat to freeze periodcially. It didn't happen every combat, but several of the bigger ones I had to keep reloading and replaying, which was really tedious. It's a known issue, but a fix doesn't seem to be forthcoming. I really, really, wish they had fleshed this game out a little more. There was so much promise and if they could have polished it a bit more and made sure that the player's choices had more of an impact on the game world, it would have equaled or even surpassed its "spiritual" predecessor.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3
												This is a difficult game to recommend or not recommend.  I'll start off by prefacing: don't buy the game if you expect something on the level of PS:T or BG1-2. It doesn't compare to those favorably at all.As for the actual review, there are a lot of good things going for the game. The world is extremely well developed and rich in lore. I greatly enjoyed just reading all the flavor text spread liberally throughout the game. The story, while nothing unique, is sufficient as a vehicle to get the player through the game. Best of all, the game actually means it when it says you can build any type of character and be successful at clearing the game. I fought a total of four times in the entire game. Then there are the characters, most of which have interesting back stories and designs.Unfortunately, there's a lot to dislike too. While the characters ARE interesting, they're also extremely flat. They never truly progress anywhere with the exception of one, and you only see that development at the very end for a brief moment. Then there's all the lore text: it's ♥♥♥♥ing massive, the equivalent of a hefty novel all on it's own. The combat system is hit or miss, as well, though credit is due to the game as it does allow you to talk your way through even combats. The ending is also unbelievably boring, just a brief conversation at the very end with a generic "This is what happened after..." slideshow for the epilogue.I think the worst of it all, however, is just how short the game is. I read through all the flavor text and took my time doing all the quests available and I still finished the game in less than 25 hours. Admittedly, I'm a quick reader, but that's pretty pathetic for a 45 dollar RPG. There's not much replay value to it either, as despite what it says your choices don't actually affect much throughout the game outside of maybe some flavor things.Overall, I'd recommend it if you can get it on sale for about 20 dollars. Otherwise, just wait for it to go on sale or see if inXile  is releasing some amazing DLC or a modding system or something.

content:
Posted: March 6
												I kept having this nagging suspicion that the game should have been twice as long. The pacing of content was tedious at times. The first city had dozens of quests, and thats basically why the ending areas probably felt lackluster. Whole areas were created with minimal quests, and almost no interaction between your decisions and the order of completion.This turned into a storyline where any single one of the quests could have been taken out, and you'd never of missed it.Even the core storyline felt discombobulated, all the way up to the end. Sure it had a "loss of memory" trope attached to it, but you could very easily see where it was all heading, even if your character avatar couldn't.In the end, the return of Isometric RPGs is a _great_ thing. This particularly isometric RPG, however, was not.I'd recommend a Pillars of Eternity or Tyrant over this title, any day of the week. Thats a shame too. I really ended up loving the universe they'd created, even if you were given only tiny glimpses of it, with limited ability to interact with it. The concept of this universe would have been better suited with an open world experience, and not constrained by the likes of an Isometric RPG. Worse, it seems as if they've set this up for a sequel or "DLC" content, with little if any point, story-wise, to return to this game.The big bad evil isn't a bad evil. The actual evil is dead. Buy it if you like really like RPGs; But only if you already own Pillars of Eternity or Tyrant.

number of helpful: 12 of 17 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18
Intro & Motivationsome people mistake the question steam reviews try to answer. it is: "do you recommend this game?" and while an objective recommendation -very much like an objective 'review'- is not reasonable to expect nor necessary to have anyway, i believe it's at least good sport to recommend or not based on what you have at hand, and not on what you expected.(long story short: i believe lots of people that're disappointed with their KS investment are blinded to what this game offers, making a disservice to both parties.)History of Me & T:ToNso here i am, recommending a game that i actually backed during KS and then didn't follow development progress at all. (i'm kind of busy anyway, no time to worry about games that are not out yet.) so i installed the game, a bit surprised that it's out already (turns out it was 2 years late. oh well), and curious to find out if they could convert me back to numenera (played some tabletop rpg of it, wasn't exactly our cup of tea) but wait! why did i even back it on KS in the first place, you should ask! was it because of my everlasting love for planescape torment? or did i want to go back to isometric cRPGs like it was 90's again? or did i simply buy into hype? (well, my complete disinterest in development tells otherwise) turns out there are more reasons: back then i was getting back into tabletop RPG scene, was curious to find out what monte cook was doing, hence my interest in numenera. i also might have been interested in a modern take in isometric RPGs, taken in by nostalgia of things that never was. you see, i was not much of a gamer when originals (baldur's gate's, planecape and others) shook the market. so i have secondhand memories of those times, and wanted to try it for myself, i suppose.Review/Recommendation ItselfEventhough I gave a "thumbs up", the most I can do is try to convey what this game offers (to the best of my understanding. keep in mind that i'm nowhere near close to completing the game, even with 23 hours played) and let you decide, since you alone know what you expect from any game.this game is some sort of a tour guide in a science-fantasy museum that we call the ninth world. visiting a museum makes you feel wonder towards the cultural excellence at display (and you can go deeper and marvel at technical excellence that makes it possible for such a collection to be available to you to admire) but once you visit every hall and some hidden corridors, ogle every painting and sculpture, and read their history, ponder what the artist tried to convey... then you leave, and museum does not stay with you. writing this review, i'm now fully expecting to not have a lasting impact once i'm done playing the game. (not impression. my impression will remain) of course this is a beautiful game the way i see it, and i expect to 'visit the museum' a couple of times in the future, to try and experience it from a different angle. but this is not a captivating novel. we don't follow story of some interesting character in interesting times, we won't turn the last page and say "this will stay with me for a life time, and i'm different person for it" (going back to museum analogy: yes, museums change people too, but not on a personal level)now, i will not try to make excuses for inXile. first, being a museum and not a novel is not a bad thing. second, they chose it and i'm just trying to show you what this game is offering. i will, however, try to offer explanations to as why this may be the case:1) cRPGs face a difficult dilemma: you have a singular software, but true to its name, you want every single player to "role play", and experience their own story. isometric cRPGs, where you control a party of 4 characters, have it even further: you now need your player to have emotional connection with every one of those 4 characters! unlikely, if not impossible2) developers could have had lots of stories to tell, so instead of making main character deeply connected to the setting, they could have chosen a more middle-ground approach.whatever the reason, that is the case: main character, the last castoff, is not a real character, but just our avatar walking through the museum. honestly, first explanation i offered is also why i didn't expect to get connected to the last castoff anyway (geralt from witcher, for example, also starts as a blank slate, but quickly gets filled as a character, hence is easier to connect to)in other words, this game is a walking simulator. if this term unnerves you, my guess is you wouldn't have liked it in the first place.Minor(?) Complaintsthese complaints are about numenera system than its implementation in the game.but the combat is simply not good. anyone familiar enough with D&D rules can get the general feeling: combat is good, because there are lots of options for player expression and creativity. hell, it's even possible to consider it as its own board game. this game, on the other hand, tries to change things a little bit, by giving you an expandable pool of resources that you choose to spend or not before the dice is rolled(traditional D&D method was this: roll the dice, add your [static] bonuses, check if you've crossed the boundary or not. modern numenera method is this: add your [variable] bonuses, roll the dice, check if you've crossed the boundary or not. however, this seemingly small change ends up frustrating, because a missed roll makes player regret his choice of not spending more resources, and a succesful roll  wondering if spending was necessary in the first place. and resource management gets more troublesome. well, at least T:ToN managed to implement a "classical" hit point system)still, not enough combat options. i'm curious to see how a more aggressive playstyle will play out, because from what i've seen so far it may end up disappointing.also, this is not my complaint but may be for others: combat is far and few between. told you, this is a walking (and more than that, reading) simulator. i am okay with it, considering how i'm not particularly happy with combat in the first place, but more because i love walking and talking and reading in this big museum.Concluding:overall, i am happy with this game and what it's trying to do. it presents a world full of wonders, interesting characters (just not the main character) and curious sidequests. surely a pleasent experience, with surely some room for improvement, but let's continue our analogy to say that it's like having terrible cafeteria in a otherwise great museum.

												Kickstarted the game since I really love Planescape: Torment.+ Interesting world: all those little stories, the atmosphere, immersion - it is there+ Combat can be skipped (suggest you do it until the bugs are fixed)- Buggy combat (and horrible UX)- Inventory and UI in general is a mess- Max lvl.. If PLanescape:Torment is 10/10 then I feel like Tides of Numenera is 4/10. I would suggest waiting for a sale and some updates maybe.

Posted: April 18
												Unfortunately I have not played the original Torment: Planetscape. However, I do have limited insight into this game as a lover of RPG games and such. First, the most obvious problem was the lack of character customization, though there is a detailed description of your character, you can't change anything about it, no options for customization other than gender. The next thing I noticed is the writing, which is good, and too verbose, too wordy. Someone else mentioned that it is writing for writing's sake and that is apt. For excellent writing that conveys meaning and evokes a response I look to Pillars of Eternity. The writing in Torment: Tides feels too clunky, forced, as if it might be trying too hard to impress, whereas in Pillars of Eternity, the writing is crisp, concise, and utterly effective. Also, Baulder's Gate series is a good example of excellent writing.So, unfortunately, I cannot recommend this game.

												This game is just so incredibly boring. Some people have said this game is short with 40-70 hours in it. I played for 4 Hours and only fought twice. I played the entire of Pillars of Eternity and Tyranny and enjoyed both, same engine; better design.

Posted: February 24
Early Access Review
								This game, even though it's only Early Access at the moment and I've only logged about a dozen hours, has been the best buy and greatest gaming experience I've had in nearly twenty years. I was on the fence about it for many weeks. I played the original Torment twenty years ago *in fact I still have the game on CD-ROM in the original flip-out packaging* and was very impressed by it but it was never one of my all time favorites because it wasn't Turn-based combat. And so finally someone got it RIGHT! TToN is a delight for anyone who enjoys substance and depth over Gear scores and Tier-raiding. This wonderful masterpiece is NOT SUITABLE FOR ANYONE WHO:1.Hates to read2.Needs combat every eight minutes or they start licking the wallpaper3.PvP Nazi's; MMO-morons; Macro-blasting Multiboxing Gear-Geeks; Thinks FPS is the metric for joy and self worth.For the rest of us, this is one of those rare games that you lock yourself away with and wish the night was twelve hours longer so you could go even further, solve this newest quest, explore that new area that you just found the entrance. One of those games that you gasp out loud when you realize something or that sits on top of your imagination and sprinkles motes of introspective wonder on to you and leads you to extroverted gasps of surprise when a key plot point clicks into place and half a dozen things all make sense at once and the World gets a full shade richer.Bravo sirs and madams at InXile! And may I humbly ask you for more, more a thousand times More! I await launch day like few days before.

number of helpful: 20 of 33 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4
												Tides of Numenera succeeds in capturing the elusive magic of its acknowledged predecessor, the excellent Planescape: Torment. It has that same mysterious feeling of being a stranger in a strange land, interacting with odd terrors and great wonders. I'd highly recommend it for any fan of Torment.If you're on the fence, I will say it isn't perfect. If you're a hardcore tactical combat afficionado, this game's unlikely to scratch your itch; this game's more of a story-telling experience than a tough combat challenge. In a lot of the crises (the game's term for 'key situations, often involving combat') there can be a lot of NPC creatures running about, and it can get dull waiting for each of them to take their turn while you sit there and whistle. I found the game did also slow a little in some of the encounters with very large numbers of combatants, which just made it all drag on a bit longer.  Finally, the game itself isn't incredibly long - I finished it in 20 hours and was scouring the locations for sidequests as I went. Some people might think that's 'too short' for an RPG, but I would contend that it's partly because there's no filler content at all, no random encounters of any kind. Everything you do, you do for a purpose, and that gives it a wonderful purity of intent. Overall I enjoyed this game more than any for years and I could barely put it down. It's a really great experience if you're looking for something a bit slower-paced, with excellent writing and an air of wonder.

number of helpful: 40 of 71 people (56%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 28
												Though billed as a crpg, this game is no Divinity: Original Sin or Pillars of Eternity or even Wastelands 2. Combat is both shallow and heavily discouraged by the game which desperately wants you to find noncombat solutions to all fights. Character customization comes with dozens of abilites, most of which are useless (there are five weapons skills only used in combat) and others so useful it's a mistake not to take them (mind reading adds important insight throughout the entire game).Without combat or character choices, what is left is essentially a combination visual novel and CYOA.How much you enjoy this game will almost entirely depend on how much you enjoy reading the game's endless purple prose. What little story there is exists as an excuse to take a lengthy tour of the world of Numenera. A world where short descriptions do not exist and every adjective comes with three friends.The original Planescape:Torment found time to tell stories small and large about all its characters, explicitly subverting the themes of classic fantasy and creating a kind of fantasy noir. Numenera on the other hand finds itself hard pressed to tell a story about any character; npcs, villains, and the protagonist find themselves a distant second to the breathless delivery of endless *lore*.If you'd rather read a sourcebook than a story, this game is for you. Otherwise, go play one of the many other flawed but far more lovable CRPGs out there.

content:

Early Access Review
								As a big fan of the old Torment and also the Baldur's Gate & Icewind Dale franchise this game turned out exactly to be what I was looking for when I backed the kickstarter. It's lore- and story-rich, has enjoyable side-quest, an interesting setting, interesting mechanics (I don't know about the tides yet just after finishing the beta but I am looking forward to finding out more. I liked the "Effort"-system quite a lot where you get to influence your surroundings and conversations by spending effort-points that refill after resting. Quite often I chose the option not to fight when viable but rather use cunning - although the combat system seems solid. So far, I haven't found anything I dislike about the game - maybe the party size of 4 persons. The (possible) companions I've encountered so far (6 if I have counted correctly) were all very intriguing and had interesting backstorys or quests hinted at. Oh, and, at least for beta, the rebinding of shortcuts did not really work for me, it kept the old shortcuts active and triggered the action (e.g. quick saving) when rebinding the key to the new key and also allowed for a key to be bound to multiple actions but maybe that is a bug still to be fixed in the final release. Looking very much forward to the 28th, only a few more days!

content:
Posted: March 8
												The real problem with reviewing games that share aspects of the great games from the past, is that it is very difficult to judge them based on thier own merits. Its very easy to make comparisons and forget that ultimately, no matter how similar a game is to its forefathers it still has to stand on its. This is further compounded by the expectations and anticipations built up using a kickstarter.I helped fund this game via kickstarter 3 years ago. I read all of the updates, but didnt really play much of the beta. I ask myself a very simple question when I play these game. Am I having fun? For Torment, that answer is absolutely "Yes". Therefore I recommend that you play it. The environments, atmosphere, and story are all top notch. If reading isnt your thing, wait for it to go on sale before you buy it, but give it a chance. Would i have liked to see more NPC's? Yes. Is combat the weakest aspect of the game? Yes. Is it better than Planescape? No! (Dude, seriously, Planescape is amazing, looking back through the nostagia filter, Planescape shines brightest of all). But in no way is does Torment feel incomplete. rushed, or even inadequate. This is well crafted game, that runs smoothly on my 4 year old laptop  (GEFORCE 840M For the Win!).I truly enjoy playing this game.

Meanwhile, I have no problem playing any other games, on Steam or otherwise.  This game has been riddled with bugs since early access, and it doesn't seem to be any better now.The real-time-with-pause action that was promised was replaced with turn-based.  Why?  Because turn-based action works better for consoles, and the studio wanted to market the game to console players, rather than to the PC community alone. That'll teach me to buy into an early access game - lesson learned.
