content:
Posted: March 11
												I had to weigh in on this when I saw inXile begging for positive reviews and cherrypicking their feedback. They are playing themselves up more than they have a right to. The game is unfinished. It never met its promised baseline goals despite getting the money they asked for and more. It is not a "true CRPG," as they claim. It's a "choose your own adventure" / visual novel with most of what's going on existing only in words and not visuals... It just screams "low budget" and they had over $4M to do it. Seems like they spent it all on $10 words and purple prose. More kickstarter tripe... My full review is pending, because I still intend to finish this game. I'm a writer, so while I don't personally regret backing this game (some of the concepts they toy with are interesting enough), I just can't recommend it to people looking for a real CRPG. I'd send them over to Pillars of Eternity instead (by Obsidian). inXile has a history of releasing abandonware and half-baked games, like Wasteland 2, which still has lots of bugs, glaring balance issues, and just isn't fun to play, even after the Director's Cut was released. Over the past year, they haven't released any patches for it whatsoever... I'm not confident that this game will improve much with patches. By contrast, Pillars was refined and polished over a series of patches until it became quite an impressive addition to the CRPG legacy.

number of helpful: 18 of 30 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3
												Uhh... that's rather hard recommendation to give but I'm gonna recommend it despite the fact that this game is very much flawed - and that's recommendation only for people that already played Planescape: Torment. If you didn't - go play it now and if you like it and want more of it then consider Tides of Numenera.Why? Because Tides of Numenera is fundamentally an echo, imitation ... a castoff of true masterpiece. It has similar themes, similar structure, protagonist in similar situation and even some similar weaknesses (combat is weakest part of both games), but its just not as good. You can say that is what we wanted: another Torment, but at the same time I feel like this game could be quite a lot better if it would told its own story, something new, different and weird, something unique.So what worked and what didn't? Setting - both Planescape and Numenera are weird, but weird in very good way, both are colorful and exotic but also dark, twisted and cruel when they need to. So while I feel that Planescape with stronger focus on beliefs and philosophies is better of two, both settings are great.Cities - both games are very much city-centric and cities in Tides are just as great as Sigil. Definitely best part of this game is exploring Cliffs and Bloom (especially Bloom), talking to their inhabitants and solving their problems. Story - just as I wrote earlier  Tides of Numenera tries hard to tell similar story to PT instead of creating something unique. Effects are well... serviceable, but I doubt I will even remember it in few months. Thankfully side quests and conversations were well written and generally interesting.Companions - while I rather liked all companions i traveled with they are rather uninspired... I'mean you have that wonderfully weird settings and all of the companions are human? Why? PT gave us flying skull, succubus-turn-good, walking suit of armor and other just as unique personas... why in Tides we don't travel in company of mutants, sentient machines or otherworldy creatures with utterly alien perspectives on current events? Combat - combat was weak in PT... its actually even worse in Tides - at least  as mage in PT you have tons of interesting spells, most powerful of which even had their own pre-rendered cut-scenes. Here your abilities are boring, your opponents are boring and stupid, strategical depth is non-existent, everything is way too easy (and there is no difficulty setting) unless you are outnumbered and your opponents will be first in initiative and straight up murders half of your party before your first move. Its probably worst combat I've seen in any cRPG (with exception of some really low budget indie).Graphic - character models and effects (i.e. spells) are poor, backgrounds... some are quite good, some lack polish, few are weak. I don't want to compare Tides and PT because of age difference - so instead I'm going to say that Tides looks little worse than Pillars of Eternity or Tyranny, but still good enough.

The tidal system, consequences, even combat all seem like there were great ideas that fall short. number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8
												Pros:* While I'm not personally familiar with the table-top implementation, the Numenera world is pretty captivating and unusual in its portrayal of life among magitech ruins. The very purposeful sci-fantasy is, to my knowledge, a bit of a neglected one in video games, and there's a lot of wonder to be had here.* Not only is there very minimal combat (an exceptionally bold move given what most people think of as a defining element of CRPGs), but its implemented via a slightly abstracted 'Crisis' system that is used to cover non-violent but time critical scenarios as well, ranging from intervention in a rapidly degenerating diplomatic situation to conducting a heist. I am delighted to see an attempt to include and mechanize these more unusual sorts of situations that come up so often in table-top, but have been so often neglected in digital formats.* The core mechanics work very well in the early game. The world appears to change a bit with each rest you take, and so there's some incentive to avoid the infamous Five Minute Adventuring Day, trying to push your limited daily Efforts as hard as they can go. The push-your-luck core mechanic works well here, and it was the most engaged I've ever been in CRPG gameplay outside of combat and story.Cons:* At the end of the day, the writing and main plot just didn't work for me. It felt frequently overwrought, extremely awkwardly paced, and I just failed to develop an emotional attachment to any of the characters or situations. I'm the target audience for very wordy games, and even I found myself pretty bored and just wanting to skim through a lot of it eventually. More than anything else, this is damning.* While the early Sagus areas are fantastic, past this point it feels like the game got punched in the gut with the "ran out of money" effect harder than I've seen in any other CRPG. A lot of what's left feels like it was cobbled together from disjoint cut content. The second Hub area feels so much more by rote than the curiosity filled playground that was the first.* The abstract Crisis system just isn't very *good*; the combat encounters, in particular, just feel awkward and obligatory more than they are tense, tactical, or fun. Half the time they don't even matter anyway, to the immortal protagonist; on several occasions I died, only to find myself waking up such that I'd somehow bypassed what the encounter was guarding!* The dynamism of the game world due to resting ultimately proves to be very minimal, and sensations of urgency quickly recede. This is made all the more the case that as characters progress and specialize, the Edge mechanic ensures that they need invest less and less into tasks, where by the last third of the game even the most challenging tasks can be trivially accomplished at no cost whatsoever. My characters felt like they'd pretty much broken the entire system over their knee.* Despite the above, the game is full of mechanical traps. The gameplay and story extremely heavily emphasize the intellectual and social, which makes the fighter-type character class a total misfire; they excel only at the *maybe* the 8-12 violent encounters throughout the game, and even the rogue-type is better for all other non-combat purposes. Within the classes, little thought seems to have gone into anything like balance, with some abilities clearly orders of magnitude more useful than others.* The game's ending is, unfortunately, in the Ending-O-Tron format. Hardly a damning sin by itself, but I apparently chose the wrong answer, and rather than getting anything like an epilogue or denounement... I got a game over screen. Not even an achievement. As the final taste of the game, it left me sour that apparently they included the wrong answer as an option.* I was a Kickstarter backer, and there was a lot of content slashed and stretch goals walked back. I work in software, I know how it goes and I understand how that happens, particularly with the marketing frenzy that are Kickstarters. What is significantly less cool to me is that these changes were announced to backers only a month prior to release, far far after such choices would have been committed to. Given that level of communication and transparency, I do not expect to back another inXile title.Unfortunately, despite initially being greatly enamored with the game and even recommending it to friends, by the end the holes had begun to show in force. Ultimately, despite some high hopes, this title is a disappointing and unsatisfying experience, that was managed in a manner that I find unpalatable.

content:
Posted: March 5
												When i bought this game i was excited, i had waited for some time for it to be released.I remember the old planescape torment, and while it wasn't THE best game out there i did enjoy it and found the story to be intriguing.The same cannot be said for this game, while it seems a vast and lifelike game, i quickly realized that the game isn't actually that big, the areas are anything but lifelike, and it feels...."unfinished".Like it was supposed to be something better, something  bigger  but they ran out of time.The companions you get in the game seem very interesting, but after exhausting their initial dialogue offer very little besides that, all the items in the game have interesting uses and history, but on the other hand you find hardly any variety in armors or weapons.In fact there are only 6 light armors in the game, and they look  incredibly, hideously   UGLY For me, wearing armor that suits the look of the main character is important, i don't want to run around in shiny silver spandex shooting energy bolts at enemies.I could use heavy armor on my nano, but the penalties for that are quite staggering.The combat is nice, although primitive, most fights can be won other ways than fighting, you can avoid some fights alltogether by talking your way out.I was expecting a diamond in the rough like pillars of eternity, but instead i'm left with a zirconia, it's nice to look at, but it's not the same thing.EDIT: Forgot to add about all the game breaking bugs in the game, a few times i've had to kill the game from the task manager because it went completely unresponsive during a crisis (combat) and a few other times when something was supposed to happen during a cutscene, but instead nothing happened and the game was stuck endlessly in that cutscene.EDIT:To be fair, after completing this game, the story is the stuff of legends, whoever made the dialogue and made up the story and the lore is a keeper, he or she made some really good stories.  Unlike some developers nowadays *cough* *Bioware!* *cough*The execution of the game fell short and the game felt like it was missing something, the story itself almost makes this a positive review.... almost.

content:
Posted: March 16
												A game so steeped in it's own lore and import that it flows from wall of text to wall of text and disappears up it's own pretentious ♥♥♥♥♥♥.I bought this after Alec recommended it on Rock Paper Shotgun.Now I find myself hate-playing it just to try and get my money's worth from it.The combat is AWFUL. Just... AWFUL.Thankfully combat can be avoided at almost every turn.There are mechanics (like Tides) that the game vaguely references now and then, but 17 hours in, they haven't been actually used as far as I can tell.The inventory system just lumps everything together in one space, no ability to sort it by type, price, etc.The UI is funcitonal if not cluttered.A lot of the mod cons of questing icons and journals don't exist in this game. The quests are varied though, I'll give it that.And somewhat infuriatingly, every decision the player makes may as well be a random outcome generator for all the feedback you get. If you go to touch some slime on the ground it could either permanently boost your stats or kill you. But you won't know which until you give it a go!You character is a faceless gordon-freeman type with all the charisma and reason to care about as some gum stuck to a public bus stop.If you enjoy reading, get a book.If you're after a rewarding game, seriously consider playing anything else.I may append my review once I've finished hate-playing this drek. In the meantime though I'm going to make sure I ignore every recommendation Alec makes.

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												This game doesn't fail on a mechanical level, it's competent and offers a paint by numbers isometric RPG experience identical to the Baldur's Gate 1 + 2, Icewind Dale 1 + 2, Pillars of Eternity, and Tyranny. What it is not, is an adequate imitation of Planescape: Torment.The superficials are there, with walls of text and colorful characters, and the sheer strangeness. But the strangeness is hollow, the intelligence behind the strangeness of Planescape is missing.Party members have their one obligatory side quest that places their fate in the player's hands, but there is nothing about them to discover. A high intellect will not unlock any new conversations, change one's outlook on a character, or change the nature of the game.There is no Circle of Zerthimon. There is a Bronze Sphere, but unlike the original, which carried with it untold lifetimes of experience, this one summons allies, and is bugged. The piles of strange items in the game will not have any use outside of being worth cash. The point I lost hope for the game getting better was when I sold off all the "Oddities" in my inventory because I needed cash to install Wolverine claws on my character.The main character, from the model to the equipment is ugly. It looks like a default Poser model. During the beta, I thought it was a placeholder. The fact that it's made it into the final product is indicative of the standards that TToN set for itself.The game is not broken, it will not induce rage or fury, it simply exists. We are all mortal however, and anyone who played  any two of the above mentioned games, or played Planescape: Torment, will find nothing new here, and will be ~20 hours of their life poorer.Anyone who has not played previous Obsidian or InXile games will find an inoffensive experience, but is better off waiting for a sale.

content:
Posted: March 19
												Hardly an heir to Planescape Torment; and certainly no Baldur's Gate.  It doesn't get the gameplay basics right and its writing isn't enough to redeem that.Torment's writing is passable, though often much too long and complicated.  Few of the characters are compelling or memorable, and the setting doesn't in any way feel like a real place.  The issue here is that Torment's game mechanics are terrible, and the game has nothing but the writing to recommend it; that writing isn't good enough to do so.All of the game mechanics are BORING.  What difficulty exists largely comes from a lack of communication to the player about how certain systems work (what does this ability/skill do?  will it be useful?) and frankly antiquated and thoughtless design choices (you can't re-pick abilities; aren't you glad we didn't explain them very well?)It's 2017 and I'm really not very tolerant of long load times in order to read a paragraph of dialogue that should have been a sentence.  It's less about your money; don't waste your time.

Posted: March 5
												This game is a fraud and I would recommend against buying it.I go back a long time with Planescape: Torment, so I was ecstatic when I learned about the kickstarter for Tides. Naturally, I became a backer of this game during the kickstarter and eagerly waited to start playing it. Having finished the first playthrough, I am sorely disappointed. Before I explain why, I'd like to point out that this game is extremely text-heavy and players who aren't prepared to spend about 80% of their time reading should avoid it regardless of the reviews being positive or negative.My main source of frustration is the fact that the devs cut the content that had been promised in the Kickstarter project. I understand that this isn't rare regarding crowdfunding, but it is a scummy, dishonest business policy and borderline fraud which would prevent me from recommending this game even were it good, and it isn't. To give credit where credit is due, the game mechanics are pretty solid. From character development to the item system,  Tides of Numenera is a streamlined, yet complex RPG. There are some improvements that could have been made, but the game is very satisfactory from a game mechanics perspective. Still, Planescape: Torment's best and most important attribute was the story, and Tides is pretty weak in that regard. Firstly, the game is very short. My playthrough was pretty thorough, yet I was finished about 30 hours in. For a game which spent so long a period in development and whose Kickstarter was considered a major success, I consider anything less than 50 hours a disappointment, and I was hoping for something like The Witcher 3, where you could easily spend 100 hours.*the rest of the review contains spoilers*Leaving behind game mechanics, I will comment on the story from the perspective of the plot, setting and the underlying philosophy.The setting is bizarre and interesting and has a proper tormentesque vibe. It is based on a tabletop roleplaying game by Monte Cook, and I will gladly take the game up if I ever return to pen and paper gaming. At times the game was a tad too bizarre for my taste, but this isn't a major minus and many people will probably like it. The plot is a good fit for the general style of the game and the setting. Although it is nothing near to being spectacular, the small amount of story this game has is pretty good. What makes the game intrinsically bad is the superficial philosophy behind it, despite several neat touches, such as the Lascar side-quests symbolizing religion. The primary question, "What does one life matter?", is tied to the primary story in a very loose way. One problem is the fact that this question is very wide, especially in comparison to the question posed by Planescape: Torment, "What can change the nature of a man?" PsT's question was interwoven in the storyline and by the time Ravel asks for your answer you have had plenty of time to seedifferent perspectives on this problem. In Numenera, the question feels forced. If we ignore wild interpretations and the places where such a wide question is inherently linked to the standard fantasy themes, it is hard to see how it relates to the primary story beyond the two times it is directly asked. Even when it is inherent in some problem which often appears in fantasy games, it doesn't seem to be significantly more developed than usual. What I felt was the main philosophical point of the story is a rather lame bioconservative eulogy of death. In very short and simple terms, The Changing God is fighting to prolong his life and The Sorrow tells you that prologing one's life inherently harms other people, so it should be stopped. I don't think that there is an ending which is further from this philosophy than the one I chose, and in my ending The Sorrow and the Last Castoff agreed not to kill any castoffs at that time, but The Sorrow forbade the creation of any further castoffs and also promised to slaughter them later on. This kind of ending is highly unsatisfying, especially as I wasn't very interested in the internal castoff-changing god issues since I perceived The Sorrow as the primary enemy. Although I could say that I am a quite radical transhuanist on the issue of death, I would be more than interested to see a nuanced bioconservative argument in this sort of a game. The problem is that the argumentation present in Numenera is quite flimsy and reductible to saying that simply living is harming other people. Even this argumentation lies on a very symbolic reading of the Tides, but without it I would be hard pressed to find one developed central philosophical argument in the entire game. In that respect, the philosophy of the game is quite under-developed even if my interpretation is lacking. Of course, I am open to the possibility that I missed something, but I feel that the philosophical background of the game is simply bad. The solid but short story and mecahincs don't compensate for this deficit in my books.tldr; Regardless of the story, I wouldn't recommend Tides of Numenera because of the dishonest business practice regarding its Kickstarter project. The setting is great and the story and mechanics of the game are reasonably sound, although the story is very short. But the philosophical background, which is crucial for a Torment game, is lacking and that makes the entire game unsatisfying. Despite the negative review, the story and especially the setting are interesting enough to potentially be of interest if you could get the game at a significant discount, for something like 10-15$.

												This game goes full retard. Its too much fantasy for me. This amount of fantasy, i lose my touch with reality. If anyone watched the movie tropic thunder there was an awesome dialogue there. Kirk Lazarus: Everybody knows you never go full retard.Tugg Speedman: What do you mean?Kirk Lazarus: Check it out. Dustin Hoffman, 'Rain Man,' look retard, act retard, not retard. Counted toothpicks, cheated cards. Autistic, sho'. Not retard. You know Tom Hanks, 'Forrest Gump.' Slow, yes. Retard, maybe. Braces on his legs. But he charmed the pants off Nixon and won a ping-pong competition. That ain't retard. Peter Sellers, "Being There." Infantile, yes. Retard, no. You went full retard, man. Never go full retard. You don't buy that? Ask Sean Penn, 2001, "I Am Sam." Remember? Went full retard, went home empty handed...I have the Numenera tabletop rpg and it made no sense at all too. I was very sceptic about the campaign world technology are there but makes no sense, mystery is over exegerrated. Sometimes when you go fishing should just catch a fish. Sometimes a bartender should be just a bartender. A bar stool a bar stool, a drink just a drink. I love the original Planescape: torment. It is my favorite game. I was very enthusiastic about this game. I backed it as soon as i could. I never backed so much to any other game. I checked back to original torment again to see if im getting old? NoIt is just this game is really disappointing. Also combats are boring, i find myself im trying to avoid combat, not for roleplaying reasons, but because combat is boring and buggy as hell. Speaking of bugs. This is not an early access game, but it behaves like one. I'd definitely refund if i could. Now its too late. Let this game be a monument of how not to make a crpg.

content:
Posted: February 28
												[Edit: Finished game twice. Extra thoughts at end of Review]7 hours in to my first Post-release play through. I have only had one combat, but felt that it was avoidable, and that I may have narrowly missed getting in to a few scraps. The turn based combat is good; an 'all at once brawl like other games would not have allowed the Numenera rules to translate well.It cleaves closely to the source material put out  by Monte Cook games, so if you are looking for a good adaptation of the RPG you will find it here. I am unsure if I found the game easy to get into because it was well designed and the tutorial was clear, or if it was just that I have had experience running the table top version of this.It is early in the release, but I have encounter only a few glitches. Nothing game breaking. And ultimately very minor that I expect will be cleaned up in the weeks to come. No crashes, no Framerate issues, runs like a charm.The game has a great deal of depth. Lives up to the promise of many options and solutions to different problems. I have not felt forced in to a course of action - and if anything - was a bit overwhelmed by the freedom I have had in it. I am a huge fan of the Planescape setting, and of the forebearer to this game. The game took no time in bringing back the old feelings of the origional. Where I feel I need to search out every corner, carefully read clues, and am worried about even tossing away Oddities, incase they are useful later on.If you are a fan of Pillars of Eternity, Tyranny, or the original Planescape: Torment you will enjoy this. Things are well written, characters are interesting, Numenera captures that sense of bizzare and wonder that players had the first time stepping in to Sigil. I imagine I will have a great deal of fun exploring the Cliffs and other regions for some time, and I expect fans of CRPG's will feel the same.Highly recommended.[New Info]As of 1.01, the game still has some bugs. Only one of them caused me any real problems during my second play through.Having logged 50 hours in the game between two plays I stand by my statment that the game was very well done. I recommend it and as a backer I feel the main draws to the game were met.My play as a kind hearted but excited scientist yielded a much different game than my cruel monster of a character who solved things with violence. My first play was around 30 hours, the second a little more than 20. I feel that the second play had 10 hours chopped off it because I knew some tricks for some crisis that I had not known my first time, so it saved some momments. Also, second play through I wound up skipping a lot of side quest, mostly because my character was an huge selfish jerk. But there were lots of interesting twist and changes to the game because of this different play style.I am currently doing my third play through, of an appeaseing coward, to see how much of the game can be beat if I am avoiding all fighting and violence.

Posted: March 7
												Hello internet travelers!The new torment is a wonderful game. But I expected much more and I don't recommend it! Why? Bellow.The end confrontation/fight was ... funny at its best. The end reminded me of Guardian of the galaxy the movie. Build up build up build up and *LETS DANCE* as end fight :D No epic ending totally turned the Tides (LOL) for me.Story is great. There are choices/consequences. Athmosphere is dark mature grotesque even. But that is it. Combat (to my humble opinion) is crap. I don't mind turn based combat but in Torment: Tides of Numenera there are no tactical choices no variety enemies or encounters. Yes you can talk with your enemies, but other than that blunt and repetative. For a RPG veteran like me (who loves a good fight) it was just lame. Torment 1 had bloody animiation and films for spells! And hell lot of weapons.  Here you get few skills IF you are lucky and Itemisation is terrible. Few weapons and armors. Tons of one time use items. The game's strenght is NOT combat or cisises. Companions are OKish, not too great not too bad. But nothing memorable (again personal opinion).The main antagonist or antagonists are almost until the end with no backstory and even when directly confronted the explanation for WHY and WHO are not not enough. *I am sorrow and I am ancient and I am bad but I am bad to prevent other bad people to make bad things*Almost no voiceover! I love reading but voiceover in 2017 is a must for a game. Especially one that much anticipated.Game is 40-45 hours of playing at best. For the price of tripple A title.That are just few of the things I didn't like about Torment: Tides of Numenera.Again a wonderful game BUT a terrible successor to the first game. 6/10

content:
Posted: February 28
												It's finally out. After seeing where this game was heading in early access, I believe this game deserves a thumbs up and quick first impression of the more polished final product. Will update it later.First I'd like to point out the controller support. It works great! Of course, it's not the same as a game inherently designed for a console, but considered its PC roots, it's as good as it gets, and when you get to also move your character with the thumb-stick, instead of pointing him where to go, it adds even more immersion. I was also glad to find an option for even bigger fonts, so reading all that text won't be a trouble for anyone on any supported screen.The tutorial segment was reworked to be shorter, though I didn't find it's older version as overwhelming as other people claimed, I suppose that change is quite an improvement to the pacing.The loading times improved dramatically and the game feels way more lightweight and optimized than PoE or Tyranny. People with old/low-end machines have nothing to worry about, the game works like charm on my Core2Quad, 4GB RAM, 1GB Radeon card.As for the game itself, I think it's gorgeous so far, won't go into details yet, but from what I've seen in early access build and new game I just started, the only thing that might keep it from my personal GOTY rank is botched second half or the game, and if it gets better and better, it can easily become the game of the decade!

content:
Posted: March 1
												Not happy with the devs' choices to make the game turn based, give no option for difficulty levels, spend a large portion of their Kickstarter resources to release the game on PS4 and XBOX1 (which also comes with the consolization of certain aspects of the game), and have a sloppy-looking UI. The game isn't bad by any means and if there was a "one thumbs up one thumbs down" option I'd choose that, but seeing as there are a ton of short-sighted fanboys who will praise this game, no matter its faults and false promises of a "spiritual successor to Planescape: Torment", I think it's wise to balance out the game's score by pushing it towards a mixed score so the devs get a big hint. The game is good and if you want a well written "choose your own adventure", then definitely pick it up. But if you were looking for a tactical crpg which also had a well written world and story, then you will be unfortunately let down and your trust in inXile will be at an all time low. It seems that inXile don't have many true fans of the charming, challenging crpg greats (Baldur's Gate 1+2+Planescape:Torment) working for them, because they have greatly missed the mark with both this game and after seeing Wasteland 2's overt faults.

Posted: March 19
												This is the only game I've ever had refunded on Steam. To call it an RPG is a stretch, at best. It's a choose your own adventure in graphical form. The combat, on the rare occasion that it happens, is flavorless and utterly unsatisfying. The story seemed decent enough, but one has to navigate endless walls of text to get to any of it. What could be said in two sentences is instead spread over three paragraphs in two different conversation branches. I get it, there's nostalgia for the old IE games, I loved them too, but part of what made those games great was there was story AND gameplay. I WANTED this game to be good so badly. Instead, I paid $45 for a poorly illustrated graphic novel that droned on and on about mundane details.

Posted: March 18
												Honestly, even setting aside that this game fell ridiculously short of being any kind of successor to Planescape: Torment, it's still just a bad game.  There's tons of half-written stories that don't go anywhere all around you.  Tons of characters, objects, areas, etc. that are described in somewhat interesting detail, but have bland 90s era graphics "representing" them.  Characters that either don't feel adequately explored, or have a bland, forced, linear exploration.  Areas with random obnoxious noises firing off in the background.  And topping it all off is a combat system that's an absolute wreck.I was somewhat wary of this game after playing Wasteland 2 and it was still a major disappointment, to the point that after several attempts I'm just giving up on playing it.  Considering the way InXile has handled their kickstarters (Here's a tip, if you claim to be making a successor to a game I'm going to assume you're using similar mechanics.  If you then have a "vote" and it's decided to change said mechanics to something a sizible portion of the fanbase obviously doesn't want you should offer the rest of us our money back) I won't be supporting any of their other products, and will be recommending others do the same.

content:
Posted: March 11
												I wanted to like the game a lot. And while the story and environments are very interesting, the game is essentially an interactive novel. Most of your time will be spent simply reading and exhausting all the conversation options and then reading some more to just keep the quests ticking over. Combat is turn-based and can be a chore when fighting a lot of enemies at once as you wait for all the AI moves to complete. I've played as a Nano (wizard) and the abilities are so underwhelming. There's very little sense of progression with levelling up bar maybe some tasks becoming easier, if not much more interesting. The mechanics of spending points on certain tasks to ensure success doesn't offer much anticipation of levelling like other RPGs do with tangible increases to your character's stats and abilities. I was a huge fan of all the old-school isometric RPGs and thoroughly enjoyed the recent Pillars of Eternity and Tyranny, but Torment Tides of Numenera is a hugely different experience. It's an experience I'm finding increasingly difficult to see through to the end.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								At their best, video games are interactive stories. They allow us to participate and meaningfully change things, not just observe the narrative. Some games rise above the rest in this regard.Torment: Tides of Numenera may be the best I've ever seen.Some of you like running and gunning FPS titles. This isn't one. If you're an MMO player who follows the map arrows and never reads why you're tasked to do what you're doing, this game may not be for you.If you love a well written story and want to immerse yourself - and immerse is the right word - in a mysterious world with exquisitely written, branching choices with real impact? You have come to the right place. Where careful reading of the text matters. Where there are no map arrows telling you where to go or what to do with a linear, chain of breadcrumbs quest. Instead, you're rewarded for paying attention. From logic puzzles to not even a single "kill X, pick up Y" quest to the stupendous writing that draws you further and further into the Ninth World, this game amazes.At time of writing, this is an Early Access beta title with only the first city playable. There are a few broken side quests and a couple bugs, which you're warned about up front. They're putting the final polish on the rest of the title over the next ~7 months. Take negative reviews mentioning performance or bugs with a heaping pile of salt, because those are disclosed up front and won't be there on release. Simply put, I can't wait.

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8
												I wanted to love this game. I loved Planescape: Torment. I wasn't going in to this expecting it to BE Planescape: Torment, but I did hope to go in thinking it would be better than this. When I first found myself disliking parts of it, I thought it might be nostalgia, but upon careful consideration, it simply has a number of flaws I can't overlook.My first major problem? It feels like it cut off about 2/3 of the game. We were just starting to see things tie together, but the game suddenly just outright explains everything to you and begins the trek to the endingtron 3000. Thanks, Tides, I was getting interested there for a moment.Storywise, it's okay, if heavyhanded. I hate saying it's just okay: there are a few flashes of brilliance, where someone obviously took a lot of time and effort to craft something. But these are few and far between. There are only so many ways you can say, "Look at this thing that was made by an ancient civilization. You don't understand it. You can interact with it a few times. Move along now." That's a trick you can pull a few times, but if you're going to do it with every interaction, you need to at least do it in a different way. The underlying question is something strongly undercut by not seeing the outcomes of your choices.Companions. There's Rhin and there's everyone else. The others didn't engage me at all. Two are vaguely interesting conceptually, but so little is done with them that you might as well have had self-generated characters. Rhin, on the other hand, is well done. She's a little girl that got lost from another world, with only part of her memories, and is being treated as a slave when you arrive. By little girl, I mean, she's an 11-year-old with no character class. She's not some psychic powerhouse, she's the weakest character in the party. She essentially makes your 4-person party into 3 people. She's also the only character that feels like she has an arc at all. She has several different paths through the game, all of them are bittersweet, and if you don't think so, you are wrong, have a broken emotion machine and bad opinions, you emotionless husk.Mechanics: You'd best be here as a sightseer, because otherwise the game fails, hard. First, the good: the system itself seems interesting, something a better game could do a lot with. You can get past most of the game without combat, which is always nice when an RPG can accomplish. Combat is really a type of "crisis", which means that encounters works much the same way if you're sneaking through an area or swinging your sword.The bad: the balance is all over the place. After the first two hours, if you carry a balanced party, you will never fail at anything. Actually, even if you carry an UNBALANCED party, you'll probably never fail. I ignored one of the stats altogether. There was one combat near the very beginning that I had problems with, after that, I don't think I failed a single thing. You're encouraged to get rid of your cyphers, but since they're mostly one-shot and you never know what you'll need, I don't think I ever used one.There also didn't really feel like there were enough encounters. Maybe that's a function of the lack of difficulty, but there really felt like I should be in crisis mode more frequently, even when I wasn't in combat.tl;dr: I'd pick it up on sale. I don't regret kickstarting it, but it's too short to pay full price. My biggest fear is that this will ensure there's never another game. The idea is that there's an underlying philosophical question you, as the player, are answering by playing the game. I think that's a good concept. The fantastical setting helps by ensuring that we're not grounded on our normal ethical compass. If you come across elves and orcs in a game, you have a good idea of who the good guys are. In Torment, not so much. It lets the game designer ask more complex questions without tipping their hands, and you can see that they're attempting it during Tides.  If you come across a race of cannibals, are they evil? What if they don't kill anyone, but eat parts of them afterwards to ensure their memories survive? To bring closure to their families? To solve a murder spree? What if you come across a race that's lost their way home, and you have a clue that could help them? Seems good, right? What if their ethics said that privacy was too important, and that you'd have to break someone's privacy to answer it? What if, on top of that, they were better off not going home, anyway? What if you had to feed someone from the second race to the first one to help them get home?Planescape: Torment did a good job of this. This game tried, even succeeded at times, but the mechanics and story brought it down at the end.

Posted: March 6
												Overall I am very disapointed in the game.I haven't been able to even finish the game, because of a game breaking bug, where my all of my save files load with the game zoomed in and you are unable to move the character.  This happened twice.  I restarted after the first time, but not the second.There was a massive amount of content that was paid for by kickstarter backers (which I was one of) that was cut from the game.  The combat is mediocre.  The overall story and world are interesting, but the actual dialog seems lackluster.  The setting/background/visuals are amazing.  The music is well done and is enjoyable.  The character models and animations not so much.  The voice acting is terrible and seems random when it comes in.  Important characters you'd think would have their dialog voiced only sometimes have one line.  I do not recommend this game.  It has tons of bugs, a lot of them that break the game, making it unplayable.  Tons of cut content, mediocre gameplay, and lack luster dialog, along with a $45 price, make this game not worth buying.  If the developers fix the terrible bugs and the game goes on sale for a third of the price, then it might be okay to pick up.

Early Access Review
								I tried the beta release and it was the best RPG I have ever played. It starts of slow and hard to understand and follow all the magical world but as you get into the game you feel more and more involved as you start to feel how much your choices matter unlike in other games where you just make raw decisions and they play out a little bit differently (mass effect). At first I wasnt reading all too much but later it really gets you so involved that it compels you to read all and it doesnt feel like a chore at all. The best thing about this game is that it is not like other rpg whatever mmo grindy things which just feel like a chore while you play because you really can enjoy it. Combat system is amazing, all new interesting ideas based on traditional solid d and d. Graphics are nice, story really interesting. Idk it is hard to find wrong things.

												An awesome game that has plenty of role-playing opportunities for your character. The world is jam packed full of lore that is well presented, with many memorable characters. If your not into reading text, it probably isn't the game for you. Those of you who have played it's spiritual predecessor "Planescape: Torment" will know what to expect. content:
Posted: March 7
												I'm at 12 hours in the game and I just left the first map. I played games like this decades ago and it does fill a nostalgic itch. I'm not 100% happy with it though.For a game that is supposed to be about a story I don't find the one that came with it great. The side quests are nice and interesting and I think they're interwoven with the main plot yet the primary quest doesn't pull me in, or perhaps it hasn't yet. It feels like the primary quest is there just to give the game progress. It's so uninteresting. After just finishing Tales of Berseria and having experienced a game story that makes you get in an eternal "one more save point" spiral just to see what happens next this one feels pointless in comparison.Again, 12 hours in and I still don't get why I should be searching for the McGuffin. The main character, the Last Castoff, is so mediocre. According to what I've seen already there are thousands, maybe millions, of castoffs. Aside from being "the last" what the heck makes the main character special? Why does it seem like the main character compelled to do the things she's doing when the other castoffs are just taking their sweet time living (or dying) normally. The answer cannot be "because she's the main character" because that's just silly.Overall it's not a bad game. Graphics are nice, sounds are fine, gameplay is good, etc. It's just that the main story didn't get enough attention from the developers. It's like everything else has been done lovingly but the main plot was just slapped in at the last minute to tie everything together.Maybe my opinion will change once I progress further but right now I'm dissappointed. I do not know how much the game will be improved by the developers (like some enhanced edition or something) but right now I cannot recommend this game. InXile marketed this game as the spriritual successor to Planescape: Torment and it shows that they really tried hard to emulate it but unfortunately they missed the mark in the story department.On a different note I would love a modern remake of Planescape: Torment.Update: After finishing the game, I really don't know why I pressed forward to finishing it. You could see most if not all of the endings simply by just playing from the last save point. That makes it have zero replayability. Perhaps one could play it with a different class but that would only change the way you go thru the crises and the small & inconsequential decisions you make, and those things are so dull. It's just a matter of getting 80% or more in the early parts. Around half of the game getting 100% with lots to spare without resting is so easy!I guess it's just not for me. Obviously others like it but if you're looking for a good and memorable story don't bother with this.

content:
Posted: March 4
												Full disclosure: I backed this sucker on Kickstarter three years or so ago at an amount that puts me in the game under another name ($150+).I feel like I should correct a few misconceptions about this game. First, it isn't an action game--if you want tactical combat, or just a lot of combat period, this is NOT your game. This game is designed so that fighting is a distant second option to other methods for resolving conflict. There are very few necessary fights, and most moments of conflict are obviously intended to be resolved via other methods, including lying your face off or doing favors for NPCs. Second, it isn't a 'quick' game--if you dislike reading, or just want something that you can sit down, play for a few hours and not have to think about, remember, or otherwise engage in contemplation, this is NOT your game. This game is designed to be intensely story-rich, which requires a certain amount of effort from players. And in fact, this game almost predominantly balanced toward story and environment, over almost all other concerns. The story itself is extremely rich, thought provoking, and intricate, and in order to fully experience and enjoy it, players are going to have to do a ton of reading, thinking, and remembering. Think of it as a particular style of game, where on the one end we have games that are primarily about reflexes and short term memory, and on the other end we have games that are about long term memory and contemplation.Third, as a creative effort, it simply cannot be exactly as predicted for backers--stick with me here. This is something people generally wouldn't know, unless they work in a creative industry, but whenever you engage in a creative effort, there is always a degree to which the result will deviate from your original direction. The more artists you have working on something, in a general way, the more divergence you will tend to have. This game was the child of around twenty established and/or well known fantasy and science fiction authors, who tackled stories, characters, and ideas. As such, it was pretty much going to deviate. I've been following the development for three or so years now and been active on the backer's forum, suggesting story ideas, approaches, and soundtrack ideas, all of which are yet another source of deviation. The result is not exactly what they promised us. Instead, we got something really, really interesting that has many of the promised characteristics, and in several cases even more than was promised us. I'd be first up, yelling about those discrepancies if it wasn't PAINFULLY obvious that the game's writers, artists, directors, and coders worked their butts off getting us a product that is incredibly polished, if slightly different than promised. They very obviously used my money, and the money of other backers well, and if it took a long time... well.... * shrug * they delivered.Fourth, this is a direct heritor of PlaneScape: Torment. That was a request made so repeatedly on the backer's forums that I would have been surprised if it hadn't been. If you played the original game, this isn't set in the same universe, but the UI, the way characters react, the way scenery is pieced together, and the way you're expected to interact with the game is going to be very, very familiar. It's a top down, heavily story driven, philosophical, often bizarre little masterpiece, and this game, like its predecessor, is going to be a cult favorite. I'm just hoping it has enough success to encourage the publisher to do more like this.Fifth, and finally, not a few of the changes are a direct result of requests on the backer forums. My suggestions all made it into the final product, as well as a good chunk of the ideas I saw others contributing. If it is changed from their promise, that is at least partially due to the feedback of backers over the years the game was in development.Right, having said all this, I feel like I should be somewhat critical of the game......Hmmm.Uh, let's see. The combat is clunky, but I'm fairly sure that's intentional, since you aren't supposed to fight most of the time. The story can be a little bit obtuse, but if you read things closely, that shouldn't present a problem most of the time.  The top down view in a complex environment can be somewhat overwhelming, but holding down tab will highlight everything you can interact with in the environment (as in PlaneScape: Torment). The game script is, no♥♥♥♥♥♥ reams long, and you'll have to get comfortable with reading for tone and implication to really get the most out of it. The puzzles, for the most part, are set at knowledge you'd get in high school art or physics, but I feel like that's not a terribly high bar. The price is high, but not nearly as high as AAA developer games.Yeah, you know what? I don't really have a lot of bad things to say about the game. Just be aware, if you buy it, that you're going to need to think alot, read alot, and explore alot, and you should be fine.

content:
Posted: March 12
												TLDR: While I really liked the story, I felt like I was not playing a game, but watching a tediously long movie where I had to manually move the protagonist between event locations and through dialogue.There is barely a "game" here. The choices the player makes don't really have an effect on the story and don't create any plot branches or alternate paths. It's an extremely linear story with the guise of choosing an end when you get there. To top it off, it's clear they spent too much effort on the story at the expense of gameplay. It's too easy to avoid almost every combat. While I appreciate alternate ways to solve situations, if I am not forced into conflict somewhere the game gets really boring fast. By the end of the game I was attacking people I wanted to help because I was tired of reading text and tired of not having much combat, just to break up the monotony.There are no difficulty levels and every combat was trivially easy so even if you do choose combat as a solution for various circumstances, it's not all that satisfying most of the time. Since combat is not necessary, I also found myself picking up loot thinking "this is cool but when will I use it?".There were a couple of interesting mechanics I want to call out. The first is the "effort" system where you have an effort pool for each of the three stats. You expend effort to increase your chance of success on skill tasks. Unfortunately, I found it trivially easy to succeed at every task in the game without ever worrying about my effort pools. It an interesting idea but not balanced well.The other cool feature are "crisis". Basically it's a "combat or alternative solution" mechanism. You enter a turn-based mode, but often times there are solutions beside just attacking. Sometimes you can talk to the enemy and try to negotiate a peaceful solution. Sometimes sneaking past is an option. There are also some other interesting combat-oriented "crisis" events with devices to activate to protect you or hurt the enemy.But, before I leave you to decide, I will reiterate that the story was very good. If that's all you care about, you may very well enjoy Tides of Numa Numa.

												Another classic FRP / RPG piece, if you are a lover of these genres this is for you, but the turn based combat is NOT for everyone, I for one hated it and as a backer of this game I voted hybrid gameplay but somehow they managed to get the game to be made turn based only, it kills a lot of the fun for me but the story makes up for it. Definitely play it if you are a seasoned role playing game player, it takes a bit getting used to to get really into the story due to the original game system but after that its classic FRP / RPG for you. The problem is you cant customize your characters apperance, the shops in the game give you cancer, money is a big issue and you can simply talk you way out of every situation. Dont be fooled by the fact that they gave a lesser rating to Tyranny, that game is what we need, not this seriously not this.

												An amazing game and a true successor to "Planescape: Torment", I enjoyed using my character's skills or knowledge to solve problems far more than getting into a dozen similar fights. Hell, even if you do get into a fight you can still talk enemies down or use the environment to get rid of them. And there are so many ways to get upgrades for your Might, Speed and Intellect pools. Wether it is going through Meres, using items that may seem like vendor trash or completing quests in a certain way. So yeah, if you enjoy old-fashioned isometric RPGs (and especially the original Torment), you'd probably love this too. I only wish the game were longer...but in this case I feel like inXile did a good job with leaving me wanting more.

Regardless of what was envisioned, but not delivered; was promised, but then changed; sounded cool, but didn't work out; was underdeveloped, over-cooked or simply not to ones liking.For what it went out to do (succeed Planescape: Torment), it is not only as close as we can get to it today, but a very good game, indeed. (It's very good, overall, though.)For anyone waiting a long time for anything like Planescape: Torment.

content:
Posted: March 4
												First, I'm a  big fan of cRPGs but I never played the original Torment Planescape. I also didn't really follow the kickstarter campaign, so was largely unaffected by the cut stretch goals which seems to have caused so much bellyaching and ranting online.So, do I recommend this game? I'd actually like to say "maybe" rather than yes or no.The short version of my review is: If you think of it as a visual novel, you'll probably enjoy it. If you want some action, look elsewhere. Tides of Numenera is a game that is brimming with creativity and interesting ideas. For example, the character that you play, The Last Castoff, is basically immortal. So in the vast majority of cases, "dying" isn't the end. In fact, dying can sometimes even be beneficial! This means that save scumming is never necessary, and you can just go with the flow. I don't want to get into too much detail (since that would be spoiling) but suffice to say that the companions are memorable, the places you visit scenic, and the overall story about the Changing God is well-crafted. However, despite the strong story aspects, I think that the weak combat system really holds this game back. First, there's actually very little combat overall. No random encounters, no trash mobs, nothing whatsoever outside of quest/boss fights. Wanna test out your new abilities? Sorry, you'll have to pick a fight during a quest. And even then, you can basically talk your way through almost ANY situation, so even boss fights are optional. I just think a little more action would have been a nice break between all the dialogue, and made the overall experience more balanced. As it stands, most of the gameplay is running between NPCs who want mcguffins and favors. And let's say you DO manage to get into a fight. It's a bit of a slow and clunky system. There are no formations, and you can't place your characters before combat. Really bad if you're playing a mage, because if all the bad guys happen to hit your PC on their first turn, you lose. And the game tends to throw enemies at you in large groups, so just waiting to cycle through everyone's turns takes really long. (For example, more your 4 characters, then you have to wait for 6-7 enemies to move). I finished it with 23 hours on record, so that should give you an idea of its length. I encountered one bug (a loading screen crash) which didn't stop be from finishing the game, but did prevent me from going to one area. Hopefully this will be fixed in a future patch.

content:
Posted: March 9
												Where to begin. I backed this game on Kickstarter at the same time that I backed Pillars of Eternity (2012). PoE was released about three years later. Torment, meanwhile, was released two years after that. Given the millions of dollars it received from Kickstarter and the two extra years of development, I was expecting a game that not only matched its predecessor, Planescape: Torment, in depth and detail but exceeded it. Instead, I was left with a final product whose status as a worthy successor to Planescape was mostly illusory. The game also failed to measure up in most (but not all) ways to Pillars of Eternity and even some of the older but classic isometric RPGs such as Baldur's Gate. But let's break it down. The first "act" of the game, which composes about ⅓ of the total game, really impressed me. Sagus Cliffs was designed with such detail that it blew Defiance Bay (PoE) out of the water. Where Defiance Bay's design felt oddly inauthentic and lifeless due to its bizarrely clean, overly-perfect, wide avenues and promenades, lack of population, and total lack of anything unique or interesting, Sagus Cliffs felt alive and like there was something neat around every corner. And that's a big achievement, I think that should not be overlooked. This ⅓ of the game had me thinking of Sigil from Planescape, Amn from Baldur's Gate II, or even some of the wacky but fascinating cities of Final Fantasy IX or VII. It felt like a homecoming in a way; back to the cities of the games I played as kid. The characters and party members also seemed pretty promising at this point, as there was a fair amount of dialogue and intrigue involving them.  I thought it would be fascinating to watch their characters develop (with perhaps a romance even?). I thought the city would be a neat place to return to late-game. I thought there would be further, late-game quests to do with the people and organizations I met early on that would yield powerful artifacts, abilities, and new insight into the lore and history of the Ninth World. I wanted to explore the area outside the city, and generally delve deeper into the story of it, it's inhabitants, and history later on. But none of it happens. Once I caught that airship out of the city I could never return, and all the quests I failed to complete would be forever lost, along with the most interesting part of the game. That was the first bad feeling I had. Then, not long after my abrupt departure from Sagus Cliffs, I was met with my second disappointment: the second act. Where the first act arrived with detail, history, intriguing characters, stories, quests, items, beautiful scenery, the second act more or less just showed up. Or phoned it in, rather. It was essentially a glorified checkpoint with little to do or see that was actually interesting. A few things here and there advanced the stories of my party members, but they were mostly silent through this act, their personal dialogue trees exhausted, and their commentary on the overall story virtually nonexistent. Thankfully, this act was also pretty short and quick, aside from the agonizing combat, which I'll get to later. So I didn't focus too much on its flaws and foibles and eagerly moved on to act three. Thankfully, the third act came close to matching the first in quality. There's a lot to do here, but mostly in terms of minor side quests that yield relatively underwhelming rewards. Did I like taking a portal to a space station? Sure. Did I get anything useful or interesting out of it? Was it tied to the rest of the story in any meaningful way? No, and aside from an inert ball I got to take with me that serves to tell me where I am at any given moment, I had nothing to show for the quest, which seemed exceedingly promising when it started. In addition, my party members hadn't seemed to recover from whatever torpor the second act placed on them. They remained mostly silent, aside from a few comments and quips here and there. I was able to complete a few more dialogue options, but they didn't really have anything interesting to say or do, and if they had anything for me to do it was relatively trivial and boring. Admittedly, I was happy with how Rhin's story played out in this act, but I can't say the same for the others. Despite the gorgeously rendered landscapes and artwork, and despite the fascinating setting, I was once again left wanting more. Once again, I left the setting of the third act without the ability to return. The game was pushing me in a relatively linear path. I was essentially playing a book, one that left you feeling like it wasn't quite finished yet. And after the third act, there was a quickly wrap up and conclusion that at least answered some of the outstanding questions, but did little else. And that's the real problem with Torment: the world, the setting, and parts of the story, are fascinating. The game inside that setting is significantly less so. It's unpolished. Unfinished even. It gives you a taste of a fascinating, fantastical world, and then the curtain falls and you realize there's nothing more beyond that taste. I mean, some of the most interesting events of the game essentially happen in your imagination thanks to the whole Mere system. Not in the game, your imagination. You don't actually get to see them, and your ability to interact with them and control them is incredibly limited. I don't want to complain too much, because the art was beautiful and it's a neat idea for these types of isometric RPGs, but it just felt like certain events warranted more attention. So what of the effect of your choices on the game? Pretty minimal. There are a few obvious ones that affect your companions, but pretty much everything else didn't matter. Even when certain characters died in the third act's final crisis, there they were in the concluding fourth act, still breathing and without so much as a mention of their death a mere minutes before. The combat was pretty lackluster. I think some people prefer turn-based combat to the real time combat of PoE or Baldur's Gate, but I'm not one of them. It's just too slow. The whole system is painstakingly dragged out. I had issues with the combat in Shadowrun: Returns, but at least the combat there had more to it than being essentially just a game of numbers. What's more, there seems to be a lack of interesting abilities or opportunities to use them. I more or less used the same tactics in the beginning of the game as in the end of the game. My equipment was virtually irrelevant too, aside from the damage and resistance modifiers on weapons and armor. I bought one set of armor the entire game, and couldn't really identify a moment where I received an item I was really impressed with. There is no lore or history to the items you find, and most of them are useless trinkets only good for selling. Finally, the graphics. Wow. Ok, I've already said several times the backgrounds and scenery are mostly really well done and gorgeous. But the characters and some of the companion portraits? The actual moving pieces? Kind of horrible. Almost like they were designed with the same technology as Planescape: Torment back in 1999. What's more, most of the characters have very little detail. Really, there is only ONE character in the entire game whose level of detail impressed me, and she only shows up at the end of the third act, and is not the main character or a compassion. What a waste. Additionally, the voice acting may as well have been nonexistent, there was so little of it. So what did it all leave me with? A question of where that $4.3 million in Kickstarter funds actually went. Apparently it created a 20 hour game with an admittedly fascinating world and gorgeous artwork, but with a very limited and linear story, underdeveloped characters, uninteresting combat, and relatively limited replayability, especially if you're someone who puts in the effort to turn over every rock and stone in an RPG.

content:
Posted: April 13
												People have basically said it all, so I won't say much except that were there many disappointments and some shady business/model advertisments....including early videos of neat things like portraits for ALL characters involved in dialogue, and more voice over work than ended up in the game...much revealed to only be in early "test" versions of the game which were not revealed as only test versions till a good time after official launch?  Yes to all of that....unfortunately, BUT...is the game still worthwhile, entertaining as all hell, and unqiue with an existential, Søren Kierkegaard, and even Kabalistic/Flower of Life...ish...kinda philosophical mash up/theme?  Hell yeah, and done well and not corny...imho.  A lot of negative reviews could possibly be butt-hurt kickstarter backers and people with legimate gripes like...promised Italian localization which was never implemented...etc, but all n all...great game that is somewhat light on combat, but if you WANT to engage in more combat the option is definately there.  For example, people might state that there are only 5-6 possible combat situations in Sagus (the first area in the game), but during my play through of Sagus, with determination of finding all the combat I possibly could, found well over or around about 12-15 combat scenarios.  Do you have to take a certain dialogue path to reach some combat?  Yes.  Can you avoid much of the combat in the game?  Apparently, according the the devs...noted post launch mind you, you are ABLE to avoid ALL combat if you try hard...they stated it would not be easy to do so, but that they intentionally designed the game so that this is a possibility.I have over 40 hours post launch in the game right now and am only in the second area of the game, but I am slow and enjoy taking my time exploring every nook and conversation.  Even clicking the NPC's without branching dialogues has some reward to it, so I do so.  Also, future updates will apparently clean up combat in some unidentified respects, AND add a kickstarter promised companion called something like "The Toy," or some such that tinkers more with the whole "Tides" aspect of the game which sounds interesting.  I know I said I wouldn't ramble, but there you have it, hard not to praise what IS present and good about this game.Sid

number of helpful: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13
												As a Plainscape: Torment fan and a Torment: Tides of Numenera backer, I will try to assess how Tides of Numenera measure up to their spiritual predecessor. Please note that I did not finish the game. The gameplay consists of exploration, dialogues, and battles: - Exploration is the standard fare. I feel that the Pillars of Eternity engine was well-chosen and the game is visually appealing, propelling you to explore every nook and cranny of the bizzare game world. - Dialogues are more engaging compared to a traditional cRPG, since having a certain skill is not enough for you to activate special dialogue options.  Instead, you and your companions will need to spend Effort. Effort is spent from a set of three pools (Might, Speed, and Intellect) that are replentished on-rest or via items. The amount of Effort you need to spend depends on your skills and on the chance of failure you are willing to accept. Overall, this mechanic makes dialogues feel fresh. Since writing was the cornerstone of Planescape: Torment, rest assured that no corners were cut here and the (numerous) writers that were involved with the game did a marvellous  job. - Battles (called “Crises”) are turn-based and heavily scripted. You may either use items and a wide array of battle abilities, gained as a part of character progression, to attack your enemies, or you may interact with the enemies and the environment instead. Actions undertaken during crises require Effort to be spent in a fashion similar to the dialogue system.  A minor complaint is that you may not control your characters individually outside crises, only the whole party; as a result, there is no way to position your characters strategically before a crisis begins. Otherwise, the battles are engaging and will certainly bring joy to the players who prefer turn-based over real-time-with-pause combat.As outlined above, I am fairly pleased with the individual aspects of the game.  However, a game is more than a sum of its parts and I feel that there is something essential missing here; something that made Planescape: Torment the exceptional game it is.Planescape: Torment (PT) was built on Infinity engine – the engine that powers the cRPG classics of Baldur's Gate (BG) and Icewind Dale (ID). However, whereas BG and ID feature complex character sheets, combat logs with dice rolls, and tactical combat controls, the user interface of PT is bare and all the dice rolling is happening behind the scenes without the player's knowledge. As a matter of fact, you would not know that Planescape: Torment is an RPG unless you knew its lineage, since it plays very much like a point'n'click adventure game; this is further supported by the easy combat (compared to BG and especially ID), heavy emphasis on exploration and lengthy (visual novel tier) dialogue over combat, and by the fact that the main character cannot die. The magic of PT is that you start the game thinking that it is a point'n'click adventure game, but during the course of the game you discover that there is real-time combat, choice and consequence, faction affiliation, alignment, character abilities, and more. Combine this with the fact that both the Planescape setting and the story of PT are weird and highly unpredictable, and you end up with a game that has you questioning its every aspect including the game mechanics – a feat successfully pulled off by few other games.Looking at Torment: Tides of Numenera (TToN), this aspect of PT is virtually lost. The complex character progression is in full sight and you are expected to spend a fair amount of time studying it. Combat is carefully separated from the exploration gameplay and turned into a heavily scripted minigame. As a result, there is no intrigue in the game mechanics, as all is laid out before you at the beginning of the game, and the exploration gameplay, which along with dialogues is where you will spend most of your playing time, is a plain point-and-click adventure game with no passage of time and with no danger to the characters.TToN is not a bad game. It is lovingly-crafted, ticks all the boxes for a good point'n'click adventure game, and the tactical combat sets it apart from the rest of the genre. Unlike PT, however, it spends too much Effort on polishing the individual parts rather than making sure that they combine into something truly exceptional. A classic example of missing the forest for the trees in my eyes. Still a solid game, though.EDIT: I will certainly update this review after I play the non-early-access content and finish the game.
