Posted: March 6
												I love RPG's and I'm not too picky. This however is really difficult for me to get into and I cannot recommend it uless it goes on sale. Usually the story grips me, so when the prospect of playing a meat bag of a god through use of technological wonders presented itself, then I grabbed it up.The reason I can't get into this title, and hopefully that will change, is because this just isn't a fun game. My interest in it also corroded when I began reading bad dialogue. People complain about the voice actors, but I liked most of the voices when they were in Tyranny, The problem is that there are some stupid dialogues in this game; at least in the very beginning.So this company makes good titles and I'm glad they put their foot forward, even if it didn't seem like it was their best foot. Therefore, I will try and rank current RPG titles and if you have the same taste as I do then hopefully this will help you better understand if you should wait for a 50% sale.1) Tyranny2) Wasteland 23) Pillars of Eternity4) (insert a RPG here)5) (insert a RPG here)6) (insert a RPG here)7) (insert a RPG here)8) (insert a RPG here)9) South Park Stick of Truth10) Planescape: Tides of Numenera

number of helpful: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8
												I kickstarted this game as soon as I found out about it after having kickstarted Wasteland 2 from the same developer. Numenera was a big name at the time and I was excited to play in that world.I just finished my first playthrough of this game, having completed every quest I found (except one, which I completed and which did not, for some reason, complete in my journal). While I do have some complaints about the title, I give this game two thumbs up. Pillars of Eternity did not set my character in the game world. Tyranny tried, but soon became boring. This game, on the other hand, drew me into the story right away.Before I go on, please note: This game is not Planescape: Torment. The developers touted that name in order to get people excited, and blowhards never figured out what "spiritual successor" really means, so there are a lot of people disappointed that this game is not Planescape. If you are expecting Planescape.. well, move on. This game will never be Planescape.Pros:+ Fantastic story with good pacing. At over 50 hours, I read everything, explored every item description, journeyed through every mere, and absorbed all the lore I could find. It was never a slog to read like Witcher 3 or Mass Effect 1.+ Weird setting. Numenera is all about the Weird. The tabletop RPG has a ho-hum system with some serious flaws, but most people enjoy the setting enough to put up with the system. Tides of Numenera rips the setting free and spares us the flaws of critical failures being as common as critical successes or average success. I don't want to spoil anything - if you're familiar with the Numenera setting, I think you will be happy with this game's use of it.+ Choice. Many conflicts can be solved in multiple interesting ways. A lot of games give you a 'choice' but it tends to revolve around cardboard morality, black hat/white hat tripe. Here is a game where you can speed through using the standard Bioware-type actions, or put some thought into your actions and discover really cool solutions that add to the story and setting.+ No meaningless combat encounters. Remember Baldur's Gate and having to fight wolf after wolf forever, regardless of your power level? The endless slog of going through dungeons without challenge, knowing you're going to annihilate everything in your path? All of the fights in this game make logical sense and none feel they were placed just to prop up playtime.+ Inventory that's part of the world. This intersects with setting a bit, but I can't stress how much I wish other games would take a lesson. Don't just give me a shiny new sword and leave the story up to my imagination. Tons of oddities and artifacts can be used and will present anything from puzzles, filler stories, meaningful narrative, to useful rewards. Quest items in most games are used once and forgotten, but many quest items can be used multiple times and often in interesting ways. Again, this makes sense if you know the Numenera setting. If you're only familiar with the old Infinity Engine games, make sure you're reading your item descriptions and checking what can be used.Cons:- Awful character customization. You are given no choice over how your character looks despite your gender. Devs tried to say it was because you are learning to live in a copy, but let's be honest here - if you pick a female, you're still interacting with a Changing God who is a male. There's no compelling reason I see that they would not allow you to customize your appearance except that they didn't want to take the time/resources to allow it. There is literally no part of your character's appearance that could not be customized and still remain plot-relevant.- Awful use of Descriptors. Descriptors are probably the coolest part of character creation in the Numenera tabletop RPG and this game does the absolute worst job it possibly could at picking fun ones for you to try. They could explain this away by giving you a flat Descriptor like the one Rhin uses, to explain the various powers you have from your progenitor. But they don't. They shoehorn in 3 boring descriptors that give you no awesome powers whatsoever. It's a travesty. - Sparse combat. If you love these games because you love tactical RPGs, I would stay far away. If you love min-maxing, I don't think this will scratch your itch, either. Combat is fleeting and you can play for hours without coming into a battle unless you push to instigate the few you find, especially early on in the game. What this means, really, is that you gain levels and are forced to choose several powers *before you ever really understand how combat works in the game.* Don't get me wrong, I appreciate not having random encounters with 15 wolves around every corner I turn - at the same time, exploring "dangerous" areas of the cities you explore feels exactly the same as exploring the safe areas. Also, combat in the tabletop RPG is fun, for the most part, especially because of Descriptors (see above). They could have done SO MUCH MORE.- Frustrating camera controls. While not a dealbreaker, because this game's combat becomes extremely easy later on... the isometric view combined with the way they use triggers means that sometimes you have the ability to walk further on a map, but you can't, because your pathing ends too close to a door or something else and you can't prioritize your walk action over interacting with whatever object is in the way. Related: some rooms that *look* symmetrical are not, as you cannot properly walk behind all walls equally, and sometimes one or two characters can block a hallway that looks wide enough for three or four.- Grammar errors. I can't remember seeing any typographical errors, but at times it felt like the entire script was run through a spellchecker and autocorrected rather than having humans read and correct sentences that don't make sense. It wasn't a huge deal, but when 98% of your game is reading, the reading should probably be polished, yeah?- Disappointing ending. I remember the first time I beat Rygar on the NES. The ending screen was just a short blurb of text. Fine for an NES game. When I beat this, I got to make a choice, but I was treated to the same - a short blurb of text. It was super vague and I learned nothing of anyone I had grown to care about while playing. I wanted to know if Zebb and Nym's father turned his life around and made their family happy again, for example. I wanted to see what happened to.. well, ANY of the playable NPCs. Granted, I only beat the game once as of writing this; maybe there are better endings if you choose a different option. I hope so, for your sake. But this game's ending made Mass Effect 3 seem like War and Peace by comparison, while this would be Cliff Notes for Green Eggs and Ham.- Lackluster companions. Okay, they weren't bad, and I loved Rhin to death. But they weren't anything close to, say, Baldur's Gate 2's chatty, loveable NPCs. And there aren't even enough to play a few times using different rosters (I think there should be at least 2-3 more companion choices). Meanwhile, they almost never interact with each other the way we've come to love (and expect) in our RPGs. They also very rarely comment on choices you make compared to other games. They are definitely a part of the scenery compared to the numenera and non-playable NPCs you'll meet, at least 90% of the time.I could probably come up with more pros and cons, but at this point you might ask, with such heavy cons, why would you still recommend this? Well, because I had fun. A lot of fun. And if you can live with the cons, and the pros sound good to you, I think you'll like it too. Happy playing!

content:
Posted: January 13
												As a Plainscape: Torment fan and a Torment: Tides of Numenera backer, I will try to assess how Tides of Numenera measure up to their spiritual predecessor. Please note that I did not finish the game. The gameplay consists of exploration, dialogues, and battles: - Exploration is the standard fare. I feel that the Pillars of Eternity engine was well-chosen and the game is visually appealing, propelling you to explore every nook and cranny of the bizzare game world. - Dialogues are more engaging compared to a traditional cRPG, since having a certain skill is not enough for you to activate special dialogue options.  Instead, you and your companions will need to spend Effort. Effort is spent from a set of three pools (Might, Speed, and Intellect) that are replentished on-rest or via items. The amount of Effort you need to spend depends on your skills and on the chance of failure you are willing to accept. Overall, this mechanic makes dialogues feel fresh. Since writing was the cornerstone of Planescape: Torment, rest assured that no corners were cut here and the (numerous) writers that were involved with the game did a marvellous  job. - Battles (called “Crises”) are turn-based and heavily scripted. You may either use items and a wide array of battle abilities, gained as a part of character progression, to attack your enemies, or you may interact with the enemies and the environment instead. Actions undertaken during crises require Effort to be spent in a fashion similar to the dialogue system.  A minor complaint is that you may not control your characters individually outside crises, only the whole party; as a result, there is no way to position your characters strategically before a crisis begins. Otherwise, the battles are engaging and will certainly bring joy to the players who prefer turn-based over real-time-with-pause combat.As outlined above, I am fairly pleased with the individual aspects of the game.  However, a game is more than a sum of its parts and I feel that there is something essential missing here; something that made Planescape: Torment the exceptional game it is.Planescape: Torment (PT) was built on Infinity engine – the engine that powers the cRPG classics of Baldur's Gate (BG) and Icewind Dale (ID). However, whereas BG and ID feature complex character sheets, combat logs with dice rolls, and tactical combat controls, the user interface of PT is bare and all the dice rolling is happening behind the scenes without the player's knowledge. As a matter of fact, you would not know that Planescape: Torment is an RPG unless you knew its lineage, since it plays very much like a point'n'click adventure game; this is further supported by the easy combat (compared to BG and especially ID), heavy emphasis on exploration and lengthy (visual novel tier) dialogue over combat, and by the fact that the main character cannot die. The magic of PT is that you start the game thinking that it is a point'n'click adventure game, but during the course of the game you discover that there is real-time combat, choice and consequence, faction affiliation, alignment, character abilities, and more. Combine this with the fact that both the Planescape setting and the story of PT are weird and highly unpredictable, and you end up with a game that has you questioning its every aspect including the game mechanics – a feat successfully pulled off by few other games.Looking at Torment: Tides of Numenera (TToN), this aspect of PT is virtually lost. The complex character progression is in full sight and you are expected to spend a fair amount of time studying it. Combat is carefully separated from the exploration gameplay and turned into a heavily scripted minigame. As a result, there is no intrigue in the game mechanics, as all is laid out before you at the beginning of the game, and the exploration gameplay, which along with dialogues is where you will spend most of your playing time, is a plain point-and-click adventure game with no passage of time and with no danger to the characters.TToN is not a bad game. It is lovingly-crafted, ticks all the boxes for a good point'n'click adventure game, and the tactical combat sets it apart from the rest of the genre. Unlike PT, however, it spends too much Effort on polishing the individual parts rather than making sure that they combine into something truly exceptional. A classic example of missing the forest for the trees in my eyes. Still a solid game, though.EDIT: I will certainly update this review after I play the non-early-access content and finish the game.

number of helpful: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25
												Hey Folks,First of all I would like to give a shoutout to all the wonderful developers over at InXile who made a bold attempt at bringing a true spiritual successor to one of the best RPGs of all time - Planescape Torment. The road to hell is paved by good intentions...I have been psyching myself up to do this review for some time now, it's been around a week or so since I finished Torment. Also, I would like to note that I have not been an original backer, though I did pledge around mid 2015 directly on the site. I am highlighting this to mark that I have not been emotionally involved in the Kickstarter process and have no idea about the stretch goals and the subsequent delivery on those. I have thoroughly enjoyed PS:T back in the days and loved Wasteland 2 even before the directors cut came out, which made all the better. Pre-game:I know it sounds a bit stupid, but the Main Menu screen looks like it has been done by High School student. It threw me off whenever I booted up the game. I very much enjoyed the way the game preselected a character type for you based on a series of answers and I actually ended up playing the proposed one. But the lack of appearance customization just plain killed me. I couldn't even choose a portrait!!!Graphics:I played on my work laptop with built-in Intel Graphics so I definitely did not have the chance to experience the full power of T:ToN. The backgrounds and environment looked gorgeous, though all of the characters - much less so. And for some strange reason the vast majority of NPCs are actually missing any kind of portrait. Combine this with poorly detailed models, zoomed out screen and literally walls of text you end up feeling like reading a book rather than playing a game. Imagination has to run wild, otherwise there is simply no connection. General Gameplay:I actually very much enjoyed the stat pool mechanic, it felt like an interesting and fresh approach. That said the balance is completely off, nanos rule supreme, majority of stat checks are Intelligence and you can actually brute force the rest just by having enough stat pool points available. I made my playthrough opting for a non violent route and I could I mostly got away with it safe for a few hard coded battles where I could actually resolve them in a nonviolent matter within the Crisis itself. But make no mistake, I did not like those moments or solutions as they felt forced and breaking the pace of the game. Combat:Speaking about the pace - any combat is just horribly slow. Every enemy turn took at least 4-5 seconds just to get them moving!!! Having a mage-like characters I never felt underpowered but I was dissapointed with the variety of spells and weapons at my disposal. And the cyphers were just plain dumb - I haven't used a single one during the game. Overall the combat felt like a last minute add-on on top of the game just for the sale of having it without any proper mechanic or item support. Story:The overall plot while not a revelation by any stretch of the imagination is decent with a nice twist or two. The companions however are a complete disgrace. There is no romantic interest, the dialogues do not get further than 2 levels down. There is only 1 quest per companion and even those are just solved almost automatically as you clear out the game areas. The dying mechanic - a cornerstone of PS:T is completely tagged on just for show. It's a struggle even just to get killed, but when you do - it's a small Labyrinth area with nothing to do there safe for a couple of 10min sidequests of kill/stun them allThe overarching plot itself is far too short, progressing in leaps as you move from one area to the other. I absolutely loved the depth of the world hinted at but T:ToN failed miserably in exploring it. All information is given in walls and walls of text. And don't even get me started on the Meres. They are just lazy game development. On one hand they require you to do tons of reading and tough choices, without hinting on what is a better/worse one and absolutely NO RETURN. That's right, you need to spend up to half-hour reading, hoping the stat pool check pan out, etc just to have zero impact back in the game. No perks or loot or anything. Initially I thought that after  you finish a mere the respective castoff would appear in the labyrinth. Nope. Interface:Is just plain horrible. The text is prevalent up to occupying almost half of the screen when in dialog. The inventory screen is dominated by the cypher section, which almost is useless. The amount of equippable slots on the characters is akin to an action/rpg and the inventory itself is showing no more than 2 rows at a time. Also, during the game you come upon a lot of items, called oddities, which are very confusing as what to do with them. Some you are able to use and even get a permanent bonus, others you can transform to artifacts, some you can actually use in quests.  So it's difficult to tell what you can safely sell. Which in the end is not that much of a problem since anyway there is little interesting to buy. Summary:However much I wanted to love it I was very much dissapointed with T:ToN. And it was made even worse because I saw that with just a few shifts in priorities in presentation and story it could've been so much better. The sheer amount of writing has come before everything else. Walls and walls of text meet you everywhere. If some of that effort was spent on expanding the item list, the skills and abilities, the companion quests, the portraits and overall locations  - it would have been a much more enjoyable experience. Queue: rotten tomatoes.

Posted: March 3
												This game is getting way more sh*t than it deserves. Some complaints are baffling: poor UI, bad portraits, too much text... Jesus, even the criticisms about combat, which is objectively kinda bare bones, are negated by the fact that fights are extremely rare and almost always avoidable, since the game - FOR ONCE - tries to focus on other kinds of interactions.Sure, there are some problems, and the niche nature of the game is bound to trigger a physiological reaction by people who genuinely didn't expect such a wierd and text-heavy game, but I feel like the bulk of the critics are KS backers who waited the release day to unleash their frustration about "cut content", the devilish console port and the absence of RTwP combat without even realising the fact that it represented one of the main problems of the original Torment or acknowledging that it was chosen through a backer poll.But yeah, thumb the game down, I'm sure we will get many opportunities to experience a game of this nature in the future thanks to such juvenile reaction about "oh so serious" and totally relevant issues.

Early Access Review
								Just a few thoughtsIt's better then PoE (Pillars of Eternity YOU ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥S!). It's more interesting. I don't say PoE is bad, but PoE texts were often sooooooo booooooring I wanted to skip them.TToN instead has incredibly interesting story and lore. I realy love every sentence of it and it has A LOT of them :)And I can't compare it with DOS, they are very different. But I can compare it with Tyranny which also has interesting story and very good voice acting. Comparing to it TToN has less voice acted lines. At least in this demo part of the game until it's released. One of the strong gameplay features of TToN which levates it over the rest is variativeness of your walkthrough. You can achieve your goal in many ways.And the story is the main and ultimate benefit here. Last time I was so interested in studying the game world was playing Planescape Torment. One billion years in future is coolest idea in a long time. Also games role mechanics feels fresh and not so dull as all those old classic ones. I strongly recommend this game, despite I REALLY HATE some of it's animations and idle poses (which are really poorly done) and lack of sound efffects, TToN is deffinetly worth of attention.

content:
Posted: March 15
												I highly recommend this game!  The world is very interesting, with very acute attention to even little details.  The environemnts are beautifully designed, every character you encounter has unique details about their appearance and personality, and the music is very well produced.  That does lead to a lot of text to read and does make the game seem to move at a slow pace, however.  I think some people may have had some expectations that this game would be "Planescape: Torment 2" and I'm not sure that the developers gave this impression when they claimed it to be a "spiritual successor."  I do believe their game does continue the philosophical themes of it's spiritual namesake.  If you are the kind of player that likes to investigate all the intricate details of a world or a story, this game is for you!

content:
Posted: March 4
												3.7/5. Not recommended at full price. It's still a decent and enjoyable game, just disappointing because it was supposed to be a successor to Planescape: Torment, and I am sad to say that I do not find it worthy. I backed Wasteland 2, Pillars of Eternity, and Tides of Numenera. This product has made me change my mind about backing this studio's future products.The setting and mood of this Torment is good and on par with Planescape: Torment, but the plot, writing, character development, and scale of this game pales in comparison. The crisis system of dealing with combat and other crises is quite innovative and enjoyable, but I don't recall having too many crises in my playthrough. My first playthrough took about 20 hours, which feels rather short, and companions did not seem to have hung around me long enough for me to get attached to them, and their development is also very stunted and abrupt. Also, they also seemed very one-dimensional yeah including *gasp* Callistege.A major part of the lore of this universe is the tides, which comes in different colors, and seem to be similar to alignments in other universes. I didn't notice if having a particular alignment impacted my first playthrough at all.The part I disliked the most was the epilogue. It's very abrupt and felt as if they couldn't get things done in time and just cut it out, cauterized the stump and sent it out.It's very ironic that calling this a pale spectre of its predecessor is perhaps the best way I can find to describe this game.

content:
Posted: March 4
												I've not finished yet, but I have to make a review now. I'm kinda motivated by my feels.Tides of Numenera delivers what I expected a good main story with rich interactions, deep characters. We are about to play Mass Effect: Andromeda and spend most of the game shooting at poorly designed aliens (it's supposed to be in another galaxy but yet it's full of biped humanoid races :')) with tumblr-written companions in a manichean plot self-centered on "MAH HUMANITY".Guys... Why would you ask for combats in this game ? I bled enough from the♥♥♥♥♥during the Eb fight in PoTD difficulty in Tyranny. I will do endless battle in Andromeda for fetch quests.Do I need to whine about the lack of challenging/reward combat system ? Hell no."Huehue. This isn not Planescape: Torment, huehue" Oh ? Really. Let me remind you my very first game of Planescape back in the days:>Be me.>Be 13 yo>Starts Planescape: Torment>Too lazy to read everying>Ends up in Sewer>♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by rats, starts fighting, get gangraped>Dies in 99% of the fight I started.>Uninstall this, blame the world for this♥♥♥♥♥♥tier rpg. Why was my first Planescape experience this bad ? Because I didn't read carefuly. I went full retard and tried to fight everything. Combat system was not elaborate, it was punitive as ♥♥♥♥ the only way I could enjoy Planescape was growing up and take my time to READ about Sigil and those characters.Tides of Numenera is exactly the same.This game is about a big story into a multiverse full of details and awesome discoveries (also cheesy ones :p). Don't cry because it's focused on the story. If you are a RPG lover, you can balance this with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ story-written game with c00l graphics and a lot of battle like Dragon Age: Inquisition ?You may be mad at inExhile because they didn't deliver what we all expected THE GOTY-MOUNTAINDEW-ACCLAIMED-REWARDSWINNING Gamu. But don't bash this game, it's a very good moment.I'm currently playing a deceptive/persuasive jack strongly golden in tides. It's a pure selfless kind-hearted cast-off and I encoutered an event in the game which makes me very proud of my choice. You can recruit a little girl, Rhin. She's held by a slave-master who is a cast-off. She uses Rhin as a ♥♥♥♥ing punchingball for her tides surges (which is cruel).If you get Rhin with you and free her from this sadistic ♥♥♥♥♥, you can leave Rhin at her fate, you can't leave her to some kind of orphenage (House of Empty Time), you can keep her with you till the very end... Or send her back to her home.During my adventure, I gave the Love she needed, I showed the importance of being selfless and helping people in needs. (Golden tides). I helped her to get back to her home. She hugged me and said me farewell.I was sad... I left the little girl I cared. She wasn't the greatest asset with her "stupid" god-rock and her unability to use weapons but she was a birght spark into this savage multiverse.And later... From a portal, gues who's back ? Rhin, as an adult. In an armor, coming to help me and telling me she has become something. Because of me, because of the bound of love. It may sounds lame & gay, quite stereotypical. But come on... She's the exact consequences of what I played with her.I feel like my choices with her, reward me... I regret nothing. Having her in my group instead of this dumb Erritis (who hit like a truck), trying to confort her under the pragmatical sight of Callistege etc...Thanks you inExhile for this moment. That was a great experience. And I've not finished the game yet.I have to say for the very first time I've played a CRPG in my mother tongue (which is french) because the translation is quite good. Really. Nothing looked awkward when I read ton of texts from npcs across the 9th world. Don't bother with the tones of negative reviews... If you are curious, you like reading and you want to live a story where your choices matter. Just go, enjoy. ♥♥♥♥ the rest.Other RPGs will balance the "lack of" you'll find in Tides of Numenera.

Posted: March 6
Pros+ Sceneries are great+ Story has a lot of potential+ Music is quite goodCons- Dialogues are bloated with lengthy descriptions of banalities (clothing, mannerisms, etc.)- Lots of pointless lore and jargon- Neglected sound design (e.g. no reverb/echo when people talk in a cavern)- The scarce voice acting is sometimes decent, sometimes ridiculous- Most companions are clichés or downright boring- Overall UI is poorly designedMy wordThe writers are focusing on world-building, yet they don’t seem to comprehend that no matter how intricate their imaginary world becomes, it will appear meaningless if the story is poorly executed. Instead of letting the writers overdo lore and descriptions, the producers should have put more resources into the audio-visual presentation, which accounts for most of the immersion in a video game.

Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS REVIEW PURCHASED THROUGH KICKSTARTER.Ah this takes me back to Planescape Torment, running around as the Nameless One with buddy skull Morte at your side...Having played through the Early Access area a couple times (not fully mind you) I can easily say I'd recommend this game. Excellent visuals, voice acting and ambient audio are lovely, and the detail in the story as well as minor characters and descriptions is just unparalleled. If you're a fan of the older Baldur's Gate, Planescape Torment, and the like you will certainly enjoy this.

												Disappointed in this one...the setting is really interesting but the actual gameplay is really barebones and pretty boring. The writing is good but too often devolved into heavy handed philosophy. content:
Posted: March 1
												Wow. So, as is usual with things like this, it seems people went into the game with vastly different expectations than what was being developed. If you look at the majority of negative reviews, you will noticed two things: First, an average time played of 1-2 hours which makes any opinions they have on it laughable. Second, the most frequent complaint seems to whining about the combat system. The game isn't about combat, in fact every single combat situation in the game can be resolved in an alternate way.Anyway, enough about Steam reviews being mindless dogpiling. How is the game itself? It's a worthy successor to Planescape: Torment I feel. There are lengthy conversations with interesting characters to be had, nearly all of the companions have their own quirks and peculiar 'things' about them, and the world itself is based on the setting of one of the best Tabletop RPGs in the past few years. Seriously, I can't really explain just how much the world itself is a character in this game, full of weird, mysterious and wonderful things.I'm also not sure what people are talking about when they're complaining about the game being too short, I'm still in the first city, am 7-8 or so hours in, and still haven't explored two entire districts of the city. I feel the people complaining about there only being a few areas must have rushed through the game and completed zero sidequests, talked to people, or explored.So yeah. If you're a fan of old school CRPGs, if you enjoy reading, and you're interested in one of the most unique game worlds in recent memory, you should pick this up.

content:
Posted: March 5
												So, I backed this game on Kickstarter, but didn't actually pay much attention to the development, other than to check out the beta and then wait for the full release. So, while I empathize with the people who followed development closely and got disappointed by things that were cut/downsized, I really enjoy the finished product that I got.This is a game where it really feels like your choices matter. I was stunned to see references in the ending sequence to choices I made that I had assumed wouldn't really matter. The story felt really well paced in the end, if a bit front heavy. If the setting interests you, and you like replaying games to see what other choices you could have made, this is definitely a game for you. That being said, if you're only planning on playing it once, you may be disappointed in the overall length. I wouldn't call it short, but there's so much depth and promise in the setting that theres room for a lot more story than what we got.

number of helpful: 28 of 52 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4
												What is the worth of a single life?My very first boxed PC game was Baldurs Gate. Then over the years I played every great Crpg. Fallout, Icewind Dale, Planescape Torment, Arcanum, Pillars of Eternity and the most recent Tyranny. I have played and replayed these games and IM happy to say that Torment: Tides of Numenera is amongst the best of them.The Story is deep as the worlds lore. You have to leave some of your preconceptions behind and embrace the alien nature and laws of this world. Where aliens, otherworldly beings and mutants walk under the red Sun. If you are afraid of walls of text and lore then this game will not be for you. If you enjoy reading and learning about a brand new world you will adore Numenera.Gameplay is the weak point of the title. Combat can be fun and engaging, with varied party setups, builds and interesting weapons and items but the way its system works can be a drag slowing the pace greatly. I have to admire a game where I can end a combat scenario without killing a single enemy, where I can avoid combat altogether. During my entire playthrough I didn't even have 10 battles. There are some technical bugs, but nothing game breaking. (Lets not forget that Planescape Torments combat wasn't great...).As a last word Rhin is now atop one of my favorite npc's of all time. (If you think she is weak I can only laugh at you.)Cheers

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												Pros:- Well written. A story focused RPG that can't fulfill this criteria isn't worth playing, just as a roguelike with terrible gameplay mechanics wouldn't be worth anyone's time. So. The story is interesting, the story is personal and it carries the game from start to finish as it should.- Good sidequests with multiple solutions. I can't stress how important this is.- Reactive companions with their own opinions and comments.Cons:- Main plot lacks narrative focus and sometimes you lose sense of what you're supposed to be doing there until you remind yourself with the journal. - NPCs, followers and even the game world itself can sometimes feel like it's missing character. Sure it's well written, a lot of it feels a little flat. The world itself seems *small* and very localized to a linear path, broken into small locations, rather than the more open exploration of Pillars of Eternity or Baldur's Gate II. - Combat isn't that well thought out.- Skill checks don't scale, so eventually you'll pass everything with ease.Conclusion:Looking at the list of cons you'd think I would not recommend the game, but I do. It's not a masterpiece, and perhaps that is why it is receiving so many negative reviews from old Planescape: Torment fans, but it is a decent and original RPG game well worth your time, despite its flaws.

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28
												I'm writing an early review, breaking a personal rule, for a specific reason. This game has already given me more time and enjoyment than a number of Triple-A retail price games do, and some people are making really stupid arguments.The positive reviews hold, but I'm going to throw my hat in the ring just to make sure that genuine reviews are sticking to the top.The biggest complaint I see is this: "http://imgur.com/a/Cwyig Everything struck through in red﻿ has been cut!"And, this is my short, effectual response: From the list, it looks like they primarily cut additional followers, 'factions', and non-essential material.The followers may be in game, and included in plot, but aren't companions. They stated in some of the Dev diaries early on that they needed to work in the vast amount of scripting it would take in an effective time period of about three years. Combine that with efforts to go back and redo things that alpha / beta testers suggested, and that ate up a lot of time. I'm willing to say that a lot of this content may very well be in the game, just not in its originally conceived form.I personally wasn't concerned with Numenera Crafting to be honest, especially since its a really niche position even in the tabletop material, which I DM from. And, I say this as an alpha tester, who got 26 hours from the early betas, and stopped so I'd be more refreshed for the final release. 26 Hours of straight narrative content is no small feat, especially for a closed beta intro.If we lost a location like the water city, it's disappointing but within reason. Though, the "Live Orchestra" promise doesn't have to come out with the release of the game. And, putting a question mark next to the unachieved stretch-goal smells of salty tears to me.﻿BUT, let's continue with the positive review!This game is a narrative experience which few even attempt to rival in and of themselves. Most games today sell a highly-detailed world-space that you can run around in to explore, with bits of flavor text interspersed to highlight the narrative, and signal-boost the dialogue. That method is not a poor one, but it has its own distinct quality. This game provides the rich narrative in full bulk, with perhaps reduced graphical and 3D flare, but rich with genuine experience.You make real choices, not just the illusion of choice, where two paths diverge only to immediately come back together with some characters resolving differently. Almost immediatley in the game, your two starter followers feud irredeemably, and you have to choose to take one of them with you. You 'can' reverse this decision, but once you start building out and equipping that follower, and siding with them in their story, it becomes quite troubling to attempt to go back and find the other again. Even more so, there are diverging paths with decisions that directly affect how your experience forward will go.It's not a particularly challenging game, unless you're dramatically unsuited for a task and attempting to save-scum it. But, it IS a game that will make you question yourself! Do I really want to do this? Is this what's going to help me int he long run?It's even better when the game SURPRISES YOU WITH CONTENT. I mean, random flashbacks after a scene that you feel should just be another shameless transition. With minimal exposition, and very little ability to save-scum, it really puts the pressure on you, as the player, to make these decisions with the direct autonomy that you have. It's the only thing you have, sometimes.And man, does it make this game feel good.But yes, the game is a bit antiquated mechanically. If you don't like the idea of a visible dice roll, or RNG at all, you may not entirely enjoy this game. Similarly so if you can't handle the old-school feel of an isometric RPG. Again, it's not an RPG for everyone, but it was never intended to be. This was what it was touted as from the very beginning, and in my opinion, it does it excellently.Now, I'm going to shut up, try and find some time in my schedule to actually finish the game. My current estimate is that I will probably rack up about 100 hours playing, so I'll probably end up with approximately 130 hours played with my beta testing. Not even including the alpha client.

content:
Posted: March 5
												I haven't put a lot of time into this game to be honest but I am probably not going to put any more into it.  While I understood from the reviews that all of this game was harkening back to the days before most of the conversations were voice acted and I was ready for it what I wasn't ready for was writing that really just turned me off.  This is probably a personal preference thing but as a person who also enjoys reading this genre of literature I expected a little more.  If you know in advance that you are going to create a game in this manner you really should have someone put a lot of extra time into the writing.  The concept seemed ok but again the writing turned me off so much in the little time that I was playing that I just couldn't do it anymore.I want to reiterate that my criticisms are mostly personal preference, I think that someone who enjoys a different style of writing than what I prefer probably would find this game a blast but it just isn't there for me sadly.  I wish Steam would give me the ability to do something other than just say yes or no to the recommendations for this game but sadly no.  If you can find it at a discount, which you can even this early after release then it's worth a shot.  If you have to pay full price, hold out for a sale just in case you fall into the same situation as me.

content:
Posted: March 6
												Summary: If the concept of the game draws you, you'l almost certainly enjoy it. If it doesnt, stay far and far away! Torment is a great game that is absolutely not for everyone.Pros:- One of the best stories and writing I've ever seen.- Plays with new ideas and concepts all the time.- A game where violence is rarely ever the only option.- When it happens, combat is very challenging.Cons:- A very short game for it's genre with very few zones. Only 3 main zones and 1 "mini-zone".- Companions seem interesting, but have very little to offer or say except one.- Character creation is non-existant, you can decide the gender and that's it.Review: Torment is, for me, an amazing game, one of the best I've played this year that absolutely blew my mind away. If you like the setting and like long reams of well-written dialogue, this game is absolutely for you. But if you are looking for a more traditional RPG, it is absolutely not, because Torment is *not* that kind of game.The game's zones are very rich and fleshed out (sometimes literally). Every NPC has a story to tell and each and every one is worth listening to and fascinating reading. The story is rich and will keep you interested all throughout. Even when the main quest falls into obscurity, the sidequests make up for it, and then some. There are always multiple ways to resolve a quest, and the game's writing and the situations it thrusts you in can leave you on the verge of tears sometimes. I know it did for me.I was disappointed by the lack of zones - Why only 3? And the game's length was very short. By the time you finished the story many things are left unanswered.As always, the lack of possible romance options is a pity. For games that put so much emphasis on the player's ability to choose, it's oddly restrictive in this manner. I can sell a young girl to a slave trader, but I can't choose to kiss someone I like?There's not much more to say. Cons aside, if you read some reviews and read the concept and feel it's for you, it probably is!On the other hand, if you're a little put off by the game's unusual theme and design, it probably isn't.This is one of those games where you can go with your gut.

content:
Posted: March 5
												For this price at this point of time i would not recomend the game.the playtime you see is the time you require to finish the game if you bother reading all the dialogs and do all side quests. As such I argue that the game is rather small and since its not what i call replayable if you feel thats adequate the game is for you.pros of the game:interesting story, allien environment.innovating puzzles.a world on itsown.innovated combat system (or just buying the rights to use an existing one was too expensive)negatives:-walls of text. at points the game is more of a novel than an actual game and has no naration.-very few encounters. The encounters are well made but quite few, I dont think i remember more than 10 of them but certinly less than 30 in total to finish the game and thats if you choose to take all the fights on an optional quest.-very few classes all with the same gameplay-instances from mereartifacts coud had easily been made actual game stages. instead you get a wall of text and some choises which are no choices really.- linear gameplay. Even compared to baldours gate2 and the original planescape, the gameplay is even more linear.- combat system is poorly designed, with very few options and an early cap. In fact there is almost minimal amount of weapons and weapon selection. as well as skills and spells. x-com has more weapon options and spells and classes than this game but the combat is not comparable to x- coms tactical requirements and most of the time combat can be completely skippsd.... which literally makes the game a novel.-character customization? bad command or file name.-character potraits for the npcs? too lazy to  make those? I mean you spend like 20 or 25 hours of the game talking to npcs.. at least you could see who you are talking to?-grafics are subpar-game intro is rediculously poorly made. The whole falling thing could had been made a cinematic. but I guess its cheaper to write a wall of text than actually draw anything. You supposely fall from the moon to the planet and the only thing you  see is a black screen and a wall of text. ITs definetly an anamnesis... Dos is back.- I seriously tried to fight the last boss... well guess what you cant.-very few maps. I think in total you get less than 30 map screens to explore and thats being generous by supposing there were hidden map screens.easy things that could be done to improve the gameallow a boss fight in the end.skip stupit introremove level capallow the players to participate in the endless war.use  multimedia some more and less wall of texting, or at least use both.add some class variety and allow a different approach for each class in the game. the tides could had been an extra type of magic. Like the shouts in skyrim... nope they are restricted as a deus ex machina for a couple of dialog options. Not even sure why they bothered to make it a skillIn either case the company that made this is blacklisted for me. Especially since they received so much backing from the users.They definetly failed to absorve the founds that were given to them in an effective way.

Posted: March 5
												In Numenera the only focus is on the story. The class and combat system could have been romoved completely for the game to really shine in its story part. It would be the perfect point-and-click-adventure. Still, in its current form it cannot even slightly compete with Torment 1, because it is basically a point-and-click-adventure with lacking RPG elements.If it were sold as such I would recommend it if not for the name 'Torment' that absolutely requires solid RPG elements. Planescape Torment features, in addition to the perfect story driven focus, a unique and appealing class and combat system. Remember the video for the Mechanus Cannon! This is why Torment is still superior to alike games by far. You could grind for hours in Torment and still have fun. I come to the conclusion that this game is worse than Torment 1 and because of this I would recommend the player to instead buy Planescape Torment.Undeserved, the original Planescape Torment has received worse scores on many game magazines than this game.

Early Access Review
								A lot of praise has been given to this title for the writing, and rightfully so. The vocabulary and structure are an elegant delight to read and makes the intimidating undertaking of reading millions of words on a monitor before completion something to actually look forward to.But TTON's strength also lies in the quality of the encounters. They are surprisingly imaginative when taken separately. As you'll gather enough pieces to form a story, it only gets better.All of this is spiced up by interaction with alien tools and skills that get you through strange situations, refreshingly different than typical RPG mythos.

number of helpful: 19 of 35 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2
												For all I wanted to love the game, I can't recommend it to people that aren't already invested.No decisions have any meaning outside of a few tiny alterations and a change in the end sequence. The excellent quality of the writing, for the most part, just hints at things that *could* have been, and aren't.You're pushed forwards from one locale to another, and while you can see their histories, their connections feel like pieces are missing between them. You're only shown pieces. While this might be excused in that you're being hunted, it just feels off, as if there were more once, and it got cut. The main theme of the worth of a single life is in no way tied to anything solid. There are many things that could have tied into it and made it an actual theme, but they aren't connected. It's a dialog choice that reappears later and has no real effect. To get any meaning out of it you'll have to dig into this like a first year psych student and make it up yourself. The main reveals throughout are powerful, but muted. You're shown the motivations of the major players and the bit cast, but they come hot and heavy back to back near the end. It feels incredibly rushed. The answers to the origin of the Sorrow are meaningless, as your actions towards it simply push you back into another meaningless choice that only affects the ending, and in a way that is basically identical to another. Gameplay and story are both rushed incredibly as you progress. You get enough experience in the last hour to go up almost 2 tiers (8 levels), which is utterly ridiculous. Speaking of gameplay, the battle system is incredibly sluggish. Pathing and interacting with objects normally is also a bit off. Dialogs will not initiate, you'll talk to companions repeatedly instead of interacting with the object you clicked. You'll bump into geometry. These things aren't rampant and constant, but they occur enough for it to be a regular irritation. Some items refuse to be used in any of the ways they are accessible until you shuffle them in your inventory. Some items simply disappear on use with no effect. These last two are probably for the same reasons, something to do with combat flags sticking around or multiple checks being made and confusing the system.  There's a tiny bit more depth here. A twisted Caster I didn't bother with. I'll eventually do another playthrough, just to poke around, update this if I missed some kind of major gem, but I'm just not feeling it at the moment.*Edit* review written prior to the QoL update. I'll rewrite this if I get around to playing through again.

												So how did they manage to ♥♥♥♥ this game up?I waited almost 20 years for this, the game is missing functionality that a game 20 years ago had. Is this real life?The game needs a walk option, running everywhere gives a fake and constant sense of urgency and stress to the character and feel of the game. The Numenera "point system" for special actions didn't translate well at all from tabletop to CRPG, especially in form of conversation function. I ran out of intellect? Really? I am stupid now? Oh look, the other characters have some points i can those instead, i guess they are as persuasive  as me.What is the point in this exactly? It completely destroys the whole immersion, in PS:T You could let your companions speak instead, the camera zoomed on them and they spoke, you didn't use their points to convery your intellect.I have played PS:T about 5 times along with FO1,FO2,IWD,IWD2,BG and some other games made by Fargo / Black Isle / Bioware and the story , the charm , the characters and combat made you come back for more. After 4 hours here the only thing making me come back is to make sure this is not really such a bad game because i really don't want to believe it is. It's just sad. After 4 hours of Numenera i feel like i could have finished one of my books in my backlog instead. I chose to play a video game over the books because i expect to play, not run around an interactive book with graphics to go with it , ♥♥♥♥♥♥ combat and a crappy interface that would feel "deep" to consoles players.To cut the review/rant short:If i haven't had fun or experienced anything special in 4 hours so why should i continue.I am maybe too old for this♥♥♥♥♥♥but i am almost confident that if i launch Torment i will still enjoy it today.So many people hate on the combat in Torment but i don't remember anyone saying it was too ♥♥♥♥♥♥ back in the day. I think it was completely acceptable and a bit refreshing compared to IWD and BG as combat was not the focus of the game anyway.It was realtime with paus function and supplied the main thing a game needs to do: Entertainment.inExile after a mediocre Wasteland 2 and now mediocre Torment are never getting another dime from me, Their games are just not worth my money. PS: I am beyond the "sit on my♥♥♥♥♥and play games all day and all night" phase in my life and don't have time for anything but good games. I value my time and will not give this game more than a second chance.Sorry inExile, you messed up and it seems like you sold out based on broken kickstarter promises that i funded.

Posted: March 5, 2016
												Just for context I am one of the post kickstarter backers who pledged on the site for 75$. Do I regret buying the game? No, not really. Do I regret backing for extras? Yeah kinda. Torment is devisive game at the moment and I feel that the game is simply not worth it at this time. I may reccomend it at a price drop but there are a number of reasons I cannot reccomend it at the time. So lets break down why I feel this game just isnt what I had hoped for.The Good:-2D backgrounds are really well drawn-Story is good (not great just good) and setting is very unique -Lots of choice and consequence The Bad:-The writing is bloated and a slog to read (they need an editor seriously)-If you play peacefully 99% of the game is reading and going back and forth between NPC's-The crisis have a novel idea but feel rather dull and uninteresting. -Lacks any meaningfull mechanical RPG mechanics outside of conversations-Lots of cut content-Feels like a visual choose your own adventure vs an actual isometric CRPG-Console versions are completely pointless as no regular console player is gonna buy this-exploration is pointless if you dont do any of the combatIf you want a proper CRPG with good writing/conversations AND fun gameplay buy Wasteland 2 and/or Pillars of Eternity. If you liked Planescape Torment and want a game with a kinda similar feel (although Planescape felt more like a game tbh) then sure buy it. But if you want a proper CRPG look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: March 17
												TL:DR: Summary: Get an e-reader instead.First, let’s acknowledge the elephant in the room. It’s quite big. Probably bigger than any land mammal that ever existed. Definitely bigger than the blue whale or even King Kong. Is it bigger than the Bloom? I think so.This elephant is called Planescape Torment and it you have never played it, exit after reading this review. Visit GOG and invest some coppers to play the best RPG OF ALL TIME. Apparently a billion years from now, it still remains the best.Tides is the ‘Spiritual Successor’ to Planescape Torment and I won’t mention it again in this review.On its own merits then…Tides is a top down isometric RPG where there is a lot of reading to be done and hardly one drop of combat to be found. It uses the Pillars of Eternity Engine, a game I enjoyed immensely. You travel the world, recruit members of your gang and collectively adventure through some of the best stories ever told. That is the theory at least.The developers collect a bravery award for designing the most unusual intro and character creation in gaming history. You are falling from the sky. You only see wind and clouds and you have to choose your actions. I died in the first five minutes of the game and had to start again.Wow - I thought. These guys are really pushing the boundaries of gaming. Fantastic! The gaming boundaries are never pushed again.You get trapped in this strange silicon/ translucent Giant's Causeway space where you confirm what action you took in certain (short and not quite of moderate interest) text based adventures and at the end your character is defined. They call it Glaives, Jacks or Nanos. Your stats are Might, Speed and Intellect. You define your skills and abilities, with certain restrictions such as Nanos (mages) cannot choose weapon skills.This beginning section counts as tutorial because you get introduced to some of the game concepts such as using effort and a little combat. That happens in an area (in your mind) called The Labyrinth which should be cool but comes across as one of the lamest ‘main character home’ in history.Crash, BANG! You land on the Ninth World or Earth not as we know it. We have moved on a billion years from now and eight mighty civilisations have risen and fallen. Some of the technology left behind by the previous civilisations is inexplicable and seen as 'magical'. These items and phenomena are collectively known as Numenera.The game world is almost stupendous. It is bright and shiny in the right areas and an upgrade to the moody PoE universe. Things whirl around and make weird sounds. It’s like visiting the best circus in the world. Early on you are able to take advantage of its weirdness and interact with the numenera in your first combat encounter. Imagine being able to take advantage of your environment in combat. You could set rocks to fall. Acidic pipes to burst. Turns out there is little combat and even less opportunities to do this.One of the strangest things in the game is that although you don’t know who you are, for some reason a large number of people do. You are the Last Cast Off. Apparently our little group has been causing havoc amongst the rest of the population and are heavily distrusted.An entity known as The Changing God has lived for a long time moving from person to person to further his own ambitions. Each time he leaves a body behind it gets reborn as it is cast off. As the Last Cast Off you have some powers and can recall memories. Cue about enough text to read as in 30 bibles. Hence, the key question is not does one life matter.  It’s whether computer screens are the right medium to read 30x774,000 words (King James version) approx. ??There are some strange and wondrous things to see. A strange creature trapped in a cage and you meet a crazed cult that worships your father, The Changing God. You could come across a spaceship and a great interstellar beast so big, people live inside it. There is a murder to solve involving a strange group of cannibals that want you on their menu.It’s not enough though. A lot of these adventures are solved easily as all stat checks can be achieved by having a balanced party. The words overwhelm you and there is not enough mindless combat to change the pace. The combat in this game has traditionally been in Real Time with the ability to Pause and use an item or skill. Here we have turn-based combat and it is hideously broken. I suspect this style was introduced for the console crowd. It’s broken and bugged. My game crashed only in combat. It was tedious and slow and poor enemy AI. In one encounter one of my party members that had fallen remained untouched for three rounds or so even as ten enemies could not decide whether to open a door. I kid you not.As you progress through the game and venture forth into new areas the overall story does unfold. There are a few twists and turns and maybe the odd ‘oh’ moment. The Bloom, the final area, is the best section in the game because it is where all the various strands to the game all appear logical and come together. I suspect the choices and consequences are probably the best I have ever seen in a RPG. Actions you take lead to consequences but I think another playthrough with a different style and choices would confirm that. The developers have stated that sometimes there are moree interesting consequences when you fail but how many players would do that when it is so easy to succeed?Ultimately, you may come to the same conclusion as I did.Infinite goodwill plus a crack team of professional and highly experienced games developers plus one of the most successful Kickstarters ever will not deliver a good game.I close my eyes and remove a certain word from this title. I think the game is short, bugged and not of sufficient interest to be worthy of my hard worked for. Wasteland 2 and Pillars of Eternity were pretty awesome though. It's a good attempt though and VERY BRAVE. There is a lot of innovation here and I could be swayed to back Tides 2. Sometimes we buckle under the pressure instead of succeeding.

Posted: March 9
												Torment is not a "bad" game - but it is not a "good" Inxile game either. The world building, storyline, characters and lore are all fantastic - at the very least the game has introduced more people to the Numenera universe, which is just a fun world. The problem (as I see it) is that I don't feel that the game systems of Numenera translate themselves that well to a computer based role-playing game.In games of similar context (such as Planescape Torment which this is a spiritual successor to) I would argue that better concessions were made to make the game fun as well as interesting with a storyline. As it stands Torment is basically a choose your own adventure novel in electronic format, which isn't good enough for me.Given the opportunity, I would purchase it again just to support Inxile and the hope that maybe they'll do another game in the Torment universe - its too rich a background not to explore, but I can't recommend that other people buy it.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm just a few hours into the beta (which is really more of a long demo) and I'm already sold on this game. It's really everything I was looking for in a sequel to Planescape: Torment, one of my favourite games of all time. I love it when an RPG is more dialogue-focused than combat-focused, it's one of the reasons the original Torment made such a huge impact on me. I felt like I was exploring and discovering a bizarre world, not just hacking through legions of generic thugs (although there was a bit where you could hack through legions of generic thugs). This game is the same, you're not some crazy butcher but a person trying to understand what the hell is going on. I'd like to give you an example of some of the dialogue focus on this game and how everything is custom made for each encounter rather than being very systematic (e.g. when you flee from battle in a Final Fantasy game, it's the same mechanic in every battle, it's not a different thing each time).Early on you're ambushed in a plot-related way. In the initial dialogue sequence you can lie with a speech check and avoid combat.If combat does start, you can take your character to the enemy leader and initiate dialogue with him in battle. You can then pass a speech check to scare him - this gives him a debuff. It's not a generic action, it's based on the events that have just happened and is unique to this encounter.Alternatively a female NPC you're with who has some history with this man can initiate dialogue and reason with him, convincing him to leave you alone.Additionally, maybe you've made a more technically minded character. If so you could activate a nearby gadget. I assume this would damage the enemies but I can't confirm it since I didn't go through with it.There's another party member with you now - I didn't check, but he'll have something to say in battle as well. I wonder what effect that has?You could actually have told your party members to leave you by now. That would have changed this fight in another way.How you deal with this is referenced later and makes a difference.I feel that in other games this would just be a generic fight. You'd battle, they'd die, you'd proceed. Here it becomes an involved, narrative experience where the way you've built your character and the way you want to play the game open it up to different possibilities. Remember, this is just the *combat* - a place where normally dialogue and speech-based characters don't get a chance to shine.There are other great touches, again enchancing the character or plot side of things, like if you tell a party member to leave you, they don't just stand around or vanish, they return to their normal life. One such example is a person who runs a shop in a certain part of town. Everything I have encountered so far has had a lot of effort put into it to convey a strong sense of personality, story, coherency and sense of place. Time and time again I'm pleasantly surprised and impressed.That said, don't buy this now if you're expecting the full game or if you're expecting a totally polished experience.

content:
Posted: March 10
												I'll try to be as on point and brief as possible about my main gripes:Skill system.In conversations you often have the option to use intellect, speed and might to get whichever result you find most appealing.This is a good thing. The problem occurs when your companions can help you with this, because the overall difficulty is below meaningless.It's like it's designed to not let you fail. Even if you do fail one skillcheck, you'll be provided with a second chance or simply getting what you wanted either way by some other conversation option.Add to this that you have more than enough chances to Rest and replenish your stat pools, or simply using "heal potions" for any given stat pool. The money to buy any of this is also very abundant.Combat/Crisis:The difficulty here depends a bit on how you build your character and choice of companions, but it's never come off as very challenging in any way.The system itself feels sluggish and slow as I spend 99% of the time in a crisis looking at the enemy go through it's movement/attack animations.Story:Decent? I don't know.. I haven't finished the game, nor am I likely to.I've been a fan of all the infinity engine games (IWD,BG,PS:T) since their first release and always loved a game rich on lore and dialogue/interaction.. but ToN is just disappointing and bland.The writing is so try-hard that it's actually tedious and it feels like the writers sat down with the intention of writing something that is really just difficult to get through.For all the fancy words, phrases and variety of vocabulary it transfers very little meaning.I guess some like that though, to be swimming in a sea of words and phrases just to describe a wooden spoon.Conclusion:It just feels like a missed chance at making something great, it's mediocre at best.. and I wish I hadn't paid for it.

Posted: March 16
												I highly recommend this game. It has great storytelling, a wonderfully detailed world, great character building and optimization options, and the ability to actually do roleplaying by playing through the story in a variety of different ways. At the end of the game, it actually wraps up the story of all of the major NPCs as well as for many of the minor NPCs that you interact with in the game, which is more than you can say for Mass Effect 3. If you like text-heavy, deep and interesting roleplaying games, like the original Planescape Torment or Age of Decadence, you will love this game. I don't understand the hate that it's getting - it took me 28 hours to play it from start to finish, exploring every nook and cranny I could, and I regret absolutely none of it. It was a great ride.

content:
Posted: March 4
												So there IS a lot of problems with this game. In particular depending on why you like CRPGs you might hate this. I did not back this on Kickstarter, so can't speak to that. I can say that it feels like a complete game.However, I loved it.If you like tactical combat, and that is what draws you to CRPS, avoid this. The combat is "eh" (mainly because I feel like everything is so slow). Depending on how you play, there also is not a lot of it.For example, you can talk or think your way around most combat. I think I only had 5 or 6 combats in my playthrough, and they were "crisis" where the victory was not "kill everyone" (or at least the only victory), but instead had alternate win conditions. Honestly, I found it super refreshing. You don't often see that in a game.It has an interesting world with an interesting plot. Some of the interactions were really good. One of the party members is up there as favorite party member in any game.Time wise you can probably get through the main quest pretty quickly. However, playing through and exploring and taking your time will probably give you 30-40 hours.HOWEVER,The game does kinda look not so great. If you zoom in the graphics actually look much better (not the character models though. They are aweful). But I like to play more zoomed out, and it just does not look great.I would have also loved to have character portriates while talking to NPCs.I did not run into a lot of bugs, at least until the end. I experienced some loading problems that made it hard to complete the game.TL;DRIf you like character development and exploration, don't mind a lack of combat, and don't mind reading, I highly recomend this game.

												As others have said, "Meh" is kind of what this game left me feeling. The overarching story is decent, but the entire package didn't work. I would recommend solely for the story, which is interesting and takes place in an interesting world.Game length - Kind of short for this style of game. I would have liked perhaps a side quest or two for each companion, and at least one more story arc. Overall there are basically 3 open maps to explore, locked from one another. In a single playthrough of Wasteland 2, I had 5x the playtime. Camera - Locked in viewing angle makes precise movement very difficult/impossible in some areas, especially during combat. You had a great system in Wasteland 2, why change it?Replayability - Very few options impact the greater story, only minor plotlines and the end-of-game summary slides. I can tell they put alot of effort in this, but they seemed to lose the forest for the trees. I will say it definitely makes your experience "technically" unique, but not disguisably so.

content:
Posted: March 5
												Recommend with reservations. I am glad I bought it, but I would read some reviews first if I was on the fence, as it might not be exactly what you are expecting.Pros:- A well done story and interesting locales and writing.- Something different.- Nice to see a different RPG ruleset (even if not faithfully implemented)Cons:-I really wanted to see a computer version of the Pen and Paper rules of Numenera.Unfortunately, this is not that faithful of an adaptation. They added hitpoints, rather than having the damage taken from  your stat pools. This seems like something that could have easily been kept, simply by balancing the game differently (or even keeping everything the same, and altering the pool totals a little)- I don't see why this really needed to be changed.Some other things, like the decision to not interrupt combat for pool spends on defense (in real rules players roll and spend points when attacking and defending) I can understand..but I still think it could have worked.  -I'm ok with it being a dialogue heavy game, I just wish there were more opportunities to actually use all of the abilities you accrue in the game. Let's face it, despite being a game about "exploration" and "discovery" and only offering XP for discoveries and solving problems, not kills--the pen and paper rules are very tilted torwards a combat focused game. Most of the Focii and abilities are combat related. The same with this PC game, but there just isn't enough combat to justify any of it. Also, most of the cyphers in the game are combat items, but you'll never find a reason to use them.-Game is way too easy and linear, I feel like some kind of wilderness area connecting the three main hubs of the game should have been included. As it is now, you are railroaded through a few small areas where the goal of a quest is often only 50 feet or so away from the various quest givers.  Also, spending points is never reallly something to worry about. I've never had a test in the game where there wasn't someone available in my party with enough points to ensure success on any challenge (even without abusing the local inn to regain points.)-I played this as someone who is very familiar with the source material. I'm not sure if I would have enjoyed it as much if I wasn't familiar with all of the lore namedropping that the game employs. Not sure how all of the lingo from such a unique setting works when it's not always explained.------I know there are a lot of cons here, I just think this could have been something so much greater. I probably won't feel the need to play it more than once. yet...still was enjoyable the first time. ------Caves of Qud, despite being an altogether different setting, is probably what I'll return to when I feel like playing something Numenera-ish in the future. Check it out if you want to scavenge the remains of long lost civilizations in a science-fantasy type setting.

content:
Posted: March 9
												TL:DR: Like it’s predecessor, Tides of Numenera is both deep and unique. If you’re expecting something more superficial and action-packed, move on.  If, however, you’re willing to play and read a captivating story that seemingly takes place across myriad volumes of sci-fi novelettes, play on!Like Planescape: Torment, Tides of Numenera gives back what you bring in to it.  It is rich in story, and never lacking in intrigue.  The combat and graphics may not be what some people seem to have wanted, but if that's what you were looking for then you picked the wrong class of game. This is more of a tome of philosophy and diversity than your typical cRPG: it brings both familiar and alien perspective to life with a brilliantly creative writing style that is sure to captivate any willing imagination.  To that end, it is a perfect spiritual successor to PS:T.When I think back to PS:T, I think of all amazing stories that seemingly random NPCs would have to share about their travels across the planes and how their lives were irrevocable altered--for better or worse.  I wonder about the relationship of the protagonist and the antagonist, about the circumstances of the very mufti-faceted reality that governed the story’s landscape, and what can really change the nature of man. It has been nearly two decades and those stories and philosophies still resonate with me to this day.  I can confidently say that after my first play-through, clocking in at nearly 48 hours, T:ToN will be apart of my future in much the same way, and in some ways, maybe even more so.I’ve only played through once, but I know for certain that choices *do* matter in this game.  Not every NPC needs closure, and might not get it, so some choices my seem ‘empty’ because you don’t see your various cookie-cutter meta-moral status bars adjust.  You have to remember though, this game has stories within stories. And as I said, it gives back what you bring in. While it *may* not always find fruition in the game, I can well imagine the fate of someone who’s life I impacted, and how they may one-day tell their story to another pilgrim of the Ninth World (assuming of course, they are around to tell it) and I sure as hell would be quick to pick up a book that comes out related to *any* of the characters I came across in this game.  However, there are many quests, dialogue options, and interactions that I could have done *very* differently, or in a different sequence that would have made real changes to the story and future in a variety of ways.  Let’s just say I have *big* plans for experimentation on my second play-though.. admittedly I *will* need some time to let this play-through sink in before I dive in again.I have read other reviewers claim that the game is too short, or warn that it cuts off in a manner similar to Tyranny, and nearly every negative review has something to say about combat To those issues I can only expound upon the aforementioned: my first play-though was almost 50 hours, and I definitely missed stuff. I didn’t find the ending to be abrupt at all. I thought each act had perfectly adequate pacing for both the story and character stat progression—I had to measure out my actions carefully in act one, but by the last act I was confident I could handle whatever came my way.. except maybe the weight of my own choices.  While I loved Tyranny’s emphasis on choice and dialogue, I would feel remiss to lump these two games into the same category, T:ToN is far more story-intensive, and you can see that story through to the end. Like PS:T this is not an item-based game.  If you’ve played any turn-based cRPGs before then you know the drill: you’re going to have to wait a bit during a ‘crisis.’ I really only actually fought in probably half of the crises, but considering the crises make up about .01% of the game, I think the combat was challenging enough to warrant the circumstances leading up to them, and rewarding no matter how they ultimately played out..It is hard for me to review a game like this because, like a good book, it is really more of an intimate experience that begs lengthy discourse.  All I can really say is if you *do* decide to play this one, accept it for what it is--rather than how it’s *not* whatever else is out there--and really play it.  Get to *know* everyone, explore every nook and plunder every cranny.. interact with everything you can.. it will be worth it. Find out just how much you believe one life matters.

content:
Posted: March 8
												This game is AWESOME. If you want a good story and reactivity, I can't recommend it enough. It has great writing, an interesting setting, the locations look amazing, soundtrack is good and I had no problems or bugs at release. It has a lot of text and very little combat - the focus here is on story and exploration, not tactics. Combat is not only rare but always avoidable - every problem has multiple possible solutions, and combat is just one of those. The game if somewhat short, but very involved: every dialogue is full of options, and even straight up failure often opens new and interesting paths (sometimes failure gets the most interesting outcome). There is a lot of interconnected options, with subtle consequences for most of your choices (even the seemingly unimportant ones). There is also a lot of explore, items to discover, things to meddle with and find out what they do... even if it sometimes kills you. Especially if sometimes it kills you - finding ways to die is actually kind of important for some quests.The setting is very weird, but in a good way. Places and people and items are unique and fun to learn about, instead of another old story about the lost dwarven kingdom or the millistaristic alien society. Instead you have veterans of a psychic war, a whole city inside a huge blobby creature and ancient... candy dispensers. It is sometimes grandious, sometimes creepy, sometimes philosophical, sometimes gruesome, sometimes silly.Now, this game was crowdfunded, and in this aspect the game was a huge disappointment. The developers made super ambitious promises that they weren't able to fulfill, made some big changes and didn't communicate well. But if you are planning to buy this after release, this doesn't really matter for you... it's just us backers being bitter.
