content:
Posted: March 5
												I only have one problem with this game:You know that one level in every RPG? The one where you enter the "dreamscape" or the extra-planar pocket, the memory realm or go "inside the computer?" That one level that's full of a bunch of random nonesense, with all kinds of crazy art, and literally every single NPC you meet says stuff like, "I'm the one who sees, but is unseen," or "this is the nexus of all places, where anything is possible, all futures exist... or is it? Maybe, maybe not. Is it reality? What is reality? If a tree falls in the forest..." You know, *that* chapter of the game that makes no sense but you can tell the developers thought they were being philosophical, edgy, and avant garde?EVERY SINGLE PART OF THIS GAME IS *THAT* PART. Every map is full of crazy nonsense. Every single character, from your companions and major antagonists to lowly shopkeepers and random street NPCs, is a red herring enigma rubik's cube that vomits a never-ending stream of sphinx riddles at you if you so much as introduce yourself. "I'm the last of the first, doomed to walk the ever-dream of the nightmare labyrinth for all eternity. Want to buy some weapons or armor?" The item descriptions go even further: "This thing is unlike anything you've ever seen. It defies classification. It's made from something you don't recognize and it does something wildly unpredictable. You have no idea what this is or what it's for. It's worth 120 space bucks."All that being said, I'm recommending this game for every other part they got right. The art is amazing, the sound and voice acting are great, the game system is clever, and I never encountered a single bug.

content:
Posted: March 6
												A setting-rich, nuanced, intriguing, and sometimes profound RPG that's more of an interactive codex than a video game proper. It's a mishmash of mostly unrelated stories interwoven with setting as the common thread, and most--or perhaps  exclusively--rewarding to the sort of gamer who is comfortable with experiencing those stories by proxy and through dialogue. There's choice, but you often lack freedom. There's exploration that involves little actual travel. The game knows what it is, but what it is isn't for everyone, and whether or not you'll enjoy it comes down to how inclined you are to meet it on its own terms.

content:
Posted: February 28
Product received for free
												Unlike most RPG's character creation is limited. You don't get to name your character or customize their appearance. You're either a man or a woman with "smooth, light brown skin" and "good muscles - strong, but not bulky - and slim hips." The games stats, skills and abilities are not exactly the same as those found in Planescape: Torment nor do they have the breadth of a hardcore D&D ruleset but there is enough to be found to create a unique build. The game will add much more depth as you begin leveling up. Your character will be named The Last Castoff for the entirety of the game.The game has elements of time travel, segments that take place within your own mind (The Calm), and often pivots around interactive memories. At first the game is more than a little overwhelming with all the strange naming conventions and world building elements. It takes some time to get your footing.If you don't like reading this game is not for you. It's basically one huge choose your own adventure novel. You'll spend 90% of your time reading.The writing is superb throughout, with just enough humour and wonder to keep the games dark tone from becoming suffocating. The writing can feel a bit disjointed at first. However that disjointed feeling is INTENTIONAL. Every strange, semi-nonsensical conversation is a layer to the story. The more layers you add, the more the story grows and the deeper, more understandable narrative emerges.The brilliance of Torment: Tides of Numenera's writing really hits home during the games final hours when a whole host of smaller story threads, characters and decisions finally bare fruit. It took me 47 hours to complete my first playthrough. That is reading everything, thoroughly searching every area and completing every side quest (which are all great and interesting). Things do play out differently depending on the choices you make so there is incentive to replay the game again.Torment: Tides of Numenera put together a solid group of companions to explore the Ninth World with and I know I will think about Tybir and Rhin in particular for years to come.What will put some people off is the combat. There just is not very much of it to speak of. I had played for almost 8 hours before I had a single fight. Every fight is a set piece that affects the story. All told I probably had to fight less than 20 times in the entire game. Now that number will vary a lot player to player because you can talk your way out of (or into) a lot of the fights. Even so I doubt there is even 50 fights to be had even if you went looking for them. It would have been nice to have some more combat to help break up the extraordinary amount of text you'll read during the course of completing the game.Because you so rarely fight it can be hard to really get a handle on the games combat system. With Torment: Tides of Numenera you don't really feel like you have a firm grasp on everything until the end of the game. Not that the combat is all that tough even when you take inexperience into account. Other than the first few fights most of the difficulty during combat comes from the unique elements of that set piece encounter. Are you trying to escape? Are you trying to interact with objects? Are you trying to just stay alive against waves of enemies? From the mid-point onward your party is pretty damn powerful.When you are fighting you'll often also be given the option to speak with enemies, convincing them to flee, change sides and more. If you do die, most of the time, you won't have to reload a save. That's because death is a core gameplay and story mechanic in Torment: Tides of Numenera. When you die you'll awaken in The Calm, the labyrinth within your own mind. There may be times when you'll find it expedient to die on purpose. Once you are done you simply enter a portal and awaken again in the real world.Which could leave you feeling like the game is now too easy or has no consequence but Torment: Tides of Numenera still finds ways to make you fight hard to live most of the time.The game is beautiful to look at. Equal parts gorgeous and horrifying (in a good way). Assets are not reused and each location is unique. The game is only semi-open, meaning once you leave a major location you cannot backtrack. However the games two main hubs (the rustic but also futuristic Sagus Cliffs and the monstrous, nightmarish Bloom) are vast and full of characters to interact with and quests to complete. It's unfortunate the fast travel system in Sagus Cliffs is poorly implemented and there isn't one at all in The Bloom.The music is great but not as memorable as that found in some other recent RPGs. There is very little voice work.There are relatively few bugs though I did have the game freeze on me once, and I encountered a few instances where I had to reload a save when NPC's, companions or the main character got stuck in an animation or failed to move like they should, preventing the game from progressing. There were also a few instances where dialogue referenced the wrong gender for my main character. I must point out I completed my first playthrough on a review build I received on February 9th so it is likely patches and changes will be present in the final build players will experience.

content:
Posted: March 7
												Finished playthrough at around 55 hours.Although it fell short of its ultimate potential, Torment: Tides of Numenera is still an excellent RPG set in an unforgettable world. Seamlessly blending fantasy and science fiction, the setting and writing are by far its strongest points. That being said, the game is almost entirely dialogue. If you don't like reading - and I mean REALLY reading - this game is definitely not for you. The combat is few and far-between, and is mostly avoidable entirely except in a few plot instances. Now, I was not a Kickstarter backer, so I can't comment on what they did not include in the game, what they said they would, etc. I'm just going to review what made it to the final product.PROS:- Amazing writing, memorable characters, fun companions (the first two you encounter are honestly the most boring), a treasure trove of lore and exploration.- Fast and easy leveling and skill system (a little TOO easy, some might say...)- Death is an important part of the game - you'll actually gain bonuses by exploring things in the Labyrinth inside your head whenever you kick the bucket. Finding new methods of suicide is always fun.CONS:- Combat sucks. There, I said it. You can easily overpower almost any enemy from an early point in the game, even without using cyphers. The combat itself is painfully slow, and just plain boring.- Your character becomes far too powerful too quickly. I played a Nano, and after selecting the stealth trait tree, all I had to do in combat is hide for the crit/damage bonus and then and cast Maelstrom. Boom, combat over. Skill check? I've got 3-4 Edge in whatever. Instant success. I never even really used any ciphers except the perma-boost ones.- The Tides don't do much of anything. It has a tiny effect on people's first impressions (I only noticed this 2, maybe 3 times in the entire game). They're supposed to be what makes castoffs so special, but aside from the rare Surge opportunity, they're utterly pointless.- Little to no replayability once you know all the twists and turns of the plot. The most meaningful choice in the game happens...yep, at the very end. Just reload your final save if you want to change the world.All things considered, it's worth the money. Just don't expect a genre-breaking epic saga like the old Infinity games and you'll have a good time.

content:
Posted: March 3
												A fine RPG in the tradition of Planescape. Decent characterization that is a little thin at times - exposition-heavy dialogue does that - and a story that comes full circle (it's not surprising, and you'll probably figure it all out well before it's explained). The graphics are servicable, with nice touches of special effects here and there, as is the sound. The music isn't particularly memorable but fittingly ambient. A good and relatively short story with some limited replayability. I found myself somewhat curious about the nature of the game's main "Antagonist" but it not so much I'd pick this up again for a long while, hoping to read something I already haven't. Recommended, especially on sale below twenty dollars.

content:
Posted: March 6
												I would like to recommend this game, but in its current state I simply can't.I've played it thoroughly. I really tried to like it. But given the amount of time and money inXile had for the development it leaves me with mixed feelings.I'll revise this review over time as gain more insight.What follows are not 100% dispassionate observations, but mostly my personal opinions.What I liked in the end:+ Choices, many different choices: Morally difficult choices. Even though some of the choices you make might be just an illusion of freedom since the outcome will be the same, you still choose your own path.+ Character with unique abilities.+ Very good overall writing: Solid story. The plot... see below.+ Soundtrack: It's varied. It contains Armenian duduk piece (which I personally like).+ Stable game: At least in my case I have had only a single crash in over 70 hours of playing. The experiences of other players may differ.Here what I didn't like:- Annoying bugs: The game doesn't accept certain or all inputs after an loading screen and so forth. On my first play-through, close to the end of the game, the loading screen got stuck at 49% when I tried to enter one of the fathoms where my party members were trapped. I had to reload older savegames and tried many variations of entering and leaving zones until being able to get through to the Oasis Fathom.- The general plot of the game is very derivative: If you played the original Planescape: Torment, you'll probably notice far too many parallels. You can smell the plot twists, if you want to call it that, from a mile a way due to blatant foreshadowing. Although the story and the writing itself isn't bad.- The combat system is awkward: I'm not sure how the tabletop handles these things, but in the computerized version it simply lacks tactics. The concept of the combat is solid, but I feel the environments in which the combat happens could have been designed better in many cases. The developers should have taken a closer look at Divinity: Original Sin, a game that does excellent turn based combat (although with its own balance issues)- Balancing: Nanos are way too strong compared to other classes. Especially when you go down a path where you avoid combat when possible, where you probably invest a lot into intellect and intellect edge, the Nano becomes far too devastating with its offensive spells in the few forced combat situations.Especially when you have a nano heavy group, many of the cyphers become pretty much useless. Unless you have Rhin in your group, get her to tier 3 and make use of her Cypher Adept ability, which kind of turns here into a 2nd Callistege or Nano Last Castoff in destruction capabilities, it's often better to just sell most of them. For the money you get from selling your cyphers, you can buy plenty of 'sleep' in order to refill your pools and hitpoints.If you're playing a Glaive of Jack they're more useful.- Graphics can be crude: In many areas if you don't zoom out as far as possible game game is not a pretty sight. Although some areas have beautiful renderings. Sure, graphics are not such an important factor for a game that lives off a textual narrative, but since the game insists on zooming in all the way every time you die and come back from the labyrinth or the first time you load a safe after you started the game, it's still another one of those (fixable) little annoyances.Maybe in a couple of months, when things get patches and perhaps the community adds additional content (some of which was cut and original ones) I could recommend the game. But not like this.

content:
Posted: March 3
												This is initial thoughts/impressions.  I will post a proper review when I have spent more time with the game but I just want to get my thoughts in writing.  First things First: this is easily my most anticipated game of the last couple years (I am literally playing this the day Zelda Breath of the Wild came out, that level of anticipation).  I played Planescape: Torment around 2011 and absolutley adored it, but was unable to finish it because of several game breaking glitches that I couldn't find my way around.  Still loved the game enough to be stupidly hyped for this.I have good and bad first impressions: The good is it captures the feel of the original with a world that is nearly (but not quite) as imaginitive and alien.  The combat system is INSTANTLY better and is no longer the mindless chaos that a lot of old CRPG battle systems tend to be.  The interface is deep but also accessible, Im pretty sure with time I'll be able to fully get into it.The Bad: The soundtrack is kinda dull, for the follow up to a game that had such a rich and memorable score its kind of upsetting we ended up getting generic background music. The intro to the game is very cool with you falling out of the sky and all, but I'm not a fan of how blunt the tutorial section is; in Planescape Torment you wake up on a chopping block, completely unaware of your surroundings, and are then given the opportunity to immediately to go explore and learn about this bizarre world around you; here you end up fuddling around with screens a bit too much.  I'll post an updated review when I have one but I'm having fun so far.

content:
Posted: March 2
												Edit: I've now finished the game and I should edit this review. The original post is at the bottom. Also, I was a backer on kickstarter for the game.Since my original review was more a warning about bugs, I can say all totaled I ran into six bugs that caused either a freeze, a crash or logic bug that hurt gameplay. The last being a shop bug where I managed to lose all my money. There are other bugs, including pathing issues, but they were easy to work around. In fact, I managed a work around on all the issues I found.I'm a fan of this genre of computer game and I was really anticipating this title based on the talent involved and the description of the product. As an exploration game, it's very interesting and I did get lost in the world at times. By the time of release, I knew what I was getting in terms of art and music and I found it appealing.I wish there was more to do with the companions as I didn't feel a particularly strong connection with most of them. And for a story that explored so many ideas, it feels like the ending could have been stronger.Ultimately, the gameplay is weak. I played the pen and paper Numenera rpg over the course of a year and I don't think any of the strengths of that game made it into the computer game. The whole purpose of the multiple stat pools is to make encounters were each character has different responsibilites, and each action has consequences for the characters performing that duty and the overall encounter.Instead, the crisis feel like your standard crpg encounter but hobbled by a thin out-of-place conflict resolution system. It's great that almost every problem can be solved without combat but why are all the advancement options centered on combat? Why not give the characters spells and abilites to improve their non-combat interactions and then make the social encounter more complex and interesting?And if you're not going to make social, mental or dexterity encounters more complex, why use the Numenera system over something like the Pillars of Eternity combat system? It would have been better to stick to what works in the genre until someone really wanted to make a Numenera computer game. You don't need Numenera to tell a science fantasy story and, here, the story is underserved by the mechanics.I'm sure there's good answers to all these questions but I cannot divine them. In terms of a recommendation, I would say that if you like the graphic novel style of storytelling, this has a lot of good moments. In terms of style and imagination, it's a good vision of the science fantasy setting of Numenera. It is not, however, a good interpretation of Numenera mechanically nor is it strong as a modern crpg.original review:Bugs, there's just too many. I can overlook a lot of them but after sitting through a ton of bad poetry and have the following major crisis fail so that I have to go through the same dialogs over and over, that is just too much.The story is interesting and I'll try to play through it but I can't tell firends to buy this until there's a bug patch or two.

content:
Posted: March 2
												As a Kickstarter backer for this game I can only say that the final product is a disappointment.The highlight of the game is the main story and maybe the back-story for 1 or 2 companions. The main story is good.However, everything else ranges from bad to mediocre:- Combat is bad and using “unintuitive mess” to describe it could be considered a euphemism. I would not call it a complete fiasco cause it's “functional” but there is no tactical layer and it's not fun.- Skill system is not far from combat: stat pools, edges, ability or skills, extra effort, resistances and fettles are words used to describe all the useless abilities of your character.- Lore dump surprise attacks. Now this depends on the person but I feel that my time is wasted when I read about a memory and then I realize that the entire exposition was pointless.- Uninspired quest design. The game doesn't bring anything new to the table in terms of choices and consequences. There is nothing innovative or surprising for someone who played Fallout or Arcanum. In fact the game fails to replicate the intricacies of the original game.- Bloated UI. It seems inXile cannot into UIs cause this one is worse than the one from Wasteland 2.I reserve the right to change my review in case the rest of the game is stellar but I don't think it will happen.I wanted to like the game, I gave it a fair chance but I cannot recommend it.Edit: The ending is really bad cause the main story unravels in something simply incomprehensible. The villain of the game reveals to be lame and uninteresting - a quality shared by many characters involved in it. It's shocking to know that such a story and companions were written by writters well known in the game industry.Ending slides were incomplete and wrong (I got the ending slides for a companion which I've left at the start of the game while no ending slides appeared for a character which accompanied me for the entire game !?) By the way, all companions have very shallow back-stories.While there are a couple of good moments to be found, this game rarely shines in any department. As such the no recommandation rating remains.

content:
Posted: March 22
												What can change the nature of a man?Torment: Tides of Numenera might not be able to meassure itself with our beloved Planescape: Torment and its not a true successor albeit it does try to be a spiritual one. TToN offers a good story, interesting companions/npcs, and great visuals.This game is not for those that expect a CRPG with action/fighting being the main part, this game is for those that wants to ponder about philosophical topics and the very question about life itself. Every action you take will have a consequence you wont foresee. Instead of the usual type of combat, we instead have a "Crisis" Its turn based combat where you are also able to solve the crisis with persuasion etc. This means that you don't really have to think to much about combat, but rather have to think about solutions. If you don't like reading, thinking and explorer your companions, then this is not what you look for! most of the critics will tell you they don't wanna read a book, but this is the very reason TToN succeds for so many of us! I felt attached to my companion and the protaganist (The last castoff) story and felt wanting more and more! It does have a few techical problems, but nothing beyond what is normal for released games now a days.I don't think there is any reason to make a huge review, because this game will be a love/hate relation for most the try/have it. So if you like to ponder about life and philosophical matters and expirience a rich story that can develop very differently for each of us! The this is the game for you.If you are still uncertain if you want the game or not, do consult the god in your pocket for advice.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								At this point, I can't honestly recommend this game.  The concept is great and I like where it is going, but in it's current state... Wait until it is further along unless you are seriously looking to provide feedback.  Here are my biggest gripes so far:-The horrendously long beginning sequence just needs to be dropped alltogether.  I understand what the devs where going for here, but it falls flat, and made me almost not even give the game a chance.  Far too heavy on expostion, that even now (about 15  hours into the game) has not ONCE been referenced in any way.  In essence, it all feels like meaningless filler, all the while, I'm like, "When the hell do I finish creating my character and START the damn game already?!"  It really seems more like the devs mean to wow people with how outlandish the lifeforms and ideas in the world are, which is great, I'm all about weird and different, but it doesn't seem relevant and throws WAY too much info at the player too fast.  Two hours or so later and I'm talking to the first two companions and I was wondering why they didn't start the game at that point.  It would be, IHMO, ten times more expedient and exciting that way.-Bugs and lack of optimization galore; my new gaming rig is less than two months old and is getting playstation-era loadtimes... Several times, the map extended beyond the GUI boundaries, sometimes menus can't be opened at all or the character stops responding to mouse clicks, requiring a re-load, sometimes even a complete reboot of the game.  NPCs keep telling me to do quests that have already been finished.  Like, after freeing a man from exectution, one of my companions warns me every time I sleep that the man will be killed soon.  Or, after completing another quest, the journal tells me to report to the person I already reported to.  Or, being told that there is a NEW murder that happened this night, then being told the details of an earlier murder which we already discussed in detail.  Ugh...-Your character receives negative buffs (fettles) when you pick up cyphers, but since you cannot (yet) sell items, the "quest rewards" actually gimp your character as they keep stacking and making your character LESS able to perform skills.  Granted, this will be fixed to a degree as the vendors are incorporated into the game, but for now, it means I just have a desire to junk all of the cyphers I pick up.Don't get me wrong, I think there is insane POTENTIAL for this game.  I loved Planescape: Torment and the previous work of this team and have a lot of faith in them.  The game just isn't there YET.  I'm sure that a few months down the line, I'll be able to give a more polished game the thumbs up.

content:
Posted: March 2
												Let me preface this first by saying that Planescape Torment is my 1# favorite game of all time and that I value story above everything in else in games.With that said I will write Pro/Cons first and finish off with my overall thoughts on the game.Pro: - Great story- Well written characters & party members- Unique world(s) and setting- Good OST that feels very reminiscent of PS:T- Dialogue heavy- Can avoid 90% of combat through dialog- Choice & consequence- Unique alignment system- Multiple endingsCons- Interface Bugs- Clunky combat system (Turn based combat)- Short- Cut contentConclusion: I really enjoyed it after my 35 hours of playing it even though I expected this game to be longer given it's long development time (4-5 years).The party members were very varied and unique and I'm really happy about one specifically that I won't mention here due to spoilers that I'm glad to have "stuck" through to the end with him/her. (Pat Rotfuss's character that he wrote is the one I'm referring to..if you really wanna know who it is look it up).inXile managed to turn Monte Cook's Numenera world into something that should be experienced by anyone who is not afraid of CRPG's that are very wordy/dialogue heavy and are interested in playing something unique that has never been done in terms of setting."It's a Torment game alright" is a phrase you will hear/read a lot about this game. What that entails is a lot of text to read, bad-mediocre combat and the ultimate question that must be you must find an answer to just like it's predecessor: "What does one life matter"?Do I recommend Torment: Tides of Numenera? YES!

content:
Posted: October 13, 2016
												I backed this Kickstarter because they promised that their game would be a spiritual successor to Planescape: Torment. What I got was a game with a pretty forgettable story, in an interesting setting, with really bad, slow combat, and a completely pointless skill system. It's not terrible by any means, but it's not worth the asking price of $45. I've been thinking about Planescape: Torment my whole adult life, but I thought the story in Torment: Tides of Numenera was pretty dull and I mostly didn't care at all about what was happening aside from the world lore, minor NPC characterization, and side quests. The plot is basically just going from scene to scene doing fetch quests around fixing a MacGuffin, which had me irritated. but I'm probably not going to remember anything distinct about playing this game 6 months from now. Still, few games keep me playing long enough to see them to the ending, so I'm going to give this a conditional recommendation if you can get it on sale. It has elements of a good story that I feel are worthy of experiencing for yourself, but it's pretty blah otherwise.Side Note: I'm playing Final Fantasy 5 now and after the second boss when Syldra sacrifices herself to the whirlpool to save the main characters, I felt more emotion in that moment over a 16 bit JRPG dragon dying than the entirety of T:ToN.

number of helpful: 43 of 84 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2
												TLTR: 11/10 when judged as an indie-RPG focusing on script and interactive environment. I wouldn't recommend it for someone looking for a combat-RPG. Torment: Tides of Numenera v1.01Torment is an amazing game for several reasons.The development focus and priorities have been fantastic! The script, the interactive environment, the maturity, the story, the character-building, and the gear are amazingly well done.RPG-FocusFirst of all this RPG is about your character. For reference most other RPGs are about all the other characters you meet, while your character is a shell with combat abilities. In Torment your past is the red line throughout the story, and it's one of the elements that make this game one of the best RPG ever made (if not THE best).ScriptThe script, affording the game more than a million words (more than twice that of the Lord of the Rings triology), is pure quality! I don't know if I'm even able to convey the totality of that statement. Every character I've met have been interesting. Everything in the story – the place itself, what happened, the people, the powers that be, the technology, your role in it all – it all fits and is interesting. There is intentional confusion and it works, unlike stories that just try to make it work. In fact the script containst the whole spectrum of literary techniques, in just the right amount and in the right places. It's inventive and original in content. The personalities I've met made sense psycologically. I never once got the feeling that there was some novice writer trying to sell me a poorly re-written classic. Everything I've seen in Torment: ToN has been a new experience. It is a new classic, through and through.StoryI haven't completed the game yet so I don't know exactly how good it will turn out to be. But I have enough pre-knowledge of the Ninth World and of the development of Torment to recognize that it all fits perfectly together so far. With a bit of thought I'm able to see some of what's between the lines of what I'm experiencing directly in game, and see that it fits. The elements that are forseeable are that way because I pay attention to the characters and the plot, not because it repeats old cliches. The story is original and fits this setting perfectly. So far the story has been stellar. It's also mature.InteractionBeyond the story, the gameplay revolve around interacting with the environment. Both people, objects and phenomenons. There are events you can participate in like a quest, but some of them will also unfold if you choose to not involve yourself. Time lapses when you choose to sleep, and how often you need to sleep depend upon your ability to manage your resources.Interaction happens through a dialogue-interface. Character-skills, items, past choices and how you have affected the environment around you already, can all affect how you can conduct said interaction and what you can get out of it. Some interactions just let you get to know the setting better or affords you knowledge you needed for something. Other revolve around something you want to achieve, and they are resolved through weighted luck influenced by your character-build and how much resources you're willing to put into the task to improve your odds at succeding. Many interactions starts out as one of the two, then turns into the other. There are often several ways to go about a task, and you can often choose your approach. They aren't equal however. An example is a certain encounter where you may be tempted to kill a certain character. Doing so will enable you to loot her, but not doing so will afford you a unique skill. You can't do both.The resolution is based on what your character is trying to achieve. It's not a given that succeeding affords you the best outcome. An example is one of the times I fiddeled with some old tech to scrounge valuables from it. I failed but instead found something far more valuable.The interactions are perhaps the best I've seen in any game. They convey the people and setting extremely well while affording you great gameplay. I love it!Character-BuildThe charater building is great within the frame of the game as a whole. You wont find any customization of your looks (beyond sex), nor of your background. This is actually really good because it allows the game to revolve around who your character was before you started playing.You select between a group of descriptors and roles, ending up with a combination of 3 of these. The role you pick further gives you some options to choose from in the form of stats, skills and abilities. These will have a bigger impact on how you play the game than any RPGs since the 1999 classic Planescape: Torment. The range of skills and abilities are great, and you have to make some hard choices. The game accomodates a flexible character very well, as opposed to the min/max dogma of traditional RPGs.Some Examples of Notable Skills & AbilitiesScan Thought. With this ability you will read the thoughts of most NPCs most of the time. For reference other games with mind-reading abilities affords you an effect once in a while. It lifts a veil between you and their intentions and what's going on behind the sceenes. The drawback is that it can only rarely be used to resolve an interaction, although sometimes it does unlock new dialogues.Perception is a skill that expand alot of interactions. It's used often and thus quite valuable to have, but the tradeoff is that it's the most redundant skill amongst your party-members. They can use it instead when resolving interactions, reducing it's value for your character (in a good way).Anamnesis is similar in function to perception and Scan Thoughts, only focused inwards on yourself. It's your aptitude to summon flashbacks from your forgotten past. These flashbacks lifts the veil between you as a player and the past of your character.There are otherwise 3 social skills, 3 knowledge skills, 3 agility skills, 3 strength skills, 5 combat skills and 3 skills that only afford your character out-of-interaction properties. A couple of the skills see little use, but most of them are used frequently.Note, according to some backers the developers failed on delivering on all the options for character customization they promised. Another perspective is that they reprioritized their funds towards game-content. This because the majority of the backers wanted them to. Personally I find their decision well worth the tradeoff. The content is so tightly bound to customization-choises that the game has to go through several new passes for every single new option added. And the options are already formidable.Your Sh*tBeyond character-building, the artifacts you find have a big inpact on how well you're able to resolve interactions. Some also unlock new ones. You will find no sword +1 in Torment, rather a sword that allow you to do something you can't do without it or which affords you an advantage of some kind. There are mundane generic items around, but you'll soon have plenty of ancient technological wonders you'd rather use, and all of them unique and «hand-crafted».My review was too long to fit here. It will continue in the comments-section. But I'll include the conclusion here.Conclusion 11/10For me this game is one of the greatest of all time. For the target audience it's fantastic and a must-have. If you don't belong to the target audience I'd recommend not getting it, rather admire it from afar for being the best at what it sat out to become.:)

content:
Posted: March 3
												EDIT 2: Ok now I hate this game. The combat is absolutely bugged. I'm in a fight towards the end (trying to avoid spoilers) and I've RESTARTED THIS STUPID FIGHT 5 TIMES NOW because the AI keeps locking up and is unable to complete their turn. This is totally game breaking. I'm no longer recommending this game until they fix the freaking combat and make it not buggy.If they fix the combat bugs, I'll go back to giving this game a thumbs up and removing my combat edits/rants.EDIT 1 : OK I'm amending my review. I would give it somewhere in between yes/no. Why? The combat is absolutely horrible. I've been able to avoid most of it via dialog, but the times when you do have to do it just aren't fun. I won't spoil anything, so basically in any of the longer fights, or the unavoidable fights, the NPCs take FOREVER to act. It gets really really really tedious. Also sometimes the combat locks up and you can't end your turn (or the AI can't end its turn) and you have to once again RELOAD AND RETRY. I had this happen 4 times in a row on a quest in the Bloom. Took me ONE HOUR to beat the easy fight because of it. Ugh. It's also really freaking annoying when you have to fight but the build up to the fight involves a ton of dialog options/trees and so when you inevetiably have to reload (due to a bug or otherwise) you once again have to replay that entire sequence.Original review left below unmodified to help balance my dueline emotions about this game.I'm really liking this game. Great style, great music. Lots of text, so if you don't like reading you might not want to play it. I loved Planescape: Torment. Beat it many times. So far this game seems like a worthy successor. I also really like that you can avoid most combat if you want and play it via dialog. If you liked PST you'll dig this. There's some nice cameos too (I won't spoil them).Side note, unlike most RPGs where dying means you reload your game, in this one dying oftentimes unlocks side quests and advances the story. It's hard to find a situation where dying results in you needing to reload.This game is more like playing a novel. There's a ton of story and information and history behind the characters. While yes, it's a video game that has graphics that represent a world/theme (and does it well) the real strength lies in the text. Just like reading a book, the text in the game helps you visualize things in ways that graphics alone couldn't. Like the conveyance of emotion. It's more about learning who you are, what the world is about, and who your companions are than it is a typical RPG where you're fighting for vengence (or some ideal or whatever), leveling up, and becoming some uber-badas. The fact that you can avoid almost all combat in the game via dialog may put some people off. In fact, you don't even get forced into combat much at all. For those of you looking for a more combat oriented game, sadly this isn't it. For those of you that want to immerse yourself in the story of the universe in which the game is set, its companions, and yourself, and are prepared to spend a lot of time reading, then you'll enjoy this game.TLDR; This is a very cerebral game. A lot of reading, not so much in the way of combat (unless you seek it out). It's very binary. Either you'll love reading the voluminous text, or you'll hate it.

content:
Posted: March 5
												(editerd after more hours of play)I'm one of those people that believe Planescape: Torment, TToNumenera's predecessor, was a good game but a poor RPG. Unfortunately, TToN follows the same steps. It is not as linear, but the RPG elements are even more scarce. For example, I was level 3 when I had my first combat (aka "crisis"), that originated from choosing the "wrong" interaction with an item. In the subsequent battle, my party was wiped, All that seems like poor RPG design choices one after the other.The combat system (if you're lucky to see it) seems to be based on Pillars of Eternity, and slightly simplified. I understand combat is not the main attraction in any Torment game, but still something more could have been done.On the positive side, combat events are originally named as "crisis" as you can have non-violent solutions to them. Also the characters are interesting, the world is original, if a bit dark and gloomy, and the usage of stats to solve issues is quite interesting as well.I wouldn't recommend TToN it at full price and I wouldn't recommend it if you're expecting a RPG, but otherwise, it's a pleasant adventure game with some (very small) hints of RPG. Edit: Somewhere halfway the game, a choice I picked while chatting with a NPC, killed me instantly. This is unacceptable on a RPG and barely acceptable on an adventure. The game has just too many bad design choices, so I'm changing the review to "Not Recommended"

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
												Ideally, a review should be an objective evaluation of the merits and flaws of a game...but we all know that these days that's often not what happens.  Sites like Steam and Metacritic are littered with "reviews" that are expressions of agenda rather than honest appraisals.  "I'm mad that there's no crafting - 1 out of 10!"  Or "I'm counteracting the 1's with my 10!"  T:TON has attracted more than its share of such sentiments, mostly because of two reasons: angst about what some see as a betrayal of promises made during the development process, and secondly, a misunderstanding of what this game set out to do and what it is.  I'm not going to go into the former at all... I'm just going to say that if you're going to pick a cause to champion, railing against developers for normal development processes is not a very good one.  But I will talk some about the second because this game is very much worth playing for what it is, and all of the whining about what is is not, (or worse, what it "should be" in some entitled fan's imagination) is just noise.T:TON is a heavily story/dialogue based game.  The core of its gameplay is talking to NPCs, exploring the environment, and expressing your character in the way you desire to.  This game allows you to do that to an almost unprecedented degree.  Most quests have real weight to them, with different ways to accomplish them (not all of which are immediatley obvious), real ethical decisions, and ramifications that may come much later in the game.  The NPCs are imaginative, and plentiful, and the writing is fantastic.  I would count it among the top 5 or so games I've ever played in terms of writing quality.  The environments are full of things to interact with in interesting ways.  If you are a lover of story and writing, this game is absolutely worth playing. The systems of the game are more polarizing, though I would argue that they have considerable merit as well.  Combat IS not a focus.  It was never going to be, from the Kickstarter onwards, and it isn't.  However, those who say that you fight "once in 20 hours" or whatver are not correct.  There are many opportunities for combat if you desire it; it's just never going to be a random encounter with a trash mob.  As far as how the combat actually operates, that's a matter of taste, but the turn based system is a fit with how the game is played in general in a way that real time could never be.  In Crisis encounters (which is what the game calls combat, which should be a clue), you do not necessarily just fight, or in some cases, fight at all.  You can sometimes activate devices, or speak to your opponents.  In some cases, a Crisis is a moment of heightened drama, not a fight.  If you love constant, context-free combat, and feel that an RPG without it is boring, then you will be bored by this game.  That is not a fault of the game, or of you.  It is simply a sign that you two don't match.I could say a lot more about this game.  The environments, especially in The Bloom, are fantastic.  I enjoy the soundtrack.  There are a wide variety of interesting items to find (loot in most games is extremely boring after you've played for a few hours and seen most of what it can be mechanically; not so here).  And again, the story, characters, writing, and breadth of choice in your interactions is non pareil.  Bottom line, if you aren't the sort to get hung up on a less than perfect running animation, or the lack of a system proposed 4 years ago that didn't end up fitting into the game, and you ARE the sort who loves to explore a unique and vibrant world, love reactivity and choice, love story and an ability to write your own unique tale, then you owe it to yourself to ignore the folks with agendas and play this game.

content:
Posted: February 20
Early Access Review
								Planescape: Torment was an incredible game. One of my favorites, and one of the best of all time in my opinion. So far, this game is shaping up to be a worthy successor to that incredible adventure. If you're new to Torment, or old-school RPGs from the golden age of gaming in general, please don't deprive yourself of this game. It's a different experience than anything else out there at the moment. Don't expect crazy awesome gameplay and combat. Do expect a philosophical mind♥♥♥♥ of a story that is incredibly well written wherein your actions have extreme weight and meaning. Expect to be suprised. Expect your intelligence to be tested. This game will not hold your hand or shy away from big words that are not in your vocabulary, but it will paint a picture so vivid in your mind that no amount of cuda cores could ever hope to match it. If this game turns out to be as good (which is certainly seems to be)as it's predecessor,  trust me when I say that this game will HANDSOMELY reward you for finishing it. Not in fictional money, or loot, no; but in an altered perception that will carry into the real world. What does one life matter?

content:

												It's a strange and gorgeous world torn right out of a good sci-fi or fantasy novel and the game's mechanics complement the story and setting quite nicely.Obviously not an action title and the turn based combat is enjoyable enough in small doses here and there. I would put the writing up there with just about anything I've ever played before.Combat is mediocre but enjoyable enough if you like turn-based rpgs. Really you are here for the story and the intersting tidal pool system of progressing through challenges (won't go into detail here).It's good. Really good. Not sure if it's great yet but I have high hopes. I would say it's already been worth the price of admission and I am only about 10 hours in (maybe 1/4- 1/3 of the way through I am guessing).Update....erghhh. Changing my recommendation. It's pretty clear the first 1/3 of the game was done with level of production and the middle third or so a good step down in quality from that with the end of it feeling like a rushed mess.The main story (and it's very linear game if you were curious) in a vacum is just good enough to get a nod of approval. However it needed to be eleveated by other aspects of gameplay and writing in order to resonate and fails to do so mainly because the main character winds up being a half-user choice created personality (you pick'em) with the other half of that personality being a block of wood. Some games/stories get passed this hurdle by providing strong supporting characters with a ton of personality or a really good antagonist whom drives the plot forward. Well here the story of your side characters fails to evolve into anything of much interest past the first 1/3 and the antagonist was nothign to write home about. The bad guy I found to be somewhat interesting in concept but again just not good enough without any character to draw the player. Overall the lore is great and stays pretty strong up until the last hour or so of the game. The prose is gold standard other games should reach for but ultimatley the story falls well short of the mark it would need to completely carry the game. The turn-based battles become more tedious and harder to avoid towards the end of the game. It really hurts the experience and it felt unbalanced and poorly planned out by the end of the game. The skills system is pretty easy to overpower once you reach the half way point of the story with a decent amoutn of time spent on sidequest which sees it's early potential squandered.  Tactical considerations are not terrible important to your success as long as you have a decent character setup.Artwise it's a mixed bag here. The enviornments are well thought out and put together. Only a few maps (particularly towards the end) fail to impress. On the other hand the character models are pretty vanilla imo. The style of the armor/clothing on some of the major models are fairly well done but alot of the others are barely distinguishable from one another and while never terrible failed to impress and became a let down compared to the background/map artwork.So in the end we have a lore-rich interesting sci-fi shell and intro that is cause for alot of excitement and then the game just kind of slumps along without direction until it devolves into a really huge disappointment in the last few hours. This is the biggest implosion after a promising start to a game since...well Wasteland 2 probably. Not a good trend for this developer and I'm really sad to have to give this a thumbs down.4.5/10

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1
												It is amazing how a game like this can see the light of day when most major releases are the same chewed-out spoonfed concepts and gigantic overhyped disappointments full of repetitive elements such as leveled loot and fetch quests. Games which are usually filled with bloatware and microtransactions. I don't need to name any examples. You know what I am talking about.This game is a big '♥♥♥♥ you' to that. It is also a big '♥♥♥♥ you' to the culture of fast, flashy graphics, "carrot on a stick" playstyles, and excessive player guidance. Is it an archaic game? Sure. That's the whole point - the entire world of Numenera is archaic. It solely exists as parts of an infinity of other worlds, so it cannot be anything other than archaic. That is one of its strong suits - it does not simplify the complexities of an infinite world.Is this a game with poor combat? No. If you think so, you are missing the entire point of the game. Visit the Fifth Eye in Cliff's Edge and talk to the veterans. The world of Numenera is largely beyond simple combat. It is so vast and complex that wars are fought as folds between time, as complexities in a universe that is perceived entirely differently by its inhabitants - many of whom you'll meet in the game. The combat in this game is interwoven in its story.But are the actual combat mechanics poor? Not at all. They are not on par with Shadowrun, but Shadowrun's immersion pales in comparison to what this game has on offer. The combat in this game is about as good as the stories of Shadowrun.But is the game an interactive book, then? This term has a negative connotation that is not necessary. The world is incredibly rich, so rich that it would simply be impossible to animate everything. By relying on intricate conversations that are highly interwoven, a level of complexity is achieved that would normally not be possible. Granted, if you do not enjoy reading, you should not play this game. You should also stop reading my review, and install Call of Duty.

content:
Posted: April 22
												I would agree with others, in that the game suffers by comparison to PS:T.  Taken on its own, I'd give it a solid B+.  With reference to PS:T, probably not higher than a B-.  I thought there were a lot of missed opportunities.  With the companions, I didn't like the arbitrary limits on how many and who could be in your party, when combat is so minimal.  And even if they're not "in" your party for combat/skill purposes, they could have been hovering unseen for social interaction purposes.  There was rarely any point to talking to them regularly, and they did not evolve for better or for worse during the game (sometimes the text implied they did, but not in a mechanical sense, with a few exceptions).  As others have said, they were all pretty boring, despite hints of intrigue.I didn't understand the character development options being so limited and combat-focused when the game is so combat-light.  Likewise the inventory management, especially the cyphers, which were almost all combat-oriented.  The few non-combat cyphers generally weren't needed, because skill checks in conversation got very trivial very fast.  The Last Castoff's character options were especially bland.I thought they handwaved away the most interesting locales, like the Necropolis.  When I think of Curst Gone/Carceri in PS:T, and how you could literally sway the fabric of the setting through interesting interactions ... there was nothing like that in T:ToN.  For that matter, the Tides didn't even matter, they should have been fundamentally reshaping the world by the end of the game.Is it worth playing?  I think so.  I didn't have problems with bugs or glitches and found the game pleasant.  The Numenera setting is beautiful and compelling.  But it would have been better to plan a trilogy and done the first part of the game in more depth.

Early Access Review
								This game was everything I was looking for and more, it scratches the CRPG itch and I can't wait for the full release next month. Overall I really enjoyed my experience and so far this is shaping up to be better than Pillars of Eternity if the story continues to intrigue me.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
												It's a little too Planescape Torment, than inspired by Planescape Torment, imo. How much yearning one has for nostalgia vs wanting something new will weigh heavily on how much you enjoy the game. I haven't finished yet, but that's largely because I keep taking large breaks. Why do I keep taking breaks? Because the game crashes often enough to be annoying. So far, the crashes fall into the following categories:1) Everything appears alright, but you're no longer able to interact with anything. Alt-tabbing out and back in and out again and you'll find the Torment Window is now unresponsive. Must kill the process and restart. 2) Audio starts to stutter, then the game crashes to desktop.3) Audio starts to stutter, then the game causes Windows to crash to the BSOD with a kernal error.#2 has been the most common crash. Sometimes the last manual/auto save was right before a crash. Sometimes not. I find myself quite lethargic when it isn't, knowing I have to repeat everything between my last save and the crash. Hence the breaks. I suspect that says something about how I feel about the game, though I do enjoy the story.Anyway, if games like Planescape Torment, the BG series, Pillars of Eternity, etc, are your cup of tea, this is more of the same. The effort system is the game's unique twist to the tried and true formula (though I swear I've seen it before in other games, I just can't remember what games exactly), and your best bet is to ensure you and your Companions all master a different stat, and maybe double up on either Speed or Intelligence (3 stats, 4 party members-including yourself). So far, it doesn't appear you can change the armor for your Companions, which makes them increasingly fragile as the game has progressed so far, so even though I'm not playing a front line fighter, I still...play a front line fighter, because I have much better defenses than any of my Companions. One Companion I'm keeping is basically useless, but I'm hoping there's some traditional RPGness to this Companion where if I stick with it for the long haul, there'll be a reward of some sort. Though, as a developer, I would definitely enjoy skewing convetions on that front. Outside of the crashes, there are a few other bugs I've encountered:1) One of the early quests didn't trigger completion. After searching the internet, it's obvious it should have triggered to another step and then completed, but it didn't. Sadly, the NPC thought it had, and no longer exists. It went undone, then was forcibly removed as I progressed to the next area. 2) Buff icons sometimes vanish while still being in effect, but will sometimes come back after zoning. You can still see the effects if you hover over a character icon when this occurs. 3) Lots of minor pathing issues where you or your Companions get stuck on an object on the map or a person. Clicking around the stuck point has, so far, caused them to repath and get unstuck. Lastly, there's an ommision I always find very puzzling whenever it is omitted by a developer: A complete lack of Windowed, Borderless mode. I have never understood the point of a Windowed mode set to the monitor's resolution that isn't borderless, as such a Window never fits correctly. Considering one can write a few lines in Autohotkey to make a window borderless, it just doesn't seem like such a mammoth undertaking for a developer to make this a graphical option, and I am completely bewildered how anyone who's played more than a few hours of games on a PC doesn't consider this a basic function for a PC game. Certainly, the developers pertrude the aura of gamers, which makes this lack incredibly puzzling. In conclusion, the game probably needs an in-depth bug pass. It definitely could use voice acting (I'm sure it was beyond their budget, but I'd probably have made that the very first stretch goal; it's all about priorities). It's too much of the same old same old for me to get too blubbery about it, but I am not hating it. I just find it a little exhausting, due to the combination of sameness and crashes. If you know another game that's very similar to Planescape Torment, BG 2, etc, is going to wow and amaze you, then I heartily recommend it. If you're looking for something with similar written depth as Planescape Torment, but in a fresh and different package...well, this isn't really it (the second part). I do wish Steam gave you the option for a neutral thumb, but for now, I'll go with a thumb down, just to potentially move the aggregate needle enough that perhaps the technical issues might get a patch or two in response.

content:
Posted: March 4
												A brilliant game. I was a day 1 backer for this project, and have been a big PS:T fan since its release. And I'm surprised and excited that somehow, despite my apprehensions, TTON has turned out to be a really enjoyable game and a worthy successor to the original Torment. I've already played through it once and I'm sure I'll return to it many more times in the future. It is easily one of the best-written games in recent years, with a unique setting, some great characters and some interesting role-playing opportunities. Loved the art design too. Generally a fascinating universe to explore and an intriguing plot to unravel. The much-criticised combat was actually fine as far as I am concerned, and the fights I chose to get involved in were fun to play. It does run a bit slow when there are many opponents, but I really don't see what is a big problem. Especially since this is not Dark Souls where combat is a major selling point. It is sad that some of the kickstarter goals were cut or changed, but the game did not obviously suffer for it.  The developers choosing to expand Bloom as a hub at the cost of the planned Oasis was clearly the right call. Bloom is by far the more interesting setting and created opportunities for some unique cool art and writing.  It is a shame to lose a couple of planned companions, as they sounded interesting, but I was very happy with the six companions the game did provide and enjoyed their personal quests, ad-hoc interjections and so on.  If the trade-off was between more companions and more fleshing out, I am glad InExile chose the latter.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3
												Tides of Numenera was an instant backing choice for me, when the Kickstarter campaign happened. Fond memories of Planescape: Torment, excitement about the new juicy Numenera setting. It has been a long 4 year wait. Did the game meet my expectations? Abso-effing-lutely.In a weird post-scifi world, filled with intriguing stories, characters, factions, locations, items ..I feel at home. This game is such a joy to experience, there's a huge amount of reading to do, and oh how well it is written. The reactivity of it all, leaves me dumbfounded on many occasions. Between devouring the awesome stories and enjoying the cool Effort system, Tide system, Esoteries, Bonded Artifacts, Cyphers, and Oddities, I stop often to listen to the amazing atmosphere-building music pieces and sound design, and to gawk at the majestic & weird visuals and environments.The Crisis system for dangerous situations or combat is great, I feel like the abilities and items of my party members give me perfect personal ways to deal with things, and I feel like I have gotten into combat when I wanted to fight, and could evade fighting when I felt my party should do so.I know there would be too much to write about, and it's all too personal anyway, I've touched upon most aspects of the game, and I love it all. I can't put to words how much I like experiencing this game.Highly recommended for fans of deep RPGs, fans of great writing, fans of oldschool reactive CRPGs.

content:
Posted: March 2
												This game is amazing.I always loved the old isometric CRPGs: Fallout, Planescape, etc. and I was super pumped when the genre's renaissance began with Shadowrun Returns, and Wasteland 2. Back in the 90s, Planescape Torment was the reigning champion of the CRPG world. A 100,000 word heavyweight of literary themes and innovative storytelling.Torment tries, and largely succeeds, at recapturing that magic.  The world is incredibly inventive. A science fantasy wonderland with a semi-medieval society built on the ruins of multiple post-Singularity civilizations.  A world of mysterious machines, half buried and half working, of mysterious and malevolent biomechanical creatures, and a world of technology so advanced it's indistinguishable from magic.  Also, the combat is terrible.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8
												Would I recommend this game? Yes!I found the setting to be fresh and fascinating. This isn't just a testament to the world of Numenera, but the excellent work of the writers and artists who made the essence of that world fill my screen. While the settings were wildly different, all of it screamed Planescape and Baldur's Gate to me - in a way that Pillars of Eternity frequently did not. Torment's environments were perfectly foreign, which made my comfort in them even more surprising. Benjamin has an essay on translation where he likens the task of translation to the construction of tangent circles -- Torment feels like that to me. Beautifully connected to, and reminiscent of, a game that I love, while complete on its own terms.--Mechanically, the game was sound. It felt like I had multiple avenues to resolve each of the vignettes that I participated in. I reloaded many times throughout my playthrough to experience some of the alternate ways of solving and creating problems.I encountered a few annoyances, but no bugs. The combat was fine. There were a few times when I became frustrated while trying to activate an ability 'behind' someone, but the perspective made that impossible. Hopefully that will be patched out.--While I'll give the game some time to breathe now, I am planning on a second run where I push entirely different Tides to the forefront. My limited exploration of alternate paths satisfied my curiosity as to whether the game handled them effectively.--I would say that it took me around 45 hours to finish this game, for those of you worried about time to completion. I did all of the sidequests that I could find, although I almost certainly missed a few.

content:
Posted: March 2
												I like the game. It does not fullfil all kickstarter promises and inXile has ruined their reputation(in my opinion) for making lots of dubious decisions and cuts based on reasosn that - after playing through the game - are cleary nothing but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I don't even want to know the reasons and why they stayed so silent on all that. Maybe its greed, maybe they are just dumb or think their fans are. Whatever. I'm here to rate the game, not some selfish and awful choices of a few dudes leading the company creating it or the publisher. Because if you get over this you have a very well written visual novella with a very fresh setting, and a enormous depth. A story with many choices and consequences, that is still rewarding if you don't save scam to get the perfect result out of every situation. Sometimes even fails are victories. If you take the time to take all those philosophic thoughts in, the game will make you stop from time to time to think about what just happened. This happened not often to me in the last years.The game is not especially hard in terms of tactics or combat. You get through it without being stuck by a difficult riddle or a challenging fight. So it has a nice flow that is about telling a story and not about super-complex RPG-rulesets and tactical combat. Remembers me in terms of this flow a little bit to a game like loom(even if TToN is 10 times longer) where you just wander around, talk to people and feel the wonders of a strange but atmospheric and well presented world.It took me about 40hours to get through the game while doing all the quests i could find. When i consider that nearly all combat is quickly over and compare this to pillars of eternity - where you wade through piles and piles of enemies -  and also end up with 30-40 hours play time, i come to the conclusion that torment is packed with 3-4 times as much story as PoE. Maybe even more. You have to consider for yourself what you like more.Note: If you are german: I recommend to play the game in english. The german translation is really bad.

content:
Posted: March 20
												Let me start by saying this: there are a lot of Steam reviews that give the game a thumbs down because it doesn't live up to the venerable Planescape: Torment. This is true, but the game can still easily be recommended. It's by no means a bad game. If recommending a game hinges on whether it lives up to one of the greatest games ever made, then you might be setting too high a bar.So no, this is not Planescape: Torment. On that note, let's get the negatives out of the way first. The plot is not as interesting, nor as personal as Planescape. The characters are not as fascinating and deeply wrought. The dialogue isn't as clever or as unique. It's also not as funny. On top of that, the animations are often janky, there aren't that many party members, the game isn't all that long (in cRPG terms), combat is a bit of a mess, character abilities and progression feel limited, you can't return to major hubs after you leave them, and the oft-mentioned Tides system has almost no impact on anything. All that would make the game sound pretty awful out of context. However, here is what you do get:  gorgeous and fascinating areas to explore, an interesting and well-written story, deep and satisfying conversation options with interesting NPCs, difficult moral judgments, lots of branching choices, and numerous fascinating little side quests and miniature stories to experience. Ultimately, it's the discovery in this game that makes everything worthwhile. While I never felt pushed forward by the plot, I was always interested in the characters and the world around me. Numenera is a great and fantastic world with tons of variety and wierdness. The developers have really explored this and used it to its fullest. The numenera you get, and even the useless oddities you acquire for sale all have their own little stories or quirks. Exploring a city inside the body of a living transdimensional monster is awesome, as are the wonderful people that live there. I wanted to keep playing because I wanted to know what was up with this immortal dimension-hopping guy over here, or what would happen if I told this kid he was adopted from a family in another time. So no, it doesn't do everything we might want from a Torment game, but it does enough to recommend it. I enjoyed my playthrough of it. I think, if you like cRPGs, you will too.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2
												I finished my first playthrough yesterday. I did it in two approaches, without actual pause to anything but a two-hours sleep, and game storyline (including save scumming) takes around 35 hours for me (and it's 23 on game timer). I believe it's means something, at least for me.So, I love a game. My primary complain is that in 4 years you can expect more content. PS:T takes 47 hours (in game-timer, I believe - can't really say) on main+extra completions, and I think I tried to be completionist there, it's 60 hours; but for first Deus Ex, that I take as another Great RPG, it would be 28 hours. I missed at least one merecaster though (couldn't say how to fix it and is it even possible), and I played as social+lore Nano, and it's definitly easiest way. Just in case, I hate current approach to "remake classical way to gaming". I've never managed to complete Pillars of Eternity, just dropped... on castle at most. But T:ToN I completed on one approach and not regret a second.Also I should admit, I pleged game on kickstarter 4 years ago, first day I believe (it was, well, 4 years ago, so I'm not sure), and dropped to follow development. I knew about cut features only, well, four days ago, and truth to said I don't mind. So, what's bad for me here.1. Foci. Only three foci, and only one of them is actually fits my game playstyle somehow - I mean that about charisma. I can't say I like it much (I played sage, not charismatic, with Lores, Concentration and Anamnesis maxed), but at least it's better then Breath Shadows or Masters Defence. Also it had nice bonus with Inspired (that works bad for my main character - I believe to get Inspired fettle you must actually ENTER aura, and when you never do it - after your character dies, for example - it just don't renew itself), other bonuses are meh. Putting one more effort to social tasks seems nice, in the beginning, but can't say I recall any moment I needed it. And last tier boni for social focus is ridiculus - when you get that fourth tier, playing around social playstyle, you will supposedly have at least one dot in Persuasion and a lot of Edge to have 100% to social rolls without spending anything. You just won't spend your Int pool to make this ability useful. With actually quite bland abilities foci, I believe, it was possible to put some more. I mean, not as foci was something play-defining for me. I felt more impact from Tides.2. Bugs. Sure, I've take my toll. First, I had scary bug that make every Crisis a chance game - sometimes it just stuck in the middle of somebody action, and only way is quit game by terminate process and replay last save. The worst issue was when it happens in combat with Sorrow in Bloom - it's actually not nice with all that pre-fight cutscenes and dialogs. Also I had a bug with Avina (girl in a quest about five women), when I find her, but didn't rid her from artifact she had, and restored Seria with tidal surge. Well, that was strange, because I don't actually *restored* her, I made her to speak, and she burst in the end; then I entered her fantom, loaded, and voila, Seria was stand there as it should be. Avina spirit never appears, even as quest says I found her.3. Equipment. Well, that's not actual issue, but I really want to have more armor choices.What's bad for other players, but kinda ok for me.1. Companions. Well, there is six characters for selection, and just three slots for them. Normally you'll get Rinn, so it's 2 characters. In that six characters we have one glaive (one-and-half, if you count Aligern), three Jacks (if you include Rinn), and two Nanos. But game definitly build into Int playthrough, not bashing your way, so that's ok at least for me. By the way, official wiki says Callistege is Red+Silver Tide-wise, and that's strange - for me, she is totally Blue. Maybe I don't get Tides at all?.. Anyway, I like Rinn, I like Callistege and I like Erritis. I find them deep and nice, even with "Callistege personal quest" I felt blurred from all over the game until last choice in underwater phantom. Hell. Because I felt it blurred.2. Intelligence playstyle. Yes, I definitly can feel how game builded with this way in mind. But, well, Planescape: Torment definitly was build into high Int/Wis character, even if you could play another style. So it's ok for me.3. Rinn. I get it there is a lot of hate about Rinn. Yeah, you would feel yourself as a real♥♥♥♥♥♥when you leave her alone - but, sorry, how do you should feel yourself, getting a homeless girl, protecting her from slavers and then dropping? Yes, that's a♥♥♥♥♥♥move, so it's nice to see that game writing don't let you miss it. Also she actually wasn't useless for me. With high stealth, armed with light shooting weapon and carrying a lot of healing items around, she became a dedicated healer, and then she got Innervate. So until you don't forget to put her in stealth after each cast, she is amazing. Also take in head I don't play with a lot of actual combat.4. Turn-based combat. Actually, that's ok for me. Combat is something that I hated in PoE (with all that timed sword strikes). Tyranny was little better, but still. Hell, I hated that even in Arcanum, and it wasn't something I loved in PS:T. 5. Mechanic simplification. Yes, in tabletop game hit points don't exist, and pools used as three types of hits. Actually, in rules it's said that Might pool is "damage by default", but neverless. I recalling early betas where there was not dedicated hit points (and interface was HORRIBLE in my option), maybe I'm imagining things, but I even thought "it's a quite bad idea, because in short game without stable recovery I would save points, as they're my hit points". Actually I don't like Cypher system, I found it too limited and class-based, but, well... it's nice for CRPG.What's good?1. Setting. Not as much inXile effort, but, I believe, it's nice implementation for Numenera, as Planescape: Torment was nice for Planescape. It actually made me to read Numenera, as PS:T made me to read Planescape.2. System. Well... I feel that it don't realised in full potential. But it's quite nicer that trendy bleak "generic classical RPG system based on d20", that seems to be so appearing to modern game design.2. Story. It IS great. Actually I don't believe in "classical narrative ways", I believe Mass Effect with video cuts and good (even with all my problems with 1st) graphics model is better for computer game. But in T:ToN I actually read all that text (PoE couldn't get me such way, and every time I starts I played for 2-3 hours only!). I believe it could be great if it was full-sounded and realistic graphics, and more gameplay options but text ones, but story is good enough to suppress gameplay and development limitations. There are things I never saw (Eternal Battle for example), and some things I would make another way or tone, but it is great. And it haven't obvious plot holes I can actually argue, and that's nice again.It's not just interactive book, it'a a game. And it's the best RPG I played for years, maybe sharing the honor with Tyranny first act. Second and third was kinda crap, but first act was great. And T:ToN is fully as good as Tyranny first act.

												A brief look at the negative reviews of this game should be more than enough to compel you to play it. The people who are drowning this game in negativity are doing so, almost without exception, with the caveat that they've enjoyed the game. However, they're angry, potentially rightfully, that things were cut that were promised in the Kickstarter. However, these omissions do not take away from what is an exceptional game, and it is an injustice to dissuade people from playing in a misguided lashing out at missed promises. I strongly recommend you give Tides of Numenera a try, if you like narratively driven RPGs. If you don't, look elsewhere.
