content:
Posted: March 3
												To start with, let me explain that I haven't finish the game yet and that most of my playtime (~50h) came from early access. However I have seen this game evolve since it started early access always, in my opinion, in a positive manner. So far, I already created the character I want to be (having experimented with character creation in early access) and I'm having lots of fun.Pros: Character Creation is different and interesting, keeping you immersed in the world from the beggining. I also think it has a good (short) length when compared with other games that have done similar things (like Oblivion). The game is focused on your character story, not the world's. I loved the choices you make about how to react and what to tell other characters from the beggining (will you lie? or tell the truth and face the consequences).  For the first time in a long history of gaming ( I started playing in the late 80's and yes, I played the original Torment) I found myself interested to see what would happen instead of reloading when things didn't go my way.  The use of the stats pool (foci, I think its called) is very interesting. I don't know the rules of Numenera RPG but the way  they are used in this game (like currency) is interesting and different. I found myself sometimes risking the throw of the dice with a 70%/75% to try and save points to a more important choice and (as mencioned before) actually accepting when it fails :) The obvious care in creating the similarities between this game and Planescape Torment: the nameless and, although not amnesiac, totally clueless character; the death mecanic as a feature; the strange world, characters and laws. Planescape Torment is one of my favourite games. In my opinion, this IS a spiritual successor to that game. You can avoid conflict (called Crysis) by choosing another path. You can even try and persuade the other NPC's in the middle of combat, which I found very interesting. Besides that, you can use the enviromnent to your advantage in the fight. As I rather like to avoid fights, all this choices are refreshing. The many ways you can finish a quest. I like quests and feel almost obligated to find every single one and finish it. The amount of ways you can finish the side quests actually begs for another playthrough to find out what would happen if I did it some other way. Cons: I like the graphics. BUT, I agree with some other reviewers that the main character portrait is somewhat ugly (I always play as a female). However, as I said before, I played the original Torment and nobody can call the Nameless One character as pretty :D  Another nitpick is that I miss the other character portraits when talking to someone. I have no problem with reading lots of text but I  like "seing" who I am talking to when it comes to dialogs. This game is too serious sometimes. I miss the humour from Planescape (mostly delivered by Morte) that gave a much needed escape from all the drama.I may change my review when I finish the game, but I highly recomend this to anyone that enjoys good writing, a very original and interesting world, interesting characters and a good story.

content:
Posted: March 26
												I recommend this game, because overall I did like it, but there is no escaping the fact that it was a big let-down.  Planescape: Torment was one of my favorite games of all time, so when I learned that it was getting a sort of sequel-in-spirit, made by many of the same people, I was very excited.  Then came the waiting.  I have no information about what was going on behind the scenes, but it seems obvious that there must have been serious development troubles, because this game was announced in March 2013 with a scheduled release date of December 2014, but didn't come out until February 2017.  I started and finished law school, passed the bar exam, and started working at a law firm in that same interval.  If I had not had to wait so long, I would not have been so disappointed.The other problem is that this game is inferior to Planescape: Torment in most respects.  P:T had a more interesting story with more interesting characters.  I really cared about my companions in P:T.  They were traveling with me for a reason.  My companions in T:ToN were just sort of there.  With the exception of Matkina, none of them had particularly good reasons to follow me around.  And none of them, except Rhin, had interesting stories or personal quests.  I also found the main character's story to be much less interesting.  In P:T, TNO had this gripping personal saga, and it was just that: personal.  TNO was confronting his own mortality.  He had to learn from his past mistakes.  In T:ToN, the LCO was just being chased by this poorly thought-out monster for not much reason (once you find out what it is and where it came from, it becomes clear that the Sorrow is little more than a weak imitation of a Mass Effect Reaper).  Again, though, what hurt this game for me was the high expectations I had for it.  I was expecting another experience like P:T, and I didn't get it.Why then, if I was so disappointed, am I giving this game a thumbs-up?  Because it was actually a fairly solid journeyman effort.  As long as you go into it with moderate expectations, this is a reasonably enjoyable game.  Far from greatness, but still decent.  It has an interesting setting and competent storytelling.  It is definitely on the easy side, although there are a few serious challenges.  I had hoped for a lot more, but it's still an enjoyable game.

content:
Posted: March 2
												Torment is a niche game for a niche category of gamers. And in this niche it does very well: story and dialogs are great, the world is interesting to explore, failure does not mean autoload of a previous save, etc. If you knew what you are getting, it hits the spot.Most of negative reviews either mention dialog focus or limited combat (not a lot of encounters and combat system being pretty rudimentary). While both of those are true, this is exactly what the game was offering and joke is on the people who expected anything else. I like good combat and would like to see it improved a bit in Torment, but the game does not deserve a negative review because of it.There are also complaints about cut content - I am a day 1 backer and I was backing the core of the game, which I am satisfied with, not the extras. I believe the game was made with a lot of care and attention to detail and I do not think Inxile just drank the extra money away (not all of it, at least). This is an issue with too many promisses which inxile didnt manage to keep fully and too much emotion from the backers who seemingly would not back the game if they knew from the start it is going to be turn-based or have only 6 companions.In conclusion, it is a fun game unless you had some unreasonable expectations or not a fan of reading alot.

Product received for free
												In its present state, Numenera shamelessly usurps Torment's name and legacy and does not even scratch the surface of the majesty, glory, importance and damn it, plain old good fun that it's "spiritual father" provided. The feeling of a hastily released and under-developed game pervades every second of Numenera and will be the subject of a myriad RPG post-mortems in 2017. Something obviously tragically derailed between the Kickstarter campaign and its actual release and the game was released "as it was" in order to recoup development costs. inXile's Wasteland 2, whilst not creation's greatest RPG, stands as a towering and eternal masterpiece compared to Numenera.Shame on you inXile, you have failed us. content:
Posted: March 2
												I am not a huge fan of this game. I have played all of the Pillars of Eternity engine games and play almost all crpg that have been released. This game was made worse by the fact it was made to port to PS$ and XBOX. Its essentially a choose your own story adventure. CONS1. You do not choose your character. You are assigned a very strange looking fellow and told how your narrow hips are just right.(I joke not that's fricking weird) The character creation system is usually one of my favorite parts of this type of game and gives games like this replay value. This has none of that. You play the same little story to pick your abilites of the last cast off and then you get to change a little at the end. 2. If you like combat like I do this is probably not the game for you.  So far I have managed to get in one fight, the combat system isn't clarified very well and the system of ciphers basically mean they are your power base for the game. 3. Very limited tactical choices. Spells bah who needs them, spend your might and intellect to make sure you hit......strange system that so far is not fun.4. Slow Load time of choices on text.5. Bad charcater models for having zero choice in appearance. Tyranny was far better and you could make your charcater look like what ever you wanted. 6. I spent 44 bucks and find myself going, I really don't want to play this, its really boring. (Its honestly a boring game)PRO's1. Interesting quests and good story with mutliple ways to finish quests.

number of helpful: 18 of 35 people (51%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 1
												-Really entertaining, unique, yet troubled lore-centric RPG-fodder-The game is essentially a reimagining of the original Planescape Torment in another world and with a slighty different story. Though the new companions aren't quite as lifelike as Dakkon, Morte and Annah, think Pillars of Eternity quality.Again it features a compelling fantastic environment with lots of weirdo characters and items to figure out.There's not much combat and it can usually be overcome by dialogue challenge also.ProDeep backstory, fascinating world. I like how the narrative fits together and you slowly unlock what has happened.You never know whether things and choices are important, you can't easily game the game as you do all others.ConBland, disappointing graphics just do the job, look like my old Planescape at times. 95k backers it says when the game starts, where did the money go?  The colorfully imagined fantasy landscape as observed in the preview/designer artwork could have been better served with a say "Original Sin"-modern look instead of returning to good old Baldur's Gate.Lack of character portraits esp. for the lead NPCs you have to use your imagination. Recently found out one has a disfigured face and a mask by reading about it later.Has no codex of NPCs and races like PS:T had (including artwork) -very lazy. Maybe their graphic artist was on sick leave all these years of developement.Other-You read a whole lot of dialogue text, might not appeal to everyone.-All builds and approaches are viable but therefore gameplay's not very challenging at all. [edit: some difficulty spikes - that's why you hoarded those one-use items]27 hours of play +5 if you read exactly every word.Hint-Make a spreadsheet on paper, note all names esp. the castoffs and their connection, you'll thank me later. Also a changing god timeline would be great to have.

content:
Posted: January 29
												Delays beyond count, features cut from the stretch goals, ported to consoles instead of delivering what was promised in the kickstarter, poor communication to backers. This is the last inXile game that I'll ever Kickstart, and any future purchases won't be until there's a steep discount.  I cannot in good faith recommend this game at this time.UPDATE.I'm updating this review, as the game is out now, and I have played the content that is available, and I am sticking to my original  negative impression.  The game that has been released, doesn't come close to the game that was described in the original Kickstarter.  It draws heavily from other games, even anamnesis 'memory recall' skill is basically soul reading from Pillars of Eternity.  The game mechanics are very basic, combat is virtually nonexistant, so there's no real need to do any shopping at vendors, it's really quite ugly, and the narrative doesn't make up for any of the flaws.  The story is a rehashed, linear novel with boring characters, who give the player no reason to care about having them in their party or completing their sidequests.For as long as this game was delayed, and how much of it was cut, it's obvious now that getting this game to console was and is a cash grab to make up for the underwhelming experience that inXile has delivered.

								Fantastic!   The current build is far more stable then previous.  Really enjoyable game that is heavy on the role-playing and story elements. content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
 Instant Classic	I just finished this game, I wrote an early access review a long time ago but didn't want to write a real review until I beat the game after final release. First off I must say the people complaining about this game aren't really rpg fans, they can't be. I have read some of the ridiculous reviews bad mouthing this game over the dumbest stuff like the developer making changes to the combat system. Who cares, they changed it to turn based combat(it plays great this way) and I see no issue with it affecting the game. The combat doesn't have to be a big part of the game anyway if you don't like the system don't get into combat, you don't lose out on XP either as most of the large gains are from the text options you choose. This lets you play anyway you want and you still can enjoy the story which is fantastic. Now to get to the actual review. To me it is one of the best rpgs I have ever played and an instant classic, to be honest it is better than Planescape and I loved that game. This game to me hangs with all the classic rpgs from the late 90s and early 2000s like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dales, Arcanum and the REAL Fallout games. The story is great and a breath of fresh air  because it is new and original enough to make it so you want to see what is going to happen next and don't mind reading all the dialog(this coming from someone who hates to read). I can't recommend this game enough to not only rpg fans but to any person who loves a good story and having their choices that affect the game world, their choices  actually changing what happens in the end game. Not really a spoiler but your choices do show up in the ending of the game, and unlike a game like Mass Effect(which I also loved) which promised to make your choices count and didn't come through, this game does.I also loved how this game lets you play any way you want. As I stated above, you don't have to fight more than a few times if you don't want too, you can talk your way through 90% of this game easily and get everything with dialog and abilities you could gain with a blade. This game really doesn't punish for roleplaying any type of character, not all rpgs can say that. The XP gains also feel well paced but depending how you play, you can exploit some of the game with abilities at higher levels and make the last parts of the game pretty easy but it doesn't take anything away from the overall experience imo.So to sum up this review if you skipped my novel above:Buy this game, it is well worth full price and a steal if you buy it on a sale. This game is for real rpg fans and gamers looking for a very story rich/text heavy game with the freedom to make choices that affect the end game and let you play any style you like with out punishment. I give this game a 9.5/10.

content:
Posted: March 12
												Before I get to the review, I have to say that I am NOT a Kickstarter backer. I bought the game a few days after release (about 3 days later).Torment: Tides of Numenera is a CRPG very much in the veins of the old Planescape: Torment game, which is regarded as one of the pinnacles of the genre (the other being Baldur's Gate 2). Expect to read a lot of story and dialogue in this game, and DON'T expect an emphasis on combat (if that prospect bores you, this *isn't* a game for you). The game took me nearly 40 hours to beat, which makes it one of the shorter CRPGs out there, but at the same time it felt enough. There are a total of 3 classes to play (a warrior, mage and a "jack of all trades" - I played the mage, in order to get most of the dialogue options).The visuals consist of pre-rendered still backgrounds (like in the case of all Infinity Engine games, and more recently in the case of Pillars of Eternity) with animated and intertactive elements. The backgrounds are, in my humble opinion, beautiful. The GUI does it's job well (even if it's a bit too "futuristic" for my taste) and the font used works well and you can play with it's size (which is important, because you'll be doing a lot of reading). The visual effects on spells and weapons during combat are okay, some of the early spells look kinda generic, but some of the later ones have cool effects and animations. Character and clothing animations are well done. There is voice acting, but only for key lines. I feel like there could have been more, especially on plot relevent characters. If you have played Pillars of Eternity, then know that this game has less voice acting than that game.The soundtrack to this game (which I got on a separate CD as a bonus) is okay and pleasing, albeit not exactly memorable (I can recall only the battle theme). That isn't that big of a deal for me, because I don't mind a soundtrack that "blends in" and doesn't interrupt reading.The story is well made, I didn't notice any glaring problems like abundant plot-holes. It kept me interested and invested in the game and it's characters 'till the end. The end itself is competent, imho, and takes into consideration a lot of the player's behavior during the game. The party members are quite good and interesting, and none of them follow any particular clichés (also, I didn't find any of them annoying, which is a big plus). There is very little combat, even for a game inspired by Planescape: Torment. You can skip a lot if you play a talkative and persuasive character (which is good), but the total number of potential (and unskippable) combat encounters (called "crises" in this game) can becounted on the fingers your hands (only one hand when it comes to those that you can't skip through dialogue - including the tutorial fight)It needs to bew said, however, that the game has a few bugs and glitches (at least at the time of writing this review). The most annoying I ran into was a bug that kept messing up the volume of voices and general sfx, making them very quiet and hard to hear. This bug occured when transiting between maps and messing around in the inventory and character screen. The game never crashed, however, and I didn't encounter any broken quests or dialogues. As far as framerate goes, my GTX 970, I7 CPU and 16 GB of RAM kept it at solid 60fps the entire time. Loading times were reasonably fast on my Samsung EVO SSD (500GB).So, let us summarize:Pros:- beautiful pre-rendered backgrounds- competent, mature and interesting story- interesting characters and party members- seamless, if not memorable, soundtrackCons:- short overall game time for a cRPG (cca 40 hrs)- buggy sound fx and a handful of other, smaller bugs- very little combat (Planescape: Torment had more potential encounters)While not perfect, Torment: Tides of Numenera is a competently written cRPG that plays fine, and I still count it among games worth playing and endorsing. Be prepared to read a lot, though.+++The Emperor protects.+++

Early Access Review
								22 hours into the beta so far.  13-jun-2016They opened the game up to all backer's as BETA.  BETA is a good word for it.  I like the game very much.  What they offer in the beta is the first "city" and so far there is plenty to do.But BETA is a good name for what they are offering at the moment, and if this BETA piece is the most polished part of what they have so far (and one would expect they would put the best they have on display), then it will be at least another year before they get all the bugs worked out of it.  I suspect they realize this given their newest comment about 2017 Q1 release.  Personally I am glad they made the beta available, and hope they offer up more pieces in beta as they get completed.This has a chace to be a great game, maybe better than the original Torment, but they clearly need our help.  So if you guys are backers, claim the Steam Beta and start finding bugs.  The bug report facility is built right into the game so it is pretty easy to report something wrong.  My list so far includes things like:1. minor gramatical errors in descriptions and dialog.2. dialog choices out of step with the game (options you get even when you don't have the prerequisite knowledge).3. two bugged side quests I cannot complete.4. characters getting stuck on one particular map.5. characters walking through a door on one particular map.6. interface getting bugged and in one place completely blank or lost altogether.All so far have been fixable with either a restart of the game, or a reload of previous save.Once these bugs get fixed, this will be one of the great ones.

content:
Posted: March 12
												Torment: Tides of Numenera might not be at the level of Planescape Torment, but it still is an enjoyable ride. At about 36h of gameplay (incl. some reloads), I would still consider it to fall on the short side, a feeling reinforced by the fairly linear nature of the main story arc revolving at different levels around individual choices. That coupled with the text-heavy content makes it sometimes feels more like a visual novel than a true RPG (not a bad thing per se but probably disconcerting for most new players).The universe is still rich and somehow reminded me of "the book of the New Sun". It remains largely underexploited, even with side quests, a gap that will hopefully be filled by DLCs.

I didn't play the game right after it released but I took a day off work recently and decided I'd dig into this.  I took the day off work yesterday and spent six hours playing this and got extremely hooked.  I played a bit more today and in about seven hours of gameplay I've hardly fought anyone, rather I've spent my time talking to everyone I can, milking each conversation for as much lore as I possibly can.  So many people have rich, well thought out backgrounds, interesting stories, whole sub-plots that you could miss if you simply ignore them and walk by.  The story telling in this game has fully captivated me and I can't wait to play more.  I'll be sure to update this review as I get more experience with the game.  For the time being, I heavily suggest playing this game if you love a lore-rich world and you don't mind reading most of the time.  If you're looking for a ton of tactical combat then this probably isn't your game.

content:
Posted: March 9
												You open your eyes. You are falling through the sky. You are the new conscience, birthed when your creator left the body you now possess. Alone, abandoned in a world you don’t know, you ask yourself: who will I become? What will be my mark on the world?Torment: Tides of Numenera is a narrative-focused, text heavy RPG. Even though it doesn’t continue the story of Planescape: Torment, ergo accessible to new players, it touches some of the same themes and builds on the formula of its antecessor. There is a lot of text. A LOT of text…The game adopts and adapts the tabletop RPG setting of Numenera by Monte Cook that takes place on a future Earth in which countless civilizations have risen and fell, leaving behind pieces of technology. These are the Numenera, that constitute riddles to be solved or devices to be feared by the new inhabitants of the planet. This gives the writing a pretty long leash to explore whatever it wants, with each sci-fi/fantasy vignette providing an opportunity to make you question what you thing about identity, legacy, morality. What do you say to a hideous mutant that everybody hates for its appearance that is considering a pretty invasive equivalent of plastic surgery? Do you think it’s better to be truthful to what he is, potentially subjecting him to a lifetime of poverty and exclusion? Is it better for him to change completely? Does he have someone that loves him for what he is and should that have weight on his decision? Should you, a stranger, even get involved with his choice? This is only a 5 minute episode in a journey that has taken me close to 50 hours to complete. You will walk on a transdimensional predator that also happens to be a city, meet an ancient warmonger condemn to an eternity of peace, a religious leader enslaved by the adoration of his followers, learn of an endless conflict between two sides who can rewind events to get different outcomes, and an alien creature that is fascinated by our mating habits. Some of your companions have some great depth. Continuing the cliché-braking of Fall-from-Grace from Planescape: Torment, Erritis is, at first glance, the heroic, reckless warrior, but with time (or the ability “Scan Thoughts”) you start to see there is something more to him and a interesting deconstruction of the Hero trope. Rhin, is a controversial companion. She is a child you can choose to take in, and once you choose to, you have to stick by that decision and keep her in the party or lose her forever. This worked well for me, because it made sense that a lost child, with a talent for hiding and who had been betrayed several times before, would not stick around once you had abandoned her. However, this is controversial because she isn’t the most useful in combat and some people feel frustrated by having to keep her in the party to see her storyline unfold. To me, she was a character I had to be a father-figure to, and would try to shield from harm, not because she was bad in combat, but because I didn’t want her getting hurt. Some call it emotional manipulation, I say I have no problem with a character that wants you to see her as more than a chess piece. There have also been some complaints about the use of less common words that, to me, English not being my first language, don’t seem prevalent enough to be distracting or unintelligible and, when they come up, add to some of the strangeness of the world.Presentation could be better, with very little in terms of narration and voice-acting and the beauty of the 2D back-drops contrasts with the blurry character models. It is evident that you are supposed to do most of the work with your imagination, often too much, but if you have the habit of reading, you probably can get passed this hurdle.The combat is relatively limited. Much of it can be avoid by having the right skills and choosing the right option in dialogue, but when you can’t or choose not to you enter a Crisis. A Crisis puts you in a turn-based battle with your party, where you can use your weapons, abilities, items do defeat your enemies. The way it stands out, however, is that in some cases you can resort to dialogue to make some opponents surrender or even turn to your side. Sometimes, even the order in which your foes fall have different consequences, although I can’t really tell to which extent with only one playthrough. These sequences were occasionally fiddly to interact with (sometimes not being clear if a character is blocking the way do something, for example) and buggy in some areas (namely in Anechoic Lazaret). That being said, I played in the first week and I’m sure there will be patches to fix a great deal of it. You can see some crisis shine with their intricacies in a way where you wished there were more of them. One of them in The Bloom is a good example: when you enter one of the areas, you are put into a Crisis that hasn’t yet turned violent, but must decide in the time-span of a couple of turns which side of the battle to take or if you can even defuse the situation. It was a welcomed change of pace that I feel could have been integrated and adapted to other quests.Having played Planescape: Torment for the first time in about a year or so, and still not having nostalgia settled in, playing Torment: Tides of Numenera felt very much like playing Planescape. Just as with latter, I couldn’t put it down for more than a day, always wishing to tie some loose thread or see what was waiting in that unexplored corner of the map. All this without bats and thugs coming out of nowhere for an arbitrary battle.For those looking for a comparison, I still cannot decide if Torment is better than its antecessor. It would take second playthroughs (which I haven’t taken off the table) of both of them to say for sure. What I can say is that Torment: Tides of Numenera is an acquired taste, but a modern masterpiece in interactive narrative nevertheless. A little polish here and there and it can stand tall and proud in my top 5 (or even maybe 3) games of all time.

content:
Posted: March 8
												This game is surely not for everybody, which might explain the many negative reviews in steam, but it also offers a depth in storytelling and world building that most games do not.Presentation: The drawn backgrounds look at least good and sometimes awesome and some even made me stop and admire them in awe. Also the locations are packed with details and always look promising. The character models are not that detailed and their animations are rather rudimentary.The music and sound effects are rather reserved but do their job well.Game design: A big plus are the various solutions the game offers to solve a problem, mostly considering various positions and make choices that are both reflecting the attitude of the character and have understandable consequences for the game world. In other words: It really makes sense to role-play and get involved into the world. A minus point is the rather thin combat system as it does not allow much strategic thinking and is more a means to an end than a complex system.Balance: As already mentioned, it is often possible to solve problems in multiple ways and even failures can lead to new paths. There is also a good mixture of dialogues, exploration and riddles. Some combats seemed a bit unfair, also due to the limited range of actions available.Story/Atmosphere: Here it is where the game shines the most. From what I have seen so far, the texts (there are a lot of them) are excellent and do not only make up for the missing voice overs or lack of visualization, but enabled me to create an even more dense world inside my head. This is both true for the dialogues, the descriptions of the environment and the interactions with the objects in the world. I really care for the fate of my character and want to know more about him and his origins and how he will develop.I have not backed  this game and only played very little of Planescape Torment but so far it has been a really unique experience and it makes me sad to see that the game receives rather mixed reviews on steam.I hope this review sheds some better light on the game which it definitely deserves.

Early Access Review
								So far I've clocked in just over 4 hours of Tides and I have to say it's just whizzed by. I've been waiting for this game to be released for what seems like an eternity (my own personal torment) and although this is just a Beta it still gives a great indication of what the finished game will be like. I was a big, big fan of Planescape Torment and this game so far is matching (and surpassing) my expectations. Great story telling, interesting characters, beautiful scenery and a multitude of choices/ options. A few other niggly things i expect to get fixed before final release - maps aren't clickable; bugs exist on UI and inventory screen (which is to be expected); the skill system does take a bit of time getting used to and it can be a tad confusing at the start; and no Morte :-(Overall a bright start and it makes me excited for the 2017 release (which seems like agesss away!)

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7
												Torment: Tides of Numenera is a overall neat Science Fantasy RPG, a lackluster spiritual successor to Planescape: Torment in some regards, and a better one in others. Mind you, I find the pseudo-intellectuality, inherently, stronger in the PnP RPG Planescape setting than the Numenera one, even if the creativity is stronger in the former ... Christianity is Platonism for the people... Thematically I think that they nailed Abandonment--it's beautifully woven into the setting, the narrative and the overall ambience-- and to a lesser degree Mystery where I am a bit mixed, whereas Legacy especially in the form of the ending is lacking and lackluster. Which brings me to philosophy, this speaks of high culture, even if the Planescape setting and Planescape: Torment of course was a mix of pop culture and high culture, and so is obviously Numenera and this game. Regardless I don't know if the developers  ran out of time or had unrealistic ambitions, or I had unrealistic expectations... Do the new companions live up to their heritage? No sadly not though I still find them fairly interesting. For my first play-through I had Callistege, Rhin and Matkina along with me. Also they seemed to be bugged so I had no inter-party banter between them :/. But on a strictly conceptual level I didn't find them as compelling as say Morte, Fall-From-Grace or Dak'kon - some of the more fleshed out companions from Planescape: Torment. The emotional journey I went through with them seemed impactless concerning their predicaments, though it probably would have helped quite a bit with party banter. As their comments on quests and NPCs were interesting and helped developing them. The companions partially had it easier in Planescape: Torment, in virtue of the fact that The Nameless One / The Player-Character had a history with, some of, them before the game began, making the player more emotionally invested in them. I didn't really care about any of the three companions from Numenera when the game was done, though there was some cool things no doubt and potential for greatness! Another minus is the bland and deliberately limited Voice Acting, I'd wish they'd use resources on other parts of the game when it wasn't of better quality.    Combat is sadly lackluster while it was a noble ideal to get rid of filler encounters, the mandatory combat /Crisis encounters weren't interesting in my combat-avoiding-Playthrough. It strikes me as a bit peculiar to use this many resources on this aspect of the game without using enough to make combat truly compelling. The occasional bugs in one mandatory fight made it especially tedious to go through several times. Overall I think the game is a glorious and worthy spiritual successor even if it's a bit bland and lacking in certain aspects, it's shining in others even if it never quite reaches or surpass its predecessor concerning its artistic and narrative vision - though it's most likely stronger in the choice and consequence department for instance. Hope that InXile Entertainment will be more upfront, transparent and honest with their backers in the future or I'll lose trust in them.

content:
Posted: March 8
												10 hours in the game and it's simply amazing. I was a big fan of Planescape and this game is a good successor. Pros:- Good Story- Deep Characters- Text/Dialogue heavy gameCons:- Honestly I don't know Right now game has mixed reviews on Steam, but after reading several of them, I can't help but feel that many people had some kind of dream of what this game might be (several of this people didn't even play Planescape based on their replies) and therefore were disappointed. Please, don't trust them. If you're a fan of reading, good story and interesting choices, give this game a try. That game is nowhere near Pillar of Eternity or Divinity: OS and thank god for that. Both these games had a lackluster story, grindy battles and TBH were a disappointment compared to P:T or BG. Unlike them Numenera HAS a story, deep interesting compnions and amazing setting.Updated my journal.

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3
												This is my first review, I felt compelled to write it after seeing the "mostly positive" score.  This game is not for everyone.  It requires a lot of patience Ultimately, likely whether or not you will enjoy this game comes down to what you look for in a game, specifically an rpg.  If you are looking for a game that's fast paced with a lot of combat or a sword and sorcery type of rpg this will dissapoint you.  If on the other hand you are looking to lose yourself in a strange eccentric world and enjoy deep storytelling this game is a marvel.  If, like me, Planescape Torment was among your favorite games of all time then this game will satisfy like no other has since.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3
												25 hours of gameplay? Either i`m that good or this game is totally not worth it. Don`t get me wrong, I really do apprieciate the story, feeling, dialogs and so. I really love the system with tree base stats and pools to use during combat/checks. But hell i`ve seen bigger demos than this game (ok i admit here i exaggerate a bit but just a bit). The general feeling after finishing this game is that i paid for greate, epic, long journey with loads of adventures. Game filled with quests, npcs that i can interact with, faction that i can join or fight with and so on. And all I was give is just a sample of this story, first act of many. That`s the general feeling. The only problem is that with all these problems i would still recomend this game if you liked BG and P:T.Now let me tell you what i really like and dislike about this game: +Stat system - you have 3 main stats with pools that you use during gameplay. Excelent idea. Simple, elegant, flexible yet this aproach force you to make decisions, to think, to tinker with points. Every lvl up means sth. There is no such thing as waiting x lvls to improve some skill in orther to get synergy etc. etc. Simplicyty is the key. Quests - quests are simply awesome. There are of course simple things such as go and retrieve, but man, there are some really good quests. Story - is absoloutly fantastic. Plot twists are superb. There would be good book out of this game. Pity book would have only like 50 pages. -Character development - c`mon 1 skill per tier? I was playing as nano, in hope of some awesome high lvl spells (remember Planescape?). Nothing even close to this. Fight - I admit, there was like 6 of total fights during my game. But UI during fight is a catastrophe. From not being able to cast a spell bcs screen freezes and i can`t scroll it, to strange lags during skipping turns with outcome that i skipped turn for my next char as well. Quests - or rather missing some big sidequests, or even big main quest. There are no faction that you can join or fight with. Each side quest is a one step quest. Minor bugs - there is one quest when you are up for retrieving a battle standar. I retrieved it three times. First i persuaded guy, then i intimidated and last but not least i did what guy asked for (i showed him what it means to fly). Gladly quest giver didn`t say a word when i brought him his unique item three times.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1
												I will recommend this game for now and from what I've experienced so far and do an update of this review as I progress or finish the game.Now, first a little bit of criticism. The intro or character creation part is a hassle, after you've done it five times or so atleast. It's just too bad because it takes a bit away from the replayability imo. I have no idea why the developers didn't use the Story Trailer as an intro and setup to the game(rather than just a marketing tool) and with a quick character creation sheet then just start as you wake at the Chamber with Callistege and Aligern. Too much info dropping with the specter  character and the whole segment feels off. This is actually my main complaint so far and it feels unneccesary and could have easily been cut off from the game. Btw quality of the content comes first in my world atleast.Since the actual game started though I've really been enjoying the conversations, quests, environments and characters. I always feel like I'm ready to explore and find out more about the world when I play Tides of Numenera. It is easy to get sucked into this game. In a good way. I mean the writing is good, not perfect but heck nor was the writing in Planescape: Torment.Hold your horses, I actually LIKED the combat. It's still a bit messy but enjoyable and for once the combat music is quite good aswell.So I'll definetly keep playing to find out more of this game. Will it live up to the legacy? I'm not sure, probably not entirely but atleast it seems like a worthy addition to Planescape: Torment so far.

content:
Posted: March 1
												It's like playing Fallout 2 for the first time. A lot of people complaning have their nostalgia set to 11, old CRPGs were not fast past until Dragon Age Origins.The setting, tones , dialouge, and depth of the world in this game is consistently blowing me away. This game has lore/conversations/minor investigations just for the sake of having them. I can't put this game down, meanwhile I rack up hour after hour in Pilliars unable to get past the first act because NOTHING IN THAT GAME IS ENGAGNGING IN ANY WAY SHAPE OR FORM.If you enjoyed combat in fallout more than in Baldurs gate, and find marvel strangeworld comics awesome, get this game.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								So far, so good. Not quite that into it yet, but I can tell I'm going to like it. Can't wait to be able to sink into it a little bit more when I find time. The game needs to be optimized quite a bit more. I'm running a 980 ti on 4790k @ 4.4 ghz with a samsung ssd evo and 16gb of ram and my computer's load kicks into high gear, not to mention the frames are poor. I have dual 980 ti's, but didn't have sli enabled so not sure how it runs when I have both of them going, but I would imagine not any better in the the game's current state. Needless to say - I'm sure it will be much improved upon by release, but for now optimization is lacking.Going to update this once I have some more hours into it, but so far it's been pretty engaging. The writing is great and the voice acting I have heard thus far is pretty decent.

Btw quality of the content comes first in my world atleast.Since the actual game started though I've really been enjoying the conversations, quests, environments and characters. I always feel like I'm ready to explore and find out more about the world when I play Tides of Numenera. It is easy to get sucked into this game. In a good way. I mean the writing is good, not perfect but heck nor was the writing in Planescape: Torment.Hold your horses, I actually LIKED the combat. It's still a bit messy but enjoyable and for once the combat music is quite good aswell.So I'll definetly keep playing to find out more of this game. Will it live up to the legacy? I'm not sure, probably not entirely but atleast it seems like a worthy addition to Planescape: Torment so far.

												For all of those who are planning to buy the game i will give you a short ater 15 hours of Torment - ToN (Alpha Access)."BUY IT!Because i was more than entertained since my first hours of the game, and i am still now!The coolest thing on Torment for me is certainly the Numenera setting! The mass of text has almost Baldur's Gate 2 level! But the dialogues are all interesting - without exception!Gameplay itself has actually only 2 things to say:1. Depending on your response in the dialogs, you collect skillpoints in the so-called tides. There is a whole bunch of these tides (gold, silver, blue ...) and the tide with the  most collected skill points defines how the character is perceived by its environment. 2. You can determine to make skill checks easier by using points from one of the pools (strength, speed and intelligence). However, these pools are limited!

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have played the first bits of the game and so far, I am very much impressed. The writing is top-notch, and it really brought back those times when an RPG game really puts you in the shoes of your character. The amount of lore, the presence of literary power, and philosophical queries places this game in my list of video games as gesamntkunstwerk (total art), as an experience. Truly, the developers are one of those legendary people who are sent to this world to create these type of games.The game has its performance issues, of course, since it is still on Early Access. A load of bugs, optimization issues, and in my case, I experience tons of lag especially in the beginning of the game. Hopefully, the developers will do work on these issues and I wish them luck on that.To sum up, this is the type of game you should buy and play because it immerses you into a world that is merely a reflection of our own. The decisions of the Last Castoff are refractions of your decisions in your own life. I think video games (open-ended/open-world RPG's in particular [tho T:ToN is more open-ended]) are an existential commodity that serves as a prism to our own experiences in life. And with the emergence of games like Torment: Tides of Numenera, I think its players will get to answer questions about individuality, the weight of their choices in this tapestry of life, and most importantly, they will get a glimpse of the essence of their existence.

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21
												I am one of the exceptions here in that I enjoyed the lengthy dialogue, despite its sometimes tedious verbosity. I enjoyed my experience, although, as other reviewers have mentioned, this game is not without its flaws. Predominantly, I didn't find myself particularly drawn to any party members, as their characterization seemed a bit tepid and lacked that distinctive allure that party members in similar game offerings feature.The conclusion was disappointingly, but expectedly, abrupt. I was pleased, however, that my dominant tides were at least referenced at the end, even if I didn't feel that they had a significant impact. The later sections in the game felt somewhat rushed in comparison to earlier sections.Again, I'll place myself in the minority by stating that the dearth of combat options didn't irk me. Plenty of alternatives exist, new and old, in terms of other RPGs if combat is a must. I enjoyed actually being able to think outside of the box to some extent, even if sometimes the presented options seemed a bit contrived or unimpactful. I really thought the "Tides" system, while admittedly simply another version of various RPG attribute systems, was nonetheless interesting in its own right, and characters throughout the game commonly remark on your dominant tides or when you behave in a manner inconsistent with previous choices.This game does take place in a futuristic setting riddled with anachronisms, and it feels like a setting straight out of a Jules Verne or H.G. Wells novel. The soundtrack is pleasant but largely forgettable, and voiceovers are sparse, which is probably a good thing since the quality of the voices, when present, leaves something to be desired.Ultimately, if you're looking for an epic that keeps you on the edge of the seat, I advise you to look elsewhere. This isn't Star Wars or Mass Effect (and I have a great admiration for these), but I can appreciate it for what it is: an enigmatic, intruiguingly bizarre, and beautifully rendered creation with sometimes engaging and sometimes tedious prose that will wholly absorb you if you allow it. It's not going to be in my top five RPGs, but it was an enjoyably unique experience nonetheless.

												Good game but not one of the best CRPGs of the last few years. I really enjoyed the world and some of the characters, but a lot of mechanics could have used more work. number of helpful: 37 of 74 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 2
Early Access Review
								It breaks my heart that I didn't get completely hooked on this game. If I hadn't kickstarted it (what like... four years ago?) I'd probably return it like I did with Tyranny and wait for it to be polished.On the pro side, they really delivered with the diaglouge and depth of conversations. Most of my playtime has been spent just talking to all the NPCs in the first town, learning their backstories, and doing some side quests. I obviously didn't get all that far but it seems like there is going to be a hell of a lot of content. The graphics for this type of game are top notch and more interesting that Pillars of Eternity, and I also appreciated the very generous zoom levels.What's killing it for me is a design decision that they can't at all back away from at this point: Combat. Whereas Planescape Torment has a tremendous amount of combat that is fast paced (for CRPG), viseral, and fun, Tides has... almost none. In four hours I've literally been in two fights that lasted all of a minute. There is so little conflict/action that I'm not even going to bother complaining about the mechanics of combat- why bother? So with that said, whats the point of having so many skills, abilities, and equipment if you almost never get to use them? its at the point where I think if I ever pick this game up again I'm going to go out of my way to be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and pick fights with everyone possible.Lastly, and I'll admit this might be premature given my playtime, but the five recruitable NPCs I've met so far are all human and are all boring.  A far cry from PS:T, where all I wanted to do was just talk with Dakkon all day about everything and anything Zerth related.

content:
Posted: March 2
												Torment: Tides of Numenera nails the old Fallout 1&2 / Baldurs Gate / Planescape Torment CRPG format.It's what I hoped Pillars of Eternity would be.There is SO much to read and learn about the world, the game ozes with history, lore, personal stories, mystical beings  and throws these at you at a overwhelming pace at first. But then you are able to set in and understand that this world is strange and complex and you are supposed to feel overwhelmed by all the quirky weird billion years old tech gadgets and multidimensional hivemind wizards. The quality of writing is magnificent and the quantity of it is simply immense (as can be expected for a Planescape Torment "sequel").While the engine is dated, and graphics are not the focal point of a game that is so rich in story, the graphical design is really beautiful. The Numenera ruleset is quirky and different from what Im used to but I think that sits well with the quirky and different from what Im used to world that the game takes place in.Combat so far has been a bit boring, but that part honestly is the least of my worries in a story driven game like this.I made a promise to my self to never pre-order / kickstart / indiegogo another product if this one falls flat on its face, but it doesnt. It delivers on what I wanted and more. Now I gotta get back to playing the damn thing.

												Firstly, it's not Planescape torment, but it's a worthwhile game to play if only because they obviously had so much respect for the original game.I personally don't get the aversion to 'trash mobs' and would have appreciated more comabt within the game because to me it felt unrealistic that you didn't actually fight much when you are going through the game world. You can't talk yourself out of every situation, especially when you are infiltrating places and pursuing your own objectives and ignoring everything else.The main quest storyline isn't anything amazing, however there is a lot of cool ideas and backstories and 'flavour' within the game that is well worth uncovering.However if you can't handle reading anything longer than this review, this is not the game for you, you are expected to read and absorb what is going on around you and what you are meant to do next.The ending felt slightly disappointing as well, but overall it was an enjoyable game that I'll probably play again once they add back the stuff that was left out due to time constraints.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6
												First quick about me, I am a veteran RPG & CRPG player, the old Planescape Torment is still my favourite RPG game.--- What I liked ---I really liked the locations in the game. Both main locations are brimming with flavour, nicely presented through images, dialogues, quests, companions ... It sometimes feels over the top, but that's exactly what the world of Numenera should be like, and it makes it very interesting to interact with and explore. Especially Bloom rocks!Overall experience of playing is also quite good, pacing is OK, there is always another interesting quest or location round the corner. --- Issues --- -- Main Soryline -- I found the main storyline very unbelievable, and also the main protagonists of it very wooden. (Minor Spoiler) There is a war between the Changing God and the First Castoff, called the "Endless War" at least 100 years old. But ... although it is such a central point of the story, it is never explained what is it for? It doesn't seem to have any objective, it is never explained what they want to acomplish. And if you spend centuries slugging at each other, with vast armies of men and machines, in what seems to be a middle of nowhere, shouldn't there be some point to it? At least a city/laboratory/important huge artifact to attack or defend, that should feature in the story in some way? The leaders of both sides don't even take part in it, they hide somewhere entirely else.I feel that a "Secret Cults" type of Endless War, 2 organizations slugging at each other wherever they can discover each other's laboratories, safe havens et, and then disappearing in the shadows would fit the theme much better.I assume it was supposed to reflect the "Endless War" in Planescape, between Devils and Deamons. That one made much more sense, was firmly rooted in the cosmology.Also the main 2 protagonists of this conflict. Bot hare so utterly uninteresting! The Changing God is a lying dork. First Castoff is an angry teenager. One of the facets of Planescape: Torment I really liked was the centrality of ideas, different characters embodying different views and ways of seeing life. This made that game very interesting, whereas here the main characters are just flat. -- The Ending --Very anticlimatic. No final showdown of any appreciable sort. I recently finished Shadowrun:Dragonfall, so much more interesting Ending there ...-- Companion Stories --If you're doing only 6, you could have made them better. I did like the story of Erritis, but all others felt bland, especially Tybir. Again, the issue here is that I couldn't really empathize with any of the characters.-- Tides --What's the point of them? It is nice to see and manage your "colour", but it doesn't seem to influence anything. For a feature that made to the Title of the game, pretty disappointing. -- Smaller stuff --Portraits! Why are there no portraits of people you talk to? CGiving a face to a person really helps.Besides, the only existing portraits, of companions (and Last Castoff) are horrible. Only 3 Foci, all of them bland ... wastes such a nice Numenera mechanic.--- So So ---Fighting system is OK, although unbalanced. That's OK tohugh, it is not a war game, and yo ucan always use some Cyphers to help you out.--- Overall ---  It is a good game, strongly inspired by Planescape: Torment. Immortal protagonist, who did some bad things in previous lives and doesn't rememeber it, lots of interesting encounters and general interesting weirdness ... But Planescape Torment it ain't. What I liked a lot in Planescape, was the exploration of ideas and attitudes. Here, you can see that from time to time, but it all feels flat. Only exception for me were the Memoralists faction, but even them, they were hard to empathize with. So enjoy the atmosphere and all the side quests, and don't mind too much the main quest :-) .

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2
												It's a very tough one to review in a short space so I will keep it brief. ToN preserves the sense of alien-ness you got with the original Torment without trying to link itself TOO directly. To me this is a smart move because to do so would only invite all the nerd-ranger (rager?) fans from crucifying it for minor reasons. I like that this game also adds a much needed extra element to conversation options because although there is no way out of the basic mechanic of that it was becoming very stale and, whilst not everyone will appreciate the change, I find the solution quite elegant as well as more realistic. It's not for anyone who isnt into descriptive text and is even more of a slow starter than others of its kind but that is because it builds atmosphere through that text so well that I would venture to suggest no other game handles that side of things better. Much like Tyranny it offers subtle but important innovations in the genre and is a brilliant and utterly absorbing game that wont be for everyone due to some significant flaws. If it's straight combat action you are looking for then don't even think about it. It has actually been made with those fussy purists in mind - how else CAN you follow a legend? I just feel the low combat model is a mistake.*edit*I have noticed that a lot of people are randomly downvoting this game across the board as well as randomly downvoting all positive reviews. Bare in mind that the achievements show that less than 15% of all players have even looked at the game in any sufficient depth. I am in that 15% and yet after 24 hrs play I have barely scratched the surface. You may be asking "but WHY have so few played it more extensively?". The answer to this is simply the way the game starts out. As I already mentioned, it's a very slow starter in terms of actual action. Expect to play for a good 10 hours and more before any meaningful combat. There ARE encounters you can enforce but there doesn't seem to be any benifit to doing so.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2
												If you liked Planescape: Torment for it's writing, odds are pretty good you'll like Torment: Tides of Numenera. I cannot stress that enough. The world of Numenera works quite well as a backdrop for a story that is reminiscent of PS:T's. My playthrough clocked in at a little over 30 hours and I was not bored once during that time. It's been a long time since I've delved this deeply into all the flavor text and NPC conversations that didn't even result in quests, but it was all just that interesting. I wish I could say the same of other recent cRPGs, but I cannot. Neither Pillars nor Divinity Original Sin came even close to being this engrossing for me. Both of those games have other strengths, Pillars looks slightly better and is closer to the old infinity engine games in terms of 'feel', Divinity has a more in-depth combat engine, but neither of those things are my #1 priority when it comes to RPGs. I'm here for the story primiarly and everything else is secondary to that.One thing that perhaps deserves special note is that in Tides of Numenera, when combat starts you don't necessarily have to kill everyone to end it. There are often other ways, even including talking to your "enemies" to resolve conflict. Most encounters can be overcome without entering combat, should you chose to do so. You can probably count the times you really *have* to kill people on one hand. I wouldn't let the negative reviews that focus on some of the things that were planned at some point and ended up not being in the game at the end ruin that for me. None of the great games in the past shipped with everything that was planned, those cuts just weren't quite as visible as developement was less transparant back then. Overall I would heartily recommend this game. It isn't perfect, but neither was the original. I was lucky enough to play PS:T when it first came out and funny enough, the reaction Tides of Numenera gets from some people is really similar to the reaction PS:T got back then. "The world is so weird", "Combat isn't that great", "The protagonist is kinda ugly". All of those might be true, but none of those things detract from the experience for me. If you liked the original PS:T I would strongly recommend checking this one out, and hey, if you don't enjoy it, Steam refunds games if you've played less than two hours. Maybe that's just me, but you'd have had to pry this game from my cold dead hands after one hour.

number of helpful: 12 of 24 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23
												Just finished the game. Overall impressions are very postive, mostly thanks to the Numenera setting and pretty good writing. The world of the game is pretty bizzare to say the least and in some parts feels like it came straight out from the creepiest pages of some P.K. D i c k novel. Of course while some quests are great, the others are pretty generic, but I wouldn't call any of them dull. The main questline is pretty good too, I found it involving and interesting with all its transhumanistic ideas and moral issues being the highlights. Now that I think about it, the game's plot also has some pretty depressing and would-be shocking moments, but unfurtunetely they are obscured by the overall otherworldliness of the setting.On a bad side, the story is somewhat unevenly paced with the Sagus Cliffs and Bloom parts being intense and content heavy while the middle and the final parts of the game feel mostly like linear fillers or story propellers.Character writing is okay, it's not stellar, but definetely not a failure as many reviewers on Steam suggest. But I must admit I felt the characters to be more of a gateway to understanding the Ninth World rather than some "very interesting" personalities you're supposed to run around and pester for the duration of the whole game.Now let's talk about the GAMEPLAY itself. That's where Numenera actually fails in a pretty bad way. While I like the Cypher System and think that it has been implemented pretty well within the game, I can't help but admit that the balance between stat pools is clearly off with Intellect being by far the most superior stat and Might being by far the most inferior, especially considering that the game is short on combat sequences.Another downside is that apart from the game's early stages you never feel threatened to run out of your stats resources, the pools are simply too big and, even more importantly, there's way too much possibilities for resting and refilling those pools. Most of the tasks are also too easy to complete, rendering the whole Effort system almost useless.Cyphers are another interesting part of the game, but just as with the stat pools you rarely feel any need for them because of how easy the game is how rare the fights are.Same goes for the abilities, there's simply too many of them for the absolutely tiny amout of combat within the game. That makes them feel unimpactful and redundant. But that's kind of a problem for the absolute majority of RPGs out there, too much useless and meaningless  junk, especially when it comes to skills and abilities.Tides are a good moral (viewpoint) indicator, but the problem with it again is that they change so slowly that no one decision feel very impactful when it comes to the Tides. It kind of makes sense when you think about it from the ideological point of view, but absolutely fails as a gameplay element.Overall I can recommend this game to anyone who isn't afraid of reading and is looking for an RPG that can offer you more than 10 romance options and 100 craftable items out of 1000 types of resources. It's a rough gem that could benifit a lot from proper play testing and tuning, but even as it is now, it can give you a lot if you bother to read and reflect.

content:
Posted: March 21
												I am one of the exceptions here in that I enjoyed the lengthy dialogue, despite its sometimes tedious verbosity. I enjoyed my experience, although, as other reviewers have mentioned, this game is not without its flaws. Predominantly, I didn't find myself particularly drawn to any party members, as their characterization seemed a bit tepid and lacked that distinctive allure that party members in similar game offerings feature.The conclusion was disappointingly, but expectedly, abrupt. I was pleased, however, that my dominant tides were at least referenced at the end, even if I didn't feel that they had a significant impact. The later sections in the game felt somewhat rushed in comparison to earlier sections.Again, I'll place myself in the minority by stating that the dearth of combat options didn't irk me. Plenty of alternatives exist, new and old, in terms of other RPGs if combat is a must. I enjoyed actually being able to think outside of the box to some extent, even if sometimes the presented options seemed a bit contrived or unimpactful. I really thought the "Tides" system, while admittedly simply another version of various RPG attribute systems, was nonetheless interesting in its own right, and characters throughout the game commonly remark on your dominant tides or when you behave in a manner inconsistent with previous choices.This game does take place in a futuristic setting riddled with anachronisms, and it feels like a setting straight out of a Jules Verne or H.G. Wells novel. The soundtrack is pleasant but largely forgettable, and voiceovers are sparse, which is probably a good thing since the quality of the voices, when present, leaves something to be desired.Ultimately, if you're looking for an epic that keeps you on the edge of the seat, I advise you to look elsewhere. This isn't Star Wars or Mass Effect (and I have a great admiration for these), but I can appreciate it for what it is: an enigmatic, intruiguingly bizarre, and beautifully rendered creation with sometimes engaging and sometimes tedious prose that will wholly absorb you if you allow it. It's not going to be in my top five RPGs, but it was an enjoyably unique experience nonetheless.

content:
Posted: April 19
												Torment Tides of Numenera, as the spiritual successor to Planescape Torment, had big shoes to fill.Which it did (unexpectedly). I was happy to back it but always thought the game would be serviceable but not exceptional. I was wrong about that. The world building is fantastic (a great world to learn about and travel in), good music, no combat every 5 seconds (i am looking at you pillars of eternity). Weird characters, places, dimensions. A good storyline that finishes satisfactory and wildly divergent questlines. All in all one of the best isometric rpg's of the last few years and although having liked wasteland 2 before this game definitely turned me into a fan of Inxile. Meaty timewise (about 35 hours) without overstaying its welcome. Would definitely recommend at any price.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26
												The idea of a spiritual successor to PS:T created a ton of hype.Some of this hype was warranted, some of it was not.I didn't follow the Kickstarter campaign and I didn't contribute (I often don't due to past KS dissapointments that I managed to sidestep with my general laziness towards contributing). My perspective comes from not having time to develop ridiculous amounts of hope only to be slapped with disappointment in the end (which is what I've taken away from a bunch of the reviews here).All I know - being a HUGE, HUGE fan of PS:T - is that when T:ToN was announced, I got a warm, fuzzy feeling.With that said, the game ain't perfect. It took 15 hours of slow enjoyment for it to grow on me. That's where I am now, roughly, but instead of coming home from work tonight and going "Let's see if this gets any better," I came home going, "Let's see how much better it can get from here." A small shift, but a notable one.On the Writing:I'm the kind of CRPG player that devours lore. I've gotta be in the mood for it, but when I am, I inhale as much of it as possible. I've seen complaints that a lot of the writing in T:ToN was unnecessary and didn't serve the plot... this is true, but I don't see a problem with it. They're building a complex atmosphere that goes far beyond the plot. I have no prior familiarity with the whole Numenera setting, but every paragraph I read, I like it a little more. It's a slow, steady build-up. A large undertaking for a setting with such a massive background. As of right now, the main plot (as it's revealed itself to me so far) is not terribly interesting and frankly feels kinda tropey ("Ooo look at me, son of <POWERFUL♥♥♥♥♥KING/DEITY/ETC> and I'm all confused and have to learn about my powers and my place in the world - blah blah blah"), but it works for what it is. It was way less interesting 12 hours in. More so 9 hours in. Even more so 5 hours in. At hour 3, I was basically calling the game a disappointment. Give it all time to grow on you and try to actually read and visualize the sometimes-long-winded descriptions. Yeah, it's wordy. Yeah, it feels like they went a little too hard after writing, but it's ultimately pretty decent.On the Choice of the Numenera Tabletop System:Again, no background with the setting or the tabletop system but they seriously could've done without it. I absolutely hate the Might/Speed/Intellect stat pool concept. It's kind of cool in certain scenarios, but it feels weak in general. I haven't had any issues with running my stat pools empty before I can safely rest up to regain the points like I've read in some reviews, but stat pools make the game feel a bit more like a chore. Somewhere out there was a more graceful way to handle stuff like this... but that would involve dumping the Numenera system and I guess they married themselves to it.On the Combat:The combat is pretty terrible (hey, just like in PS:T!), but not wholly unenjoyable. It takes a bit of getting used to and there isn't much of it, so I suppose that's a plus. The concept of cyphers is virtually useless. So far I've acquired plenty more than I've been able, or had the need, to use and every time I get a new one, I groan because my main PC gets it and he immediately gets cypher sickness, so I have to figure out who I can give it to avoid the penalties... what's worse is that combat is rare enough that I don't want to put points into cypher-related skills because I'd rather dump them into stuff like Persuasion and Perception to allow me to further dialogue in more interesting ways.On Character Progression:Leveling characters was so-so. In other CRPGs, distributing points and choosing skills was always  something that made the pleasure center in my brain go off everytime my party members flashed on a level up. In T:ToN, it just felt incredibly limited. Starting with only 3 classes and kind of ending up pigeonholed into 4 party members sharing 3 roles, trying to divvy up dialogue-related skills among them while also trying to keep them combat ready with more useful skills feels a bit tedious.On Available Party Members:The size of the cast of party members is pretty standard fare for a CRPG. Party size is 4 (including the main character) and you have a choice of 6 different characters you can use to make up your Last Castoff's team. The characters themselves are interesting in their own ways, but ultimately underwhelming. My current party makeup consists of Aligern, Erritis, and Matkina. Mainly because I wanted to hava decent spread and 2 jacks, a nano with decent combat abilities, and a glaive have been a good mix for me so far (I recently traded Tybir out for Matkina because I liker her backstory more and my Last Castoff is built with Intellect/dialogue checks in mind so Tybir was kind of redundant).Some of the people who have managed to scale this far down this wall of text might be thinking, "Man, this guy is not making this game seem like it's worth much," but I have to say that at this point, T:ToN's whole is actually much greater than the sum of it's parts. At some point, the feeling I was chasing after from PS:T clicked in and I realized that this really IS a spiritual successor to PS:T.For all of it's faults, my initial disappointment turned to disinterest which has now ultimately turned into a simmering appreciation. I'm now hoping that it'll turn at least to a low boil before I see the credits roll.Pesonally, I would have much preferred a PS:T successor that took place in the original game's setting with a much wider scope than just running around Sigil and getting a peek at a a few alternate dimensions. Hell, I would have accepted just another romp through Sigil (the city is constantly changing - they could have done a LOT with that concept, frankly).What we got instead was T:ToN and you know what? I'll take it.-----TL;DRThis♥♥♥♥♥♥ain't your granddaddy's CRPG - Numenera flies in the face of everything you know from D&D-based CRPGs... you'll have to be open-minded and allow for the paradigm shift if you want to actually enjoy it.For PS:T Fans - It's definitely worth playing. The art and general weirdness are actually quite reminiscent of PS:T if you allow yourself to see it. It takes its sweet♥♥♥♥♥time getting good, but eventually you'll start to get those flashes of PS:T that you're looking for. Don't let the completely different setting and system fool you into writing it off immediately.For general CRPG Fans -  If you like dialogue/lore/reading heavy games with incredibly weird settings, you might wanna look T:ToN up and give it an honest spin.For combat-heavy CRPG fans - Move along. Nothing to see here.

Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video: Is it worth it? Torment: Tides of Numenera 

			Views: 23,143		

			***DISCLOSURE REMINDER: THIS GAME WAS BACKED BY SIDALPHA ON KICKSTARTER*** Torment: Tides of Numenera is a CRPG developed by inXile Entertainment.		

I showcased Torment: Tides of Numenera on my FIrst Impressions Series Is it worth it? And I can honestly say that I am exceptionally impressed with the game's story arc and it's mechanics so far. It definitely shows off the Numenera TTRPG system and that it can indeed adapt well to a PC Gaming experience.A true CRPG by every definition that I can think of, I found nothing to fault with the game.. and as a Reviewer I was actively looking for issues. If I were to claim a fault it would be some of the walls of text can get a touch tedious and could potentially turn away those that are new to the genre, but fans of CRPGswill eat it up as much as I did.9/10 This game has been outstanding so far and I look forward to exploring everything it has to offer!

content:
Posted: March 9
												Welcome to T:TON, the show where everything's made up and the points don't matter. That's right, the points are just like a hat in an orgy.My only gripe in this game is irrelevance of character building, and oh boy is it a big gripe.You'll make a talky guy and you'll 250% all conversations and the companions faceroll all combat content.You make a combat guy and you faceroll all combat content and 150% all conversations without breaking even a sweat.If you have the foreknowledge to know what permanent stat boosts to hit in the beginning of the game you'll hit all the knowledge/perception/anamnesia checkpoint rolls flawlessly straight out of the gate even as an inept monkey without even his signature wrench.Its... all... fluff! Like storyline to Diablo 3, T:TON treats character building decisions as the crusty cream over the doughnut. Wether or not its there, you're going to scarf down on that doughnut like it was made out of angel dust aint'cha?I can understand that it gives everyone a chance to finish the game and enjoy it like a book.But I wanted an choose-your-own-adventure novella with meaningful choises!I wanted it to -hurt- that my character is a learned nano and every talky conversation with npcs would be like pulling a teeth in toothfairy cringefest watching a horribly socially inept parrot try to woo a lady. But nope, inability in conversation skills isnt even a hinderance! At the direst of moments just cram down some juice to boost your intellect straight up after dumping it in a check, no biggie! Waaaay enough intellect angel dust to just blow it all on conversation checks.I wanted to feel like a big dumb brute as a strong glaive and mercilessly eviscrate all my foes for I would be unable to peacefully talk them down! Wellp... nope. I'm actually about equal to the bonafida learned nano despite the huge int malus. So the big dumb brute just forces his flowery words into everyones proverbial listen-box and walks off scott free.Okay, but what about their unique skills, wont those make the game feel different when you're playing on other classes?.... aaaahahahahahaha! Good effing luck! You can get the Jack's signature move by buying an item and using it to sweet talk another from a second guy right after you get to Sagus Cliffs.Whoa, oh boy that really ought to make a Jack player feel dumb, but atleast he could give the item to an npc! How about the Nano's mindreading, surely thats atleast unique in so- nopenopenope.You'll miss out on a bit of mindreading content in the beginning. Thats all there is. But sooner rather than later, you'll get Scan Thoughts from an item. Oops.Well... then... surely there are some unique special abilities only the Last Castoff can learn that'll atleast make you feel special in combat?! ... not... really. What you can do, companions can do more than adequately and some even stupendously better.The only -real- choise is how pretty do you want to paint yourself with pixels in wether you get enough armor use to wear heavy armor, or mill it out in light armor. And even then you can wear heavy armor just to spite everyone since its only -6 to str and dex plus a paltry -30 to esotery attacks. Nothing some appropriate edge cant overcome.The only truly unique thing for your mc is anamnesia. Which I suppose everyone is going to max anyhow since whynot. And even then one point is enough to unlock all the hidden past reading content. Hnnnngh.I DIDNT COME HERE TO ROLEPLAY AN ERO NOVEL I CAME HERE TO MAKE HARD CHOISES BETWEEN PRETTIER BOOM OR AN UGLIER BOOM DAMMIT!()"/!=(&!&¤=/()(?%¤/&=)"!&¤(/!#Crumpbisquits.To a compulsive minmaxer this is horror come true. I've began to think that the only real ending to the game is the one which scores you the Terminal Velocity achievement. It... it leaves me satisfied. He went the way of the dodo without ever even putting one stat point into a stat pool - a true 'Murican hero.
