Posted: March 9
												Like many people who got this game, I'm a fan of Planescape: Torment and every other Black Isle game. Even though I missed the opportunity to back the game on Kickstarter, I bought it on release. Currently on my first playthrough and loving every moment of it. It captures the feel of PS:T well with the very weird setting and focus on story and dialogues instead of combat. The Last Castoff (protagonist) has a fantastic hook with an obvious nod towards the Nameless One, without it being a rip-off. People who are giving this game a negative review need to remove their rose-tinted glasses. Of course it won't be as good as PS:T after seventeen years of nostalgia.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3
												Captain's Personal Log, Stardate 42552.6.. Wait, that's from an other game isn't it? Where was i, oh yes..Ahem, Torment: Tides of Numenera. (That's the one..) Okay, here goes.Well, this game is a bit of a tricky one to review if you ask me personally.I've been slowly trying to piece things together with this one because the game has tons of choice based answers and quests, and there are three types (might, speed, intellect) of checks to be made, and then there are additional outcomes depending on availabe/invested skills etc. (still interested,...? Well, continue reading then!)All your choices will determine how the rest of the world sees you (tbh, i haven't really noticed much difference between how your choices affect the way the story goes) so it's all up to you if you want to be a good or a bad guy..So yeah, it's easily to say that this game runs deep. However, once you figure out how this system works it makes things a lot clearer and also a lot easier to accept when or how to use them accordingly. The story is not as rich compared to recent games, but it's still good (well to me anyways) and so are most characters you'll encounter throughout the game. (there's plenty of backtracking tho, but i guess that comes with this type of game, yet it shouldn't be a problem for those who love them like myself)The combat was a bit different in the beginning and it took some time getting used to because you will need to make choices on how to fight your opponents, while often interacting with objects located in your surroundings. Then you need to invest in your character's skills and make checks ranging between Might, Speed or Intellect. The same thing you need to do with investigating/negotiating/manipulating/tinkering checks or simply trying to learn more about what's going on while gaining knowledge about who you are and where this knowledge will take you.. Your character/party uses cyphers which are magically based artifacts (so you won't actually be casting or crafting your own spells this time) so to speak. You can also equip gear and substances that aid you in or out of battle. You don't need to run around half naked, waving a stick while shouting something about the world being as flat as a pancake.. (they won't believe you even if you did, trust me..)Graphic and soundwise the game is good without really causing any woooooow effects etc. It's good, or at par with the rest so let's leave it at that shall we?To conclude: Would i recommend this game (yes) But, please make sure you are going at it with an open mind, or else you might not like what you get in return or if you're expecting anything less than absolute greatness you'll likely get disappointed (or if you 'really' hate reading, because you'll be doing that for at least 75% of the time..).I bought the game at 50% off from an online games site because i'm not that confident with preordering stuff or spending too much money for a game that's still in development etc. So, keep that in mind if you want to keep your "losses" expenses at a minimum alright? Check: instant gaming . com (EU) for better prices, daily deals and discounts.

												+Rhin, but other companions suck.+Music, although feels like Planescape's remix.+Art, however portraits and while zoomed ugly.+Game world, unfortunately doesn't feel alive.+Above average story, yet lacking and disappointing in some places.+Playable, without combat, which sucks if you want it.+Lot of interesting dialogues, on the other hand in most cases choices without dire consequences.+Interesting conception for protagonist, who is nevertheless boring and forgettable.+Good read, just sometimes feels overdone.+Somewhat satisfying, somewhat not.Recommended, but can be disappointing. Cut content, unused potential, unpolished translation, too much aspiration for being second Planescape, too little own soul. Like father, like son - bad as a game, shinning as read, just not shinning enough be able to see reflection. The father is kind of displeased. Shame that Steam doesn't give a third option between "yes" or "no", but I'll give a credit of trust, that they are going to make a huge update with new companions and content.

content:
Posted: March 9
												The fact that Numenera is 1.2 million words is both its greatest strength and weakness. I struggle to think of games more generous in ideas, and also struggle to think of a game that needs more of a trim. It's easy to get a little bewildered by the strangeness of the world that lies in every interaction. It's easy to lose sight of the humanity among all of the ideas vying for attention.  I love it though, I really do. This is the kind of game where the world-threatening Cthulu space-cosm is relegated to the side-quest of some dingy bar. It's the kind of game where you're just some guy or gal looking out for their own hide, and getting to define what exactly "your own hide" is, while dragging some people along with you for the ride. It's the kind of game where a tesseractal cube tells you the secret of the universe - through inscrutable similies. If you're interested in ideas and concepts more than execution, and like I bounced off of Tyranny and Divinity like as if it was made of cement rubber, I think you'll find a lot to enjoy here. Just for gods sake ditch those losers at the start and find Rhin and Erritis. My advice.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												Torment has both a long history across iterations and rosy glasses syndrome for the predecessor.  Although Planescape:  Torment has been universally lauded in hindsight, it's initial release didn't do well enough for the notoriously money-hungry TSR at the time to greenlight a successor.  After decades we receive a new setting and original story by a new studio, some of whom worked on the original game.  I would like to say to every reviewer that spent 30 hours or less and declared it a feeble attempt that you didn't spend enough time with it.  Sure, you can gulp down a rare vintage French wine as easily as Mad Dog 20/20 and opine that you don't see the big deal and question why you had to wait a dozen years for the French bottle.  You can do that and you will be an idiot.  Torment:  Tides of Numenera grants instant nostalgia, but it isn't the same game.  You aren't playing a continuation of the Nameless One's adventures (that story concluded) and the setting and interactions are different.  Some people simply can't get past that.  I would not say that this is a gripping tale that needs to be debated in the halls of academia, but it is a well-crafted thought exercise that considers many of the finer points of philosophy, chief among them what constitutes self.  So, for those on the fence:  the vast number of negative reviews seem to be from people who either don't understand this type of reading heavy title ("this looked like a neat RPG, but I had to read") or desperately wanted Planescape:  Torment 2 ("why didn't I get Morte!").  Both types can be ignored.

content:
Posted: March 9
												The fact that Numenera is 1.2 million words is both its greatest strength and weakness. I struggle to think of games more generous in ideas, and also struggle to think of a game that needs more of a trim. It's easy to get a little bewildered by the strangeness of the world that lies in every interaction. It's easy to lose sight of the humanity among all of the ideas vying for attention.  I love it though, I really do. This is the kind of game where the world-threatening Cthulu space-cosm is relegated to the side-quest of some dingy bar. It's the kind of game where you're just some guy or gal looking out for their own hide, and getting to define what exactly "your own hide" is, while dragging some people along with you for the ride. It's the kind of game where a tesseractal cube tells you the secret of the universe - through inscrutable similies. If you're interested in ideas and concepts more than execution, and like I bounced off of Tyranny and Divinity like as if it was made of cement rubber, I think you'll find a lot to enjoy here. Just for gods sake ditch those losers at the start and find Rhin and Erritis. My advice.

												The game has been getting some weird and in my opinion undeserved flak here on the Steam reviews. For once the critics have done a better job og giving this game fair reviews than the players, could be because of the fact they actually PLAYED the game instead of just listening to others trashtalking?Either way, T:ToN is a fantastic homage to PS:T, although the setting is a completely different one the vibe is most certainly there. Beware though, it is a text heavy game, and if you're the kind of person who thinks everything should be voiced this is not for you. The setting is marvelous, and the writing is exellent though, so to me it never felt like a slog when i read (as opposed to for example PoE where I started skimming text a pretty short way into the game.Combat is decent, turn based with enough abilities and tactical options for it to be interesting, although it's not the games strongest point. On the other you won't see alot of it, this is as far from a grind fest as you can come. Play it (read it), love it. I know I do.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28
												So I just finished my first play-through, at about 40 hours with a Gold/Blue dominant Tide. Some thoughts:COMPANIONS - I chose as companions Tybir, Rhin, Matkina and Aligern (before finding Matkina and after I sent Rhin home). I really liked them, in particular Rhin's story, personality and relationship with the Last Castoff felt really special. Matkina is a total badass, and was fun both as a character and as a combatant. Tybir's story was a bit diluted, but it hit home for me in the three-four occasions where it progressed, really touching. I managed to finish Aligern's quest too, but I had him in the party on and off, so I felt a little less connected to him.AREAS - I really loved the variety of locations and the detail of the backgrounds, visually they felt really appropriate for the setting and for the story. As far as game hubs go, I wish that Sagus Cliffs was 1-2 areas larger, and that it would be explorable again after the Valley, maybe with some wrap up for some NPCs, or some follow up quests for the initial ones. I think it might have been interesting to offer more than one way to enter the Bloom, also. Speaking of which, it was a great area to explore and absorb, I really liked it. About the end, I can understand some of the complaints I've read, but I don't mind how the whole Labyrinth/Calm area is used, I actually enjoyed the extra work to get back companions and the interactions with the other Castoffs.MAIN STORY - Great story. I don't get why people felt that the reveal of who the Changing God is so underwhelming, to me it was the best choice the writers did for the story. A great villain doesn't come from who he is personally, but from how he chooses to act based on what happens to him; basically, both in PS:T and T:ToN the Villain is an early version of the Hero, showing us how choices are what make the difference between good and evil, not our intrinsic nature. I liked how many themes and atmospheres were similar to PS:T, but significantly different: the never-ending war; the nigh-immortal protagonist; the many beliefs that drive individuals and factions to extreme actions and consequences; the quest for inner peace and redemption (protagonist and companions); the sense of helplessness in regards to the lack of knowledge (history, how things in the city works, superior entities ruling our existence). The only great difference, which I enjoyed and is tied to the difference in settings, is that PS:T was rooted in a world where rules are clear: rule of three, good vs evil, the Lady of Pain, alignment and the Outlands, etc. In T:ToN everything is blurred, leaving you without a "map" of what is best or right or good: you really have to go through some events, obstacles or quests by trial and error - and that's how adventuring in the Ninth World should feel like, in my opinion.INVENTORY, JOURNAL - I like the restrictions on the companions' inventory, I like the variety in weapons and armours, although as someone pointed out, some character builds are left without a decent weapon until later on in the game. Aside from that I liked the possible upgrades to the Last Castoff and to the companions' equipment. Oddities and Cyphers were good, and the Merecasters were fun and interesting, I also think there was an adequate amount of those for the dimension of the game world. As for the Journal, I was initially very disappointed by the lack of the Codex, but seeing as we're apparently going to get it later I won't complain, for now.CHARACTER OPTIONS & COMBAT - Some people thought that the game doesn't offer variety in character creation. I agree strongly that the descriptors and foci for the character are few and underwhelming, and that the classes don't seem to matter that much, at least not as much as dumping all your point in a single Stat. Of course I went for the Intellect route, thinking it would remind the experience with PS:T and being a max-WIS Nameless One. Skills and Esoteries were fun, some are OP in my opinion (e.g. any skill that moves a character across the battlefield) but in general they are well suited for the game. Crisis was very slow and buggy at release, seems better after the patch - also a few critical Crises (Miel Avest, Gullet) feel better now. Some extra fine-tuning would help, though, as it's never very clear where and how far you can move your characthers, or pathing in general.ENDING - At first I was a bit annoyed that the ending was so tied down to my Tides and previous choices, but considering what I said above it makes sense. I chose to play towards a Gold tide, and the curiosity of the first time player added a Blue tide. That's fine, and it only encourages me to attempt a different path very soon; now, I don't know how hard or easy it will be to get a Red tide, or a Blue/Silver tide, but if I recall correctly, also in PS:T I was struggling to get certain alignment. And that makes sense too, after all, because most of us are driven naturally to doing good actions, saving people and being altruistic. I hope the options to go in a different direction are there and are implemented well enough, but we'll see. Having said all this, the Gold endings I was "allowed" to choose were appropriate: self sacrifice and saving others is consistent with my previous actions and with how I played my Last Castoff, and to be honest, with me as well. So, the game reflected well who I am through my choices, and gave me the corresponding output at the end.In conclusion, I think the game is solid, it captures the elements I liked in PS:T and the right atmosphere from the Numenera RPG and blends them in one great experience. I think it holds a good re-playability, and the fact that we're getting patches and possibly extra content indicated that this aspect will be further consolidated. I hope Crises get worked on, I hope the Codex for the Journal is added, I hope more descriptors and foci are implemented, but for the rest, I'm really happy with the game and I can't wait to play it again.VOTE: 8/10

content:
Posted: March 10
												This game is simply amazing, I made a clever nano with a silver tongue. I put so much point in intellect and persuasion that I made most of the game without fighting (except where I had no choice). Hell, I took control of a gigantic being (the Bloom) that ran on despair for fuel. I could have killed if I wanted too, but I decided that since he was the enemy of my enemy I might as well let him live. I ended the game by choosing to merge every castoffs in my body and becoming a God that surpassed the Changing God. I became known as the teacher of healers and much like the avatar I brought balance to the world. This was only one ending amongs't many. For my next playthrought, I am torn apart in between and impulsive warrior or some backstabbing thief or something. What I love most about this game is that nothing is black and white. You might decide to be merciful one day, and the little creature you spare end up being some serial killer later. Hell is paved with good intentions. Even if the combat system is quite clunky, there is merit to it and I learned to enjoy it. There is a form of tactic to it and it can be rewarding at time, keep in mind this is the game main weakspot, the other being the lack of voice acting, but I can understand that since the script is more than a million words long and that voice acting is quite costly for the devs.10/10 would play againI want more content or else I will die, I need my dose of tides.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10
												I remember playing a bit of Planescape:Torment back in the day, but I don't really remember it that well.  So I came at Torment: Tides of Numenera from a fresh perspective, I also know that spiritual successor doesn't mean direct sequel.  So I wasn't expecting one.  I have to say that I was almost immediately immersed in this game.  The Numenera setting is a mind blowing, imagination inspiring setting that I have had such an amazing time in this game.I'm about 30 or so hours in on my first play through, and I really don't want it to come to a close.  I'm also, for the first time in a while, feeling fairly conflicted about which paths to choose, because the consequences of my actions actually seem to carry weight.  The combat is simple, but can be challenging as well.  I'm playing a nano, and I've just reached tier 4, so I've got some pretty sweet abilities.  But I actually get more fun out of trying to avoid combat if I can.  My next playthrough will be on a Glaive (the warrior class) and we'll see how differently it plays from that angle.This is quickly becoming one of my favorite cRPGs in recent times, easily eclipsing Tyranny (Tyranny was great, but really really left me wanting more), Pillars of Eternity was good too, but came off a tad generic.  Again, for me, the star of this game really is the setting of the Ninth World, and the ecclectic mix of characters, settings, and abilities you'll find there.  I highly recommend you give this game a try.  Once you make it through the first hour and half or so, you'll be hooked.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
Early Access Review
								TL;DR - What's available right now leaves me wanting more - I powered through it before my classes start back, and I didn't realize the beta ended when I got on the airship!! I want to play with my speedy glaive more!Negatives :Out of the thirteen hours I've put into the game (so far), I found one bug - Using the south eastern terminal in the Peerless quest without clearing out the southern drones will stick your party in place without the ability to move or to attack. Even if you kill off the peerless using Opportunist, you're still unable to interact with the game entirely and thus are stuck having to reload.Along the same track, older saves from early versions will keep your game from loading, but anyone using exclusively steam won't have that issue. If it becomes a problem, go to your InXile folder inside Appdata/locallow and delete the saves folder!Positives :The world is phenomenal. The interaction is very Pillars of Eternity. The characters that I have met thus far have been enjoyable, though part of me wishes you could dive a little deeper into them. I'd really like to be able to gut Fulsum's hold over the Underbelly and generally just sew chaos while I pretend to be the Changing God!The side quests are numbeous, fairly recognizable, enjoyable and more often than not completely worthwhile - I'd like to see further expansion on the invasive surgeries that you can get in Cliff's Edge, but I also run chromed out in Shadowrun so maybe that's just me.The combat is solid. While it can be tricky to get ahold of at first, this most recent patch (Tidal Surge, Dec2016) seems to have made things a little more accessible and easier to grasp without losing *all* of the math going into combat.Wishlist:I'd really like to see an option to speed up combat - Specifically enemy animations and general combat speed.I'd like to see further gear customizability - Not just for the Last Castoff, but also for their companions! I'm not saying I want to stick Rhin in a suit of full plate, but interchangability would be nice if it could be introduced somehow.Closing thoughts:I'm very much excited to play through this multiple times in full with different builds and party compositions. I do hope that all of our companions aren't necessarily introduced in the first city. I'm excited to see what changes happen with the Cult of the Changing God - Being a selfish and careless character for that run was really great for making them do all of my dirty work! Here's to looking forward to inXile putting out yet another phenomenal title!

content:
Posted: March 9
												I don't know how inXile is going to walk out of that one.Planescape: Torment fans are going to be offended by the usage of the word “Torment” in the title.Kickstarted backers will hate them for all the cut content and failing to deliver on the sweet promises.Those who buy it off Steam will be frustrated and disappointed because of the ridiculous pricing.To be honest, Tides of Numenera is a good game, with an unusual setting and short yet enthralling story. At the same time, it's utterly awful. Attention to detail, user-friendliness, thoughtful balance? Virtually nonexistent. I can ♥♥♥♥♥ about things that annoy me here for hours on end.If you found Pillars of Eternity's dialogue to be too bland and heavy on lore, this one might feel a bit better (though the dialogs did at times get tedious!). If you don't like long overextended games, TToN's pacing might turn to be a pleasant surprise.If you love complex character development, you might find the roleplay system too primitive and simplistic, but the quest and dialogue variability adequate.Recommended to purchase on a sale, with as few expectations as possible.Personal recommendation for Fargo: modesty is a virtue.Personal thank you to Mark Morgan, who once again did a great job.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6
												Old school gamers who loved classic 90's RPG games such as Baulder's Gate, Icewind Dale, and of course Planescape:Torment will love what this game has to offer.  Rich and immersive story telling that forces you to slow down and take your time to read the dialog and put things together to figure out the optimal solution to quest lines.  The game lets you tread a path that mostly stays clear of combat situations if you desire allowing you take an intelligent approach over fighting.  Killing NPC's doesn't net you XP so your focus can remain on character and story, yet even if you choose a more brutish approach over compassion or intelligence you will find an interesting and fulfilling game to play.If a good game is a series of interesting choices than Torment is exactly that, a series of interesting choices leading to interesting consequences.  Despite its relatively short 35 hour play time its rich, compelling, and satisfying to play.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10
												I just finished my first playtrhough of the game and finished in around 34 hours of actual game play.  I did as nmany optional quests, maps, and more to explore the world, and I really enjoyed it.  I tried the game, aand after about an hour,I gave up and created a different character.  I saw that there were ways to avoid combat with dialogue and challenges, so I decided to embrace that and became a charming jack, with skills like persuasion and deception and then added perception for a talk-y character who gets out of things and can convience anyone of really anything.  And I would often go hours without combat.  Later when it was needed, I was able to slide my Jack heavy party into stealth ambushing, with a fun group of folks.  So I enjoyed the game.Now mechanically, the game is limited to just three stats and classes, but the massive amount of skills and abilities helps out with that.  And combat is interesting, and you can stealth and flee, or try to find items to interact with to end teh encounter that way, so there's a lot of cleverness to that, but overall, the mechanics were about what you;d expect from these sorts of RPGs, from Wasteland  2 and Pillars to Baldur's Gate and Fallout.  Where the game really shines is the Ninth World.  It has a very bizarre, fleshed out, and detailed world, and better than the previous worlds.  It felt, in terms of flavor, like an odd cross between the original Planescape and the flavor of Sunless Sea.  In fact I found quite a large number of synergies in flavor from Torment: Tides of Numenera and Sunless Sea and Fallen London.  The flavor was sharp and totally on point, and the world was evocative.  It breathed.  So the result is a fun game, where you have a lot of options, and often I felt like prick becuase I;d choose something that kept my party together or my warrior...er...glaive...from heading off, and I had to be really antagonsitic about it too.  It had some nice moments where I didn't like myself.  Anyways, good game, with the expected amount of fun!

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
												A great game. I think it is more "Tormenty" than Planescape Torment itself.The setting is very fresh and interesting. I think it is now my favorite setting. There is much to explore in this game. There is a lot of text to read - but it is interesting text (not boring walls of text as in Pillars of Eternity). Quests are interesting, have multiple solutions and influence one another. There are no fetch/kill quests. The characters you interact with are very memorable - each of them has a background, backstory. There is a lot of hidden "tastes". It is worth talking to absolutely everyone, play with every oddity in your equipment. You may always discover something new.What some people may not like is the amount of combat encounters. These are almost non-existent. The game is more about the exploration than combat. Many of these can be avoided as well. So this contributes to the perceived shortness of the game - it took me just above 30 hours on my first playthrough. But seeing as almost none of it is combat, I think there is quite a lot of content. But I personally think some more dungeon crawling could be fun. Having said that, the encounters there are are actuallu quite interesting - killing the enemy is not always the only solution. Also you may utilize environment in the fight.So I think this is not a game for everyone, but if you want something fresh this is definetely worth trying. If you want more classical cRPG experience, this may not be for you.

												To begin with the obvious: this is not a "combat RPG". Just like in Planescape Torment, you will mostly be offered detailed, well written stories and dialogues.Most of the game can be played by talking your way out of any situation.The combats are just too spaced and short lived to have any relevance in considering if you will enjoy it. content:
Posted: March 5
												I just finished the game and if I were to give it an overall score i'd give it about a 6.5/10.I agree with what most other people are saying about the pros and cons of this game.  It really is a mixed bag of sometimes having amazing writing and other times being too long-winded and convuluted.  Combat is definately one of the weakest points, but like most have pointed out it is not the focus of the game.  I thought the visuals were great for displaying the amazing weirdness of the world without taking too much from your own imagination.My favorite part about the game was by far encountering all the mysterious numenera and discovering their secrets.  The creativity and the writing for the many different types of numenera is what I would consider the games strongest point.  I had more fun reading about and using all the different oddities, cyphers, and artifacts than I did progressing through the main story.  This shows that there is something lacking in the main story, but it is a positive for the attention to detail in the rest of the game.  I ended up not caring so much about "What does one life matter?" as I did about "What bizarre piece of technology will I find next?"If you like exploring and learning about an amazing alien-like world with lots of logic-defying and imaginitive technology, I'd recommend grabbing this game once it goes on sale for sure.

content:
Posted: March 8
												This game may not be for everyone but its a rich rewarding experience that was pretty different than any other game I'd ever played but in a good way. Sometimes the game was confusing and vague and I suppose that its done on purpose because your character is supposed to be a new consciousness with a hazy memory of past lives, but it didn't keep me from being immersed in the setting and wanting to know more and do more quests. Probably my favorite part of the game were the very cool companions. Having kickstarted the game it is sad to see that not all of the stretch goals were put into the game but I do think they put a lot of effort into the game.  Overall it felt like playing an interesting sci fi fantasy book and I would play another game like this so I hope there is another.

content:
Posted: March 13
												A game for fans of the truly classic computer RPGs, where reading large volumes of text to comprehension, and a fondness for the literary was a strong must. Not a game for the twitter, snapchat and ADHD crowd, those those that prefer action over story.It took about thrity hours to complete my first run through, though there were enough options along the way that I do intend to play through it again with a different character outlook and choices along the way. This should give you some indication of what kind of time investment you will need to make to complete the game.If you are strong RPG fan you'll know that the underlying systems can vary a great deal and be perfectly functional for delivery of the story, and the same is true here. There are some interesting new systems for cRPGs in play, and none were burdensome, so overall I am left with a positive view of them.This is one week after official launch, so keep this in mind at the time you are reading this. The developers have indicated they still plan to add additional companions and other expansions, so my next play through will likely be a year out.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
												Bit disappointed as I ordered the immortal edition and havent received any downloads or links, or any instruction.This game is good, but very short. It is nowhere near the length of PoE and does not have as much content or flexibility. For a game that emphasized choice and consequence, it does not live up to its promises. The adventure is on a railway track, you cant go back to any locations once you have left them, character developement is kind of redundant, you dont need all of those combat skills because there arent enough opportunities for conflict and your party members, considering how much talk was made about how versatile they are, break down to one of two major life choices to decide their fate.As a fan of the tabletop I have to say I cannot believe that you don't get to fight ANY mutated future monster hybrids, like, not one, except the Nachywhatever. Also, no wilderness exploration locations? Whats that about? Numenera is full of that. There are 3 major locations. All of which you have seen extensively in videos and screenshots. The game was spoiled for me by this. They gave way too much away online and hinted that there was a lot more to explore, but no, if you have flipped through the screenshots and watched the trailer you have seen 99% of locations in the game.Considering the amount of money they raised and the promises that included, I am disappointed overall. *SPOILER TIME*Why the tides? Do you have to have a hamfisted karma system in every game? When it works it works, fallout etc, but here I thought the whole idea of tides was childish and forced in. It made very little difference to gameplay and was not fully thought out. It detracted from the game a lot and is definitely not Numenera canon. I mean, why can the rest of the world live without tides and be fine? Why does only the Sagus protectorate descend into madness with the tides removed? It makes little sense and is explained by, we are castoffs we're special.so lets say the Changing god has been around for a thousand years, which he hasnt as it is stated that he started this practise after the tabaht conflict which was a few hundred years ago in the game. So they also say he changes every decade or so. lets be generous and give him 500 years. At a castoff per decade thats 50 cast offs. So he would have had to be over 3000 years old to have around 300 castoffs. A lot of which are dead/disappeared. So the Sorrow, this extradimensional being is summoned into existence for, at an absolute max 300 people? Over 3000 years? That have affected a tiny portion of the world and made it sad? Not buying it. Should have just made a cool canonical numenera game. Basically this game follows the plot of throne of bhaal/shadows of amn. why does every game you guys make have to be about gods and changing the world/universe?? You know most rpg people would be happy with more freedom over character origin/backstory and a main quest that was about the land you are in specifically, you know factions, politics who you work for etc an just that, but well done and fleshed out. Not always, I am the chosen one, I must know myself/find my creator/mysterious scientist man/god who is bothering/hunting me. Its like the hero's journey on steroids, every time. If you are going to make a game out of existing IP then why not use that IP and lore that worked so well? Why invent new areas/factions/really big important reasons? if you already have lore and history that not only works a lot better and has had way more time to be improved and refined but you have also paid for the rights to, then why oh why would you recreate the same story you have told with other IP in this universe? I suspect that there is someone within your team that is like, let's make a difference guys, let's change people's perspectives, let's enlighten people. Yet instead of doing those things you are forcefeeding us the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t karmic/universal/finding yourself story in different formats. We are not looking for games like this to enlighten us or make us better people, there are plenty of opportunities in the modern age for access to material that is much more profound and likely to affect us than a Crpg. Please just stick to making good games and stop trying to affect us spiritually, it is incredibly boring and done in a really amateurish way.All in all this game has all the elements to be truly great. I am hoping that a decent amount of time is spent on making some great DLC to really open it up and give us a more exploratory/self created adventure.

content:
Posted: March 1
												The epitome of a story-driven RPG. Lives up to the original Torment in many ways and will likely surpass it if the developers continue polishing and adding to the game.It boasts a STAGGERING - 1.2 million words of text. Surpassing the original Torment's 800k by 50%. It crushes Dragon Age: Origins and Pillars of Eternity and their ~700k words. It even surpasses Baldurs Gate II with its 1 million words.Tides of Numenera is the ultimate story driven RPG with more text than every book of the Harry Potter series combined.I played the Beta in early access and then started a new game after full release. Every time I've opened the game I've played for 12 hours straight. The world draws you in and keeps begging you to stay.This is a game with endless story potential and mind numbing amounts of information to take in. This is Earth 1 billion years in the future. One can barely begin to imagine what that vast history could entail. And you get to explore it as much as you can. You'll only scratch the surface, but what you find will give you many many hours of entertainment.The combat is - as far as I can tell - completely optional. And while you will probably want to dabble in multiple combat events, you can further reduce actual combat by simply using stealth, diplomacy or the environment to solve the problem. Being attacked by a swarm of bloodthirsty drones? Sneak past them to disable their AI core. Attacked by nightmares? Paralyze them with nearby technical equipment. There are many options.To keep the exploration interactive and engaging without using constant heavy combat, your existing ability stats can be used as a depleting resource which can be restored by rest or items. So for example if you need to dig up some treasures under a pile of rocks, you may have to expand some of your "Might" stats, reducing the available resource. Deplete the resource too low and you may find that you'll lack it when you need it next. And you can never be sure when another need arises, and many of the resource checks can only be done once. So if you mess up, the story can change.Luckily, your companions can also help in many situations - though not in all. So hang around with the right people and you can have all the muscle, speed or intelligence you may require. But just like you, their resources will deplete and they will eventually run out.While resting is the obvious way to restore said resources, it often costs a fair bit of money, and furthermore - rest too often and you may find that the story of the game world passes you by and events can spiral out of control. Events that could have been solved one way, may eventually end in a completely different way because you tarried too long. Yet you never feel pressured for time since nobody really keeps track, you just have to trust your gut instincts.The companions are well written and have deep, complicated personalities. They will interject themselves into events and discussions, share information, gear and abilities. They each have their personal agendas with which you can help with or not. And many of the choices you make can have unpredictable outcomes. ---All in all, Torment: Tides of Numenera is an excellent game as long as you have no illusions about what you're getting yourself into. It's not a combat heavy game like Pillars of Eternity, or any of the old Infinity Engine games or later series like Neverwinter nights - though it's story depth could certainly be compared to that. No, Torment is all about the story and the setting. Torment is a massive 1.2 million word "Hands on" Novel that you can experience. And it draws you in like any great sci-fi or fantasy book (or series of books) should.You're an immortal being with fading memories of a thousand lifetimes, walking the Earth 1 billion years in the future, trying to figure out who or what you really are and how you fit into the events unfolding around you.

												I remember being 12 on holidays over christmas and playing a PnP Rpg my cousin had made based on of all things William Shatner's Tek War. In any combat situation he was likely to murder our entire party if we actually tried physical combat. It was all talking my way out of stuff. This game reminds me quite a lot of those times.tl;drGreatest Visual Novel ever written. 11/10 would read again!

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8
												Tides of Numenera is a great game if you play it for writing and atmosphere and mediocre at best if you play it for combat and mechanics. Its plot, while a bit short, is quiet interesting and unusual, side quests are fabulous and a vast majority of NPCs are wonderfully written. World of Numenera is intriguing enough and a multitude of useless but colourful artifacts that you gather in course of action adds a lot of flair. It's really a pleasure to delve into unknown aspects of this world, visit its wondrous places and get to know its inhabitants.At the same time, combat is awful. Luckily, you can evade it for most part, but when you can't,,, turn-based style works poorly here, where you often meet a lot of enemies and have to wait through their endless turns time and again. Especially now, when game sometimes freezes or bugs out and you have to restart from the beginning. Much-advertised tides mechanic is sadly almost non-existent too.But despite all these faults Tides of Numenera is one-of-a-kind game, well, two-of-a-kind, together with original Torment. You're not gonna find another RPG with these awesome and picturesque walls of text where you can resolve most of the conflicts with words. It's well worth to try out if you're a fan of this kind of RPGs.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12
												To begin with the obvious: this is not a "combat RPG". Just like in Planescape Torment, you will mostly be offered detailed, well written stories and dialogues.Most of the game can be played by talking your way out of any situation.The combats are just too spaced and short lived to have any relevance in considering if you will enjoy it. And most of them will offer a "pacifist" mechanism to reach an objective and close the combat.Although the characters have a decent backstory, they provide limited interactions with the player.But there are numerous quests that will let you express a personnality. You can be cold and calculating, just, curious...These quests are short and compelling enough to let you want to try chaining them and completing all the side quests available.

content:
Posted: March 5
												I just finished the game and if I were to give it an overall score i'd give it about a 6.5/10.I agree with what most other people are saying about the pros and cons of this game.  It really is a mixed bag of sometimes having amazing writing and other times being too long-winded and convuluted.  Combat is definately one of the weakest points, but like most have pointed out it is not the focus of the game.  I thought the visuals were great for displaying the amazing weirdness of the world without taking too much from your own imagination.My favorite part about the game was by far encountering all the mysterious numenera and discovering their secrets.  The creativity and the writing for the many different types of numenera is what I would consider the games strongest point.  I had more fun reading about and using all the different oddities, cyphers, and artifacts than I did progressing through the main story.  This shows that there is something lacking in the main story, but it is a positive for the attention to detail in the rest of the game.  I ended up not caring so much about "What does one life matter?" as I did about "What bizarre piece of technology will I find next?"If you like exploring and learning about an amazing alien-like world with lots of logic-defying and imaginitive technology, I'd recommend grabbing this game once it goes on sale for sure.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11
												It's not often I feel compelled to write up a review of a game but some games such as Torment: Tides of Numenera deserve it, partly because of quality but also because of the anticipation of waiting so many years for it to be released.  I was a massive fan of the original Planescape game  (which at the time was underrated by a number of prominent gaming magazines), and is my favourite RPG of all time.  With regards to Tides of Numenera I feel that it has the potential to be nearly as good as the original Planescape but falls someway short.  That does not mean that it is a bad game, only that it is a good game that has a number of flaws that prevent greatness.   First the good:Setting - originally I was disappointed that the Planescape campaign was not being used but having seen the decline of Dungeons & Dragons over the past couple of decades (which Planescape is a part of) in the end I was glad that they went with the Numenera campaign setting.   As a reader of Jack Vance and a fan of the blend of sci-fi/fantasy that influences Numenera, I found the Ninth World instantly engrossing, and, just like with Planescape, felt I wanted to explore it further.  I particularly enjoyed the less linear sections of the game including Sagus Cliffs and the incredible Bloom, one of the best game worlds ever.Story/characters - I enjoyed the story, which kept me engrossed towards the end of the game, and appreciate the amount of text used to flesh it out, which I believe was over 1.2 million lines of dialogue.  I enjoyed in particular the back-story of the world's inhabitants and the games subplots perhaps more than the main story itself, and felt that this area started to approach that of Planescape.   Some people were complaining about the amount of reading involved so this game is not for everyone but for myself I thought it was well written, comparable with Planescape.  I also liked that you could basically complete the game with almost no battles if you chose to, relying on other skills such as guile or stealth.  Other reviews were not happy with the lack of spoken dialogue.  Whether this lack of dialogue was a design choice or because they ran out of money I am not sure, but I do personally find spoken dialogue too slow and distracting and much prefer reading at my own speed.   In term of characters they were generally very interesting and I felt that the personalities of the companions that accompany you were well thought out and each one intrigued me, particularly Rhin.  The downside to characters was that there were not enough of them but I will bring this up later on. Loading screens - when I heard this game used the same engine as Pillars of Eternity I was immediately apprehensive as my experience of that game had been ruined by loading screens.  Thankfully, Torment load screens were not a problem on my computer and the game was structured so there were not dozens of rooms to be entered (probably because of the game engine).   Stats/Skills - I found the use of Might, Speed and Intelligence an interesting system and how you could put points into tasks.  I particularly liked how failing a task could actually open up new options in the game world, which offers potential new playthroughs.   I also enjoyed the types of skills on offer and levelling up characters, although I felt the level cap was a little low (see not so good). Combat - there were a few complaints about the turn-based combat (which Planescape did not use unless you count pressing the spacebar to pause the action) but I have to say that I am a fan of this as it allows me time to think and strategise.  I thought Tides had much better combat than Tryanny (which seemed to be mostly AI and confused the hell out of me), but not as good as Divinity which had some very interesting spell combinations.  Now the not so good:Length - this for me was the biggest weaknesses, partly due because of the games strengths.  Around 40 hours into the game, and really starting to enjoy myself, all of a sudden I found myself levelled up to tier 4, and the game was starting to draw to a close.  40 hours seems reasonable but this was after completing every quest and having already played a large section of the game with a different character type before restarting, so it is feasible you could complete the game in much less time. I feel that the world setting was so good, particularly the Bloom, that I just wanted more, and it was very disappointing that it suddenly nosedived to a conclusion.  From what I am reading online it appears that the developers cut a whole game world and it certainly feels so from the flow.  You really feel that you are building up to something fantastic only for the carpet to be pulled from your feet as you are steered towards the end.  Hopefully, they can allay some of these issues by releasing additional downloadable content.Transition Linearity/Maps - although there are a couple of hub areas which give a degree of choice of how to approach quests there were a couple of linearity issues with the game.  For example, once you complete a certain stage you cannot go back.  There are a couple of points I would have liked the option to return to Sagus Cliffs to see if choices I had made elsewhere have influenced events in the city but this never happened.  This is possibly linked to the length of the game but there was a point on one map where it looks like you had a choice of portals to different locations but in the end you are shuttled through due to the approach of the Sorrow, which I found a little disappointing.  I also felt that more dungeon areas should have been introduced, particularly during the Valley of the Dead Heroes level which is more a sequence of rooms.  Tiers (levelling up) - this is related to the shortness of the game.  The maximum tiers you can reach is 4 (which is about 16 levels) and when I levelled up and could go no further, I had the sinking feeling that the game was starting to end.  Ideally, I would have liked a bigger game world and the opportunity to reach tier 5 - downloadable content please!Bugs - there were a number of bugs in the game that I noticed including one that actually prevented me from taking a certain action to complete a quest resulting in the game freezing.  I also encountered a couple of freezes during battles.  With so much time spent developing the game this is something they should have got right.  Thankfully, unlike certain Atari RPGs (Greyhawk - which when patched is fantastic btw) at least they did not hinder my enjoyment of the game.  Merecaster Sections - I grew up on Fighting Fantasy gamebooks so I am not put up with interactive text but I found these sections incredibly dull.  The problem was that they contained massive amounts of text and I was not clear what (if any) effects my choices were having.  I will have another run through the game to see if this improves.  Minor gripes:Extras - while not a major issue I would have liked some form of overall world map to have been available.  Planescape also had a codex/bestiary which I found interesting and I feel that Numenera missed out on this, although there may be some plans to introduce this via updates/downloads.  Overall I would say this is a good game that just misses out on great due to missing one major game location which leaves it feeling slightly unfinished.  I think expectations hindered it, and the fact I was not a Kickstarter Backer mean I am not as disappointed as I could have been, but it is worth purchasing if you are not put off by reading and turn based combat.  The characters, story and gameplay options mean that it is interesting enough for a second run through using different character companions and the Bloom is one of the great game locations of all time.  I would definitely be interested in more updates and games involving the Numenera game setting.

												Very good game - though not for everyone.This is a game for you if what you are looking for in an RPG is: - an interesting story - a unique and original setting, different than a standard fantasy world - well-written companions that seem to actually be a part of the world instead of just extra bodies helping you in combat - quests that you can complete in multiple different ways - lots and LOTS of written text to readOn the other hand, this is probably not a game for you if what you are looking for is: - more classical "fantasy RPG" experience - more action-oriented gameplay (there are no random combat encounters in this game) - more visual experience (as opposed to text-heavy one) - deep and complex combat system

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8
												I kickstarted this game free and clear the instant I found out about the campaign, waited four years to play it and I am mightily satisfied. The game is a thoughtful and well written RPG, and an excellent introduction to the unforgettable Ninth World Numenera setting.Like everyone else I have some complaints, but if you like to read and you're not bothered too much by some clunky mechanics, your money won't go to waste. Now for the complaints.The cypher system, a peerless tabletop system, is not particularly well suited to CRPG gameplay. The adaptations committed to make it playable strip away a lot of its tactical nuance. Its true that you can "avoid all combat" assuming that "abusing the hide button" is satisfying to you. The crisis system makes for very specific encounters, but there's really not many of them, so a lot of the time the game is a "running back and foreth simulator" which was fine with me, but I can see people getting impatient.The art is amazing! The graphics are... not. I found the models for the characters to be quite low clarity. Its very difficult to get a good idea of what NPC faces are like, which makes it difficult to get attached to them. Some of them are meant to be horribly disfigured and you just... can't see them. Even the NPC portraits lack impact. There's also no text area where combat logs and chat transcripts are kept which seems like a tremendous oversight.Overall I definitely recommend this game. I also recommend patience and circumspection while playing it.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10
												I thoroughly enjoyed my first playthrough, and plan to do at least 2 complete others.Beware, this is a text heavy game, and there is very little "action", so to speak. I personally loved it. I liked talking or sneaking my way through crisis. I may have had to fight at some points, but it was due to my choices, I believe.I liked the level up system. I loved that combat didn't really matter as far as XP is concerned, and that you don't have to grind to advance the story.I liked every single companion you can recruit, their respective storylines, and their relationships with each other.I enjoyed each and every interraction with NPCs, even though sometimes I felt limited in my choices, and more annoyingly, I coudn't act on the knowledge I gleaned from reading thoughts most of the time.I liked how interacting with a Merecaster could make you change things in the past, though I must admit that apart for one instance I didn't see the difference it made in the world. But it may be because I didn't really understand what was actually going on.The story and universe were compelling and very interesting, if a bit short.All that said, there are a few thing I didn't really like. First is the feeling that my choices were deeply meaningful to my character and their companions, but not that much to the world at large, and most importantly, not that much to the end of the game. Second is the difficulty. The game was much too easy. Most of the time you can't really fail, and even if you don't try to make a good combattant, you most likely end up being a monster. I honestly breezed through every crises but one, and even that one felt difficult because the others were so easy that a medium difficulty one seems tough.Third is the length. The story was very very interesting, as stated above, but I think it could have benefitted from a longer development, or maybe branches. Because that was quite linear, which is a bit of a shame given the kind of game it is.But other than that, I had some of the best time I had lately playing a game. There are a few bugs here and there, but they are mostly inconsequential or easily bypassed.I must admit, 45€ is a bit much for what is there at the time of this review, but I know that more content is coming, and that it is included in the price. So I'm pretty sure it will be worth it sooner rather than later.All in all, I would give this game a 8/10. Solid gameplay, marvelous world, wonderful NPCs and companions, possibility to never actually hit anyone would have made this a 9 or 10, but the shortness of the story and botched difficulty make it an 8.

content:
Posted: March 6
												This game is a little rough around the edges in some places, but underneath its issues there is a really great game. It's innovative, intelligent, and a lot of fun. I backed this game on Kickstarter years ago hoping primarily for excellent writing and thought provoking ideas, and it delivered.On the gameplay side, specifically combat, I think it's a lot better than people give it credit for. It's somewhat clunky but ultimately I enjoyed it quite a bit. I don't understand how people can be so virulently critical of the combat in Torment, yet a  game like Divinity: Original Sin is praised for its combat, which I found to be just as clunky and much more frustrating.Also, the character advancement system is pretty different from what you'll find in most RPGs, and I found it quite satisfying.Overall, I'd give it about an 8.9 / 10.

content:
Posted: April 10
												The world is engrossing and feels like a real, utterly bizarre place. The companions were interesting with mostly satisfying storylines. The story was a good read, with a twist toward the end that I didn't see coming, and I'm looking forward to playing through again and seeing it from a different angle. The combat was passable, but I had more fun trying to avoid fighting anyway. The pacing can feel a bit off - the story can meander a bit, especially as you get lost for hours in sidequests, and then suddenly it jerks through major revelations before each one has really sunk in. Overall, I'm really satisfied with my experience and I really hope we get a chance to explore more of the world again in an expansion or spin-off ("The Amazing Adventures of Rhin," perhaps?). A-

content:
Posted: March 3
												As a whole it's a better experience than most of the other RPG schlock out there, and from the little I know of the source material, they did a good job of keeping the experience grounded (and weird). I have some major gripes though.For the main plot you're just carted around on an amusement park ride. So simplistic and lame. My super intelligent, observant nano was not able to figure out the very obvious plot points and identities of characters. The game forced me to act like a dupe, with no real power to affect other characters or the story. And then at the end, some morally questionable caretaker "ancient being" forces you to accept their power and their reality, when the story up to that point is about creating your own reality? The choices and consequences were lacking.The companions, too, felt short. The three I used were the hero, the jack, and the kid. I enjoyed their personalities a lot, and I might have missed something at the end game, but the characters just petered out. And, I got absolutely no closure with Matkina when I subsumed her to become God. Again maybe I'm an idiot and missed some doors at the final scene. But in my playthrough, they just stopped existing at a certain point.Combat was easy mode but fun. I didn't like the occasional bugs with trying to destroy terrain, or the knock down bugs that cause turns to stall. Those sucked, but otherwise, one-shotting everything while still feeling in danger felt like a good balance for a story game.The game is fun.

content:
Posted: March 23
												I Picked this up being a fan of Planescape: Torment and the Numenera tabletop RPG. I will approach this review from that angle. The Numenera system works wonderfully in a video game format with minimal modification, and at least for me is much more approachable than the tabletop version, given that it can be hard to visualize a world so alien.   I was a bit disappointed with the lack of character customization, given that the game would lend itself to it better than most. As far as a Planscape: Torment successor goes, it is acceptable.  Not the highest praise, sure, but when you're trying to make a successor to the best written game of all time, it's hard to eclipse the original.  The writing is solid, the world building is excellent, and the combat is mediocre at best (Still better than Planescape). Much like the original, it's a great game if you want a story.  If you want a combat centric RPG, Tyranny, POE, or any of the classic CRPGs would be a better option.

								Tides of Numenera by nXile studios is the successor title to Torment Planescape (1999) developed by Balck Isle. No longer based in the 2nd edition D&D universe of Planescape. We are in the 9th world of Numenera. However Torment: Tides of Numernera is wirtten by a heavy hitter in the gaming industry Chris Avellone. Chris has worked on titles such as the original Torment, Fallout 2, Baldur's Gate. This is most definitely what people are calling  "text heavy" and it's exceptional. This is a great rendition of the pillars of eternity unity engine. Character models looks great, every district you enter has its own artistic merits and acheivment. You can't help but play to learn more about the world of Numenera.

content:
Posted: March 14
												If this review had a title, it would probably be "I liked it BUT".What actually is in the game is good or great. The storyline is great, the companions are decent (except Erritis who's great), the fights are few but each of them has at least a little quirk (and at least they don't suffer from the RTWP plague), the setting is interesting, the choices are enough to keep things interesting but not so many that they lose weight.The problem with this game is, even to someone like me who started with zero expectations (I haven't really followed the kickstarter, I just backed it to reserve a low-price digital copy of the game) it's painfully obivious how much content has been cut. There are several important mechanics that were *clearly* designed with a lot more content in mind (the Labyrinth is the most blatant one, but *every* mechanic ends up feeling shallow because of this), and even the main storyline feels a bit short, with several major characters under-explored.So, whether I advise getting this game or not depends on your expectations.Are you expecting something as wide, deep and revolutionary as the first Torment game? You're going to be sorely disappointed. There *are* things in this game that wouldn't feel out of place in its predecessor, they're just too few.Are you just expecting a good small-ish RPG, with above-average writing and mechanics that at least don't get in the way of the story (looking at you, Pillars of Eternity, I love you but your battles are made of annoyance and boredom)? Then you might enjoy this.

content:
Posted: March 18
												A fantastically sculpted adventure.  Beautifully drawn landscapes are populated with interesting characters, and the world has a spectacular back-story.  Gameplay itself is fresh, and the story is not combat driven, although the player has many opportunities to engage in violence if it is sought.  Read the first page of the manual, then learn the rest through experience.It's an excellent game in the same vein as Planescape: Torment.  This is definitely worth playing, and inXile should be supported in their efforts to make great rpgs.  In all those millions of words, I didn't find a single typo.---Spoilers follow---The narrative is compelling at first, but falters after the first act, and the game is ultimately over just as my interest peaked.  Maybe I'm a jaded fogey, but I feel like the game needed two more acts, and several more hours of gameplay and interaction in order to bring the narrative to a satisfying close.  Overall, the story feels rushed.  Many revelations don't even have time to sink in before the player is forced to make game-ending decisions.  The big, scary antagonist's motives are never fully explained to my satisfaction (they are revealed in a database in a memory-- come on!), and the human antagonist's motivations are ultimately boring.I enjoyed the meres, but felt they needed more impact on long-term gameplay.  I like the memory referencing oolatek and the Heavy Metal movie!!!

content:
Posted: March 5
												I don't understand why the negative reviews about content and whatnot. This game is brilliantly written, engaging and a must have for any crpg fan, or any Torment fan. It's not PoE and it's not Planescape:Torment, which you can buy cheap on gog...It's a new game, full stop.inXile will listen to people's feedback and will surely adjust the game for quite some time. I've been having a blast and I'm pretty sure I've got quite a few surprises ahead of me. The combat is hard as hell, the lore is awesome and well, the game deserves a special praise from an old school gamer like me. Just make sure you read every review inXile, and make it shine even more. Not much I can add, people have talked about the graphics for instance (yes, they could be better inXile, more lively - the scenery I mean), just don't accept the red reviews as a reason for not playing the game. It's a masterpiece in its own right. Now patch it, make it even better.Edit after I finished the game:Too short I'd say, but wonderfully written, everything comes into place magnificiently. I would have enjoyed a way way bigger world to explore, more secondary quests and well, don't trust a lot of text makes a game longer. I'm an avid reader and I read stupidly fast. Even the characters emotions.I never got to savor my leveling up, which was a pity.I loved the fact I could avoid almost every fight (maybe this was the culprit for a fast gameplay).The ending is...interesting. I've got a save right before so...All in all, needs an expansion of sorts. Needs more places to see, more characters to interact with. Of course I didn't do all the sidequests, mainly the first ones (I was just too engaged to avoid leaving the place without a second thought).All in all, I loved every piece of it. Thank you inXile. Gief more.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17
												(Spoilers ahead!)TLDR: If you go into the game with no expectations, you'll probably like it on its own merits. If you were a Kickstarter backer that hung on to every update or someone who will compare it to their childhood memories of Planescape Torment, you probably won't like it.As a Kickstarter backer, I was really pleased with the end results. However, I also didn't keep up with the updates, and looking back at what was promised (and what was delivered) I can definitely understand why people feel frustrated with the game. One companion I was really looking forward to, the Toy, was cut out of the final release. The Ruins of Ossiphagan only appear in a flashback sequence that is entirely text. The "Labyrinth" is more of a two-bedroom house. I only ever opened 3 fathoms and they didn't introduce anything new upon revisiting (though maybe I just didn't explore enough).What I don't understand are the poor comparisons to PST. It's called a spiritual sequel so it makes sense to draw a comparison, but the things people claim PST did better are not really there at all. Nostalgia is a very powerful thing. Taking on some of the complaints I read in the other reviews:"The combat is bad. It's turn-based instead of real-time with pause."The combat IS bad. But so was the combat in PST. Can anyone actually say, with a straight face, that the *combat* was their favorite part of PST? I was constantly pausing in PST to micromanage anyways, it was hardly different from being turn-based. At least in TTON I eventually got enough armor and resistance to be able to take things on as a mage on my own; in the late game of PST I still died if anything so much as breathed on me."The characters/models are ugly and there's no romance options."There were also no romance options in PST. You could kiss Annah (and Ravel...) but that was about it. The PST characters/models were also pretty ugly and the portraits looked like weird claymation models at best."It's too short, and there's not enough exploration."Let's see, PST has Sigil, Undersigil, Curst, Hell, Sigil again, and the Fortress. TTON has Sagus Cliffs, the Labyrinth, Valley of Dead Heroes, Miel Avest, and the Bloom. Honestly do not see a difference in length/exploration here. Personally, I preferred exploring TTON due to the greater environmental variety--was there even grass in PST? Ever?"Too dialogue heavy, uninteresting writing compared to PST."I had to laugh at this one, since PST to me was entirely about the dialogue. In both games you can avoid this dialogue (if you want a bad time). I do feel like the writing is less compelling than in PST, but that's subjective. PST was more... visceral, and urgent. After getting attacked by shadows, finding Pharod became a huge priority. Whereas in TTON, it doesn't feel like you're in any immediate danger. Yes, the Sorrow is after you but it doesn't actually pose a threat until at least halfway through the game. I felt more like someone on vacation that thought it'd be fun to mess around with the locals.Now, to discuss the game on it's own:The setting is gorgeous. I loved the unexplained weirdness of the numenera, and how you'd come across ancient technology that people just shrugged off as everyday. The giant, immobile robots that have been in the same place for thousands of years and are the architects of the entire city? Yeah, that's just my factory boss. The cannibals that live underground? They're just creepy archivists, and sometimes they help the authorities solve crimes.All the companions are human, which is a shame when you live in a world with people from different planets and even different dimensions. None of them, except for Erritus and Callistege, have anything immediately eyecatching about their characters. But they eventually grew on me, through their interactions with you and each other. Take Aligern, for example. I thought he was a real buzzkill, and needlessly suspicious of Callistege. I only took him with me because I wanted to see the Cult of the Changing God first. But then I started calling myself the Changing God. Philosophically, I'm not entirely wrong (I have his body, his memories, and his experiences--I might as well have been the Changing God just with amnesia). And it was so fascinating to watch Aligern trying to decide whether or not I actually was the Changing God, and if he could still trust me if I was. THE Changing God, the one famed for being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and that he blames for the destruction of his village--is suddenly at his side and telling him that she will help in his search for answers. That's when I really started to feel for him, when I wanted the answers just as badly as he did. Rhin annoyed me at first because she had to go everywhere with me, and couldn't even be temporarily swapped out. This poor kid is getting mauled, shot at, burned, psychically punched, and more, and she still won't wait outside until I'm done with this fight. I had to take her into a hell dimension infested with insane murder cultists (Bad Parenting 101). But through it all she remained so, so sweet. She also gets better mechanically (as a healer and cypher user) and seeing her finally being useful in a fight made me feel like a proud parent.The game feels way too easy after the first 30 minutes. I rarely had trouble passing any ability checks, especially when I could just have a party member do it instead. By the midpoint of the game, the combination of my accumulated skills, bonuses, and edge made it so I could pass any intelligence check...without expending any effort. That feels like it should be a good thing, but it made the Bloom's challenges trivial. There's a portion of the game where you can get bonuses on checks if you convince your companions to go with you, and I didn't need to take any of them because my bonuses were already so high. I also had thousands of shins that went unspent--you can only buy armor for yourself and upgrade your companions gear once for less than 100 shins.They took an interesting direction by trying to replace mundane dungeon junk with unique items classified as "Oddities". I definitely feel like that design choice added to the mystique of the game world, but I'm not sure if it worked entirely because some of the descriptions had me wanting to hold on to everything just in case it would be useful.I will admit that combat felt more fun in the end game, after I had enough stats and equipment to be able to do what I wanted. Wiping out 4 murdens at once with a powered up Flash was nice. There's just something about it that feels very clunky. Maybe it's the character animations, maybe it's the slight delay after selecting an action, I don't know. I dislike that you can't buff NPC's that are helping you out (aren't they also allies?) and in the early game it feels almost impossible to hit anything without spending all your effort on a single attack. I rarely ever used cyphers--in the early game you're low on shins, and in the late game you can one-shot a lot of things as a nano. The Tide system is an interesting take on morality meters. Apparently it only affects the game in very subtle ways, so I never really noticed if it had any affect on the game world. Honestly, I'm fine with that. I liked it because I could treat it like a Myers-Briggs type of personality quiz. I still feel like the game is very skewed towards Blue though, especially if you want to piece together what's going on. I tried my best to follow my Idealist path, but in the end there were just so many more opportunities to gain Blue Tide affinity.On a final note, although inExile is getting some heat from unfulfilled promises, it really felt like they were listening to their backers during development and trying to incorporate their ideas. It might be just a coincidence, but most of the issues I raised when reviewing the beta were addressed in the final version. Nice!

												Excellent old school RPG. However a bit too much reading for my taste, but I still played it to the end. Because the world is so interesting and different. But that is probably not realistic concidering how massive the script it is. Would have liked a little more character progression, revisiting old areas and more "filler" combat stuff to balance out all the reading. After the bloom, it felt like an act was missing, because the ending seemed somehow rushed.  I rate it 7,8/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16
												What can change the reception of a game?In my mind the game here falls short of its predecessor. That is not to say it is unworthy of your time, which is why it gets a thumbs up. Merely that it does not reach the heights of PS:T. The writing is quite good, but weirdly truncated and towards the end it certainly feels like the narrative was abruptly cut-off. No doubt victim to real life realities of a project for which we can only speculate the reasons. Its ending is perfunctory and cauterised and all the elements which were being woven together abruptly resolve. Surely another longer closing act was needed to bed down all the story elements and really deliver the pay-off it had been building.On the writing as well, I believe the story seemed to suffer from the "mystery" of the setting. With a sort of pick and mix approach to differing magics and technology. There was no consistency or explanation of much of anything. Everything you come across is a new and wonderous technology from a far-forgotten age. All of them apparently from different ones. Which in some ways begins to dampen your excitement as you realise you will never be able to put any sort of coherent lore in your head. Whilst i understand that this is the whole point of the setting, I think that it could have been reduced somewhat by the writers if they thoughIt's full screen narrative sections are beautiful and feel wondrous, Giving the sensation of being a handcrafted tabletop experience and the outcomes of which certainly seemed to have quite a bit of depth (Though minimal impact outside of them usually)The companions, whilst interesting also seem to lack any real input on alot of what's going on. Only ever interjecting (from memory) on main plot moments or there own set PLOT MOMENTS. Whilst I did develop a soft spot for them, i felt there was little opportunity to demonstrate it. The opening section of the game sets up the idea that your companions will have disagreements and there will be consequences and though notably all of the banter in the game is usually the companions sniping at each other (very little friendliness), there is rarely an opportunity to interject or any real consequences for the group dynamic. Finally, the inventory items were a great opportunity that seemd to fall flat. You get all these marvellous oddities which just scream to be used in quests or interactions but never have the opportunity to do so. I kept most of my items in order to find if any items could be used in obscure ways. But I was only ever able to do so on one occassion where I didn't pick the item up right next to its point of use. - For a game with a supposed emphasis on reactivity and conversations , I feel like this would have been an excellent opportunity to reward players who kept certain items because they liked them, because as I said all the items seem cool and interesting and are just BEGGING to be used. Of course this sort of reactivity takes time and as I said earlier it does seem like they ran out of it on even finishing the main storyline.A flawed game but an interesting one. If there is anything I have learned in my gaming across the platforms, it is that many things can change the calibre of a game.
