content:
Posted: February 28
												There's a lot to live up to when claiming to be the successor to Planescape: Torment. TTON suffers from a weak first half that's plagued by an excessive amount of descriptive text and dialogue for unimportant players in the story. I recall sighing whenever I laid eyes on yet another named NPC and wondered if the first interaction would contain 4 sentences of descriptive text, to 1 of actual dialogue. Aside from the nauseating verbage, there simply aren't enough quests that take advantage of the society and culture presented to the player. The Levy quest is a great example of a quest that reinforces the setting, yet very few quests do so. Thankfully, The Bloom's content is much better than that of Sagus Cliff's. The most controversial subject to consider when appraising this title is holding against the promises Inxile made during their kickstarter. Clearly, they bit off more than they could chew: numerous companions were cut, an entire major city hub was cut, and the factions are questionalby bareboned. Comat: typically a shallow affair that boils down to spamming your one-time-use cyphers against your stronger foes. climactic battles are particularly poor due to how long it takes the AI to complete its turnsUI: it's a shame you can't modify the interface at all, given how much Inexile touted its inclusion in Wasteland 2. the icons for the menus are obtrusive and get in the way of looking at the world. one pet peeve I had was when completing checks, even if you had a 100 percent chance of success, the game pauses for dramatic effect, EVERY TIME. it was cool the first hour, when you're getting your bearings, but after that it's just obnoxiousSound: there's a severe lack of environmental sounds, particularly in Sagus Cliffs. A lot of effort went into the Bloom's soundscape, which makes me believe the project was mismanaged. Voice Acting is also an issue, particularly because there's so little and yet some of it is pretty bad (e.g. Alligern). It's pretty baffling how they didn't include VO for the main players of the narrative, especially considering that the game opens with a voiced narrator that never chimes in again.TLDR: Should you check this out? Yeah. Some companions, the music, and The Bloom alone, make this worth a playthrough.  TTON complements Mask of the Betrayer nicely as titles that aim to scratch the Torment itch. Its legacy, however, will be that of a title that was sold on lofty promises that were ultimately too much to adhere to. What we have is a solid title that raises more questions about its development than its own narrative.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												This "spiritual successor" to the RPG legend PlaneScape: Torment does its best to mimick its predecessor, but falls ever so short on a few important facets. Me saying this might be a bit hypocritical though, as I did not play PS:T back in the day, but I know of its premise and characters. As a huge fan of recent proper RPG game renessance had to give it a go.Playing TToN is like reading a novel most of the time, with some added loot management and interactive choices (and few consequences) added as a bonus. Now I'm into reading even huge♥♥♥♥♥long book series, so in that sense the game was not off-putting in itself, but while TToN has lots to say, it does not always just feel quite alive. Its a longish game (clocked 51h) if you wade thru all the million point two words it has. Some parts of the storytelling is very interesting, some parts just feel its extra filling, lets say like fetch quests on some open world game!The companions and NPCs are not often super interesting, and their interactions with you feel lacking. The "crisis" combat sections - around 15 fights in the whole game - are mostly cool, but too easy at least after the first few, and as an INT character its trivial to power thru all the discussion choices to get "best results" without fighting.The game's systems feel a bit too simplified for yours truly's tastes. I hear many companions, a big city hub and things like crafting got dropped. The first area is superb (and takes 20h!), the ones after are tad 'meh'. I'd like TToN to have more voice acting, now its just first sentence of some important plot related discussions. There are also some technical issues and bugs; long discussions start to lag more and more, combat can get stuck (game breaking) and so forth. If there will be a Special Edition like Pillars and Divinity:Original Sin had, I could give it another go. It's not a bad game in any sense, but not a masterpiece either.7/10

content:
Posted: January 16
Early Access Review
								As a backer for this when it was announced I had decided to check in on the game to really get a feel for it and see if I was a fool for backing it or not. Long story short, I am very happy with this game and what I have played. I have played almost 10 hours the past few days, sending in bug reports as appropriate (ran into one major one that blocked continuation/completion of a major quest and a minor issue with character creation not showing the correct Health value during creation, though it did show the correct value once you left character creation.) but overall the game is in good shape.This game more than any other really feels like playing a tabletop RPG. There is a ton of options for making decisions (including ones that will outright kill you such as diving in the initial sequence) and ways for your character's unique traits to really shine and affect gameplay in meaningful ways. The Tides system is also very clearly setting itself up to be the most interesting morality system ever put into game form. It really feels like I am making a unique person with unique views as I play and the system does a great job of distilling your character's motivations and thoughts into a tide.Combat in the game is fairly basic and straight-forward. It too feels like a true representation of a Tabletop Rpg combat system. But what makes Combat great is that it is almost never the only option available to you, and indeed it is often the least interesting.Overall, I am very excited for this game and cannot wait to play its complete form!

												I backed the game when it came out.  Didn't really follow the development too closely, so was unaware of all the "cut content".  Did a 22 episode let's play of the beta a year or so ago - 


YouTube™ Video: Torment: Tides of Numenera pt. 1 

			Views: 2,926		

			Beta, part 1 Game played @ 2560x1600 resolution, 2x AA		

I've played Planescape: Torment a couple times and am familiar with how it feels.  This game captures that perfectly, imo.  The plot is awesome and original, the turn-based crises are cool to me, the setting is weird as hell, and I like the companions I'm using in my playthrough.  The meres, or choose-your-own-adventure illustrated story segments, are amazing.  This is an excellently-written book that you can play.  That appeals to you, or it doesn't.  I love it.   Great job, inXile!

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												Finished game. Took my time. Did side quests. Pleasurable. But also, some negatives.Game feels short. A few acts short. Sagus, intermission, Bloom, and final act. Feels like there should be 2-3 more steps on the way there somewhere. Game is nowhere near as long as old torment, or icewind dale, or baldurgs gate. Storyline is fairly predictable, once you hit mid-game you can see where its going. A few twists but nothing mind-blowing.Another gripe, is bland companions. None of them were honestly interesting. Just...people, with their own problems and a short quest to solve it. Few paragraphs of text allocated to their background and quest. Meh. Now old torment, THAT had memorable companions. Floating skull, fallen angel, suit of armor, that githyanki or whatever... Those were interesting. Numenera companions, by comparison....bland. less then bland even. I finished game with half companion slots empty, because I could not care less - and because i did not need their abilities truth be told.Gameplay - you can talk your way past every single fight - this is not always interesting, like cheating. Also, once you get a full level and some mid-level gear, you can steamroll the NPCs - combat is unbalanced a bit, either its too hard, or becomes too easy. By end game you can become literally unkillable - you regenerate HP faster then you take damage, with certain gear and skills. Oh and you get a nice sword that bypasses all armor and resistances. Unbalanced.But main gripe is that skill checks are incredibly easy. You literally CANT fail past a certain point, and that point is a third of the game in. Game gives you all these various proficiencies, like lore-mechanical, or weapons, but, honestly, you dont need most of them, skill checks are that easy. overall, its a nice game. Worth a playthough. But nothing spectacular.

content:
Posted: March 11
												It's not really boring to play, but not great either, and many occasion to get frustrated.The huge problem of the game is the project rushed the phase where gameplay mechanics are tuned, polished, balanced. The result is the game get released with zero gameplay mechanics working, incredible. Let see the details:- Tides, the idea is good, to play a small game of roleplay. In chapter 1 there's some coherency, more or less. After that it's just broken, all logic is changed or weird and half broken, the result is a big fail.- Combats, it's not because the game allows skip most combats that they deserve not have any difficulty design, and I'll ignore the too frequent lack of design of each combat. Huge fail.- Skills check, it's just a joke, the system is just broken. A part of the problem is coming from allowing free rests, awful idea. But the core of the problem is just before half of game you'll end succeed any. That means that this is a fake gameplay mechanism.- Cyphers, one more pointless illusion because it's a fake gameplay mechanism. There's no point to use them, in that context, they end be just lost of time.- Character building, you'll reach max level long before end of game, that's ridiculous, it should have been polished a bit to avoid that.- Character building, with all gameplay mechanics not working, it ends be broken too, not a surprise. The problem is this contributes to build the feeling of a fake game.- Companions relationship, i ended have them loving me, but I'm still wondering what gameplay it involved, it felt so empty. Gameplay requires provide feedback to players otherwise it's pointless blinded walk.- Find items and inter-actable stuff, there's obviously zero thought about this gameplay element, it's either move the mouse everywhere in a tedious scanning, either use highlight key and use a kiddish picking.- Frankly i'm bored do this list, just pick any gameplay mechanics and it's broken. The only exception is some puzzling badly designed.Another very damaging error is the vanishing of main plot. Seriously find a piece to repair an item, that's the plot? What a failure in whole chapter 1 and chapter 2, then finally there's a vague main plot progression. I understand the game goal wasn't to make a RPG story guided, but that's going much further than that, it's the pure lack of plot building through most parts of the game.Current state of the game is a huge amount of wasted element, just because dev resigned and gave up tune any gameplay mechanics, lame.Save your money, buy anything else instead.

								I had high hopes for the game but as it stands I cannot suggest anyone buy this; not for full price at least.  To begin with there are some massive, game-breaking bugs....can no longer save my game, followers stopped following then when I finally manage to zone they are there following but i have to click about 50 times to get an action to work, opening a box for loot, click the transition icon to go to new zone....none of that is working properly now.The game itself, combat was made to be pointless in that there is no xp at all for it, no loot at all for it....its just something thats in the way of progressing and it makes for boring combat..  The Tide system I absolutely do not like, its basically that every char will have 3 mana pools (called might, speed, and intellect I believe)...everything you di uses these up; making a dungeon really suck as you can end up unable to even melee.  Just horrible bugs and bad design.

number of helpful: 21 of 44 people (48%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 28
Worst game start ever ...First you fall down from the sky, only accompanied by a wall of text. Not even a few pictures. Not even a single picture of a sky! Nothing. Just (spoken) text. And more text.Then you are trapped in a tiny room that looks a bit like the Geth server from Mass Effect. There you begin to play Zork, the text-only adventure. I am not kidding. If you read all the blurb and pretend that it matters, you will most likely play Zork for a full hour. Of course it doesen't matter, because once you leave the room, you can create your character from scratch.I have nothing against walls of text in good games. PST is one of my all-time favorites, but this is just stupid. The start felt like the entire artwork has been cut out of the game, just to meet a deadline, although I know that's not the case. Its just a royally stupid design. Its supposed to be an immersive way for you to pick your character class, but giving you the same three options (brawny/tanky, deceitful, intelligent) leading to the holy trinity is nothing but embarrassing.The first combat ("crisis") that's forced on you will give any XCOM2 player horrible flashbacks of how the camera jumps arround ... "Look here!" "Now look here!" "Omg you got to see this!" "Oh and don't miss this!" "Hey, over here♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥" ... because all players are idiots and must be pointed at everything with blunt force, even if the entire scene fits comfortably on your monitor.Once you've survived that atrocious beginning, it gets a bit better. You meet the first two (interesting) companions and learn a bit about yourself, but the game keeps bombarding you with walls of text that mostly don't matter at all. It doesen't even give you the chance to get attuned to the world by discovering stuff yourself. It just dumps it on you, bookshelf-sized. Either soldier through or get the hell out.Torment also prides itself with its unique "combat" and the fact, that you can avoid most of it by talking or using items. That part is true, but the most important reason to avoid combat is that its unbelievably anticlimatic. I'm generally not a fan of turn-based combat with character chains, but Torment manages to crank up the chore by adding extra "mana"-pools for every action you take. It feels completly pointless, like an arbitrary hoop the game forces you to jump through just so that you'll think twice before trying to kill something or use one of your skills with an acceptable RNG. Not to mention that once you are out of "intellect", you are a dumb ox and couldn't convince a child to have free candy. Once you are out of "speed", you are apparently moving in slow-motion, and couldn't dodge your mom's frying pan.Immersion? Lost.Edit: I read a few other reviews explaining the tabletop rules this weird mana-system comes from. Apparently, in the tabletop version there are no HP. Mental attacks hit Intelligence, hamstrings hurt Speed, slashes hurt Might. The more manabars are empty, the more crippled you become, until you die when all three are gone. It still sounds a little weird, but makes more sense than the "Let's please everyone (aka noone)"-approach TToN uses.The entire "crisis" thing should have remained a crazy idea on the design table and never made it into the actual game. The combat is super slow, makes the camera jump arround from character to character like crazy, and the outcome is always the same as in every other CRPG before. You either talk your way through, press a button to deal with your enemies, or loot their corpses at the end. Nothing new here, just wrapped into an extremly tedious new package. And, as always, fighting your way through the world yields much better rewards and more XP.Combat in Torment is about the absolute worst of CRPG combat I have ever seen, from The Black Eye to Pillars of Eternity. Not because of the alternatives it offers. I like that part, but because of how the combat is done gameplay-wise (cumbersome UI, camera hopping, overly simplistic 1-move/1-attack, three types of mana) and how few incentives the player is given to actually do something other than killing everything.I will continue to play this game and see how far they drive this weirdness. The companions and the overall story is interesting and reminds the player a lot of Planescape Torment. Reviews say it gets better later on, and I sure hope so. Steam asks if I recommend it, and honestly I have to say, I wouldn't know a single friend whom I could recommend Torment to.If I was asked to recommend an oldschool RPG, I would point towards Tyranny, which had my attention from minute #1. Four hours into Torment and I still have to force myself to keep playing.P.S.: No Morte = no successor to PST, spiritual or not. The game world wins the prize of extra-crazyness, but its not Planescape. I hear they cut Morte, aka Oom, out of the game during development. Probably done by the same guy who designed that first room.Overall, this game would have been much better as a book, because the story is interesting, but the actual gameplay is atrocious.Edit: Now that I've played it for quite a while, I have to say the companions aren't as fun as they first seemed to be. Aside from that bickering contest at the beginning, only the child has anything to say during the game. There is like no party banter whatsover.God... I miss Morte hitting on Annah and Fall-from-Grace ...

number of helpful: 11 of 24 people (46%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 7
												So far it is not a classic CRPG. What a relief! (and I do love classic CRPG's)If you want to play a classic CRPG, play a classic CRPG.Why would you want a copy of the past, when you still have acces to it?This game is rather an interactive visual novel, with RPG elements.Amazingly well written one, that will immerse you and kill your social life.Don't try to find something else in it, because you will probably fail.Don't compare it to Pillars of Eternity - it is a completely different game.Don't compare it to Planescape Torment - it is a completely different game.It is not another the-same-game-but-different, nor an 18 year delayed DLC.You do not waste dozens of hours in generic dungeons?You do not waste dozens of hours fighting every little insect pack?You do not waste dozens of hours in overcomplicated skill tree?Hmm... that is probably why the game seems to short for some...Or it is because they try to play it like they play all other CRPG's -- by "skipping all the boring text to quickly get to fight monsters".Prepare yourself to reading a good book. Approach this game with love for the past of CRPG gaming, but without any fear of experimentation (well, it is a game about future), and you will be rewarded. If you fall in a trap of exaggerated and distorted attachment to tradition, you will...fall in a trap :) I mean, I do understand all the nostalgia, but you can have it and still appreciate choices they made with this game. You just need to accept, that inXile took the risk of taking something "old" and loved, and making something new and different to it, while still maintaining all the neuralgic elements. They was creative instead copy&pasting. Not surprising, now they have to swim through all that hate they get from conservative gamers.So if you are not a conservative gamer, do not listen to conservative-negative reviews. And if you ARE a conservative gamer, please do not buy this game. You will most certainly be dissapointed, and as a result you will write another negative review, which may lead to someone not buying the game...Someone, who would have loved it, but will be frighten away by you.(I'm 34 yrs old so this is not kindergarten vs grandpas kind of opinion)Ultra subjective last sentence: People are different, and I'm a more of a Fallout2 guy instead of Baldur's Gate guy so I actually love that the game has turn-base mechanics in battles instead of real-time-with-pause, but what's even better for me, that it actually doesn't matter at all, because I play as a pacifist and try to avoid every fight, and this game is one of the few that truly allows it. Thank you ineXile.

												*Introduces one of the wildest, most creative settings in recent memory, filled with insane possibilities and prospects.*As the hours go by, a sense of incompleteness slowly begins to pull you away from TToN’s immersion.*While the foundation for an interesting system was indeed laid, it’s like it was left unfinished, sadly not reaching its full potential*Takes us back to the old Baldur’s Age technique of marvelous paintings that are meticulously drawn, but are sadly void of life.*Depending on your playstyle, you should estimate that about 70-80 per cent of the content is spent in dialogue trees, reading.*Not a combat-based game, but a series of dialogue-checks that after you expand the basic Might/Speed/Intelligence pools, are not even that challenging.*Despite the shortcomings it’s very easy to fall in love with TToN’s setting and its enthralling penmanship.*It’s sad to see a very passionate community of gamers being divided and polarized. Maybe expectations were set too high, maybe there’s a lesson for all of us in this bizarre tale.*Definitely a niche game, Torment: Tides of Numenera is under no circumstances easy to recommend to an impatient low/med level gamer http://www.dsogaming.com/special/reviews/dsogaming-torment-tides-of-numenera-review/

								This is a comeback of the best RPG ever Planescape Torment by its original creators. It does not happens in Sigil and has different story line and universe history, but it is as great for story lines, questions that it raises, complicated answers that you will choose. So save a lot.

content:
Posted: April 15
												Well worth the money if you like old-style RPGs and pulp sci-fi novels. If you're some kind of game-mechanics-production connoisseur, then maybe it ain't. I'm the first sort.Upsides: I liked the story and the idea of the main character, and how the character interacts with the game world, lots of interesting ideas and thoughtful psychology. The writers are obviously fascinated with objects and artifacts and how we interact with them; everything you interact with is described in Proustian detail, it's great fun if you like to read (if you don't, it's probably infuriating). The world was strange and intriguing, enough to make you wish there were more of it. And little to no fighting! Which, as a contrast to something like Pillars of Eternity (also great but in a different way), was refreshing.Downsides: The scale was smaller than I expected, and it ended strangely, abruptly (though one could argue the real story had ended already a few minutes before the "game" ending). The companions (except for Rhin and Matkina) were pretty dull, I'm thinking that next time through I'll try just not having any at all, see how that feels... Kind of a low-budget feel overall, but still a top-notch story and main character.

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1
												I backed this game on Kickstarter, so it's been a couple years coming. Unfortunately the finished product isn't anything more than an excellent argument for why crowdsourced games can be a bad idea.This game doesn't stand on its own merits and, really, was never intended to. From the beginning it was pitched as a spiritual successor to Planescape: Torment, which was a well-written novel expressed through a bad (by today's standards) game engine. Much of the appeal of PS:T came from exploring the incredibly cool and weird D&D setting of Planescape where it all went down, and the equally cool and weird setting of Numenera is a good fit for an unofficial sequel. So that's all well and good. The other main part of PS:T's greatness was its cast of characters.Tides does an uneven job of bringing the Numenera setting to the computer screen. There's a lot of awkward callbacks to Planescape that feel fairly out of place in the Ninth World, like the "Endless War" made up for Tides for no apparent reason other than because Planescape: Torment featured the Blood War, but that can probably get away with being called fanservice. The deliberate references and callbacks to Planescape: Torment make this game weaker, but they're obligatory since the only reason anyone funded this project was out of nostalgia.The developers clearly lacked a strong understanding of how Numenera plays, or at least were shaky on how to best translate the feel of the tabletop into video game form. Cyphers, which are supposed to be the star of the setting, are reduced to a series of bland grenades and healing potions that are just sold by vendors on the street. Since the game actively punishes getting into fights, both because enemies tend to be stronger and more numerous than you and because the "Crisis" combat system is tedious and awful, the vast majority of items and abilities are useless garbage which you nevertheless must manage at least a little because they kept the Cypher Sickness mechanic.It's difficult for me to find things worth writing about this game. Wherever there are game mechanics you're much better off avoiding them--fighting is boring at best, frustratingly unfair at worst. Approaching the game as a piece of interactive fiction, something has to be said about the Tides: they're a really bizarre morality concept which the game makes a big deal about but which are way too vague and unintuitive to actually become meaningful. Basically, depending on your words and actions your levels in the five Tides go up and down. There is text to indicate what the Tides are supposed to be about but there's a complete disconnect between your choices and the fluctuations of the Tides. If you're compassionate it's a toss-up between Gold and Indigo, if you're brash it's a toss-up between Red and Silver. Oftentimes they'll mix and on rare oddball occasions you'll lose out on Tides, even though most of the time even if you go completely against what a particular Tide is supposed to be about it doesn't drop. You're likely to gain a lot of Blue just because they hand out Blue for exhausting dialogue options and asking a lot of questions--which is standard operating procedure for these games so that you don't miss out on content. I have no idea what the point is. The Last Castoff is an aggressively blank brick of a character and most of your dialogue is gormlessly asking questions and whining that you have no idea what is going on. It's a pretty big letdown compared to the Nameless One from Planescape, or the main characters of the Dragon Age series, or the Exile from Knights of the Old Republic II. Even the utterly generic PCs of Icewind Dale II had more character, and they were solely defined by their class, alignment, and who was speaking to the NPCs at the time.Since the main character is a blank slate, it falls to the NPC companions to carry the weight of the storytelling, which they don't. This is an area where the developers constantly inviting comparisons to Planescape: Torment hurts them hardest. The party members here aren't exactly on the level of Dak'kon or Fall-From-Grace or Morte. Most have no compelling connection or tie to the Last Castoff, which already is a problem, and they don't really do much to endear themselves to the player either. The developers chose to make them all very optional, which also means that they can't develop as a team, as was done in Dragon Age or KotOR. They feel like hirelings with short stories attached that they can spew out if you bother to ask them.Look, if you really want Planescape: Torment, just (re)play that game. Tides is boring. Tides is awkward. It very painfully wants to be something that it very clearly lacks the creativity to be. There's lots of little design decisions that add up to big frustrations and immersion-breaking laughs at just how pretentious and absurd this game can be. For example: the lengthy sidequest where if you rest an arbitrary number of times the quest-giver literally falls off a cliff off-screen for no reason. Or how about the numerous (optional, to be fair(?)) fights where if you do choose to [Attack] your enemies all get to go first, with no possibility of you getting the drop on them (of course you can't position your party or do anything to prepare before the fight, I guess because someone decided that would make it too easy). This is a pretty bad RPG by today's standards (even PS:T handled combat better), and it's not great interactive fiction either.

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 5
												Torment:ToN currently holds a score of 84 on Steam, which is why I'm writing this review.That's far too low.The reasons for this title to have a score lower than approx. 92 (which is about what I'd give it) are as follows:Torment:ToN was not designed to appeal to mainstream gamers. It was Kickstarted by people for whom the original Planescape:Torment was one of the best gaming experiences they'd ever had. People buying it on Steam without having had experience with PC games from the 1990s are unlikely to get something they expect.Torment:ToN won't be playable for people who don't read much, or who read slowly, or who need plenty of hand-holding to figure out what to do. It's true the game has a fantastic journal which notes new information for you and keeps track of what you're working on, but players who grew up with the flashing 'X' on their mini-map and an arrow pointing in the direction of the goal are likely to get overwhelmed.Game critics have called the Crisis combat system poor -- I don't understand this, personally. I enjoy the combat system enough to want to see it return in other games. It's streamlined, sensible, and challenging when it should be.Other critics have said the game should have been longer. I'm just out of the first area and I'm already planning my second playthrough. I expect to get many hours of gameplay out of Torment.Note also that this game is not priced at triple-A cost. It's about forty dollars now and I've already got sixty hours of gameplay on it.People say the character models are wonky. I don't understand what people want. I think the graphics are beautiful.In my opinion, the majority of people giving Torment a thumbs-down *must* be the sorts of players for whom it was never intended: children, poor readers, gamers who don't like an intellectual challenge, gamers who depend on iMac-easy tutorials, gamers who need to be told exactly where to go...I think this paints a pretty clear picture.If you love great interactive fiction and the ability to twist your story 1,000 ways, stunningly creative settings, and truly inventive puzzles, this is a game you're going to like.If you're really, really into first-person shooters, you should probably move along.Bravo, InExile. This is easily your best work of art to date.Last note: there are many scorching, damning reviews on T:ToN. Most (all that I've seen) are by players with as few as five or as many as thirty hours in. As I wrote, I have sixty hours and just left the first area. Subtracting a few hours for when I left it paused, let's assume I spent thirty-five hours on that beginning section. What this means is either I'm a terrible reader, or these negative reviewers aren't playing/reading much of the game. Often these bad reviews mention that the game is boring to them. Clearly, if you skim through a book, it's going to be boring. By all means, take bad reviews into account, but note the played hours, too. It's simply not possible to *get* Torment without putting in time.

content:
Posted: March 4
												Overall...I have to say I'm very disappointed. Numenera is definitely not the game it was promised to be.The Good:Music and sounds - Weird, bizzare and mysterious, just like the 9th World itself.Location design - Incredible, weird, curious, mysterious, "numenerish".The Bad:Main Plot - "What does one life matter?", in the end the game doesn't really answer that question.Side quests - They are just there, forgettable and in the end it's all about the % roll on persuasion.Linear Structure - There is no open world. Game is divided on hubs, every hub has a few locations to visit, but at one point you'll be asked "Are you sure you want to continue?", and then every single quest from that hub will become "Failed", there is no going back.Compaions - VERY boring, uninspired, weak compared to the Main Hero, small choice to begin with and the most interesting one (The Toy) was cut out of the final version of the game. They don't have very interesting backgrounds and sometimes simply join you "just because". They don't have much to say, and when they finally say something it's not very interesting.Skills and Spells - Not much to choose from, very boring and bare-bones compared to the "Corebook Numenera" skills.Turn-based Combat - Sluggish, boring, completely NON-tactical. It was a huge mistake to make a pool on Kickstarter asking if people want turn-based or real-time. It was a bad choice, real-time would be much more tactical and interesting.False-advertisement Polish Dubbing - People were promised to hear the legends of the polish RPG dubbing, and we hear them indeed, for about 3 minutes. And that's it. Read the rest of it.In the end I'd say there are way better cRPGs out there. Numenera sadly feels solid only in some aspects but very weak in the others (more important ones). cRPGs should be all about you, your companions, relationships, friendships and adventures together. About tactical combat and overcoming the odds with clever use of your skills. Dialogues with your companions should make you feel something (like in Baldur's Gate where you could be betrayed in the most important moment as well as fall in love in someone who was near-irredeemable evil and change their heart).5/10, very expensive, very lacking in the core aspects of cRPGs, painfully boring combat, good soundtrack with emotional music but nowhere near as many emotions were put into the dialogues.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26
												As someone who's played Planescape: Torment many times over the years, I've been excited about this game since I first heard about it.  In general, I can recommend it on its own terms, and I think that, for the most part, though it does not quite live up to its ancestor's greatness, it does solidly fulfill expectations of existing PS:T fans.Pros:- The degree to which the Ninth World and its denizens are fleshed out and given life is marvelous.  The writing is mostly very good, and occasionally even better than that.  Some of the descriptions manage to find novel ways of conveying impressions and events, which reflects not only on the skill of the writing team but their dedication, in whole or in part, to truly evoking the gameworld.- Several of the companions are highly memorable.  I've only done one playthrough so far, so I haven't been able to fully explore all of the companion interactions (I only used 4 of the 6 extensively).- The visuals are great.  The backgrounds are static and pre-drawn, but the detail, variety and outright strangeness on display bring a heavy dose of the weird to the proceedings.  In many ways, graphics such as these, done right, are more evocative, more creative and more detailed than ultra-realistic, 3D graphics.- Lots of quests, some big, some quite small.  All of them display an attention to detail and self-contained emotional impact that makes them worth completing.  The general story and arc of the game is also compelling and evokes many of the same issues and tropes that made its antecedent so wonderful.- The game system is easy to learn, flexible and, unusually for an RPG, gave me no headaches with regard to the UI or its implementation.- The music is mostly electronic and ambient in nature, but does an excellent job of setting the mood in the various locations in which you find yourself throughout the game.Cons:- I didn't run into a ridiculous amount of bugs, but I did experience crashes every so often; 6 or 7 times if I'm remembering correctly.  All required a forced closure and restart of the game.  Most of the crashes happened only shortly after I'd saved, but a couple happened several minutes into extended combat/crisis situations, resulting in my having to replay a fair bit of dialogue and fighting/evasion afterward.  It's not gamebreaking, but its definitely frustrating.- The game is, as RPS noted, slightly artificial in its feel.  It was definitely designed with a specific audience in mind, and while this can lend a game focus, it also constrains the margins and limits of what the game will or will not be.  PS: T felt organic - Black Isle made the game they wanted to make, and they hoped there would be an audience for it.  This game feels a bit more like a product crafted to meet demand.  As such it doesn't leap out at you with new and fresh insights and experiences the way its predecessor did.- The story while multi-threaded and satisfying, is still essentially about how you try to defeat the menacing bad guy.  This makes it feel a bit more traditional than PS:T.  Likewise, much of the mystery lies in determining the motivations of others, rather than in self-discovery.  - Not enough combat.  And before you say, "But it's not about mindless fights!  And neither was PS:T!", I'l go ahead and make clear that I know that.  But where PS:T was ~65% story, 35% fighting, T:ToN is, if you avoid unnecessary violence, 85% combat free.  These are rough %, but the point is the same.  I'm glad it focuses on story, interactions, quests, puzzles, etc.  But the game plays this virtue almost to a fault.  I had so many cyphers and awesome weapons and armor, and only got sparing use out of it.  It is possible to play a bloodier playstyle, but it still doesn't seem that it would shift the ratio that dramatically.- Too easy.  Once your main character has enough edge and stat pool boosts, you're basically going to succeed at almost eveyrthing.  Since your companions can also use their stats to help, by the time you're 40% through with the game, or so, barring failure to rest or bring refresh items with you, you're not going to fail many, if any, skill checks.  It's a testament to the story, world and lore that despite this the game remains compelling, but some additional difficulty would have been nice.Conclusion:In a game like this, story and characters are king, so those elements win out over concerns about difficulty and lack of combat.  That said, you can't just ignore the flaws.  There are some things that may turn some folks off and, potentially because it tries so consciously to ape its forebear, it falls short of the greatness of PS:T.  That said, after completing it today, I felt that pang of regret and sadness at knowing the journey was over, the one you feel when you finish a particularly great book or game, and I'm already thinking over when I'll play through it again.  I think T:ToN is a very good to great game that falls short of true excellence, and would recommend it to those who loved PS:T (despite the noted differences), and those who love CRPGs in general, especially if story is of critical importance.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												An outstanding achievement, especially considering it was built within the framework of a crowdfunding budget. It is a worthy follow-up to Planescape: Torment both in terms of its writing and how it tackles themes of identity within a truly atypical landscape. Despite some of the familiar-looking fantasy trappings of some locations, Torment: Tides of Numemera constantly serves up reminders that you are not in Fantasy 101 Kansas anymore. Tides of Numenera, like its predecessor, plants both feed firmly on the narrative side of the fence. Combats and dungeon crawls are of secondary concern. If you aren't fully prepared to engage with the narrative and the world-building, then this is not the game for you. If you love a good story-driven RPG, though, or if the narrative was always your favorite part of the Infinity Engine era and its successors like Pillars of Eternity and Tyranny, then take the plunge into the world of Torment: Tides of Numerea.

												Not a traditional RPG but that's what I like about it. It's more about the journey, the choices and the story. There isn't a lot of battling (and that does tend to be somewhat slow) and I'm ok with that. I find that the people who are nay-saying this game are mostly upset they aren't killing more things.  The game is also very weird and wonderfully strange and I like that a great deal. It's unlike any other type of game in that regard, pulled from the depths of imagination. It's a very very different world, this one.

content:
Posted: March 21
												This is an old-school RPG with all of the pros of 90s gaming - high on ideas and low on fluff.Some of the complaints here are totally unjustified, money-driven and give you a huge sense of how entitled gamers have become. For the record, Planescape: Torment was also 40 Euros/Pounds/Dollars back in the '90s. Torment: Tides of Numenera is an immersive experience that expands your mind, confronts you with hundreds of philosophical questions and makes you look at morality in a completely different way. InXile should be applauded because this is the first RPG I actually could stomach for a long time. There have been a lot of saccharine, stupid games in the genre over the last 15 years and the imagination that went into this game is a feat in itself. If you want epilepsy inducing 4k graphics, non-stop killing and brainless clicking, look elsewhere. This is a game that demands your absolute attention, logic and abstract imagination. Torment: Tides of Numenera has the same undeniable quality, weirdness and presence that PS:T had... except it's not Planescape, the combat is turn-based and it's a bit short.  Pros:- Some of the best game writing in a long time.- You can think or talk your way out of any situation.- The Crisis system is an inventive take on turn-based combat.- The graphics are a great nod to the original Torment.- Excellent soundtrack. Dark, atmospheric, ambient. - The meres: mini-stories that allow you to influence the game.- Forces you to think critically.- Numenera's Tides System is a new take on morality - all of it is relative.- Beautiful, weird and downright disgusting locations.- The visuals and animation breathe new life into the isometric RPG format.- Items can help or harm you and all of them are odd.- The sheer number of options and outcomes make it very replayable.- Totally alien and dystopian: free of shouty 21st century politics.(potential) Cons:- Shorter than expected. - No faction system.- Very text heavy. If you don't like reading, don't buy it.- Not for zombies. Requires imagination. - There are some minor bugs in the current version.- Some very blatant re-hashes of the original Torment.- Small choice of characters.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16
												I feel like this game is getting mixed reviews because people are holding it up to Planescape: Torment. This is not that game, by far. Planescape was a masterwork, to be sure. This title stands on its own, with it's own flavor. The music is great, the sets are lovingly crafted and the dialouge is a good read. If you're looking for a ton of combat, right out of the gate, this game might not be for you. I've managed to avoid a lot of Crisis by talking my way out of it. That's just my style, though. I understand that this is a departure from the tabletop game, and that is a bit of a shock, to some. However, the tabletop game requires only 4 XP to advance. That feels a little slim for a CRPG. You do so much that waiting for a single point of experience might feel a little castrating. The XP tolerance between advancements is acceptable and picking advancements often leaves you making hard choices about the direction you want your characters to take.I'm really liking this game so far but, I am a sucker for this setting. It's so unique and fresh compared to a lot of the high fantasy or hard sci-fi that is available! If you like CRPGs and are hankering for a new experience in a sea of sameness, give this a shot, please.I'll do my best to update my review as my play time increases. Thanks for reading.You can check out my Let's Plays Here: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_y8SVakbroEAI5jW5wSOBgAnd my stream here: https://www.twitch.tv/ben_smash

content:
Posted: March 24
Product received for free
												Though it’s not afraid to lore dump on people who seek such things, the adventure occupies a world that’s bigger than your unnamed protagonist and will just carry on around you with or without your understanding. Ignore some quests for too long and they will progress without your input, eventually resolving themselves at times and leaving you without reward and experience. Or perhaps you’ll undertake an action that seemed to be for the best and suffer the consequences when forced to view your solution from another angle. There’s talk of a mole-like monster hiding in the dumps that keeps burrowing under people’s houses, prompting them to fatally collapse on their occupants. Surely just killing off that pest would benefit everyone, so why not gather up the flaming torches and pitchforks?Because there’s rarely just black and white in Torment; there are varied shades of grey. And there is always another solution available for people who look for them. Though the game has a reasonable combat engine, you can avoid the vast majority of conflicts by charming, lying, bluffing or threatening your way out of most situations. Even when a battle does break out, you often have more options than just putting everything to sword. A relic left by an advanced civilisation long dead has its basement filled with hostile AI drones you could probably bash to bits if you wanted. Or, you could try creeping around the sides and purging command consoles to restore them to default setting. Because even in the realms of high fantasy, the answer to almost any IT issue is to turn it off and on again.I appreciate moments like these, because if Torment has one big failing, it’s the hopelessly drawn out and somewhat clumsy battles that always seem to take three times longer than they should. In the combat system's defence, there’s a lot to fit in; each character has a healthy range of battle options, and the equipping of ciphers which act like (often) one-shot special attacks. Effects range from the commonplace, like blasts and stuns, to the more remarkable, such as when a target is forced to walk around muttering randomly to itself for six turns while it drops a trail of money. Some characters can hide from sight to escape the enemy’s attention, or to set up devastating ambush attacks. Others have skill sets involving grappling hooks, short-range teleportation or especially harsh words.But the world itself is Torment big star, shuffling in alien creatures from different dimensions or sentient beings of gleaming liquid metal as the norm because why shouldn’t they be? Why shouldn’t that fountain shoot gibbering eel-fish instead of water? Why shouldn’t there be a centuries-old would-be warlord, cursed with immortality and now forced to stand in a corner as punishment for a war waged so long ago, it’s faded from memory? Why shouldn’t some of the artifices you find be ridiculously useless knick-knacks from a race of people history insists never existed? Why shouldn’t someone’s half-remembered guilt of an age-old atrocity be manifested in your own mind to offer slight stat buffs? Full Review // http://www.honestgamers.com/13344/pc/torment-tides-of-numenera/review.html

content:
Posted: March 11
												Hello friends this is my somewhat short, but hopefully somewhat useful review of tides of numenera. I'm going to break this review down into four separate categories followed by my closing thoughts. -----------------GraphicsSo let me be honest with you this games graphics isn't anything special, It's a crpg and I feel graphics isn't one of the major factors you should judge this genre of game on. That being said character models weren't all that impressive but they weren't by any stretch terrible. Some world environments actually looked pretty interesting and had a beautiful tone to it. I feel like the special effects of this game was its strong point in the graphics department but also it's most frustrating part. For instance there are certain parts of the game when you meet the sorrow and witness its grandstand this is amazing looking and creates a moment of awe, as well as some other maps you encounter look incredibly vibrant and colorful. While others look very plain and unimaginative. The most frustrating part is getting special passives later on in the game. These passives create a colorful shine effect around your character, near end game my guy looked like a walking Christmas tree about to give me a seizure. Overall the graphics where solid and did its job well that job being able to support the story and help tell it.Graphics : 7/10-----------------SoundSo let me start of by saying the soundtrack in this game was good mixed with a feeling of who gives an S***. There were times where the sound matched the mood correctly and gave me a sense of emotion and feeling to the task or event at hand. There was also times where I didn't even notice the music in the background at all tuning it out. Which made me wonder how their soundtrack was so hit and miss I could never really wrap my head around it. I feel like the major points of the story the music fit in well supporting the mood while delivering the message it set out to send us.All the music in between I honesty couldn't care less. None of the music was really terrible just most of it didn't really matter to the game. I feel the sound track aside all the ambient sound and voice acting (what little there actually is of it) is superb and immersed me more into the game. Sound: 7/10-----------------GameplaySo there is a common theme in my review which I'm sure you all have noticed. That theme being the story is the major strength of this game and I'm judging the other aspects of it based on how they support or elevate the story. Which brings me to my next category game play. Oh boy this game is hit and miss there are amazing moments to be had followed by head scratches and for game play this also holds true. The game play is honestly not very imaginative in this game and extremely straight forward.There are two aspects to the game, running around talking to people and making decisions based of stats, skills and tidal abilities, then there's the combat. The first part is fun and has rewarding moments along with emotion and enlightenment. Though I feel that this ties more into the story with a mix of it being game play. The game play being you holding tab looking for things to interact with and get into the lore and story of the world. Which leads me to the second part of the game play which is more of the definition of the word and that's the combat.Man oh man, I honestly don't know how to describe the combat for you I feel like the combat almost had no purpose. I mean it's not real time which that's okay but it's a turn based system without any real strategy or relevance. Abilities really didn't matter at least for me they didn't I was a glaive did not upgrade any abilities or used any at all for the entirety of the game. I put points into edge, stats pool, and effort I believe that's what it was called. Then I proceeded to click and auto attack on every enemy I went against till they died. Ciphers once again cool concept, it's a really powerful item that gives you stat boost or damages your foes or both but it can only be used once before its lost.Unfortunately I used a cipher one time against one enemy throughout the entire game, even then I didn't have to I just was curious to see how they work. In the end all I did was stack artifacts that made me hit harder and sell all my ciphers I had for gear. Maybe this is a glaive thing and the other classes aren't so fortunate but by mid game my guy couldn't die and my auto attacks where taking 50 to 75% of enemies life pools a strike. To me I feel like the purpose of combat was to make the game last longer and nothing more, that's how bland and tedious it was for me as a glaive at least.  Gameplay: 7/10 (the aspects relative to the story, the combat id give a 4/10)-----------------StoryLast but not least by any stretch, the reason why I bought this game and I'm sure many others did the story.Tides of numenera is carried by its excellent story telling, lore and connection you feel with the castoff and his allies. If by any chance you are 1/3 into the game and aren't feeling the story I advise you to stop playing the game. Why? because that's how much this game relies on its story to flourish. Without it, it's not even worth a steam summer sell for 75% off. Is the story perfect? No, but is it interesting fun and keeps you waiting for what happens next? Hell yes. *Slight spoilers* you are a cast off of a deity called the changing god who is in essence immortal. He achieves his immortality through transferring his consciousness from being to being improving himself from his previous life. Your role is one of these castoffs trying to figure out what is going on in this world. The game has a lot of choice leading to numerous altercations and outcomes depending on how you act and treat your followers or the world around you. The voice acting is amazing but there is barely any which is unfortunate because I believe if the game had more of it, it would appeal to a larger audience. Warning if you do not like to read do not purchase this game it's basically a visual novel with combat being its mini game in between chapters. Overall this game is good but it has its share of flaws that are out shined by its interactive and amazing story telling. I would love to tell you more but I do not wish to spoil the main reason why you should play this game. Story: 9/10Closing statementsI had fun with tides of numenera I believe the game could have been a lot better though, There were a few moments in this game that where the best I have ever played in a crpg. That being said it was also inconsistent at times which lead to frustration, the combat is poor and needs to be revamped for future games. Also, some story telling which was the best and most brilliant in the game were flashbacks. To be able to play these flashbacks in real time would have been awesome instead we got a screen that we click on with nothing to show for it. Overall in the end I had a blast it was well worth the 26 hours I spent to complete it.Overall: 8/10

												Just wanted to throw a positive voice into the growing mass of hate here.  I never played the original Torment, but I have played nearly every other crpg I am aware of at least (from fallout 1 to pillars of eternity with many many in between) and I have been absolutely loving this game.  It's everything I'd hoped for.  Even the combat; while somewhat simple and thin is fun to me.  Especially considering how infrequent you get to actually do a fight.  It's certainly more fun to me then combat in wasteland 2 was, InXile's last title.  Maybe it's just cause I love to read and roleplay in a game so driven by the narrative, but I would certainly reccomend this to anyone who's at all interested.

content:
Posted: March 8
												A smidge too verbose for its own good, bits of text that wants to be lofty and poetic but it's just pretentious. Surprisingly sparse fighting, despite a great many combat options, abilities and skills.Managing expectations is key here. If you want another Baldur's Gate or Pillars of Eternity you'll leave this game angry and frustrated. However if you're prepared to play an RPG heavy on good old adventuring, to read a lot of text and to submerge yourself into a very strange and alien world (perhaps too alien) you are in for a treat. Tides of Numenera is much less accessible and niche game than the original Torment. But it's mechanically very solid, bursting with content and dazzling with creativity.

content:
Posted: March 4
												It's clear from the store page reviews that this is not a game for everyone. So is it a game for you?Torment: Tides of Numenera is a spiritual successor to the original Planescape Torment game. In this case, spiritual successor means that it follows the same sort of weird setting, wordy, and philosophical story that the original had. It is not otherwise connected in characters, story or gameplay, so you don't have to have played the original to enjoy this.While there are plenty of fairly pretty (but not cutting edge) on-screen graphics thrown around, the game relies heavily on text to get its message across. If you don't enjoy reading through a lot of text, you probably won't enjoy the game. Combat (which can usually be avoided if you talk your way out of it) is in the game, and can be hit-and-miss. If you've got the right party setup or you figure out the best way to use any environmental tools provided in the combat area, it can be pretty fun. If you have a couple of members who aren't good fighters, it can be far less enjoyable. It does get easier (and more enjoyable) as you level things like the ingame 'edges'. Combat is turn-based, not real-time-with-pause like Baldurs Gate or Pillars of Eternity, so it can run a bit slower than fighting in those systems. There also isn't really any trash-mobs to fight - all fights are usually important to a storyline, and so there's a limited amount. If you enjoy regular combat in your rpgs, this game is probably not going to excite you.The story takes a bit of time to get into as you get familiar with all of the terminology and the weirdness being thrown at you, but does seem to click after a couple of hours and become fairly absorbing, One thing it does do well, much like the original Torment game, is transport you to an unfamiliar rpg world that doesn't play to the usual rules of orcs and dragons. It's wordy, to the point where some may consider it too wordy, but if you enjoy a highly descriptive game then you should find something to enjoy here. Overall, while it has its flaws it does seem to be a fairly good spiritual successor to Planescape Torment. I don't regret putting money into the kickstarter for it all those years ago.

								I started Tides of Numera on a Sunday hoping to get a glimpse into a game that is still early access. Simply put, the writing is excellent, and if the rest of the game is of similar quality, this has the potential to be spectacular.  If you are on the edge, I highly suggest the purchase.  This is from someone who never had the pleasure of playing Planescape.

Gameplay: 7/10 (the aspects relative to the story, the combat id give a 4/10)-----------------StoryLast but not least by any stretch, the reason why I bought this game and I'm sure many others did the story.Tides of numenera is carried by its excellent story telling, lore and connection you feel with the castoff and his allies. If by any chance you are 1/3 into the game and aren't feeling the story I advise you to stop playing the game. Why? because that's how much this game relies on its story to flourish. Without it, it's not even worth a steam summer sell for 75% off. Is the story perfect? No, but is it interesting fun and keeps you waiting for what happens next? Hell yes. *Slight spoilers* you are a cast off of a deity called the changing god who is in essence immortal. He achieves his immortality through transferring his consciousness from being to being improving himself from his previous life. Your role is one of these castoffs trying to figure out what is going on in this world. The game has a lot of choice leading to numerous altercations and outcomes depending on how you act and treat your followers or the world around you. The voice acting is amazing but there is barely any which is unfortunate because I believe if the game had more of it, it would appeal to a larger audience. Warning if you do not like to read do not purchase this game it's basically a visual novel with combat being its mini game in between chapters. Overall this game is good but it has its share of flaws that are out shined by its interactive and amazing story telling. I would love to tell you more but I do not wish to spoil the main reason why you should play this game. Story: 9/10Closing statementsI had fun with tides of numenera I believe the game could have been a lot better though, There were a few moments in this game that where the best I have ever played in a crpg. That being said it was also inconsistent at times which lead to frustration, the combat is poor and needs to be revamped for future games. Also, some story telling which was the best and most brilliant in the game were flashbacks. To be able to play these flashbacks in real time would have been awesome instead we got a screen that we click on with nothing to show for it. Overall in the end I had a blast it was well worth the 26 hours I spent to complete it.Overall: 8/10

content:
Posted: April 13
Product received for free
												While I have never been a big fan of CRPGs, mostly because of their boring combat and often slow and uninspired character creators...one thing that is almost always on display with CRPGs is superb writing. inXile returns to form with their kickstarted spiritual successor to what many people consider the greatest RPG of all time... Planescape Torment. Torment: Tides of Numenera is a spiritual successor in just about everyway...well...I think it falls short in pacing, as the game can certainly drag on at times. But it does a good job going away from the boring Paragon/Renegade or Good/Evil moralities. You can find yourself having a number of different tides, which help shape your character. The character sheet/customization is pretty lacking, especially with almost no ability to customize your looks.But if you like strong lore, strong story-telling, and a well written (but not too long) story I would certainly purchase this game.

Early Access Review
								Pretty damn good for an alpha -- the potential for greatness, both in gameplay and writing, is absolutely showing. I made it through most of the available content, but unfortunately ran into some issues with my save file. Which is fine, it's an alpha after all. I'm extremely excited to see where this game ends up after another half year of development. The devs definitely have their work cut out for them -- the engine is really clunky and has a lag-like quality to it. Additionally, there are a lot of little edge case bugs. Having played enough of the game to know its merit, I can get past that, but I doubt that the general reception would be so favorable.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8
												++ Good and immersive writing & setting, left me thinking about some of the characters.+ Different from other recent RPG:s (such as Pillars of Eternity) in its emphasis on solving problems through dialogue, making the game feel fresh even for an RPG veteran+ Failure can also result in interesting events+ Combat sequences are not "filler", each encounter is different, and there is usually a non-combat solution available+ Text adventures in the style of old "choose your own adventure" books bring some variety to the gameplay+ No grinding for levels+ A fairly good amount of content if you do all the sidequests you can find. Good for at least one playthrough, possibly more if you want to find everything.- Some minor crashes in combat sequences- Although combat scenarios are well done, the "flow" of combat could be better- "Choose your own adventure" sections could have a wider variety of possible good endings, now there is often some optimal path to take and lots of ways to die, resulting in a need to reload- Unless you develop an interest in the game world and its themes, there may even be too much text at some points to develop minor NPCs.- A bit too many "lore dumps" from minor NPCs. Fortunately, the main story is not told just in text but also through gameplay and visually.- Some areas are a bit too crammed with stuff visually, leading to a theme park aesthetic in e.g. the Valley of the Dead zone.Overall a very solid 8/10.

content:
Posted: March 11
												If you like classic CRPG's, this is one, and is enjoyable if that is what you are expecting.  I am recommending this game for that reason alone.  I will continue to play and enjoy this game.  Good job with this game.But I can't say great job.  I just can't.As someone who Kickstarted this game, and waited FOUR. LONG. YEARS. I am also disappointed.  Foremost, I am disappointed by the companions in this game.  Compared to Dak'kon Zerth, Annah, Fall-from-Grace, Ignus and Morte...this game doesn't have teeth (cwutIdidthere?).  Erritis comes close, but ends like a poorly told joke.  Rhin is blatantly designed to evoke Feels.  But Feels should be organic, and take time to grow into.  Her story is interesting but its in the wrong place.  Aligern, Calistege, Tybir and Matkina are boring.  They don't have interesting mechanical choices.  They don't have interesting narrative choices.  I feel like I can swap them in and out without ever caring.  Even the art for them is boring, from portrait to character model.  They should look like fantasy heroes! Iconic! Not bland normal people trying too hard.  I want to throw up everytime I look at Calistege -- really, she lives a thousand lives at the same time and chooses to look like Effie Trinket?  Where is the torment of these characters??? Where is the betrayal?  Where is the hideous past?  Where is the struggle for growth, the triumph over OR fall to darkness???  Where are the amazing, genius connections and mysteries of the characters that you gradually uncover throughout the course of the game?  Come on! That's the core of what made Planescape amazing, not the weirdness of the environment, or being able to die over and over, though I appreciate the homage.  The characters in this hardly react to my decisions!  Their banter is almost non-existent!  Also, for as huge and zany as this game wants to be, it feels awfully small.  You had four years!!It's just disappointing.  Please go look at Obsidian Entertainment.  Pillars and Tyranny both blew my mind, and I can't throw my money - - sodden with tears of gratitude - -  at them fast enough to get more of those GREAT games.  Wasteland 2 was good, but not great.  So Inxile is now at strike 2 for me.  I really really want devs to make great CRPGs, but it's not worth $$ backing for just another good game.

content:
Posted: March 9
												Overall I liked it. It tries really hard live up to the "Torment" legacy and while it unfortunately falls short of this ambitious goal, it's still a enjoyable experience. It focuses heavily on the story element with combat being very infrequent to almost non existant depending on choises made. Where it falls short is mainly in it's companions and general difficulty. Where Planescape really made you work to achieve "good" results Numenera feels a bit more like an extended choose your own adventure, as long as you have the right skills nessesary most things solve themselves rather effortless, if an dialog option shows that it require the use of a skill it's almost univesally the "right/best" option.The companions, while well written, are a bit unfortunately not well integrated into the story. You'll encounter them, learn their intriguing backstory and then drag them with you until you hit upon "their" sidequest, after which they are for the most part done narratively. I miss the interwoven and gradually exposition of the Planescape companions.Still it's a good game in a nieche genre so I'd recommend it.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16
												Torment: Numenera HISHE (How it Should Have Ended) ReviewTorment: Numenera is a true sucessor of the Planescape formula. A rich and deep story on an interesting world bordering on a literary adventure of the surrealist fantasy genre. While it is certainly worth playing, it falls short from it's goal of achieving the same level or even surpassing it's predecessor. Not surprisingly, this has far more to do with the narrative aspects than the gameplay or technical aspects, simply because of the fact that, a true roleplaying game worthy of such a label has to be focused first and foremost on storytelling, it's characters, the choices made and their effects on the world. Numenera's story isn't told as well as Planescape had been, even with the advantage of being made 20 years later, after much experimentation and innovative narrative mechanics have been developed. Even if we take into account that surpassing Planescape Torment is essentially the tallest possible order for any Roleplaying Game, and Numenera is much better written than most recent triple A RPG games, its shortcomings are so glaring that they cannot be ignored.Planescape Torment had a similar Main Character, one who started life suffering from an accute case of amnesia and immortality. However, if we take a closer look, the similarities become evidently superficial. The Nameless One was a character who could indeed become any class, and voice many different opinions at any point, he could be a bully or a hero, kind or aggressive, but unlike the Last Castoff, he always did so with style. The Nameless One was always his own character, never a clean slate, a tabula rasa. The western industry standard of writing for video games, especially RPGs, is the idea that the character must be written is such a way that the player will feel to be the one fully in control to be properly "immersed" in the story, free to do as they please. Instead of creating immersion, what this actually does is create an awkward dynamic where your Dovahkins, Wardens and Vault Dwellers are template characters instead of having a mind of their own. The only effect this game theory has on storytelling games is creating a disconnect of the narrative and it's central character.The InterrogatorThe worst part, however, is the way how the Last Castoff interacts with the world, or more accurately, how the world interacts with her. Go out and ask the first person you see the following question "Tell me your story". The last thing that person will do, is to answer what you asked. Not only it is invasive and even creepy, people will often not reply to questions with objective, direct and concise answers, especially when they have ulterior motives and well rounded personalities. The only explanation for the way people talk to the Last Castoff is if they are being forced to speak in such an open and unusual manner by some kind of influence from the Tides. This would be a way to justify it in game, but even then it would simply be an excuse to spare the writers the trouble of coming up with realistic interactions and explaining away the bullet point, excel table, conversation style of Numenera's NPCS.Torment: Tides of MacGuffinNumeneras are MacGuffins, the definition of a Numera is exactly what a MacGuffin is. MacGuffins are useful storytelling tools, but they often create Deus Ex Machina situations. The Tides themselves are Lacanian/Campbellian archetypical forces, and can only have such a powerful effect on reality when we accept the premise of existence being a construct of the mind, human or otherwise. It's an interesting premise that would be especially easy to accept when taking the 4th wall into account. Unfortunately, even when it is the very center of the story, since the nature of the Sorrow is to be the actual representation of Campbell's Shadow, it's not properly developed, well explained, or interestingly delved into. Even the Changing God's personal quest falls flat and uninspiring by the end. Especially since it's revealed to us at a point where it was simply way way... past the time to sympathize with the character, and there was no bond at all formed between the player's character and the Mysterious Girl. It's a shallow and hollow sideshow, instead of an emotional reveal.Railroad Ending The game ends with yet another interrogation type conversation, where the Sorrow delivers a heavy dose of plot exposition, in a similar way to the Architect's Monologue in Matrix: Reloaded. It isn't as bad, and allows a window into the mind of a being that couldn't have been understood, according to the story, except for the fact that it totally could. It would be far better to discover all about the Sorrow during the story, exploring the past, learning about it's origins from other sources than simply "asking for exposition". Too much exposition is awful by itself, direct exposition from the main villain? I shouldn't even have to say anything about it.If the idea was to show that the Sorrow isn't truly the villain, but the hero. That Castoffs are in the wrong, selfishly destroying the world to achieve their own ends, and the only option to destoy the Sorrow would be the ultimate act of selfishness on their part... then it falls flat on its♥♥♥♥♥completely.HISHE (How It Should Have Ended)After the main villain makes its whole spiel about how the Last Castoff has to choose options A through Z: Kill the Castoffs by subsuming them into 1 person, Kill the Sorrow to let Castoffs Live but condemn hundreds of thousands in the present and potential millions in the future to a horrible death, allowing the Sorrow to persist, thus condeming the Castoffs to extinction by it's Grim Reaper hands, etc...The Last Castoff finally decides to take an active role and confronts the narrative of the Sorrow, showing the flaws in its reasoning and taking it down from its high horse forcing it to accept the moral low ground on which it stands. Then, with the power of the Tides, the Last Castoff makes it see the horror of it's existence and kill itself, letting Castoffs and humans free to choose their own destiny, accepting the consequences of their choices.The Sorrow is a World Killer. It has killed millions if not Billions before and deprived other tens of billions, if not trillions, from being born. It is a genocidal force that wiped out civilizations, allowing such a thing to live would be a far greater crime, even at the cost of hundreds of thousands of lives. Because at some point in the future, it would be inevitable that technology would once again discover the power of the Tides, conscience transfer or whatever, and after the Sorrow managed to prevent access to the Resonance, it would be far more difficult if not impossible to stop it. The effect of Castoffs bodies self-sustaining with Tide energies is a potential problem, but only when they actively decide to use the Tides, every other subliminal effect implied is either too subtle to be perceived or just hasn't been properly represented in the story to be relevant. We live in a world where our emotions and self-image is constantly manipulated by chemistry, propaganda, marketing, and even the temperature or hardness of where we sit can change the way we look at things and how we feel about the world. This is a very poor excuse to condemn Castoffs to death, especially in a world where people constantly use Numenera to influence each other and the world around them. Where telepaths and empaths, Machine Intelligences and Ctonic Ctullhian transdimensional entities move around the world unchecked and unfettered.As it is, the moral of the story is that The Last Castoff is simply not smart enough to debate against the Sorrow, "technology is too dangerous", "the price of Immortality is too high" and "It is more moral to embrace mortality and live a short happy life in ignorance than to pursue the understanding of fundamental forces in the universe"

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22
												I have to say this game surprised me more than I expected based off of all the feedback that came froms critics and fans alike. I was a kickstarter backer of this game, but I had no *real* expectations of what would come of this. Like most things on kickstarter, the end product can be a mixed bag. That is what I would say we got with this game here. A mixed bag.HOWEVER, it is still a pretty decent CRPG. It takes awhile to get going, but once it does (especially when you get to the Bloom) it is a truly fascinating game that takes place in a new and interesting world. It aims high and falls short in many ways, but more often than not it hits than misses. Like many have said...the dialogue is interesting...but sometimes feels like they are just trying to fill space or be clever for the sake of being clever. Yet, for each instance of that you will find many more examples of just plain weird and out there concepts that will pull you in.If I had to give it a score out of 10, an 8.3 is where it would sit. It is a perfectlly servicable game, that perhaps with patches and some refinements to dialoge, combat and glitches could rise to an 8.5-8.8. I do hope they continue to make games like this, but based off of sales and feedback it seems unlikely.Note: I wish they had been more open about cut content. Well I personally don't hold ire like some of the backers, I think it just send the wrong message right before release. Like I said, this is a decent RPG and if your a fan of these games play it. Unfortunately, their poor handling of cut content just....made it so it whimpered out of the gate more than was needed.
