content:
Posted: March 25
Product received for free
												I'll take a bit of a contrarian stance on here to most of the people commenting: I never played PS:T, and I have no familiarity with anything else regarding the game's world or the developer other my experience playing this game. I can respect the people that come in with their expectations and biases, but I'm evaluating the game based entirely on its own merits.First off, T:ToN is an exceptionally-written game. As many have stated, it's much more an interactive visual novel than it is a classic game -- something, to my understanding, that made PS:T such a cult hit. It is a great surprise to me, then, that there is so much egregious focus in other reviews on the combat mechanics not being this or that. I was recommended the game by a friend who was a big fan of PS:T and backed this game on kickstarter, and he was very upfront about what I should expect based on the developers' history. Nowhere did he mention "damn man, PS:T's real time combat system really sold me the game!" No, it was "hey, you should check this game out, PS:T had an exceptional story and narrative and this game is its spiritual successor."It should be understood, certainly, that T:ToN is not a conventional game, but I don't think it ever promised itself to be. The entire game is intended to lay out a very detailed world, and build up a compelling story based on very subtle and sequential revelation. Many people complaining about the pacing, I imagine, were expecting to plow through the game with a bunch of combat as you chase down the mystery of the Changing God, and were broadsided by the fact that the game is far more reading than it is fighting. But that's where T:ToN really shines: the developers clearly never intended to make this a fast-paced experience, and you can definitely tell they placed their efforts entirely on developing the strongest narrative possible. The story is central and key -- and yes, that means there are a bunch of characters who are small and irrelevant from a gameplay perspective. But these characters add to the overall depth of the story. NPCs in this game aren't NPCs in the traditional sense: they're narrative delivery devices, and laid out in such a way to add bits of depth to the player who is willing to spend time and effort to explore. You're not going to get Bioware little romance plots or a Beach Scene with the Team, or really detailed Friendship Time Scenes with your companions. Your companions feel extremely real in that regard: they're aren't your friends or pals, they're people who incidentally end up traveling with you for personal reasons.I won't talk to any points regarding the story in terms of content, as the story is the entire reason you'd play the game. In terms of replayability, though, some have said there is none; to a certain extent this is true, but I think the writing is interesting enough that you a 2nd playthrough is certainly possible and would be enjoyable by making very different decisions from your first playthrough. It was about 25 hours for me to beat the game on a full playthrough doing as much as possible, and I could see another 15-20 on a replay. But, as with most RPGs, this is something I'd do down the line in a couple years' time and not right away.Does this game have some flaws? Absolutely. I think the stories with the side characters could have been fleshed out a bit more, and I think more effort could have been made to develop a world map to tie in visually tie story events in with the narrative. I really enjoyed the Meres from a storytelling perspective, but felt some of them were a little too abstract tying things in with present time. But most complaints of this nature are minor.Play this game if you enjoy reading books with good stories. But if you're looking for a gameplay-driven real time action RPG, steer clear. The devs made a niche game that is not going to have a lot of widespread appeal, but they really nailed the niche well. I'll definitely keep my eyes on this company in the future.

content:
Posted: April 1
												This is a game that wanted badly to be a Planescape: Torment successor, but never really came close enough to it in depth. Everything bad you might have already read about its mechanics, balance, cut content and broken promises is entirely true.But. If you are a backer like me, you already know all this, and you don't need a review to confirm it. If you are fine with replaying Planescape: Torment again and again until the end of your life - go ahead. Might be worth it.If, on the other hand, you are simply a fan of isometric RPGs with great stories, fascinating worlds, branching quests and extensive dialogues instead of combat, and you are looking for something new worth playing - you should definitely buy and play this right now. It's not "the new Planescape: Torment". But it's the closest thing to it you'll get anytime soon, and it is a great game in its own right. Well, maybe not technically a great *game*. But all the things mentioned above are in, and they are great. Why should you care if inXile promised anything else to someone like us? You are not us. You don't have to be disappointed.Honestly, this game doesn't deserve the review score it gets. The developers do, though. That's what you get for promising to surpass a legend.

												I consider the hallmark of a good RPG to be two things. 1.I stayed up way too late playing it.2.I'm planning my next playthrough before I'm done with my first.So at 7:30AM, having not slept, and planning to be a Nano using two of the three party members I left behind, I decided this game qualifies. I found the world intriguing, the story interesting and the characters likable enough, some more so then others. The system for battles and general gameplay was great and I loved how simple and easy it was to understand and use. Overall a good experience, a game for people who love an interesting world and story to explore. Hardly perfect, a few things did annoy me a bit, but after playing and hating almost every cRPG thats come out in recent times its nice to have one that I felt motivated to play and not bogged down by game mechanics.

Posted: March 19
												My feelings toward Torment: Tides of Numenera are mixed. While much love and dedication was obviously put into this CRPG, its hard to ignore it's weak points.I chose to recommend this game because at the moment of writing the game's overall score deserves some positive correction upward. I think people should be encouraged to play this game, and games like this in general (such as PoE and Tyranny), though when it comes to this title they would be served best by curbing their expectations.Pros:* A fascinating world full of wonders to explore and discover.* Interesting questlines and characters, for the most part.* Well written narrative, for the most part.Cons:* An incredibly frustrating combat system with long waiting time between rounds. (Although you can choose to avoid combat most of the time).* Banal and unsatisfying asnwers to some of the game's most intriguing mysteries.* Rushed ending that fails to meet the expectations.Verdict: Play this game to enjoy the ride and don't expect a mind blowing closure, just try to avoid the combat.

content:
Posted: March 10
												It felt a bit short and a bit hollow compared to the Torment of yore, but it is a true spiritual successor.  Lots and lots of text and dialogue, it was very well written.  There is usually more than one way to obtain whatever objective you have.  NPCs are complex and nuanced, each with their own motivation, personality, and attitude.Very few required fights, and those that are forced are almost always objective oriented... you're trying to survive, escape or reach some goal rather than just kill the enemies.  It's a neat idea, and mostly successfullly pulled off - that said I would have liked to see more of it.  I also would have liked more opportunities to just pound some baddies.The supporting PCs are all unique and very well thought out - you will be interested in your followers, their objectives, and what they have to say.The leveling system felt a bit thin - most of the combat abilities weren't terribly useful in my "jack" (rogue type) playthrough.The whole "tide" system felt really undeveloped - supposedly your behavior opened up options that you might not have had otherwise, but even after finishing the first playthrough I wasn't really sure whether it made any difference at all.  Overall, I was mildly disappointed, but the original set the bar very, very, high.  I still recommend the game on its own merits.

content:
Posted: March 12
												I just finished my first play through of Tides of Numenara. (I didn't play it during early access, seemed silly to play a partly complete story based game before it was finished)Overall, I liked the game.It's certainly a niche game. You have to like reading, as in full length novels type reading. Combat and character building took a massive back seat. If you play these games to level up, collect loot, and test your characters in combat, pass this game. You won't like it. It kept the original Torment "feel". Everything is strange, weird and alien. It takes some time to get the "feel" of this strange universe. The game eases you into it by taking a page out of the original Torment, your character starts with no memory. Everything is just as strange and new to your character as it is to the player. The universe is complex, and I actually caught the game breaking it's own internal consistency at least twice. For example your character is pretty much immortal (not much of a spoiler, you find this out 2 minutes into the game), as well as other characters who belong to your characters "race", only extreme things can actually kill them, however, the game forgets about this fact at least once. (not to the main character)One page it didn't take from the original was the lack of wacky party members. You got some crazy extreme ones in the original, (a floating scull, a succubus, a man who burns forever..) Nothing like this here. In fact I found them to be "ok". The exception to this would be Rhin. Though she is a normal human, her character differs enough the she breaks the mold from the rest. Not that the other characters you take on are all boring and dull. They all have backstories and little mysteries attached to them. The game can be progressed in various ways. You can avoid 75% of the combat with your choices, character skills, and some luck. When you are actually in combat the in game system is passible for certain. One thing that bothered me with combat was there was no in game explanation as to what all the damage types did.  Combat was also very buggy. Certain functions just stop working and cannot be access for no in game reason and random times. This bringing me to my next point...BUGS!!! Combat had the most of them, (stealth for example, sometimes I would not be able to select it, sometimes the menu would come up, I would have a good percentage of success, but the "ok" button would not work) If there was an in game reason for this I had no idea why it didn't work. Other abilities seemed to be prone to this. Twice the game got "stuck" on the enemies turn.  A couple times I would somehow break the combat rules and do something not allowed that usually got my character stuck and unable to end their turn. Outside of combat the game gave me issues saving, sometimes it just would not allow me to create a new save file. (thankfully "quick save" always seemed to work) Sometimes I would be unable to select anything for some reason. The only way to fix this was to save and reload. Another frustrating bug was if you look at something then shortly afterwards move to a new area, the window giving feedback gets stuck on your screen. The only way to fix this is to go back and look at the same object and allow the window to close on it's own. Had the game lock up randomly at least 5 times.One thing I have to bring up, the game creators have a video showing a slice of the game. In this slice they show pretty much every NPC spoken to using actual spoken lines. The game has hardly any spoken lines at all when you actually play it. Worse still, once you arrive at the same slice of the game, none of the characters who spoke in the video speak any of the same lines, (it's all just text reading). I'm not sure what's up with that. I don't mind reading everything, but I don't like being tricked into thinking the game has certain features it does not.To summarize; if you liked the original Torment, you will like this. If you like reading/story heavy RPGs, you will like this.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								As of version 0.1.2:InXile has truly created a spiritual successor to PS:T with this game; the world is overflowing with story, depth of character, intrigue, excitement, and choice. That said, what exists now is VERY similar to PS:T and I hope there is a significant directional change as the story progresses further and deeper into Numenera's 9th World.As an early beta, it is undeniably riddled with bugs, balance, and user interface issues; all of this is to be expected of course. Thus, I don't mind so far and am eager to see the game become more painted, polished and perfected. I have seen FAR worse betas. Many, many, much worse.My two greatest likes about T:ToN: the beautifully painted areas, and the wonderfully scripted text/dialogue. In this InXile has shone.What I hope to see more development in: For it's otherwise gorgeous artwork, the user interface (menus, gui/hud, etc) is lacking in the artistic department; it is unfortunately drab and plain. It doesn't reflect the beauty of the world it overlays. There also seems to be a significant amount of interface lag when attempting actions, dialogue, or navigating menus. As noted elsewhere, the game itself seems to suffer from slow transitional load times. Im fairly confident, however, that these problems will be addressed before final release.In summary: This may be the game I am most excited to play in a very, very long time.

content:
Posted: March 13
												Less like a traditional cRPG to me and more like an isometric choose your own adventure game which happens to have pretty decent writing overall (there is a lot of a reading in this game) so if you like choose your own adventure books you will probably like this but if you go in expecting something like some of the newer cRPG's released of late like Divinity Original Sin, Wasteland 2 or Pillars of Eternity as examples then you may be slightly disappointed. There is a lot of content the developers cut from the game which annoyed me as a backer on Kickstarter but they have promised to work on bringing as much of those things as possible with few exceptions later through free content patches so I have not dwelled on that aspect in this review. Since I have also not yet completed the game I did not delve deep into the mechanics or too much of the gameplay specifics in this review, I will update this review with that sort of information once completed it but until then this is more a general review about the game format/style, value and issues I have with it so far in my playthrough.Combat in the game happens rarely and way to easy to avoid with little to no effort in my opinion, the stat/skill checks are very easy which makes the world feel less threatening in the sense of not on edge worrying about game over screens much and less rewarding because the game is heavily weighted in favor of you passing checks and balances to avoid most conflicts so avoiding them does not feel like much of a challenge. Normally in past cRPG's avoiding conflict was harder so when did manage to wriggle your way out of getting into fights it felt more rewarding.It does not feel like you are in much danger most of the time and also feels like hardly anyone poses much of a threat because of how easy it is to talk your way out of most conflicts plus you tend to ressurect in your mind in most cases when die anyways with very few perma death situations. Investing in combat abilities feel somewhat redundant for most of the game so I found picking things that boost worldly knowledge and things to help pass dialogue checks a better choice overall. I have seen others calling this game akin to a 'visual novel' but that is not an accurate description of this game and to call it that is a bit misleading since there is enough actual gameplay and action to counter that perception. The writing is good in general, the companions are interesting enough even though there is not much in the way of quests for them, the world setting/lore is very interesting plus the music is also fairly decent at times but it is not the game I hoped it would be when backed it on Kickstarter if being honest. I was expecting a high quality traditional cRPG but this is pretty much a choose your own adventure book in isometric game format. I am pretty far into it I think but have yet to finish it so do not know if it drastically changes between now and then though I doubt it will to a large degree. Overall I would give it a 7/10 so far of which the score I give it may go up or down slightly by time I finish it. I like Wasteland 2, Divinity Original Sin and Pillars of Eternity more than this overall even if each of those have their own flaws, this one I put on par with Tyranny as it stands currently. I will likely update this review when finish it. If you are unsure whether will like it because of how expensive it is you might want to wait till on either 33% or 50% off sale, I think it is worth at least 50% of it's current price personally so around 20-25 GBP, I do think it is a bit expensive at 35 GBP for specifically people unsure about whether will like it or not and if you are one of those people then you shold definatley avoid buying the 50 or 70 GBP versions. Obviously also take into account my valuation on things might not match how you value things but I stand by what I said for those who remain unsure about picking this game up.

content:
Posted: March 14
												Torment: Tides of Numenera is a very unique experience that encourages roleplaying over min-maxing metaplaying, setting it apart from most other cRPGs. The way the game plays takes a little getting used to, as you'll find yourself taking in massive dialoges rather than strategic battles most of the time. But it does this very elegantly. The numenera system might seem shallow at first glance but offers a lot of depth as you progress. Torment is clearly not a game for everyone, but I highly recommend it, especially to fans of the original planescape torment. Easily one of the most exciting games I've run this year!

content:
Posted: March 13
												Don't buy this game for the gameplay.Don't buy this game for the graphics.Don't buy this game expecting intricate dialogue interactivity.Buy this game for its world and its stories. The reviews that say this RPG is less game and more 'choose your own adventure' are spot-on. If you're the type of person who buys PnP campaign settings or pre-made adventure paths and likes to read through them (not even necessarily play them), this game is for you.As someone who is somewhat tired of the standard fantasy tropes on display in RPGs today, the Tides of Numenera's setting and characters are a breath of fresh air. Yes, the game has glitches. Yes, random NPCs are willing to give you their life's story at the drop of a hat. But if you can look past its flaws and enjoy it for what it is, Tides of Numenera is well worth your time.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24
												Overall, I really enjoyed this game.The good:  The story was well written and I really liked the companions I chose to bring along.  It had a very Planescape: Torment feel to it, as befits a spiritual successor.  There were a lot of quests but none of them felt like chores.  The ability to not just interactively "remember" the past but actually change it is quite a cool concept.The neutral: The game does strip down much of the staples of the classic RPG genre.  Combat is infrequent (and mostly voluntary), gear upgrades are few, there's no such thing as grinding and even character progression feels somewhat unimportant.  Most of the game revolves around dialog and your choices there, and there's basically no truly "trash" encounters.  These could go either way - I found them a refreshing departure from combat-heavy games, but if you enjoy killing a lot of stuff and getting a lot of gear / XP then you may find this game lacking.The bad: Tidal surge is a mechanic that both seems fascinating and woefully underutilized.  In fact the entire Tides system had no obvious impact upon the game, in spite of being a key focus to the plot.

content:
Posted: March 6
												While it doesn't feel like a true sequel to Planescape: Torment, it certainly gets a lot right.  Definitely the Spiritual Sequel, which is what it's supposed to be.  A sequel released in a timely manner would not have been as good.  I'd argue that the Numenera setting is even better than the Planescape setting.  The wonder and imagination is all here.  It's as mysterious and intriguing as PS:T, if not more so.  If you are into atmospheric, text heavy RPGs this is one of the best.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17
												Disclaimer: I backed the game on Kickstarter and played it on GOG rather than Steam.The first thing anyone should know about this game is that it is very heavy on text and could almost be thought of as an interactive novel rather than as a game. I've you have never played any games like that (such as Planescape: Torment) I would not reccommend buying this game yet, as the price is quite steep. Wait until you know for sure whether you like this style of game or until the price drops.With that out of the way, I can say that this game is in my opinion a more than worthy spiritual successor to Planescape: Torment. There are significant differences between both games, but they clearly fall within the same niche subgenre withing RPGs. However, as much as some people seem to have fond memories of Planescape, I never liked it all that much. Its setting and characters did not feel relatable to me. This made it hard for me to care about the story or the world, altough it must be said that some of the characters definitely had their moments. In comparison, Numenera offers a setting that is an interesting blend of fantasy with science fiction and a bit of post-apocalypse. In many ways, it feels familiar and therefore is often much more relatable. But this familiarity is constantly broken up by strange and mysterious elements, giving the setting the weirdness that also defined Planescape's setting. In my opinion, the better setting also leads to ToN having a better story. In contrast to Planescape, ToN managed to make care about the world, the story and characters and kept me engaged and from beginning to end. I feel this is the most important aspect of any RPG and would therefore greatly reccommend this game. Of course, whether you like a story or not is heavily subjective as it depends entirely on individual preferences, but I had the best time playing an RPG since I played Baldur's Gate.That being said, the game is not without flaws. Its is relatively short and the combat system feels like an afterthought. Even though this game focusses on story rather than combat, I do feel that combat is essential to any RPG. A better combat system and more content would have greatly improved this game.

number of helpful: 43 of 90 people (48%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								Let me start by saying that I hope I'm able to change this review someday. I love Numenera,  I loved the original Torment, and the small parts of this game that work show a lot of promise.That said, the "game" is far too incomplete to get a recommendation at this time. It's at a very early alpha level of bugginess, such that all but the most patient of gamers will not be able to tolerate it. If you don't imagine yourself happily persevering after the fourth time you've crashed during character creation, you should probably wait a while before checking this game out.Even if you are prepared to save after every action and reload a lot, brace yourself for a shocking lack of content. You'll get a quest, head out for the dungeon, and then get a dialog telling you to imagine you just completed the quest. At the current state of development, the game is very thin.These two complaints should be addressed as development progresses. One thing that won't change is that this game looks and plays like a game from 1999. Thats not a bad thing, it's just what a gamer like me wants, but it's not for everyone.Those complaints aside, I haven't returned it and continue to slog through it. Why? Because it's a great portrayal of the Numenera setting and system. Because the writing is top quality and the dialog trees are extensive. Because I suspect that I will love this game when it's done and don't want to wait for them to finish it. So, if you're the kind of person who loves Planescape and plays in a weekly tabletop Numenera game, this title is worth a look. Otherwise, I'd keep my eye on the forums and pick it up when it's got a little more meat on it's bones.

content:
Posted: March 4
Summary.Torment: Tides of Numenera is a party-RPG, 35-40 hour long, the battle system is poor, the story is fine. The game is good, but it fails to compete with either nostalgia or the other RPGs available. Approaching it without comparison or expectations would provide the best experience.Update. Completed the 2nd playthrough. The game tracks most of player's choices, but doesn't show if an event is the consequence of player's actions, time-dependant or a default scenario; There is not enough information in battles shown (i.e. no log, no rolls, no opponent's stats or defenses);There is usually one weapon per type (Heavy, Medium, Light) per stat (Might, Speed, Intellect) per area (except for Medium Speed weapons, there are sometimes 2 per area).Key points: The story is fine, the lore is rather bizarre, the information is presented in pieces to form the whole picture by the end (some side quests bite later during the main ones);Several ways to resolve quests;The decisions sometimes provide immediate or clear results, due to the game's structure you see some outcomes only in the epilogue;Areas change subtly depending on the actions taken;Terminology is different for the sake of being different - "nano" is a mage, "CRISIS" is combat, "fettle" is an effect/status, "oddity" is useless loot and "numenera" is an artifact in the most common meaning (matearial product of human culture/civilization);3 battles in the firsrt 15 hours, more unskippable battles later, turn-based combat, hard to say how balanced it is;No stealth outside of combat, which means inability to scout areas before encounters or start combat with an attack from stealth;RNG-based skill checks in dialogues encourage to use F5/F9 often;Several choose-your-adventure (text-based) sequences, several dialogue pazzles (i.e. answers mean something);Good graphics, good animations (but there's no option to speed it up);"Heavy" UI, no option to sort items in the inventory (which gets more problematic as the player acquires more items);Good soundtrack, annoyingly voiced commands (turned off VA after 10 hours);Customizable controls;No fast-travel and a lot of running through the same locations;Some side quests are bugged (v.1.0.1);Companions, who are available, but not in the active party, don't gain experience;Tides seem to be the same thing as allignment in D&D and it can be min-max'ed as well.There are other games doing what TToN is trying to do, but better.For hardcore RPG experience - The Age of Decadance;For nostalgia - Pillars of Eternity.

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
Just like they used to make them!What a fantastic game!"Tides of Numenera" is a worthy successor to "Planescape Torment", my favorite game of all time. Although not as good as the original, ToN is a first-rate RPG just like they used to make them back in the days.Pros:+ The atmosphereI can not stress this enough. The atmosphere in this game is simply gorgeous. The game makers perfectly managed to recapture that special Planescape feeling. Exploring the streets of Sagus Cliffs felt just like exploring Sigil for the very first time so many years ago. And "The Bloom" is one of the most scenic areas that has ever been created in video game history in my opinion.+ The LoreLots of philosophy, just the way you like it. There is so much stuff you can learn about this world and it's always told in an engaging and informative way. + The StorySuspenseful story-telling, cool characters, it's all there. I've heard people complain about the ending of ToN, but I can't share that opinion at all. The ending (at least the one I chose) was a perfect conclusion to the story arc.Neutral:+- The PartyIn my opinion the biggest "flaw" of the game. The NPCs are not nearly as interesting or fleshed-out as the ones in "Placescape Torment". No companion has the charme of Morte or the wits of Annah. They are likeable (most of them), but I wish there would have been more interaction and more depth to the characters.+- The UniverseToN takes places in the Ninth World, which is not related to the Planes you know from D&D at all. In the beginning this was a bit of a let-down for me, regarding how much story potential the Planes still seemed to contain. In the end though, I found this new universe really fascinating. It's thoroughly developed and I think you should give it a chance. Don't listen to people who say: "It's not the Planes so it's bad!"+- The Game MechanicsNot really a bad thing. I like the new mechanics, but boy does it take time to get used to them. The fights are turn-based and you now have ability points that you can spend in order to increase the chance of success of a certain action. It's closer to an actual Pen & Paper RPG.+- The LengthIt took me about 30 hours to complete the game including most side quests. Not too bad, but I think the game could have lasted just a bit longer.Negative:Nothing really. The game has some small flaws, but nothing serious that would interfere with the game experience.Bottom Line:If you can get over the fact, that the new Torment is set in a different universe and you don't mind learning new game mechanics, I strongly suggest you buy this game. It might not be as amazing as the original Planescape, but it's a very strong second installment that manages to fill the foot-steps made by it's predecessor.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
												9/10Overall: An excellent example of Inifinity-engine style storytelling in the mold of Planescape: Torment. One of the biggest strengths of TTON is that it is without the excess weight of some elements that (while fun) don't contribute to this particular kind of narrative RPG; specifically, excess grinding and extra-story combat. On the downside, of course, some people will miss those things, and some will be further disappointed at the fact that this really is a specific story with a lot of beautiful text (ala PS:T), and not a free-form RPG like Baldur's Gate, where you can build a character of your choosing. However, the limited choices when it comes to character creation are still quite robust, and I didn't feel like the story was missing anything for not having, for example, more than three Focus paths to choose from. Major Pros:-Tight narrative that allows for MUCH more reactivity than I expected, making choices that felt thematically or logically correct actually have impacts (sometimes extremely significant impacts) to gameplay. Unlike BG/BGII or even PS:T, for example, sometimes a quest item is actually as useful as the person who asks you to retrieve it claims it to be...-Interesting characters with personal motivations beyond "You seem trustworthy; allow me to join YOUR noble quest!"-An interesting character with personal motivation that is EXACTLY: "You seem trustworthy; allow me to join YOUR noble quest!"Minor Pros:-Beautiful music and art-Background item descriptions blend into interactivity and actual bonuses/powers; be sure to examine all the Oddities carefully.Major Cons:-The final act was so tight that I'm willing to bet anyone who doesn't play a heavy-Intellect/Lore/etc character, AND strive for finishing side-quests, will feel like it is lacking. The major narrative is strong and well-implemented, but I think it would be easy for someone playing a different kind of character to miss some things I found and enjoyed (though, I suppose, I could be wrong, depending on the usefulness of Smashing/Quick Fingers/etc as skills to find other ways around problems).Minor Cons:-Voice acting didn't hold up to the music and art; I was OK with it, but some characters were much weaker than others in this regard. -I was surprised there are only 4 character tiers (sort of the equivalent of levels, or level-brackets) in the game, as I was assuming it would have the baseline 6 from the tabletop game. I was certainly not under-powered at the end, but when I stopped advancing, I had to go and check to see if that was a bug.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7
												What an awesome game. Please buy this game. Support these kind of classic RPGs. It's a dying art, this gaming medium of interactive storytelling. When you use your dollars to show your support, you help the writers and developers know that their work is appreciated and desired. This game is frustrating. It's frustrating in the best of ways. It's frustrating in that you can't outsmart it every time. You will make mistakes. But mistakes are OK! Mistakes sometimes lead to opportunities you wouldn't have had otherwise. Failure isn't always the end. Sometimes it's the beginning. This game is meant to challenge you. Don't savescum for best options. Accept that you'll make mistakes. Burn through your limited resources. But talk to -everyone-. So many people have a story. So many of them might have some hidden secret for you. I think that's what I loved best about this, was digging through the small secrets and finding big ones. The characters were fun and interesting to play with, the setting was weird and alien and macabre and funny-- it reminded me so much of the original Torment, a game with such a weirdly alien setting that no one should feel 'comfortable' there. You will fulfill and subvert tropes almost constantly. This game isn't a challenge to be summited. It's a story to be read-- an experienced to be shared.

												Piece of advice before you buy this game: expect a lot of reading. If you are not a reader, do not get this game. It is that simple. A few of the 'negative' reviews seem to have to do with the amount of reading this game throws at you. Do not get the game for the combat, get it for the story, the characters. You can get by with very little combat, actually, depending on how you play your character. There are a variety of ways that you resolve a single quest and develop your playstyle in the process. This game has more depth than you realize, although it does need some polishing to be honest, and I won't lie: I'm a bit disappointed in the cut content despite knowing that's a reality all game developers face. I hope that the developers can continue to polish this game now that it's been released and add more content that can address some of the concerns other people have. I still say, however, this game is worth the purchase.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												This game is getting a thumbs-up from me, WITH qualifications. Also, since the game labels itself as a spiritual successor to Planescape:Torment, I will be making references to that masterpiece. Also, some SPOILERSBefore you decide if you want to get this game, you need to figure out if you love to read. Personally, I love reading, so this game is a few steps up for me. The prose is effective and appreciated. If reading is a chore for you, skip this game. I say skip it in that particular instance because the combat system is not sufficient to make this game stand on it's own. In fact, the game has no real challenge of its own due to a problem within its mechanics. See, for any skill check or combat check, you will use your pool of stat points as a finite resource. This could be a potentially interesting system, especially if you combine this fact with the notion that even failure on skill checks brings a reward (sometimes even a better reward). You would have a system where failure was as common as success, leading to an almost real-life scenario where people fail and live with the consequences.Except the Edge mechanic burns this system to the ground.As you level, you will eventually get Edge points for your stat pools. In essence, Edge gives you free points to spend on a task EVERY TIME you attempt a task using that stat pool, e.g., 3 Edge for intellect means 3 free points spent every time you attempt an intellect task or attack. This corresponds to a rough 45% increase for your chances for success. For free.Then you specialize one character per stat pool, and you'll never fail a roll again. Ever. Taking the uncertainty out of the system was a mistake, particularly since combat does NOT have variety in its abilities. In fact, Planescape:Torment had more combat options. Let that sink in; a game from 1999 had more combat options and variety than one released in The Year of Our Lord Two Thousand and Seventeen. Sigh.And since we are on the subject of comparison, let's compare companions. PS:T's companions not only had more depth and backstory, but they all revolved around the theme of that game; "What can change the nature of a man?" T:TON's companions, while ranging from acceptable to pretty good, never achieve the success of its predecessor because they don't cleave to the theme of their own game: "What does one life matter?"In fact, the game doesn't really deal with this theme either. If we saw, more directly, how the tidal manipulations of the other castoffs and the Last Castoff himself truly hurt the people around them, we could see the tension between hurting others by merely existing. However, it all rings false when I play my character like a paladin and improve the lives of almost everyone around me: Sagus Cliffs and most of its serious problems resolved, including the removal of the adversaries, who want to wipe out all life on Earth, yet I'm told at the end of the game, and not really before in any significant way, "sorry, your existence makes life miserable for anyone you come in contact with" I can't help but roll my eyes at the fact that my suspension of disbelief lies bleeding on the ground before me. Outside of this attempt using the titular tides to move the theme, there are no other appeals to "what does one life matter/"Also, some really annoying sound effects tied to buffs can't be turned off. REALLY ANNOYING effects.So why the heck am I giving this game a thumbs-up? Because the whole is greater than its parts. Any one system from this game held up to the light looks mediocre at best, but when put together with everything else, it... works, and I don't regret a single hour of the 22 I spent beating the game. It doesn't come close to topping Planescape:Torment, but it doesn't have to. This is a fairly well-written game that takes lots of risks; while those risks don't always pan out, I prefer developers to take risks and fail on occasion as opposed to playing it safe, Assassin's Creed style.TL:DR If you like to read, give it a shot; not as good as PS:T but still good.

content:
Posted: March 9
												I think it's a very interesting, and overall very good game. Would I recommend it? Yes, for sure. Alas, it isnt a game for just anyone.tl;dr: If you like reading, and like slow pacing, and you are looking for something fresh and in some ways unique, with characters that have their own stories and are memorable (at least some of them), you liked Planescape Torment, and have enough time and have ability to focus, go ahead and get the game!On the other hand - if you can't focus, prefer fast pacing, are action oriented, and you are more Pillars of Eternity type of RPG player, with more fighting, dungeon crawling, and you arent interested in companions at all, but progress and very visible main story is important for you - you may not enjoy Tides of Numenera. What did I enjoy? What did I think was done right?+ The world/setting is very good and pretty interesting. It does have that bit weird feeling to it, as Planescape Torment had.+ Characters are very good. They aren't just a stat-sticks, that you drag along. They have their stories, their opinions, and the world reacts to them.+The game is story driven, and the story is good.+Quests are very interesting, because they can be solved in so many ways! And I don't mean: just one-or-two possible solutions. There's plenty!+it's a game you can re-play and discover many new things on your next playthrough. I think it is worth re-playing and I am just about to do that.+After you finish the game, and will look up the achievements that you can get, you're like: 'wow, is that really possible to do THAT? I need to try!' The game is flexible, and the more effort you will put into it, the more things you will discover.+Combat system - it's new, and fresh. It is turn wise, and at first I wasn't convinced, because I hate turn system with a passion, but in this game, the turn system has it's merits. It isnt used only for combat. It's more narrative, you can even try to talk to your adversaries at times and try to get them to your side. It's different from just - go and kill everything that moves.+You don't like fighting? You don't have to fight. At all. There are many ways to solve the problems, and fighting is only one of options.What I think they could improve:-No intro/movie at the begining - I couldn't care less for the cutscenes, but because there is no intro, you are plunged into a world you know nothing about, story you know nothing about, and you get all those seemingly random quests you just go and do, without really knowing why the heck are you here and what is your purpose.  BUT! Give it a chance, the more you will play, the more you will understand, and the more you will see that 'random' quests arent as random as you think they are :-)- There is just too much of text! Wall of texts absolutely everywhere, make your attention go away quickly. But if you will pay attention and go slow, it will seriously pay offOverall I think that it's a very good game, and I am very happy it got released. They did cut some content, but what is left in the game is well made. At first, I was very confused and didn't like the game too much, because I had no idea what's going on, and it smelled too much like a weaker copy of Planescape Torment. But I gave it a fair chance, and I am very pleased that I did. The story isn't a copy-paste of Planescape, which I did dread for a time, it has many options and you can play as you like. So it's honestly a game to experience.I am very pleased that I got it, that I didn't quit, and I am totally going to re-play. I consider the game Time well spent.

content:
Posted: March 16
												Mixed feelings about this game but I would sum it up like this: Very buggy, NOT ready for release!The bad first: Really, it is awful due to constant crashes. I have a little over 60 hours logged with this game now and I would say over a quarter of that time is wasted on crashes due to hangs etc (memory leaks?) in Crisis battles. After 5 hours wasted on the brain fight in the last two days I have given up and come here to justifiably slag the game off! As a number of other players everywhere have reported the same issue I find it hard to believe they were not fully aware of this problem in beta testing and released it anyway.I assume it's a memory management/leak or similar as it's fine until you get a crisis with several adds, then the memory usage jumps up to 2Gb, 3Gb and keeps climbing and the game freezes.If - hopefully when - they fix this, then - and only then - would I say, yes, it's a great game with plenty to offer.  Fixed, it is a refreshing chance to level up by questing and solving problems and puzzles and having your actions alter the game. Mindless kills mobs to gain levels get so tiresome after a while, so in this respect the game is a winner.But, as I say, unless/until they fix the issue with crashes during crisis events, then give it a wide berth.( Writing writing as at patch 1.01 ) This review reflects that the game is not fully playable, rather than how playable it is!

												pro:* great storytelling* mind-blowing setting* great quests, with many different possible endings* no good/bad morality system, rather an five-different-affinities system, which allows also for mixed affinities (are you e.g. more the knowledge-seeker, or more the narcissist, ...)* good-looking and good-sounding game (for my taste)con:* combat can feel a bit clunky, in particular since there are chances to miss attacks. All in all, this is a great rpg in the spirit of Baldurs Gate. If you are into that sort of thing (including reading a *lot* of text), then this is your game. I love it! It is rather slowly paced, though, so if you get bored easily, then this might be not for you. I don't like the combat, but then again you can talk (or sneak) your way around many encounters, without missing too much, in particular it is not the killing of enemies which gives XP, but the resolution of problems (and acquisition of knowledge).

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10
												I just finished this game and enjoyed it pretty much. It is a successor of Planescape: Torment in a way that it is an exploratory game. T:TON is about discovering the denizens of the sixth world, finding clever solutions to people's problems, using junk you found on the way to invent new solutions. It is fantastic, the quests are well thought-out, the game truly shines in this aspect, every quest has several solutions, you can find another one and another one way to get what you want. You can see the amount of love and care that was sunk into this game and it really makes a difference.To add to this the designers managed to solve a problem as old as crpgs: How to avoid ruining the whole experience by saving/restoring. It is pretty hard to die, yet characters have three pools which they can use to solve different tasks which refresh every time they sleep. If you sleep a lot, you can solve every problem that can arise, with a little twist: Some quests change when you sleep, some goals become unattainable as time passes. This system is brilliant and most likely will become a new basic mechanic for crpgs. The world itself is beautiful and exciting, however I feel it is a bit fragmented, some cohesion would have made it even better. Several companions can be hired, most of them are interesting, and have rich backstories. The story of the game is enjoyable, not as great as P:T's but still entertaining and iimmersive. Considering everything I can only recommend this game to everyone.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13
												Many reviews (and the game's marketing) focus on its credibility as a spiritual successor to Planescape: Torment, or lack thereof. For people wondering how it compares: overall, it doesn't quite reach the same level of storytelling as its ancestor. It's also significantly shorter, with my first full playthrough clocking in at about 25 hours with almost all of the sidequests completed. I completed the entire game with only two combat encounters, and, although the combat system is uniquely designed and fun when it works (it's certainly much better than the endless waves of enemies in PS:T's Baator), its frequent bugs and the very, very slow turn-based movement eventually take the fun away. Because there are so few unique locations in the game, the world also feels much smaller and somehow less memorable than that of PS:T.Despite all this, you'll notice that I've still recommended this game. That's because, if you move away from the gigantic shadow of nostalgia that PS:T casts over it, this game is still incredibly fun, presenting a great array of dialogue options and possible actions to resolve situations. Many encounters, despite seeming linear, can actually be replayed in a vast variety of ways which have small impacts on subsequent situations in the game. I also enjoyed the stat-based system, which, although simple, fits with the overall feel of the game. Picture Baldur's Gate 2's Athkala, with all the combat replaced by stat checks and RNG, except with more depth to the NPCs and more nuanced dialogue choices and ways to resolve conflicts. If that sounds like something you'd enjoy, buy this game.I've also seen a lot of comments about the companions. If we're comparing them to PS:T - they're more interesting than Falls-From-Grace, but none of them manage to beat Morte. Companions have many interjections and their own story arcs, although the most fleshed out companions are Erritis, Rhin, and Matkina by far. The former two are particularly memorable, and resolving their quests actually felt like it had far-reaching consequences. Their character arcs are incredibly satisfying. While the other companions also have multiple resolutions (or none) to their quests, they feel more "standard" and less reactive than the others, who actually have evolving dialogue as you discover more about them (like Dak'kon).In conclusion, even though it was short and not as memorable as its predecessor, the overall package makes for a very good game. It suffers because it's not "great", like PS:T was. But if you play with an open mind and don't expect it to be exactly the same, you've still got a solid RPG with storyline branching, interactive companions, excellent NPCs, and very interesting and unique quests. Recommended for RPG fans.

content:
Posted: March 9
												I had relatively low expecations for this game, and was very pleasantly surprised. I was hoping for an rpg/adventure where exploration and dialogue counted far more than grinding away at combat, and that's what I got along with a solid story, fun setting, great writing, and entertaining companions.Did inXile hit it out of the park? Well, if you compare it to the original PST, then obviously, they did not. The game is smaller, occasionally frustratingly so, and not nearly as ambitious. (although one of the upsides of the relatively small size is that there's virtually no filler) But that's an absurdly high bar. Compared to other indie(ish) RPGs like PoE, Wasteland 2, Shadowrun Returns, AoD or Tyranny, it's difficult to not call Torment: Tides of Numenara an excellent game. (unless the whole "lots of talk and hardly any combat" concept is not to your taste)Actually, speaking of other similar titles... I think it's absurd and unfair that this game is currently far worse reviewed than, for example, a game like Tyranny - which had a lot of potential, but was clearly released unfinished, and features far too much pointless filler. I think many of the poor reviews are less about objective judgement and more about shattered, impossibly high hopes.

content:
Posted: March 10
												I'd recommend this game at a $30 price point.The Awesome - I loved the art, loved the story and the writing as a whole.  They did a great job creating worlds and characters that will stay with me for awhile.  The blend of sci-fi and fantasy was refreshing.  I thought Planescape was well served in these regards.The Okay - I enjoyed the original game mechanics (spending of attribute resources to accomplish tasks and pass checks) but certainly felt they could have done a better job detailing character progression.  Every level/tier I gained was a surprise in regards to what skills and abilites would automatically be doled out.  I had already invested time, money and points into a number of them having no idea that I would get them for free a level later.  The Penny Pinching - The technical execution re: animation, models and combat polish was quite frankly amateur.  There's no excuse for not having matching character models and portraits, no NPC portraits during conversation and in-game armour for the main character only.  There's a ton of other shortcuts taken but I digress.  It's the little details like this that make a good game great.  It cheapened the experience and made you wonder what they spent all that money on.  The phyiscal game itself reminded me of a "hidden object" game in terms of production value.  Obviously not the games strong suit.Ultimately it's a well written storybook with some beautiful backdrops and whimsical art.  The game itself leaves you with a sad sense of what might have been as it feels like they dropped a finely tuned engine (the writing) into a cheaply made car.  I hope they get a second chance to right the wrong because what matters most is certainly there.

content:
Posted: April 6
												7.5 / 10 Another long time CRPG / PS:T player here.If there wasn't so much hype about this being the spiritual predecessor to Planescape : Torment it could be an 8+/10 game. It is a high-quality title certainly worth the time to explore with some niggling design issues. Disclaimer, I intentionally started playing this at version 1.02 after a lot of early bugs were squashed that possibly plagued earlier users.I'll start with the good. Big props to the immensely detailed environments and the intricately written stories / mini-stories you will encounter. The sheer whackyness and ambience did certainly (on occasion) rival/mirror the experiences that made PS : T great.The bad: By far the biggest let down was the poor companion character development. Very little emotional depth and story development to your tag-alongs which was one of the best parts of PS : T! Huge omission. Also mid-to-late game it feels like there are no difficult challenges combat either combat or skill-check wise. So long as you've spread your skills out between party members, you almost never fail. Also the story intensity arc is ratherflat throughout the game, meaning the ending feels almost arbitrarily tacked on and somewhat anti-climatic.In summary, this game's entertainment value comes in the sheer randomnessand quirkyness of the Ninth World and it's numenera coupled with very detailed artwork and writing. The main story, combat and emotional development does however feel like it gets lost in this detalied randomness at times.

content:
Posted: March 17
												Couldn't put it down (on GOG). I love that each item, place, person, etc. has its own place in the world, makes you wonder. You run into a superintelligence with enigmatic motivations, then a group of soldiers broken by endless battles where they died over and over, and then round the corner to talk with a time traveler who can't remember how they started but remember meeting you countless times.A few things are explored in depth, but there is much more breadth than depth. I liked taking each idea and imagining how it would work. How would you function if you were one among an infinite number of alternate versions of yourself, a human GPU? What would you do with the energy of a star?The weakpoints are mostly a matter of going in with the wrong perspective. You HAVE to be willing to read; almost all of the best parts are through text. The combat will not stand on its own, don't expect Pillars or Tyranny or Baldur's Gate. The villains and side-characters are great, but companions are unfortunately shallow.The game is a dense, weird, compelling scifi book about possibilities, with a good dash of choice. Expect that, go in with the attitude, and love it.

content:
Posted: March 19
												(Full disclosure: Kickstarter backer)I aboslutely loved the original PS:T, and consider this a worthy successor.  As good as the original?  Well, no.  But I consider that the greatest CRPG ever made, so nothing else compares that well either.  Nonetheless, this game has faithfully recreated a similarly mysterious world in which you can spend hours unravelling its mysteries.  It's fantastic fun to dig around numerous NPCs and interactables for little bits of knowledge or small rewards.  If you liked Planescape:Torment, or NeverWinter Nights 2's Mask of the Betrayer, then you'll definitely enjoy this.As far as downsides go, the game definitely isn't perfect.  First off, the combat is not terribly enjoyable.  PS:T's was bad too, but this is worse.  On the upside, your choices can avoid almost all of them.  The companions also don't hold up as well as the original -- several of them are not nearly as quirky, interesting, or interactive.  Lastly, there's a _LOT_ of reading.  Even compared to PS:T.  Plenty of the language is used is...overly complicated.  Esoteric words, etc.  Not necessarily a downside, but I can't recall another game that made me consult a dictionary as often -- and that's from an avid CRPG fan and book reader.There's also plenty of Kickstarter drama surrounding this game, but don't let that concern you.  TToN was funded at the height of Kickstarter's popularity, yet before developers got good with managing promises and rewards.  Combined with poor communication on their part, and it resulted in some upset backers.  But the game stands on its own, and is still worth playing.I would hands down recommend this to any fan of the original PS:T or NWN2: MotB.  If you like CRPGs, and don't mind a word-heavy low-combat game, then you'll probably enjoy this as well.

content:
Posted: April 15
												I was an early backer for this game after hearing about it in conjuction with the Numenera tabletop RPG, and I have to say it lived up to its expectations well. The story is very solid with lots of decision points and tidbits to uncover.The gameplay follows the Numera tabletop system very closely, but still proves incredibly fun to play on PC. For newcomers used to typical RPGs, it's worth noting that not all "Combats" have to be resolved with violence. Unique to this game, though familiar to tabletop gamers, is the idea that many environs can be used to solve encounters in place of swords, and that's assuming you don't just talk them down.The game itself captures the world and atmosphere of Numenera to an amazing degree, really bringing out the sense of living in a world loaded with things beyond our ken that players can somehow finagle to accomplish something. Not to mention the fun of exploring everything the world has to offer and uncovering many different secrets.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19
												I would recommend this game but with some reservations. It might be best to get the game when the price drops or after future patches and added/re-added content. I enjoyed playing the game, with three different playthroughs, but not without some criticism. The very nature of this being hyped up as a spiritual sucessor to Planescape: Torment already set expectations too high and caused them to over-promise, which ended up coming back to bite them. But taken for what it is, it is a decent game. It just could have been more.  World/Story - The setting is imaginative and intrigueing and the story is pretty good. The plot is a bit linear and, unfortunately, it feels a little rushed in the 2nd half of the game. Relative to my expectations for an RPG, the game's playtime is dissapointingly short and the areas are small. You get a strong sense that they had earlier iterations that were much more epic and had twice as many locations, but they ended up cutting out half of it. That's probably the biggest dissapointment for me. It's all over too quickly. Character Progression - On a related note, the level cap comes a little too quickly, at least if you play as a completionist and do all side quests. This is a feel bad thing in any RPG. In all three of my playthroughs, my main character reached the cap with about 1/4 of the game left. There was 1600+ experience past that which I couldn't use. That's easily enough XP for another 2 Tiers. If they added abilities for 2 more tiers, they could easily raise the cap to 7. Choice and Consequence - This is probably one of the aspects that they nailed pretty good. There are usually at least 2 or 3 ways to resolve most quests, sometimes with vastly different results. There are also lots of variable dialogue options that affect your tides. That said, in the long term plot, there isn't as much of a sense that your choices matter as there could be. It's all sort of foisted upon you as you're rushed to the ending. Graphics/Art/Music - The area backgrounds look beautiful and are well done. The character/NPC avatars are much more simplistic and clunky in comparison. The background music is pretty good for setting atmosphere, though maybe a bit empty at some points. You do get a sense sometimes that there was extra graphical/animation polish that existed in earlier iterations that they took out. This aspect is not that big of a deal to me though. Dialogue - It should be expected for this type of game that there is a lot of dialogue. This isn't a bad thing in and of itself. Anyone who wants a hack and slash dungeon crawl doesn't get what a game like this is supposed to be about. That said, sometimes they got overly verbose for details that didn't matter. 90% of the game is reading text and it could have been paced out better with a little more combat and exploration. Even Planescape: Torment wasn't as heavy on the text-adventure aspect as this is. Combat - Combat isn't quite as bad as some people are saying. It isn't a great though and the Crisis system can get buggy. With the relatively few combat encounters there are, and the fact that you can talk your way out of most of them, players may feel like they rarely get to use their combat abilities and thus character progression feels a bit empty. Much the same goes for all of the Cyphers, which are unique one-time use items, but you don't get enough of a chance to actually use them. Skill System - The general idea of the skill system is pretty good. The way they implimented it, however, probably makes the game a bit too easy. With investment in Intellect based skills, Edge points, plus the ability to use your companions to help with skills, it is easy to pretty quickly get to a point where skill checks are no longer a challenge. With a few exceptions, after the beginning it's possible to breeze through most of the game's skill checks regardless of your character build. Needs to be rebalanced with more risk and limitation. Tides - This is one of the most interesting and flavorful aspects of the game. The way that your choices determine your tides and the world subtly reacts is pretty well done. My one complaint about the tides is that I wish there were more explicit ways you can use them in gameplay. With a few exceptions, the tides are just a display of the morality of your actions and are not as reactive as they sold it to be, within a given playthrough. The subtle effects of the tides do show more across multiple playthroughs though. Companions/NPCs - Aside from Rhin and maybe Castillege, the companions don't feel as fleshed out as they could be. There is a significant lack of companion interaction, party banter, and voice acting in general. The game also pretty much encourages you to choose a team in the first area and stick with it, and there's no going back to the first area once you leave. There are no mid or late game companions. The lack of NPC portraits also takes away from immersion. Also, unlike Planescape: Torment, most non-quest-related NPCs can't truly be interacted with, they just show one liners above their head if you click them. Basically, I think the game has a lot of cool ideas and potential, but they just didn't flesh it out as much as they could have, or they gutted their own ideas a little too much to a point where quite a few features that were either promised or that actually existed in earlier iterations of the game ended up being left out entirely (including: NPC portraits, more voice acting, more companions, two or three more game areas that could have easily added 10-20 more hours of content, and so on). That makes the game feel a little empty or over streamlined.With all of that criticism, I still would recommend the game because it is still a unique experience, it has a unique setting and story, and it has its share of flavor. In some basic ways, they did capture the feel of Torment, they just could have refined it more instead of putting time and money into making it a console port and over streamlining content. I also am holding out hope that there will be future patches and add-ons that make up for at least some of the criticism.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17
												This game takes place in a world that kept me going "oooh", "aaah" and "what is THAT" constantly, and this is coming from someone who has read/watched/played dozens of different fantasy/sci-fi worlds.The Ninth World is alien, strange, wonderous, and the amazing writing makes it real. Every area has its own set of characters, creatures, structures, landmarks, quests, etc. I almost never bother with sidequests in any game, and on my first playthrough I did 90% of them - and was rewarded in more ways than one.Most (if not all) quests offer interesting thoughts and some tough dilemmas that will make you ponder on the "right" answer before you choose an action, and even after you do, you might wonder if it was the best of all decisions.The game mechanics are easy to get and offer customization for each character class, allowing for different playthroughs with significantly different abilities.While I did play the original Planescape: Torment, I don't bother comparing it to this one because, quite frankly, it's pointless. I was 17 when I played it (more than a decade ago!), it took place in a different world, with a different system, and different writing team and standards. The first of the series was great, unique game, but the only thing you can possibly compare to the newer one is the writing, and even that is a case of "apples vs oranges".My only complaint is that the turn-based combat is a bit too slow due to the AI taking very long to act. The mechanics work fine, but the speed could be better. Not enough to make me dislike the combat, but enough to note it.

number of helpful: 31 of 67 people (46%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7
												This is actually a complex game to rate, as there are a number of positives and negatives. So, without further ado, let's start by the positives: - The setting and ruleset: This one will look like a negative, but it's actually a positive. Numenera, the tabletop RPG, sells itself as innovative both in terms of settings and rules. Sadly, it is not, in either case. That is not to say it is a bad RPG in any way. It is not. It just oversells its “science-fantasy” setting, when it is really just fantasy with an interesting makeover.In the same sense, while it attempts to portray itself as an avant-garde, alternative game, which favors roleplaying and exploration, it is basically a simplified D20 RPG with pretentious names, not getting even close to real RP-heavy settings, such as FATE, or even WoD. Although I do realize this makes the game look very bad, it isn’t. It just isn’t what it attempts to sell itself as.Those issues, however, doesn’t affect the PC game. The rules, which aren’t really that good for a P&P game, work really well on the PC, and the setting translated very well for the electronic media. I was actually quite impressed.- The theme and mood: as stated above, the setting clicked very well with the engine used, and it oozes with character. In this one regard the game succeeds greatly in doing its stated purpose of being a rebirth of Planescape: Torment, with interesting scenarios and exotic NPCs.- The plot: although only the beta has been released so far, and only for backers like me, it was easy to see that the story is well written and woven in the game itself.And now, sadly, we move to the bad:- Your companions: in a nutshell, many of them are bland at best, and tremendously annoying at worst. While I did like some of those, the game starts poorly, by not letting you have both the real interesting ones, which are clearly the most relevant to the story, with you at the same time. I can only hope that this changes as the story progresses, but I am not optimistic about it. The glowing Glaive (that is a warrior, for the not overly pretentious RPG players) is one of the most annoying NPCs I ever had the displeasure of having on a party, and that includes James Vega! Which brings us to two related issues…- No romance: for some insane reasons, Numenera forbids you from having romance options. While this stance is forgivable on games such as Tyranny, where every NPC either hates you or is terrified of your very shadow, or Pillars, which basically had only the most superficial interaction with your companions – to name recent examples – Numenera, in theory at least, is a game about your interactions and relationships. And now the game intends to tell you that, in a game about interpersonal relationships, there can be no romance?This is probably the (second) worse sin this game committed, and the one that made me want to ask for my Kickstarter money back, if that were possible. Let me be clear: I am not talking about sex scenes. I believe we all had more than enough claynimation sex scenes with Mass Effect and Dragon Age. However, the lack of romance in a game about RPing is not only prudish and a little schizophrenic, but a real offense to the sensibilities of any reasonable human being, who knows that, in a tightly knit-group of people working a living together, romance is almost certain to bloom. This was the main deal breaker for me personally, and it wasn’t even the worst problem with the game. That would be…-Misrepresentation: one could call it more simply, lies. As I said, one of the main issues with the game are the either annoying, irrelevant or simply uninteresting companions that can join you in the game. That might have not been a problem if only there were more of them. Sadly, in a one-sided decision by inXile, they decided to cut one third of the possible companions in the game, and two of the most interesting ones at that!Added to that, many features were cut, such as crafting. And to put the cherry on top, the company was “unable” to inform the players about said changes, only doing so a few weeks before release.Unfortunately, despite the game’s no irrelevant qualities, I find myself unable to recommend it to other players.

content:
Posted: March 15
												It seems like there is a lot of hate directed at the game, mostly from backers, and it mostly boils down to tantrums about this not being a PST reboot.Honestly, I found the game quite enjoyable.  It has an intriguing (I am fairly certain that I misspelled that, but I am seriously not going to be bothered to spell check it - or anything else for that matter - so deal with it) game world, it has interesting quests and solutions.  Furthermore, to be quite honest, it is a bit of fun playing a RPG where you can actually avoid combat in almost all instances.  Does this make it an adventure game as some suggest?  Why?  What is the core concept behind a RPG - that there has to be combat? For reals now?  It is an RPG.  It gives you the choice - you can fight, or not, its up to you.The game breaks away form most RPG convetions, which also seems to be causing a lot of tantrums, which I dont fully understand.  Should every RPG include the same 6 stats?  What is the big hub-hub about something different?I find this game refreshing and interesting.  It does not adhere to all the norms of C(conventional)RPGs.  It took me some time to get used to it, and to be honest, several hours in, some of it still feels slightly odd, but I can live with it.On another note, unlike Pillars, the game has had me laugh a lot more.  There is a bit of humour in there.

content:
Posted: March 6
												I was a huge Fan of Planescape Torment and considered it the best written story in a game for the PC.  Planescape Torments charm came not only from it's narrative but also from it's characters and who they interacted wtih the world, and with each other.Torment Tides of Numenera had some huge shoes to fill!   Tides of Numenera just about fills those shows.  Does the game feel like Planescape Torment?  Yes it does right down to the ending.Torment Tides of Numenera is a Really Great RPG and one that is worth reading, I mean taking.   For what the game is it's done really well, it's very tight story.   Could it be better?  Yes of course it could be better but what they accomplished is really good.  The story is fantastic right to the end.  You will find yourself invested in the game and you will end up making some pretty tough choices through out the story.The characters all have unique stories and personalities.   The Battles which are called Crises all of different ways of reaching the goals.It's pretty wild world with a Giant Transdimensional Organism as one of it' stars.I really recommend Torment Tides of Numerna if you are a fan of Planescape Torment.  If you love fantasy and scifi I would recommend playing the game just to go through the story.Let's see this world expanded more with a Torment Tides of Numera 2.

Posted: March 22
												"Torment: Tides of Numenera" is a game that is not for everyone.There's a lot of reading, so if you're illiterate, I tell you here and now, stay away from this title.Many people will find the combat system is not to their liking, and there are plenty of other aspects to this game which the vast majority will complain and wine about, as this is a game that does not fit into their perfect world view of what they perceive as a quality purchase.I personally enjoyed this game quite completely.I experienced no issues with running the game.I had no qualms about the combat, on the few occasions where I felt fighting was necessary or perhaps unavoidable.I enjoyed the artwork and the graphical style, though I longed for more detail, the abstract nature of the models and descriptive text presented in game, gave my imagination room to breath and expand.I found delight in the main story and side stories and interwoven events that made me feel as though my choices actually mattered, rather than having those choices just lead to the same result as in similar games.YOU may not enjoy this game. YOU might even hate this game and regret purchasing it.However YOU! Yes YOU, in the back there, standing and staring blankly off into space.You're going to play this game and come away feeling satisfied and a little thrilled.You are like me, but not exactly like me.YOU should try "Torment: Tides of Numenera" for yourself.No, not you... I was talking to the other guy... girl... over ther-- oh they're gone.Nevermind. This game is not for everyone.

content:
Posted: March 13
												I was a backer and have now completed the game. I consider it a worthy successor to Planescape: Torment. The game system:The effort system works a lot better for this kind of story than AD&D 2nd ed did. It's easy to pick up, and you are forced to choose when to invest resources in a particular outcome, and how companions can aid you. It's okay as a tactical combat simulator; not the best, but this game isn't really about combat, and combat was frankly the weakest part of Planescape.The story:I think it was better told, and coalesced nicely with some things illuminating what came before and some just being side stories, and it not being immediately obvious which was which. I think the philosophical message/underpinnings were a little clearer in Planescape, but Numenera feels a little more personal, and better at the gradual reveal of the true story going on. Stability:Pretty good. Once or twice a combat would go a little wonky and a character would lose their turn, but otherwise I played for 20+ hours and didn't crash or run into any noticable bugs. Graphics:For an isometric game, it's beautiful. The different areas have a strong sense of art direction and consitency, and the words used to paint the rest of the picture did the job admirably. I never felt that everyone was speaking stupid because it was a video game.On the whole, I give it a strong thumbs up. It tells an interesting story, has gameplay that forces you to make interesting decisions, and doesn't overstay its welcome.

content:
Posted: March 6
												A very "Torment" experience. Combat is much better than in the original Planescape: Torment (where it was adapted from dungeo-crawling AD&D 2 and never felt right). Texts are plentiful. Locations are exotic.The companions, probably, not as good as ones in PT, but then again, I only ever really like Morte and his jokes. The game is shorter than PT, but this might be actually good, because this kind of games wears you down a little with lack of diversity in activities (a lot of reading, and a bit of fighting).All in all, this is a good game, probably deserving of "Best writing" award for 2017, though probably not "Game of the Year". It is also an experiment in moving the gameplay balance away from combat toward dialogues and other interactions with NPCs. As an experiment, it is not enirely successful, but not a complete failure either. It's an opposite or Action RPG, where there is so much combat that it tires you out quickly. Here, sometimes you wish for talking to stop and fighting to start.

content:
Posted: March 4
												Reminiscent of Planescape: Torment, Torment: Tides of Numenera is an excellent story driven rpg. For me the most important aspect of an rpg is the developers ability to bring the world to life, this game excells in this respect with a creative, original setting and well written, varied characters. The setting is also well drawn.The isometric camera works as well as in other games of this type.Reflecting the balance of the game, the combat system is less complex than in some other games of this type, such as Pillars of Eternity. This feels appropriate given the greater emphasis on non-combat solutions.Playtime was 39 hrs for my first complete playthrough, which is probably a bit of an overestimate and is less than some other games but nevertheless felt like good value given the lack of tedious "fetch 10 of X" style quests and time wasting filler combat.Much of my enjoyment came from the text which made me lol on several occasions and the game would be less well suited to those who don't like reading in games.
