Posted: March 6
												An amazing game. So many things to read, to do, to look at. I absolutely love the writing, the characters, both companions and regular NPCs are fascinating to listen to. There are several options for almost everything. Combat is rare and almost always avoidable. One fight most of my group was fighting while one member was working on ending the fight in a different way.The world itself is great, I love getting tidbits of information about the wider world, even things that are not in the game.While in a way completely different, the game still reminds me of Age of Decadence (which has way harsher combat) and Shadowrun Returns (which is more linear) in that they are all heavily driven by lore.My main complaint would be the subpar interface. How far can you walk? Move your mouse very far away instead of showing markers whenever you are moving in combat. And of course the markers have a delay. Sometimes companions block interaction spots and you have to zoom. And sometimes interactions and movements feel sluggish. But it's not enough to make it a bad experience. Just an annoyance sometimes.

Posted: March 10
												Having played BG1 a handful of times and BG2 so many times I lost count I have been watching this game with high anticipation since it was announced on kickstarter.  I'm ~27 hours into the game at this point and am close to the end and have been having an absolute blast playing it.  My first run I chose a non-combat character to learn as much of the lore as possible and it really is one of the best I've seen in a game - the story and setting are incredibly interesting and the writing is also top notch.  I will be playing a more combat oriented character in my next game, and to be fair there are a few points that I feel might turn people off:[list[ Combat seems like to needs a little work - don't get me wrong it is fun, and I do love turn based combat systems, but something seems to be missing.  Good news is devs have announced improvements mad to it in an upcoming patch Tidal Surges - this seems like an amazing concept yet feels tacked on - I've barely had a chance to use tidal surges throughout the game and am unsure what this really adds to the game (maybe for the ending?).It really is a fun game though, and very much brings me back to the glorious settings of the old BG series.

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27
												*** Yes, but set your expectations accordingly ***I'll adress this review in particular to fans of this game's spritual predecessor, Planescape Torment.While it would be unfair to call this a bad game, it does feel like a shadow of what it could have been, to say nothing of how it stacks up against the masterpiece whose legacy it was trying to live up to, Planescape Torment.While the writing is mostly good throughout, I felt a distinct lack of the humour, quirkiness, and freshness of the title that this game is trying to imitate. It seems like this game is trying to hit many of the same keynotes that PST hit, but done without the same sense of confidence and originality. For as much as the game boasts about the word count in its script, I never felt as connected to any of my companions as I did to Morte or Fall from Grace. That's not to say that the characters your meet aren't interesting at all, but it seemed like the devs were more focued on breadth rather than depth as far as your interactions with other characters. This extends to the antagonists of the story, which felt drawn similiar yet less compelling than the antagonists of Planescape Torment.I think what the devs missed about Planescape Torment is that for all that game's (excellent) philisophical musings, they lost sight of the fact that some of the most memorable moments of that game were the humourous banter between your companions, the bizarre and quixotic situations you found yourself in. Remember getting sucked into a Modron Maze, or engaging in philosphical debates with a reformed succubbi in a brothel for quenching intellectual lusts? None of that here, I felt as if the game takes itself too seriously ( or more likely didn't have the dev time) for such interesting diversions.There is a distinct lack of polish throughout. While the digitally painted backgrounds for the most part are creative with a wonderful sense of art direction, I wish I could say the same for the character models and sound design. I also find it odd that there's no option to customize the look of your character aside from choosing a gender, and the lack of character portraits for the people you're talking to in dialogue seems a strange omission.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12
												I kickstarted this game many years ago and my name is on a gravestone! I have finished the original torment numerous times and I am a big fan.TToN is good but not great. I finished the game in ~18 hours and I believe I finished most of the side quests. I had a great time playing it so I do recommend it.Don't expect to be playing a game as good as the original Torment. Even side by side, today, the original is better. This shouldn't be a mark against TToN though because it'd be damn near hard to beat the original Torment.Good:- Story is engaging, setting is interesting- Visually impressive - lots of cool things to see and each locale was unique- I thought the bar with the psychics was the coolest part of the game. Especially tracking down who wasn't real.- Lots of talking that I didn't feel like skipping through the majority of the time.- Many of the decisions I had to make had me umming and ahhing as I agonized over them- Companions have interesting stories that made me want to know more (Especially Rhin and Erritus)- Length of game was about right for me- Combat was well implemented. I think the difficulty was about right for the game - pretty damn easy- Lots of different ways to play, but I think the Int builds were the favoured path.- I didn't encounter any bugs and the game never crashed- A couple cool Torment throwbacks (particularly a person's name, and one of the characters in the psychic bar).Overall, what was keeping this game from greatness to me was not things it did wrong, but things it didn't do at all. I'm looking forward to any further entries in the franchise and I wish the developers the best of luck.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17
												I never played Planescape Torment all the way through until some time last year. Until that point it had taken me several times to get passed the first hour. The game is dense for lack of a better word. And while the reading can be fun, it can also be laborious and confusing, particularly in the early game.Somehow. Somehow, I made it past the heavy intro and was rewarded with one of the best experiences RPGs have to offer, but I could understand why the game was so critically acclaimed and hardly played.Before I continue, I'll give the impatient folks the quick rundown. Should I buy this game? If you don't mind reading, and are open to interesting stories without the need for action. If you're a fan of the Numenera setting. If you want an RPG you can soak in, or think about for a while. Then yes. If not, or if you're only halfway into any of those suggestions, then no.The Torment series, which is what it is now, is defined by wordy texts and heady philosophy. They aren't RPGs as you may think of them, so much as they are adventure games with RPG mechanics. They also exist in bizzare settings and are not easy to get through. Not because of any mechanical challenges, but rather the literary challenge of committing time to read these things. They have more in common with the kind of narrative games you see in Japan than Mass Effect or the Witcher, which is to these game's credit in my opnion.There are bugs, but all RPGs have bugs. The bugs in my playthrough happened twice, and it was nothing a simple reset couldn't solve. I think I lost 3 minutes of gameplay at most.The combat is interesting, but could use some tweaks to make it more palatable. It's infuriating trying to move around the game world, or figuring out distances. Often a lot of effects and abilities are going off at once and there's no combat log to help you get a handle on things. It uses the Pillars of Eternity engine, which is already a cluster of nonsense checks and balances. Thankfully the largess of these combat additions aren't so important as to break the game, and combat happens very rarely.In fact, if you take a moment to pause and assess the situation before engaging in the "crises", you'll find an easy solution if brute force isn't working. Which is wonderful because it's very easy to have a team of completely useless combatants.In the end it's technically better than Planescape's combat, but also more challenging, and not always in a good way. Still, Planescape could use with much less combat, which Torment has learned from.As far as the story goes, I had a hard time getting into a lot of the text, as has been stated before, it's DENSE, and not always in a good way. Planescape was wordy as well, but there was an interesting terseness to it that drew you in, where Torment mistakes synonyms for artfulness. It's not amateurish, but it gets in the way often.Numenera also deals with complex situations and weird hard sci-fi, and the dev team went with the terrible interperetation of the setting where you have weirdness for weirdness sake. Nothing can ever just BE a thing without it needing a paragraph of complicated text describing a single object. Numenera as a setting works better when it's like Samurai Jack, Adventure Time, Star Wars or Rick & Morty. Settings where you're presented with alien worlds, but the functionality of those worlds is simple enough to follow along.Your companions are interesting, though not as charming as the ones in Planescape, though I'd blame that on the post-9/11 focus on darkness and cyncism that creeps into all writing nowadays. Nothing can ever be dark with levity, it's either insipid Joss Whedon immersion breaking smarm or overwrought seriousness, and Torment leans on the latter. In the end I'd like to learn more about them, as the ones I did get to know more I did like, but couldn't interact with on the level of the companions in Planescape. If some companions were cut to make the ones we got deeper, then I'd rather the dev team cut even more, even though all the fanboys are crying because one or two of them didn't wind up in the final cut.I remember spending an entire weekend afternoon going through the book of Zerthimon in Planescape. THAT is how you do a companion quest. The companion stories in Torment sort of flit in and out and never really solidify or change in a meaningful way. I remember the devs talking up how companions may come and go, and while the first two (Castillege and Aligern) have an interesting parting of ways, I never felt like my companions would ever really leave my side, though two of them did wind up leaving at the very end before the final fights for good and well written reasons.Now that all the complaints are out of the way, I felt Numenera was well worth my time, and I'd say it's the best of the inXile/Obsidian retro callback games they've been working on (Wasteland 2, Pillars, Tyranny, etc). I'll probably play it again some day after the updates come through.I did back this game during the kickstarter, and I did enjoy myself, and I did get my money's worth. But it's easy to think about how this game could be better. That and the requirement to actually READ and not simply mash buttons to see violence is probably this games biggest detractors for a lot of people. It isn't perfect, but then again there isn't a single great RPG that is. Not Earthbound, Planescape, Morrowind, Baldur's Gate or Vampire: the Masquerade Bloodlines. And now Torment will join the ranks of RPGs with great storylines that no one will play because reading makes them feel icky and also there are sometimes bugs. :P

content:
Posted: March 9
												Sigh. I really wanted to love it. I did enjoy quite a few parts of it. But in the end the feeling it left me with was disappointment. It feels unfinished, its concepts barely more than a sketch. A good start leads to a rushed and uninteresting ending. The majority of characters elicit no emotions from you whatsoever, they are actors in an incoherent drama you don't really care about. Some of them don't even enjoy a luxury of having a discernable personality. And as some people pointed out: a lot of text doesnt necessarily mean good writing. And yes - it is a spiritual successor to original Torment, that can't be denied. Unfortunately, the only thing which it failed to inherit is the original's quality. A game with great potential which it succeeded to fulfill only partially. I'm pressing a recommend, only because there are few if any similar games out there. That, however, does not mean that this one meets the expectations it had set for itself.

content:
Posted: March 8
												Absolutely amazing game. I was early backer and yes game had it's highs and lows through developement and yes there was some content that was cut. Game developement isn't just so straight forward process, it could be handled better but in the end I think we got a great game. I've played a lot of PnP Numenera and they just nailed the 9th World atmosphere. Story and characters are great, every NPC has nice background and you'll have walls and walls of text to read and immerse yourself in fantastic world of Numenera. Other thing is exploration, explore everything, tinker with stuff you find, try to find out how it works and what you can do with it if it works (or if it doesn't!). I didn't feel like any location was empty and bland, every map has some depth to it. Personally those things were by far most important for me.Combat still feels clunky and they are currently working on fixing freezes and crashes. That said I didn't had any problems except one game crash while I was in comat crisis. Note that this isn't combat oriented game in any means, if you go with pacifist playthrough expect something like 3-4 fights, if you want to play more agressive cast off, expect something like 15-20 or so. Other than that, I would really love to see more of everything, more cities, more maps, more foci. I can't say that this game doesn't have it's flaws, but if you like slower paced RPGs and if you like game full of flavorful characters please give it a try.If I had to give this game some rating I think it would be 8/10, it really hit the spot for me. With some work on combat, additional reactivity to your choices, more maps (mostly cut Oasis of M'ra Jolios), more foci and some general polish this game would be easily 10/10 for me.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20
												I loved the game. It made full use of the Dying Earth setting to deliver a slew of strange concepts, which I found extremely stimulating. The writing was generally of a very high calibre, and even the descriptive text I found to be a cut above almost anything else in the RPG genre (c f Pillars of Eternity where a lot of the descriptive text and worldbuilding is awwwwwfffuuullly boring and should never have made it into a finished game - though it's a good game for other reasons). I liked the reactivity built into the interactions. I replayed Planescape Torment recently and something that bothered me was how there'd often be no recognition that you'd done or learnt something. For example, I'd be well into the Clerk's Ward, having done every quest I could, and still have the exact same conversation with Pox outside the Mortuary, asking who the Dustmen are and what they believe. From what McComb said in one of the streams, this may have been a casualty of technical problems with the engine. Numenera had excellent reactivity - if I'd learnt something related to one character or which might be relevant to a quest, I'd usually have an option to bring it up in conversation in NPC interactions. Consequently, it was very easy for me to look at the situation the Last Castoff was in, think 'How would I deal with this?' or 'What would I want to know if I were in the Castoff's position?' and explore the resultant avenues of inquiry.It's probably fair to say I was most interested in the setting and writing behind the individual quests, which is where the game was strongest. Gene Wolfe's The Book of the New Sun is one of my favourite literary works of all time, and Jack Vance's Dying Earth isn't far off (honourable mention to Michael John Harrison's Viriconium - Harrison is, much like Wolfe, a technical writer par excellence). The thing I most would've wanted that the game didn't give? More! And by that, I don't mean that the game is short - I don't know exactly how long it took me; my recorded gameplay time is just under 43 hours, but I spent quite a bit of time with the game open in the background while I was doing other stuff, so I'd estimate I'm in the mid-30s for game time, which is not short. What I mean is I loved the world and quest writing so much, I'd love to have played a sprawling, Baldur's Gate 2 length game, seeing all of the weirdness that the Ninth World has to offer. But I understand this would be beyond budget and not worth the return on sales. Anyway, the game's flaws don't feel so significant to me.I can see how they would turn someone else off the game, however. Combat was flawed, for example - not irredeemably bad, but with faults in execution such as the time taken for turns, and poor encounter design. The central storyline was also not great. It didn't feel like the game's primary antagonist related particularly well to the game's purported theme, nor was it well-developed. I think the inadequate attention paid to the Sorrow is probably the biggest failing of the game's writing. An additional area to the game, in which you explore a location related to the Sorrow's origins, would have done a lot to remedy this, even if it wouldn't have fixed the direct role of the Sorrow in the story's central conflict.The Changing God was interesting and I thought dealt with well. Possibly more could have been done with him, but he's a concept which could be pushed in so many directions, and there's so much that could be done, that it'd be very hard to look at any particular use of him and say that that use exhausted his concept or executed it perfectly. Some of the flaws other people experienced I did not find - for example, I liked the companions. Again, more could have been done with them, but what is there is not bad. The only one I did not care for too much was Tybir, who was simply too generic. He wasn't done badly, so that failing is no real knock on the game. I also liked the visuals. Sure, more animations would have been nice, particularly combat animations, but I thought the art style and colouring were vivid and evocative. To summarise my view on Numenera, considered alone: I liked it a hell of a lot, and it's probably my favourite RPG since the Witcher 3, and before that... Vampire Bloodlines? Arcanum? I'd put it comfortably above other relatively recent high quality RPGs like Pillars of Eternity and Fallout New Vegas, which I also enjoyed but didn't resonate on a deep level. The writing with respect to the individual characters and the setting are top-notch, even if the central story lacks in some respects, and earns the game a place in my pantheon of great videogame storytelling experiences.How do I think it compares to Planescape Torment? Having replayed that game recently: quite well! PST is a more coherent game, from a storytelling perspective, and that gives a good argument that it is better from a literary view, but I didn't think the setting was as fascinatingly varied and exotic, and the quests aside from the central storyline weren't as consistently engaging. Combat in PST was also, rather than being deeply flawed, fundamentally bad and odious. Character wise, PST has an edge, because each companion related thematically to the central storyline, though I found that the common thread of the binding nature of torment and suffering was a little relentlessly dour.On the whole, I'd say they're closely comparable in the level of enjoyment I derived from them. I suspect my view that they are comparable in terms of overall merit is premised on my affinity for Dying earth science fantasy settings over straight fantasy settings, even ones as strange as Planescape, so take that for what its worth.

Posted: April 5
												As I have never played the original game I just started without any prior knowledge (besides the basic stuff I read up about the world).At first I was very confused and couldn't get into the story at all. Too many strange words without explenation, confusing people, places. Etc. But the more I played the more I got into it, so much that I couldn't even stop playing this game. The story is really amazing, well written and executed. I can't imagine I ever read pure text in some side thing (Mere) that had nothing to do with the main story itself, but moved me deeply. Very well done.A warning anyway. This is a RPG with a lot of text. Really a lot of text. And text that needs to be read to actually understand what is going on. This is not an action heavy RPG. You can really skip, escape, avoid all battles. There is also not the ultra loot here. So shop interfaces are very simple because there is no need for more.I highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys a deep great story with amazing art work and fantastic locations.If you came here because you played Pillars of Eternity, this is very different. The battles are turn based, there is not much loot and no vast areas to scout through some hidden artifacts.Came for the story, stayed for the story.Highly recommended. Will play it again.

content:
Posted: April 18
												This game is full of amazing ideas and insane concepts, all packed into a condensed space. Though you probably know by now, only play this if you really are in the mood to read!It's one of those things that throws so much overlapping content at you that you'll feel overwhelmed until you realize you only really have to pay attention to the stuff that interests you (ala William Gibson or Cloud Atlas). The game emulates the world it creates: everything feels old (it is really retro) and confusing; like layers upon layers of unknown culture, you are often lost, but find ways of sorting out the problems by exploring.Gameplay wise, you mostly LISTEN in this game: talk to NPCs, learn about the world, solve quests. The combat is fine thanks to it being turn-based. Inventory management is minimal, as are most systems not related to dialogue (though it can be odd that, when you level up, you are often making precise decisions about things you will never use in the game at all). The "pools" system, like RPG stats that deplete based on checks that determine if you fail or succede, is novel.It's telling that many people's favorite part of of this game are what's called "meres." Essentially when the game strips everything else away and become a simple choose-your-own-adventure. At its heart, this game is a graphical representation of a very inventive paper & pencil RPG sourcebook, which a cool story running through it.Also: If you are a fan at all of Jack Vance, you should definitely pick this up!

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11
												I've been waiting for this game since it was announced, and it was well worth the wait.The world is astoundingly detailed: everyone and everything has a meticulously crafted story.  In many places, those stories will intertwine with eachother, both on a short time-scale, and across chapters. The end result is that almost every decision you make feels important at some point or anothers.  From a mechanics perspective, the Tides are a refreshing change from black and white morality that has become so common in the past 15 years.  It leads to some interesting conversation paths, though there are times when it feels as if it was designed to have a bigger impact than it did.  The crisis system is also a novel new approach to combat.  The wide array of options in handling conflicts is incredibly unique, and led to interesting challenges.  It probably could have been featured more heavily, but the lack of  conflicts may have been due to my conversation-based playstyle in my first game.  The game does suffer a few minor issues, however.  I was absorbed in the game, but not as the player character.  So much of the game is about the world that the central character can slip your mind.  Another flaw is closely linked with the crisis sytem.  By focusing on alternate methods of conflict resolution, the violent approach feels less developed than similar RPGs. With the focus of this game being so far from combat, this doesn't feel too out of place.  Finally, the character models feel bland.  With one or two exceptions, your eyes slip away from the cast, and to the gorgous backgrounds.  The disparity between character and background visuals feels odd.All in all, this game was successful everywhere it needed to be to feel like an appropriate successor to Planescape: Torment.  The game could still use development in a few areas, and I expect that content updates in the future will help to improve on some of the problems.  It would be a real shame if the team doesn't create a follow up to fully marry the storytelling at which they've excelled with improvements to their core game.

The story and characters were good but it had a lot of downsides which I'm surprised were not fixed considering the game was in early access for so long.ConsBare minimum voice acting, even for companions.No diaogue portraits shown during conversations (can make it a bitconfusing who you are talking too, especially without voiceovers)No charactor customisation (aisde from clothing)No clothing customisation for compationsBuggy movementMissing Kickstarter promises.Considering the developement time and money this this game raised it kinda fell short of my expectations and cheaped out on some of it (like customisation, voice acting etc). content:
Posted: February 6
Early Access Review
								I finished the first act in the current beta and I wanted to share my thoughts with the community. Now I am a long time favorite of games like Baldurs Gate and Icewind Dale + pretty much all other RPG's, but I never played Planescape Torment - unfortunately, so I was excited to try this alleged successor to what many claim to be the best RPG of all time.First of, this game is different in the sense that it is a true rpg - meaning that you can actually avoid combat pretty much all together through diplomacy, threats and deception. Now to some, I imagine that might feel boring, but to me its really a treat to be entertained in an old-school kind of way. It feels like you are living in an excellent book, where your choices matter. Its also sci-fi fantasy, so don't expect to find much in terms of familiarity in neither the world itself or its inhabitants. Sure there are a few kinks here and there - but nothing gamebreaking, however the lack of character customization seems disappointing.I would recommend this game to people who enjoyed a game like Pillars of Eternity for its writing - not the combat. You absolutely have to enjoy lots and lots of complex reading, so if you are a 'big words hurt my brain' kind of person, then you will probably not like this game at all. There are no fancy coup de grace killcam animations and the actual combat feels underwhelming, but I like to think of it this way; I may find the♥♥♥♥♥of a baboon ugly, but I still like to watch it sway in the brisk wind ...Rating: 4/5

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18
												Having played Planescape: Torment many times, and with all the information I had about Torment: Tides of Numenera prior to the game released, I had the highest expectations when I bought this. Although not as great as Planescape: Torment I still think it's a good game with a good story. One of the main differences is the main character, the last castoff, that - unlike Planescape: Torment - isn't the main focus of the story and is more of a tool/vessel whom the story unfold around. The game is more 'a' journey than 'my' journey. The roleplaying game is toned down and the emphasis is on the narrative. The companions, with a few exceptions, feels less likable and interesting compared to those in Planescape: Torment. I wish the developers had dared to go further with their imagination in the creating process.Very nice graphics. I loved it. Sagus Cliff, the Bloom...beautiful, fascinating. Characters, for example the last castoff, is unfortunately quite "robotic" and the visual effects of spells/effects on characters a bit annoying after a while.Music is great, especially in the beginning - ambient - though there were an overall lack of songs that stood out, like "Fortress of Regrets" in Planescape: Torment. Sound effects are sometimes too prominent.Many of the quests and sidequests are even better than those in Planescape: Torment. Lots of different ways to solve them with lots of different results.    New system for skills, abilities and fighting. I like it and I think it's promising. The biggest problem is that it's too easy. In the beginning of the game it's ok but quickly the challenge disappears. You fail a skillcheck because you choose to (can sometimes give interesting results), not because you run out of skillpoints.  8/10Knowing what I know now, do I regret buying it at full price? No.Will I buy any expansion in the future? Yes.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1
												Hello all,I am early in the game and from what I could see, the game is good, but not good at the same time.I am really hesitating between recommanding and not recommanding the game at the same time.First, the game is gorgeous, you can't say they didn't make a great work there, the pillars of eternity engine is certainly great (though I would have liked some coop like baldur's gate).Then the story, the story is certainly worth it, it is really well written, intriguing and you really want to go deeper into it.The narrative is certainly the strongest point of the game with some stuff I could argue about like the change of scenery coming out of nowhere which in game is only a story, you take a couple minute to get into and by the time you're into it, you're back in reality... Some game effects could have been added to make more immersion.Music and narration goes along with it, all pleasant and makes you want to hear more.The the mechanics, the gameplay, the combat system... Well, let's start by saying that turn based combat isn't bad, I personnaly like turn based when it is well made such as fallout 1,2 or more recently divinity original sin!BUT WHY OH WHY CHANGING THE MECHANICS SO MUCH??? The first torment was a blast combat wise... This one is really a deception... They threw away the D&D mechanics relative to the Torment universe to create a really poor system with 3 stats (might, speed and intellect) which form a "pool" from which you can drain points to perform successful actions or having a chance to fail them... Meaning, if you make a warrior, you will have high might and most likely succeed your might test all the time until your might goes down to 0 ! (example if you have 9 in might, you make an action and decide to spend 3 points to succeed it, you will have 6 left in might until you can replenish it)The system is horribly bad, just like the cyphers which are kind of like a one time use magic object.Going away from the classic D&D rule set is the biggest mistake they made, they should have conserved it even if it would cost more to have the right to use them! Which also did cost them the class system which is down to the nano (the mage/mechanic), the jack (jack of all trade, master of none, kind of rogue) and the warrior, well, what's more to say about it? Master of weapons and armors.Heck, even taking the pillars of eternity system would have been better! It was their engine so why not take their combat system instead of this horrible pool system!Even by beeing a warrior with everything in might, if you empty your pool, you can fail a test... Same with the nano I am playing with right now.Finally, the interface is really blend and I would have appreciated to see the portrait of NPC you're talking to avoid confusion while reading a dialog between more than 2 characters because this ask you to be really attentive to each name popping during a conversation.The dialog window could have been made better to avoid the need to scroll down when making a choice.Appart from that, the game, the animations of the decor, the story, everything is great and is the reason why I would recommend the brilliant writing of the scenario... Don't play Tides of Numenera hoping to get a deep RPG system... The RPG is all about the story and what it will make you discover althought many already state the story feels short.Fort a 50$ game, this is quite a let down! I am finally glad I didn't back the game.The world while seeming quite alien is lacking of mystical creatures and npc like the modrone, the black knight, morte, Anna, Ignis... And all the fun, weird, original and deep characters which could travel alongside with you in the original game. They made us go back to something classic.

Game ran flawlessly for me thorugh dialogue and battles alike.For the folks with negative reviews - not having a name and the amnesia are part of the story, explained rather well near the end of the game.  If you have completed the game and have read stuff...Yes, you can largely avoid combat.  I avoided 90% I suppose?  The other 10% I was able to solve without slaughtering everything on the map (even during a battle there are ways to end it sooner with interactions and conversation).  I like this!  And you definitely could play it the other way, though I imagine things would be more difficult and drastically change the ending.I liked the followers, they all had their personalities.  Problem I ran into was the only character to completely level up before the end sequence was my own character, so there was no real opportunity to catch another one up to replace those who needed to leave late in the game.  Less of an issue I guess if you're not fighting your way through.  Perhaps fighting through affords more xp?I played Planescape: Torment.  The atmosphere is there.  I didn't hold some preconceived notion that this should be a sequel-better-than-original though.   It's its own game, review it on its own merits.As far as I'm concerned, this is a well done game and I very much enjoyed it.

content:
Posted: March 20
												  So a thumb up , as you cant rate the game. Thumbs up buts its really not a game for everyone, some of my friends stopped it just after a few hours completely bored by it ,i cant blame them.  Inxile are not really good at story stelling, 5 min into the game you know who you are and what is chasing you. Unlike the original torment keeping the mystery till the end. You are bombarded by wall of texts and cryptic stories , no idea how they relate to you , nor are those collections of shredded novels especially interisting  . Hard to make any sense of it until later.Pages and pages to read without reasons, with barely any player input.Many will give up...    You should approach this game more like a classic adventure game than a roleplaying game.You character building doesnt matter , nothing is challenging,you will have plenty of points to succeed in everything.The game certainly lack of adrenaline and momemtum. The turn based combats are so tedious slow and lacking of strategic options you will try to skip them the most possible and use skill checks instead.The cherry on the cake is they sometime hard lock the game.However it has strong points, the unique and alien setting.It's a pleasure to explore those bizare, unstettling and gorgeous environements. I always appreciate when people try and dare new things, its a very strong point for me and mostly why i give a thumb  up . This is not dwarves&elves fantasy, its an alien multiverse  and in that way at least partially a successor of planescape torment.The writing is good, if the story telling is not, its a showroom for the numerama pen and paper rpg setting . You can get attached to the companions, especially rhinn and their side quests were a pleasure to complete. 20 hours only to finish it thats far below the classics , manys flaw indeed,years too late  but as a backer  cant say i feel scammed.Too small budget, likely inexperience of some members i guess. I would back a torment 2 if they could learn from their mistakes and read our feedback.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								ok, wow, where to begin?  well, first off, i liked the story so far as ive seen.  it's an interesting concept and keeps my attention moderately well.  The sound track is good, and i enjoy elements of the gameplay, but...1)  the graphics are pretty awful.  I mean it, it honestly looks awful, even when comparing it to PST which this is supposed to be the successor to this game.  2)  Combat is a chore.  the few fights i actually had were pretty horrendous, the abilities were pretty pointless as you could only use it once or so and then its done for not just fights, but until you rest next.  it made combat really unsatisfying 3)  The overwhelming sheer quantity of bugs!  Ive played this game no more then two hours and have already ran across over half a dozen (already documented) bugs ranging from game crashes to freezing to simple things like the portraits vibrating weirdly when the mouse scrolls over them.  I know its in early access, but im barely into the game and already finding this many issues?  seems a bit ridiculous to me.4)  general lack of care for the characters.  When i first played PST, i instantly fell in love with one of the first characters you find.  He was unique, he was witty, and he was memorable.  The 3 companions i met so far ive played with and am trying to want to get to know, but they are just really really boring.  This might just be a judgement call on my part or a matter of taste, but they are by no means worth remembering or so much as caring about.don't get me wrong, i want to like this game.  i'm going to play it to completion (or as far along as completion goes for now), and if it changes my mind, i'll gladly rewrite this review with glowing reccomendation, but sadly, this game doesnt live up to half the example of PST.  If i were a potentially interested buyer, give this game a hard pass.  Its too late for me, but save yourselvesUpdate:  ok, as of the december 20th update, i need to revise some of my statements.  The graphics, while still lacking, are refined and look a little better.  Combat actually feels fun now that it doesnt cost ALL your ability points to use an ability once or twice, and i actually ran through the game with only minor hiccups and bugs, nothing game breaking or disheartening.  Still dont care bout all the companions, but thats more that you dont get to explore their backgrounds.  They may not have an instant eye catching appeal, but once you get used to them being around, they grow on you.  All in all, i still wouldnt reccomend the game for preorder but, maybe when its out february 28th 2017, it might be worth a try.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8
												I love RPGs in general and I have been looking forward to this game for several years. I regret that I didn't have the income to be able to back it when it was in its kickstarter phase as I would have loved to.  It claims to be a spiritual successor to Planescape: Torment and I think it delivers on that and then some. Here's my overall thoughts on the game.  The Good This game grips you right from the start and makes you start asking questions. What is the Sorrow and why does it hate me? What is the Changing God trying to do? What do all these memories mean? You learn over the course of the game answers to these and many more questions in such a great setting. The Numenera world is the first one since Planescape itself that makes me want to take up tabletop RPGs again. It's that interesting. You never know what is around the next corner from a mirror that kills you to Total Recall style mutants to a psychic bar and everything in between.I love how virtually everything in this game from the Crises to the quests themselves can be resolved in a multitude of ways that all feel meaningful. Failure isn't always bad necessarily as it often results in resolutions you never would have seen coming. When it comes to the skills and abilities, the developers have done more with less. There may not be a huge variety of abilities but there's enough that each choice you make feels meaningful and there are a wide enough variety of builds that even replaying as the same class doesn't mean you'll be the same castoff as before.On a technical aspect, I really enjoy being able to effectively choose which input style you want to play with. Most games seem designed with keyboard/mouse or controller in mind and seem extremely clunky with using the "offhand" input. This game not so much.  The Bad I get that this game is centered around dialogue and story but the combat is at best mediocre and at worst strait up boring. There are a lot of bugs with the heavily scripted fights in the second half of the game that was relatively untested compared to Sagus Cliffs crises that we got in the early access. Even when your UI doesnt lock up from the knockdown bug, there are a lot of pathing and pacing problems that make you want to go grab a drink until your next turn. Several fights seem to take longer than they should due to respawns in fight that make you want to ignore the fight and just beeline to the objective.There are also NUMEROUS bugs with the current release of the game. These vary from minor cosmetic things to the knockdown bug where you have to alt+f4 the game and restart to game saves being deleted entirely. I wish the developers had given early access the full game to test these kind of things out because I feel a lot of these bugs are going to hurt unless they're addressed soon.  The Ugly For all it's greatness, this game has its fair share of mediocrity as well. I'm a big fan of game music and still listen to PS:T soundtrack to this day. This game soundtrack will not be something I listen to very often. It's not bad, it's just not great either. Nothing stands out other than the tidal noises and opening theme.It also doesn't feel like any of the companions except Matkina seem especially memorable. Callistige is a pretty generic mage, Tybir is a pretty generic rogue, Aligern is a generic fighter (who happens to be a Nano, wtf?). Rhin is a complete waste of a slot until you get to tier 3 then she goes from zero to hero faster than a Disney film. I haven't used Erritis much but I didn't get anything more than a "nuttier than squirrel turds" vibe from him what little I used him. The banter is few and far between and generally unless prompted, once you talk to them the first time and ask everything, you won't need to talk to them anymore. I wish they had been more unique overall.Overall I think this game generally delivers where it matters and most of the failures are easily remedied or ignored and I will continue playing it for a long time. I hope you all will too!

content:
Posted: April 25
												When a game that starts as a kickstarter to one of the more beloved RPGs of its time, Planescape: Torment, is announced, a certain amount of hype is created. That hype becomes bolstered by a wildly successful kickstarter campaign in which numerous additional funding goals are completed and a slew of content is promised as a result. When the dust settled, reality set in. Clearly the developer faced a series of unexpected issues when it came to realizing the vision of the Numenara setting and Monty Cook's Cypher system for the gameplay. Changes were made, content was removed and the game was released to much clamor and outcry, both from detractors and supporters. So the question is, how is the game?My playthrough of Torment last 36 hours and involved a ton of reading, talking my way out of fights and finally, learning how to fight. I found the setting to be engrossing and interesting and completely bizarre. They really managed to capture the insanity of the Numenara setting and in doing so, at least evoked some fond memories that I had for the Planescape setting and even the few novels that were written.The story itself is a fairly common one, the search for one's self. This is brought about through exploration, conversationa and the recalling of memories. Certainly the amnesia trope is a somewhat common one and it was mostly utilized here to good effect. While not anywhere near as engaging as the Nameless in Planescape, your character was still an interesting blank slate.Like most RPGs, this game contains a series of main story quests, side quests and even some companion quests. While the game does manage to avoid the "go kill me 5 monsters and bring me their parts", most of them are still fairly standard. I must admit I did enjoy moving about the various locales and seeing hot spots that could be manipulated. The sheer amount of strange creatures and entities available made for an enjoyable journey.The combat, as has been pointed out elsewhere is not the strongest. It was not really until well until the game that I started to come into my own in terms of fighting. Part of this is because I chose to talk my way out of nearly every enocunter I could find. The downside to this was that I never really had the opportunity to learn fighting strategies early on and it took me a long while to get past the first few mandatory battles. I also did not realize until well into the game that during a battle (or Crisis as they are called here" you can sometimes speak to your enemies and in some cases actually talk them out of fighting. There are also a number of enocunters that include parts of the terrain, traps, devices, etc that can help turn the tide of your battles. I just wish there had been more exposure to the combat, since it wasn't all avoidable. The stat pools mechanic was also a bit of a strange thing to get used to. These stat pools covered things like trying to persuade or intimdate somebody, to snatching an item off of an unsuspecting NPC, to actually being required for us with combat and combat abilities. Much of this information is just not really properly explained all that well. I think a more extended intro with more tutorials would have been highly beneficial. Still by the end of the game, your stat pools should be so high that you are able to easily make your ability checks.There has been much talk about the length of the game and as always, your mileage may vary based on your indivudal play style. I know that I missed out on some content, including one companion that had their own quests. I also missed out on talking to a certain beast in a tank that I look forward to doing next time. I also played the game and talked my way out of so much, that I intend to try it a different style next time. Having said that, many may be expecting the kind of enormous, epic sprawling adventures of Baldur's Gate 1 and 2. This game is a smaller game, featuring perhaps 5 different areas to explore and aside from the first one, they begin to feel confined after a while. Another issue will be the exclusion of promised materail from kickstarter stretch goals and I can only hope that the developers add as much of that content post release as they are able to.I found a few bugs here and there, but thankfully none of the game enders that others have reported. There has been a little patching activity from the develoeprs since release, although the month of April has been relatively quiet for them. If they continue to support the game, then this should help remove many of the issues that others have described.Ultimately, this game is my type of game. I like the sometimes absurd setting, the ability to talk my way out of battles and at least the illusion of choice in this game. I would have liked to see more useful loot in the game, as I found I had to buy my best weapons for the most part. I also would have liked far more encounters and combat opportunities. Perhaps my play style led to that outcome, I guess I will find out next time. While I would have liked to see more of all the content on offer, I did find what was there to be compelling and worth playing from start to finish. While this game may never end up reaching the heights of its spiritual prdecessor, I think many will find it to be enjoyable. Maybe wait until it goes on sale.

content:
Posted: March 4
												Absolutely beuatifully written game, well worth investing your time into if you love deep story, great characters and an incredibly strong backgound. This game is *not* a BG clone, it has many of the same mechanics and many similarities but there is definitely less combat overall and vastly more options to deal with potential combat situations (or you can just smash faces in like a pro if that's what you enjoy!). The game does an excellent job of bringing the tabletop RPG to life and converting the mechanics to work in a video game, about as well as it could possibly be done I suspect.It's very hard to give more specifcs without spoiling anything, which would be criminal given how interesting it all is, but suffice to say your moral choices make a huge difference to peoples lives and deaths but you're not being *judged* for them, you're seeing the consequences, after all... what is one life worth?If all you want is click and loot then Diablo or Path of Exile are great games that satisfy that itch, if you just want another Baldurs Gate, probably look at Pillars of Eternity. But if you want a deep story with fantastic characters (Favourite so far: Rhin... Patrick Rothfuss knocked it out of the park with her!) and some very interesting game & combat mechanics all very much in the flavour of Planescape: Torment (for those who played it waaaaay back when), this game is for you imo.As someone who both played Planescape when it came out and backed the kickstarter for this I couldn't be happier and more satisfied, awesome game and well worth it.

Posted: March 4
												I'm sure the Good Ship Internet is already groaning under the weight of reviews comparing this with the original Planescape: Torment, which is only to be expected. The entire premise of the Kickstarter seemed to hinge on our collective desire to have more of that sort of thing, please and thankyou. It basically succeeds, I guess? Only much like with Pillars of Eternity, now that I finally have access to the Further Adventures of Videogame Systems I Found Thrilling in 1999, it's no longer something for which the Me of 2017 has any patience. I was messing about with Divinity: Original Sin to pass the time before this was released and realised it is exactly what I wanted all along, a worthy successor to those venerable Infinity Engine titles but infused with all the vigor and innovation of almost 20 years of gaming evolution. On another, much more specific topic, that dialogue window. Bleh. You spend so much time (SO MUCH TIME) in conversation with grotesque interchangeable character models, particularly if you choose to placate your way out of ever having to engage in the tiresome combat system. Could they not have hired an artist to sketch some portraits for the NPCs? It honestly feels like I'm just reading a wiki at times rather than interacting with characters in a fantastical realm. Anyway, recommending because it performs exactly as advertised!

content:
Posted: April 9
												BETTER THAN THE ORIGINAL (YMMV)This game has some of the best writing and most interesting story of any video game, ever. I was majorly disapointed with previous "tribute" RPGs like Dragon Age and Pillars of Eternity. I feel that this game finally hits the nail in terms of storytelling, even surpasses our favorate late 90s classic CPRGs. The writing and original settings are top notch. Lets say that it TTN was a novel, it would probably be winning SciFi literary awards. What makes it even better than a novel is the way it tells the story by letting you explore and interact with the environment, rather than merely scroll through pages of text. The setting of this game is in a specific part of the Numenera world that was segrated specifically for the game, basically on the opposite side of the world from the table top setting. So all of the settings are original totally unqiuely created for the game. The Bloom was the area I was most impressed with be there was lots of original weirdness and interesting backstory to all of the areas in the game. Additoinally because of the alternate outcomes to a lot of events this game is definately worth mutliple play throughs. I've already beat it twice but am waiting for new (free) content to be released before I try the thrid time.

The fact is, the game is great fun, if you are into this type of game. One has to understand it isn't about making the biggest, baddest warrior there is, although you certainly can and can beat the game that way. But that isn't the game's focus. content:
Posted: March 1
												Despite what many of the top reviews are saying right now, this game is fantastic. The negative reviews are mainly for a mismanaged Kickstarter. So long as you aren't part of that, then this outrage doesn't effect you.The actual game itself is a very well written spiritual successor to Planescape Torment. However, there is even less of an emphasis on combat, so if you prefer more combat heavy RPGs like Baldur's Gate than this may not be for you.The RPG mechanical elements themselves are pretty light. There are 3 "effort" skills you can spend to pass checks, which can only be recharged by items and sleeping. The combat is also based on spending these skills to use abilities. The main alluring part of this RPG is the top quality writing and all of the different choices that can be made during quests and even outside of quests. For example, in many quests, you have the ability to learn deep secrets from people. After finishing the quest, you could always go and trade those secrets away for another secret, perhaps one that can save people, or perhaps one that you can use to your advantage. Is this something you want to do?Torment: Tides of Numenara is all about these kinds of choices. If this sounds appealing to you, then I highly recommend the game!

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28
												T: ToN is a great game and a worthy successor to the Torment name. The strengths and flaws of the two games are pretty similar, so if you're looking for an immersive, story (text) heavy game to explore and think your way through, here it is. + The world and characters within it are fantastic, it's easy to immerse yourself in a place that feels alien setting-wise but familiar mechanics-wise. This is the thing I love most that both Torment games share. + The writing and quests are overall very good. The quests react pleasingly to the different ways you can solve them and the descriptions and dialogue are often thought-provoking and fun. There are times when a little too much text is dumped on screen without much other interaction, but if you don't enjoy reading you wouldn't be playing a writing-heavy RPG in the first place. People who are complaining about "reading a book"... what the hell did you expect? ~ The combat is solid, but not wonderful. I did run into a couple of bugs in combat (I didn't encounter any outside of it) which was annoying, but eh. I expect a few bugs in a game this size. I actually enjoyed the turn-based combat here more than the Real-Time-with-Pause of Pillars of Eternity, which surprised me a bit, being a big oldschool IE fan (BG, BG2 etc).- It's quite easy. The combat and skill checks are at least reasonably challenging to begin with if you avoid sleeping while you do all the first town quests like I did, but after that there's not anything that took more than an attempt or two to ace. I don't really play narrative games for a heavy skill test though, I play for the story and setting. Making the moral and investigative choices in dialogue is where the "difficulty" lies in my mind.- Yes, the final act ends a bit abruptly and the game is a little shorter than I'd like, but it's not worth getting bent out of shape about. 64 hours for a methodical runthrough of an RPG seems decent enough to me. I don't care what budget the game had or where that came from, I care if the game is fun and (in my mind) worth the money, and this one is.If you're the sort of person who likes investigating all the nooks of a game before moving on, this one has plenty of fun to discover. People wanting a more mechanics-heavy challenge or who get bored reading long chains of dialogue, then yeah, stay away.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21
												MAN.  I don't write many reviews, but I already feel compelled to share my thoughts on this game.I'm roughly 1.5 hours in and I'm in love.The story is alredy compelling.  I'm traversing every conversational path I can with the worry that I'm negatively effecting my relationship with the strange and fascinating characters I've met already.  I can't wait to read more about this world.The user interface is GORGEOUS.  It's fast, sleek and polished.  It's flowy and vibrant and relaxing. Very well done.The character creation process was definitely my favorite done in any RPG I've played to date.  And I've played a LOT of them.  70% of my library is RPGs.  I love RPG's.  So much.The music is to die for.  It's beautifuly done and it changes flawlessly as tensions change in dialogue.  I already feel like I could play this entire game with VERY little (and quite possibly none at all) actual combat.  And I LOVE it that I have that option.  I'm already envisioning replays with different attitudes and builds in mind.  I believe they will create completely unique experiences already.The price?  Meh, so far I'm feeling good about the purchase.  But I think to make that detrminaiton before 20 hours is probably silly and something that would have to be changed later.  So I'm abstaining on this topic while leaning towardy the thumbs up side in the early leg of the race.If you've been watching this one, get it.  If you start to watch it now, pounce the INSTANT you see it go on sale.  Games this well done take me back to my 15 year old summer nights reading choose your own adventure books while my actual imagination was still vivid.  Now I'm old and jaded and I require advanced technology to take me there.  But this game is doing an EXCELLENT job so far.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12
												Pros:+ Good writing with interesting characters and lore.+ Open-ended quests with lots of roleplaying opportunities.+ Really rewards you for being thorough and gaining as much information as possible.+ Lots of skill checks.+ Weird and wondrous sci-fantasy setting.+ Combat is mostly avoidable.+ Almost every piece of loot is unique.Cons:- Combat, while better than PST's, is mediocre.- Inventory is as bad as the one in PST.- Some bugs.- No codex (may be implemented later).- RNG-based skill checks are and have always been inherently pointless.- By the halfway point, you (or your party) can successfully complete any skill check, making your character build somewhat irrelevant.If you're looking for an RPG with deep, strategic combat, look elsewhere. If you're looking for a hardcore RPG where you're forced to specialize or else end up with unviable character, look elsewhere (i.e. Age of Decadence). If you're looking for an RPG that is less about what you can do and more about what you choose to do, Torment should be right up your alley. It successfully recaptures the strengths of Planescape: Torment in providing you with plenty of interesting characters to talk to, exotic locations to explore and deep, open-ended quests to complete. As a fan of PST and interesting content in general, I'm very satisfied with Torment.

content:
Posted: March 13
												I know its a bit early to say it but this game is probably my game of the year. I enjoyed Torment's strange atmosphere having never played anything like it before, and I found the story increadibly engaging and gripping. The interesting mechanic of balancing your exertion between combat and world events, with the same action pool for both, added a tactical edge to the world map and combat both. For the most part the game is very forgiving as well early on, with death being as much of a mechanic as a fail state throughout. All in all I would recommend this game to anyone with a love of weird absurdist sci-fi fantasy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, old-fashion crpgs, and a hard on for being the most important person in the world.10/10 best game

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13
												I rarely game anymore because games lack depth of thought and/or story, but that also include, enough freedom of choice and consequences to make you feel your choices matter.  The original Torment had it and this Torment takes it to the next level.  Though there are some really vocal complaints here, I feel their focus is not on the right elements. This is truly a game worth playing if you want to experience multiple immersive, exciting stories. Pros:- Great storyline, imaginative experiences all around, I found myself caring about lots of characters in the world aside from just your companions.- Great visuals help you dive into a strange world.- Ambiental sound and effects would truly move me and involve me in the scene, be it grossed out, excited, tense or mystified.- Creative and interesting environments, oddities and interactions that allow your imagination to go wild.- Challenge level is simple enough so that you can focus on playing the story multiple times with different options vs min-maxing and finding the perfect build.- Multiple friends started at the same time as I did, and we would talk about completely different experiences, companions, resolutions, and paths.Cons: - As other people have complained: Still quite a few bugs in interface or interaction of storylines that won't complete unless worked around.- Clunky interface issues with visibility, overlap and some actions don't effectively produce the corresponding audio.- Not really much challenge to the game if you are into "beating games."- The main con I see is that many people who don't like to read a lot are going to miss out on one of the best gaming experiences in a long time.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14
												Easily the best game I've played so far this year, but I have those opinions you get when you like something recognizably flawed.For a 'spiritual sequel', this game is actually at its best when it forgets to be the distant progeny of Planescape: Torment and explores its own vast, colorful world. The Last Castoff's personal conflict with their past was a dim shadow of the Nameless One's, but the potential conflict with the world, lingering at the edges of the game, was by far the greater.I feel like the Ninth World was meant for a game that truly fits the word 'epic'. I'd really like to see this setting in particular, and the loving way in which it saturated the gameplay, on a grander scale.Like, I get what it was trying to do, with the whole quest of self-discovery, that's all very 'Torment'. I liked it for that, but I wasn't surprised when it didn't quite capture the intimate, personal feel that PS:T had. It had one-off NPC's that were more interesting than half the major characters. Vendor trash that was more interesting than artifacts. The game was flavorful to the extreme, but that flavor itself was often at cross-purposes with its stated narrative goal. This was mainly a game about people dealing with a precursor, a history, that was innately unsympathetic, even hostile, to them, and trying to find a way to make that harmful past serve their future. It was a good metaphor for the Ninth World itself, what with folks poking through the garbage of great ancient civilizations for useful junk, but the whole feel of that was sort of muddled by the end, because, well, spoilers, but also because the devs themselves seemed to forget that treating the characters like set pieces defies the message they were ham-handedly trying to send. tldr: Beautifully-written, organic world. Rich characters. Slightly stilted 'themes'. Play it.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												Full review here : https://forums.inxile-entertainment.com/viewtopic.php?f=46&t=17771What has made into the final game with all the cuts and delays it’s superb, It’s detailed world full of interesting characters to meet and the side quests are very interesting. We have a robot who wants to have children, an octopus (Nychthemeron) that can only talk at night, and you can make it night just for that alone, you will meet a cult that worships the Changing God and you can tell them that you really are him to sleep for free. We meet cannibals who eat the dead to preserve their memories or people that fight in the endless battle between the Changing God's army and the opposing force.It really is a joy to read every interesting opinion that a character has. All quests can be resolved in multiple ways.The most interesting part of the game comes after the first major city, in the Endless Gate I had a great time listening to Inifere and trying to solve all the possible outcomes. Also, that holds one of the hardest fights that can lead to game over screen if you fail, and of course if you choose to fight. After that , aside from Miel Avast, the next major hub will be the Bloom written by George Zeits who is responsible for Mask of the Betrayer from Neverwinter Nights 2.The Bloom area is where the game really shines, it shows it’s full potential by using the setting, writing and the great soundtrack from Mark Morgan (same composer from PS:T, Fallout, Wasteland 2) Some examples from the Bloom : a robot who collects hosts that are only beautiful, a spaceship that has smashed into the bloom - that is huge monster like where people live, trade and so on. You can also find out what different mows want and feed them people or even your companions in order to open portals to other dimensions. It all feels very alive, and well put together.There’s a unique crisis system here that involves using your party members to distract a tour guide while you steal an important quest item, if you resolve to violence the battle will be almost impossible. The other companions you can find throughout the game are Tybir, Rhin and Erritis. Rhin is interesting because it’s a kid that can talk to Gods and Erritis, well, he is written by Chris Avellone and you can enjoy his full potential only if you choose a certain class with a certain ability. Tybir is just the funny guy in the game, and well, that’s about it. The characters while being interesting it can't compare to PS:T.Graphics in the game are good, especially in the bloom area, I like that we are able to zoom in very close, about the size of PS:T characters.I have read on forums that people think T:ToN is lacking in humor but that’s not true, the game has humor but a more mature one then the first.The whole story of the game is great written and you can have different endings based on your choices and the Tides. The Tides serve as a kind of alignment system, but a more complex one, because it can change depending on what you say to a character.Another great addition to the game are the meres : devices that can help you get into someone's memory and change the future, there are some that you need to interact because of the story but most of them are scattered throughout the game for the player to find them.Conclusion: I will recommend the game despite it's flaws and cut content, it’s a rough gem that can suck you into the great written story, a story that was written by 6 different actual writers and it’s complexity and narrative, detailed characters, choices that matter and reactivity all over the place will make Torment Tides of Numenera a game hard to miss for anyone that likes a real RPG and don’t bother reading. Maybe some of you will want to hold on until patches and cut content to be added, but for myself that I waited so many years to finally arrive , it’s a good experience, especially since true RPG’s with real reactivity are hard to come by today.

content:
Posted: March 7
												Excellent, bizarre, well-written, you won't find a unity-based isometric rpg like it.  The world of Numenera is vivid, like something out of a bad nightmare/fever dream.  The writing at times can be very Lovecraftian, and the descriptors very superfluous but it works in this setting.  It adds to the surreal atmosphere you are immersed in, the characters are unique, the side quests plenty. Basically, if you don't mind reading and like western rpgs like the ones Blackisle did, and Obsidian make - you should enjoy this one.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28
												I enjoyed the game.The game is very text heavy, and contains a huge amount of background and detail. It's not unusual to spend half an hour or even an hour in a single scene, investigating every detail and talking to all the NPCs, trying to understand what's going on. It's also nice to play a game in a fairly unique setting rather than in generic fantasy world #2514. So buy this game if you're someone who enjoys reading, story and depth. Avoid this game if you want a by-the-numbers JRPG where you're looking to grind through a thousand combats, maximising every stat.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17
												All I expected it to be. It`s a true spiritual sequel to PS:T; Strange, alien worlds, oddities aplenty that you can take interest in or leave by the side, truly unique and interesting companions and several novels worth of dialogue, both optional and main quest related.The effort system is quite innovative and well done, if surprisingly easy to game, and the Tides system is, possibly, the best way a game has ever quantified your alignment and how that influences how the world around you reacts to you.It IS quite a short game for its genre, which many seem to consider a negative, but I would heartily disagree. Tides keeps a very tight narrative focus, which would be impossible for a game of much greater length, and allows for a much easier replay to explore choices not taken the first time. It does not meander endlessly through sidequests, sideplots, base building and what have you; it`s a game about one man/woman, the choices they make, the emotions they feel, and their impact on the world around them, and it is better for that than a thousand epic fantasies of chosen ones and dark forces.And let us not forget that PS:T itself was quite a short game, and it too was better for it.A hearty reccomendation for what may well be the best Roleplaying game of 2017.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19
												Many people got this game because they liked Planescape Torment. I got this game for one reason: Pat Rothfuss. This review is thus aimed at people who are doing the same.He wrote an NPC called Rhin who is designed from the ground up to be more or less worthless. For most of the game, she deals 0 damage, dies in 1-2 hits and her only redeeming function is that she can use special consumable items and hide. I can't help but feel that this is a deliberate bit of trolling on Mr. Rothfuss' part, but the game isn't so terribly difficult as to make her presence in the party a terribly big deal. Besides, having Rhin in your party probably means that you're generally going to take the non-violent and sneaky options instead of chopping your way through everything.In any case, Rhin will be instantly familiar to a Rothfuss fan. She tosses out lines like "He's not a rock. He's a stone." and all that goodness. Unfortunately however, I have to report that there isn't really much there. Rhin is very interesting, but her full story is at the periphery and much is left to the player's imagination. This is a really text heavy game, but I don't think you would have a very thick booklet if you were to print out all of her dialogue. The rest of the game is cool and imaginative. I liked the story (which is probably one of the most high-concept bits of science fiction I've encountered in a video game) and I liked the other characters for the most part. You can definitely feel that Pat Rothfuss had some creative influence on the overall direction. But this isn't the Name of the Wind by any stretch of the imagination.Overall: Don't buy this expecting to find a huge amount of Rothfuss inside, but it is still worth exploring nevertheless.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5
												Ok, so I'm another one of these guys that hasen't written many reviews so bare with me.Short and sweet:PROS:Awesome story with amazing backdrops and characters.  The diolog between them is funny and the voice acting is pretty solid. The quests are enjoyable and well written for the most part with some pretty amazing surprises along the way.Finding out what "random" stuff does in your inventory is a nice treat and some of the items have some pretty amazing stories associated with them.CONS:  (and sad to say, the motivation for me coming here)The combat.  Holy jesus the combat is pure infuriating at times.  It's not because it's overly difficult and you can't manage to figure out how to deal with the enemy.  It's because in some cases you just can't layout a strategy because you can't select different characters and set them up.   You MUST lead in with your main character who cannot die or it's GG and in many of the cases I've found so far your enemy has a much higher initiation level than you.  So they go first.  So, you lead in with a character that can't die or it's GG (while your allies don't die but get "knocked out" instead) against enemies who in large part can move first.  Pure rage inducing.Why this company, who made Wasteland 2 (among others) with it's amazing combat, would choose to make such horrid combat decisions is just adding to the anger.  I'm a pretty big InXile fan and LOVE wasteland 2.  It is a huge letdown in this game that you can't select seperate characters and move them individually.  As far as i can tell you can't even decide who stands next to who in the "lineup".  I love the overall aspects of the game.  The story is really pretty amazing.  The combat though...my god, i just don't understand.   Those 2 things make such an impact on the pure frustration levels of the game that I just can't figure out why they went with it.Would i recommend the game, yes.  Overall, yes, i would.  But it's a strained yes.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12
												Overall a good game but nowhere close to the original "Plancescape: Torment".The game desipite it´s only roughly 30-40 hours long campaign still a good match for the original in aspects of general playtrough (focus on story not on battles) and unfortunatly companions (P:T as combat aid, T:ToN as combat aids (minor) and skill mules (major). Aside from that they are glorified NPC´s)The new mechanics work and fit into the story. The overall story is also good (if short)Despite the overall matches sofar there is however one, or rather three, big part/s that invalides the game as a successor instead of a standalone: It has nothing to do with the charactes, places or story of the first game. Places: As the name of the original suggest it takes place on the "Planes" more specificly the first 2/3 take place in Sigil, a place called the City of Gates (to other planes) and is filled with creatures of said planes. T:ToN on the other hands play on the "ninth world" and among other things you see at least 2 spaceships and in "flashback" one space station.Characters:The only character that comes from the first game is Adahn. First Game he was a fictional character that could be brought to some sort of live by telling people that it´s your name. T:TON makes it the name of the previous host of our body in the game. Story:The only elements of the original story that makes it into this one is that the Protagonist can´t die (with exceptions). The reasons in P:T was that we underwent a ritual to seperrate us from our mortality. The reason in T:ToN is that we were made this way as a vessel for the changing god.Summary: Would buy again (even the Immortal Edition but that one only in a Steam Sale) but take down the "Successor of Planescape: Torment" Award. That one is undeserved. Even as a "spiritual successor".

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11
												TLDR: If you like crpgs or want to try and dip your toe into the genre, this is a good place to start.  There isn't too much combat to worry about and slow your enjoyment of the story.  Great replayability, if you like reading and want something different from typical scifi or fantasy play this game you won't be disappointed.As a gamer that has never played the original Planescape: Torment and having limited experience with crpgs, I went into this a little intimidated.  The ones I've played were daunting in terms of gameplay, while they were all rich with deep storytelling the pacing of the game would often be hampered with the endless amount of creatures which  you would have to fight between story sections.  Some of which could be a frustrating wall until you grind even more weaker monsters to progress yourself.  That is not the case with Torment: Tides of Numenera.  I completed the game on my first playthrough in 40 hours, throughout that time I had very limited combat encounters and instead got to enjoy and immerse myself with the well written story and side lore that each environment you cross paths with uninterrupted by needless combat.  The developers weren't kidding when they say they have a books worth of story packed into this game.  I enjoyed this game, on the second playthrough you'll likely skip a few dialogue here and there but not in the same manner as other rpg games where you'll make a few different choices but be lead the same way.  In this game, there's a lot of replayability.  There is no way you can see everything in a single playthrough even if you save-scum.
