I enjoyed this game, on the second playthrough you'll likely skip a few dialogue here and there but not in the same manner as other rpg games where you'll make a few different choices but be lead the same way.  In this game, there's a lot of replayability.  There is no way you can see everything in a single playthrough even if you save-scum.

content:
Posted: March 29
												I was a backer of this Kickstarter, and now that I've finally had a chance to play it, did it live up to my expectations?  Well, it's not quite up there with Planescape, but I was enthralled by the world.  I actually recommend reading the Tides of Numenera Novellas first, because they added an extra layer of familiarity to the world and locations (finding a certain skeleton and the weapon beside it actually made my jaw drop as I realized who it was, but only because I had read the novellas). The world is fascinating, the characters I traveled with a little less so (although there were definitely touching moments with some of them). The final conflict was a little underwhelming, and I may go back to try it differently.  But the whole concept of effort and finding alternatives to fighting in the Crises was intriguing and well implemented. But there were so many interesting stories, and the central plot, once unveiled, will leave me thinking for a long time.  It may not stand up with the classics like Baldur's Gate and Planescape, but it's only a small step down from them, and still definitely worth the time of Isometric Role playing games (and interactive fiction fans who don't mind dealing with some of the trappings of traditional RPGs).

												What was special, really special about Planescape: Torment, was the sense of intrigue in every corner of the world. That everybody you talked to, every corner had some new story to tell you. Some were sad, some were funny and some were really weird. Some of them were better than others; but they were all worth your time.I think, for me at least, Torment: Tides of Numenera captures that feeling that the world is vast and strange and that, even if it is at the end of the day, a construct with a finite amount of narrative for you to see, you never quite have a full handle on it.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18
												Torment: Tides of Numenera is a decent execution of the heavily-story focused old-school Isometric RPG type game.The setting and little side stories of Numenera are by far its strongest aspect, with the 1-billion old world filled with strange stories and technological wonders from ages gone by. Considering a majority of your time is spent learning and interacting with this world, it being so interesting and fleshed out alone makes the game worth playing. It is, and this cannot be overstated, absurdly varied, imaginative, weird (in a good way), and unlike any other setting I have seen in other fiction. I will not soon forget it, and it is easy to see the vast amount of writing, design, and other work that it took to craft this detailed a realization of this world.And then there is the rest. I found almost everything - the main story, companion interactions, combat, navigation - middling in quality. The main story is focused on an interesting concept of a 'Changing God' who lives forever and spawns endless immortal castoffs who are powerful and do much to shape the world. This leads to some interesting lore, but is undercut by the antagonist being 'The Sorrow' (seriously? a generic unstoppable evil force?) and the crux of the conflict being highly abstract and removed from real-world moral concerns. The story is also undercut by spotty pacing, big intermittent info dumps, and mixed quality of writing. The same is true for companions' stories; some or better than others, and the writing of the characters is actually quite good, but all suffer from how they are delivered. Don't get me wrong; the story is not bad, on the whole I found it pretty interesting and worth going through, but it feels like it could be told much, much, better. Likewise, the world-building dialogue is often delivered in uninspired ways, much as it was in Wasteland 2 - you can ask for backstory on everything, to the point that it becomes tiresome.As to the gameplay - my biggest complaint for the game may be that the combat feels terrible, and there is not much else of interest. The combat system itself is actually pretty cool, but the degree to which actual combat moves slowly and clumsily is ridicolous - in the age of the recent X-COM revival and other far superior turn based combat games, it is strange that this one is so badly executed. This is not a huge deal due to how little combat there is (the vast majority of it is avoidable, which is cool), but sadly the dialogue-based solutions around violence are rarely very interesting. In the vast majority of cases I could simply use my 'Persuasion' skill, which made it seem ridicolously overpowered and the actual act of pulling of dialogue solutions unimpressive. The game looks good insofar as the worlds are detailed and imaginative, but is otherwise underwhelming as far as graphics go; all characters are only ever low-poly models which you see from the usual isometric perspective (there are portraits for you and your companions, but they doo little to help things). It could really benefit from less stilted dialogue, some cutscenes (such as the story trailer), or really anything to make it less of a choose-your-own-adventure book. The audio is barely worth mentioning, except that something started making a constant sound effect in the latter half of the game that was maddening. So... yeah, a narrative-driven game with a flawed narrative but a fantastic setting/premise and many memorable details. I do recommend it, if only because there is very little like it out there, but with the caveat that the execution is rough and going through it will involve far more reading than playing.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26
												I played this game after going back and completing Planescape: Torment and, honestly, it's very very loosely attached to it. The only things that a taken from that are a few vague themes. I'm not complaining about that at all because this game stands up on its own. As with every game like this, the main upsides are going to be the story and the characters. The characters and their development were done very well. Each person has their own unique feel and you do genuinely get drawn into their own stories, none moreso (for me) that Rhin. The story, on the other hand, was pretty bare bones but I feel it was more a vehicle for the characters and it was interesting to a point. The look of the game is also great, lending a lot to the themes and the different ages of history that you're told about. The cyphers and esoteries (spells) are also quite cool and well animated. Now for a few gripes I had. Firstly, the voice acting. The quality itself was fine, as you would expect from a higher budget indie game but the amount was quite disappointing. You expect to have voice acting all along the main storyline in games like this but, even when you would expect it, it wasn't there. For example, the last encounter of the game had no voice acting. Secondly, there is A LOT of text. I feel like these 2 points are linked but I feel this would turn off a lot of people. Finally, the combat mechanics were a bit poor. I feel like it would have benefited from a system with disengaging strikes and other things from the game Tyranny. Overall, it's a great, interesting game with a hell of a lot of character and you can just tell the devs loved making it. If you like story, grab it. If you like old school CRPGs, why haven't you already got it?

number of helpful: 6 of 18 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14
												One of the best stories I've ever experienced in an RPG, a truly memorable adventure from the beginning till the end. The writing is top-notch, there is no artificial padding of gametime, no grindy bits of any kind, the pacing of the story is constant and flows well. Sadly, there is not much actual challenge, but I didn't get bored at all. Yep, it's around 40 hours of almost pure storytelling.Just don't expect it to be some sort of tactical simulator with lots of micromanagement and strategizing, it's a type of an RPG more similar to visual novel-ish choose-your-own-adventure-ish Shadowrun Returns style games (yet I felt there was still less reading than I had to endure in Shadowrun: Hong Kong!). So if you find the premise and the setting appealing and you're ready to read a lot - definitely give this one a shot. And don't listen to those who fanatically worship Planescape: Torment and other Infinity Engine games in the reviews around here, because more often than not they're out of their minds.

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
												I played the original Torment back in the day multiple times over multiple years. I was a diehard fan of the game, delving into several of the nooks and crannies of that wonderful universe.I can't speak to anyone else, but I love this game.The Numenera setting does a great job of keeping the weirdness and mystique of the Planescape univserse. I greatly enjoyed the writing, the worldbuilding, and the storytelling.One of the things I liked most about this game was how easily you could go through it with little to no combat. Even the fights that were there could be approached in a way that involved fleeing/problem solving with no actual fighting. I really dug that.I will say, however, that this is a wordy game, somewhere between a Choose Your Own Adventure game like Sorcery and the new age iso-RPGs like Pillars. This combination was practlically geared for me, but it might not be for you.Also, the mechanics in some circumstances can be quirky, though not overbearingly so. I would have liked the ability to save while in a conversation or a "Mere" (a choose your own adventure style diversion that occur occasionally in the game). I personally like the turn based mechanics they introduced into the system, and likewise really like the streamlined Numenera system for skills that they use, but it may not be some people's cup of tea. That said, I'd say this compares to the original Torment, which had its own quirks in converting the Infinity engine used in Baldur's gate to work in a much more character focused game. They both have a few areas that could use refiniement, but the other parts of the game more than make up for it.I truly hope this game does well, I think it deserves to do so. I much prefer this character heavy type game over InXile's (still good) squad-based Wasteland series. I hope they make more games in this world, and continue to refine this particular system. I heartily recomend this to anyone who enjoyed the first Torment game.

content:
Posted: March 4
												It's interesting.  It's certainly a great throwback to the great Bioware cRPG games of the past with many much needed quality of life additions and some pretty great unique ideas.  I both enjoy and detest the 'crisis system' that handles combat.  When it works, it's wonderful.  It's like doing a pen and paper game.  I like that not every battle has to end in all enemies dead.  I would suggest I fought less than thirty battles over the course of the entire game, and this was, to me, far more satisfying than the sort of constant grind that Tyranny, Pillars, and Dragon Age embrace.  Battles feel memorable and that's an absolute breath of fresh air we've needed to see for quite a long time.  On the downside, somemtimes the AI in combat is really profoundly stupid and I get the impression some of the combats aren't set up very well.  I had to savescum a little bit.  The story, which should be front and center of everyone elses review, is good.  Choice, to some degree, maters.  I would suggest it matters more than most modern cRPGs.  There are legitimate multiple endings.  I can't say I enjoyed The 9th world as much as I did Sigil from Planescape Torment, but I think they did the best they could with the source material.For those thinking of buying this game it can get pretty esoeteric and verbose.  Know what you're getting into.  Know that there is a hell of a lot of reading involved.Edit.I see from my reviews a lot of people didn't like what I had to say about the game and a lot of reviews that aren't from major publications are negative.  To start, I wasn't a kickstarter backer, so I didn't go into this game expecting much more than a fun blast from the past.  I agree it could have been longer.  I wish the companions were better developed.  I've also been interetsed in Numenera the RPG for years.  I woudln't be shocked I qualify as something of a unicorn fan.  Looking back at what I paid for it, if I hadn't been given it as an xmas gift by a friend (they paid the full price and I'm not a reviewer), I probably would have waited for sale.  Either way, I enjoyed it.  I'm now really looking forward watching youtube videos explaining everything that went on in the game.

Posted: March 28
												I was a backer of this game and am very satisfied by what I received.  I have fully played through twice already.Is it as good as Planescape: Torment? No.  But then that is true of literally every other CRPG ever made so that is a ridiculous standard to hold it up against.  The followers are not as engaging as those in Planescape or Baldur but the world is suitably bizarre and interesting, the writing is good and frankly, the absence of 'trash mobs' which infested all of the classic Infinity Engine games goes a long way towards my enjoyment.I will echo what most people are saying, if you are cool with tons of exposition and like to read you will enjoy this but if you are more combat focused you probably will not.Something else to keep in mind when comparing it to Planescape is that Planescape was almost unplayable due to day 1 bugs, most people discovered Planescape after it had been officially patched and then community patched.  There are supposed to be additions and fixes coming (for free) so this may be another game that grows in reputation in the months and years after release.

Any cuts that have been made have not influenced my opinion. The game, in it's current state, brought me 30+ hours of interesting story and fun. While I do still place it below Planescape: Torment in my all time hall of fame, I'm happy to have supported the developer with my purchase of the Collector's Edition.

Posted: March 2
												I've only played it for 5.4 hours so far, yet I already know that I like it a lot.    I backed the game on Kickstarter, so I might be biased towards liking it, however I disliked other games which I had backed (including Wasteland 2, from the same developer) and so I did not expect it to live up to my expectations, but it did!I adored Planescape: Torment (PT) and Torment: Tides of Numenera (TTN) is exactly like it.      When you compare the Torment games to the Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights games, then NWN are the most combat heavy and the Torment games are the most dialogue heavy, with BG being in between.     I usually dislike dialogue heavy games, because many games have♥♥♥♥♥♥dialogue, but the Torment games had great writers working on them and I haven't met a single boring NPC in the 5 hours of play time.The type of storytelling that games excell at, is where you get to explore a world. Many wannabe movie directors make games nowadays (esp. AAA games), but the linear stories are anathema to the interactive medium of games. The Torment games are not linear.       In the storytelling aspect, TTN is a lot like Witcher 3 with more dialogue.If you like dialogue heavy games, you can't go wrong with TTN.If you dislike dialogue in games (because it's usually badly written), then I suggest you give the much cheaper PT a try first.Edit:Many reviews are mad about cut content etc.I didn't follow the development the last 4 years and didn't play any alpha versions. I don't even remember the promises made for the game; all I expected was another PT.Thing is, PT was mostly an interactive novel with very basic RPG elements.TTN is the same thing. Shocker! I know. I got what I expected, which is the first time on Kickstarter for me.So to make it clear: TTN is mostly reading, not combat.

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
												Trying to follow up PlaneScape: Torment - in my opinion the best RPG story ever told is ambitious. Tides of Numenera comes really, really close, which for me is enough. Especially considering how rare games like this are.The atmosphere, mystery and above all uniqueness of the setting are great on their own right and when comparing it to PlaneScape I only like the latter slightly more because of personal preferences.The lack of actual or forced combat where you hit things with a weapon is impressive - the game even calls them "Crisis" encounters and there's often a way to do something other than killing all the enemies to get through it.The companions and places you visit are interesting, but left me wanting for more (which is often a good sign). It didn't feel like I got to know any of the companions well enough beyond their main backstory. The first big hub of Sagus Cliffs wasn't as interesting for me as Sigil or the other, weirder places you get to visit later in Tides and I wanted more of that.The variety of meaningful choices and reactivity to them was probably the best out of any RPG I've played. Despite having hard-fought and "ideal" solutions to problems that probably wouldn't have any consequences later I was more torn than I ever have been between the all the other options. All because of how well written the game is and how many intriguing choices the game had for me.The story of Tides manages to invoke similar deep philosophical concepts to the original Torment while not retreading the same ground. The plot, while slow to get going had some interesting twists and an overall satisfying conclusion.Overall I haven't played anything as compelling as this since the original Torment.

content:
Posted: March 26
												Despite it's many flaws, I still recommend this game... but if you get it on sale. This game will draw comparisons to two games: Planescape Torment, and Pillars or Eternity. The former is in terms of spiritual succession & writing whilst the latter is in terms of technological performance & gameplay. Compared to P:T - it's not as spolished, feels a bit incoherent at times, and I think the companions aren't that interesting. The story is more of an interactive novel with not much impact on the world and quests that can be solved quite easily (a few just by going to the next map and talking to someone). Compared to PoE - I hate the "crises" combat in this game. It's awful and makes me realise why Obsidian went with pausable real time combat, rather than with turn based. But luckily most of the compbat in this game can be avoided which is nice. The maps in TToN feel a lot smaller, but on the plus side have a lot more 3D assets with things actually happening (i.e. light arks, water dripping, light pulsating, etc) whilst PoE felt like playing on a painting. So I seem to have been quite negative compared to both P:T and PoE, so why the recommendation? I feel that I got enough enjoyment out of this game to warrant buying it on a sale. Some of the quests were quite interesting, the world artwork / 2D assets were very qurky, and (very) few times it made me laugh. FYI: even thought it says Ive played it for 2 hours, I've played it offline for 47 hours and done every quest I could find.

Posted: March 19
												There's a lot of salt in the review section for this game, which is unfortunate. After sinking almost 50 hours into it, I found it to be a well-written RPG in a fascinating world with a compelling story.It seems to be unfairly held up to the original, which is hailed as some perfect zenith of gaming. If you have rose-tinted nostalgia goggles on, then yeah, you'll probably hate this game. It's not Planescape torment.But playing this game, and juding it on its own merits, I found it worth my money. The combat wasn't great, sure, and the graphics aren't anything to write home about. But as I mentioned above, the game takes place in a fascinating world, with a well-written and intruiging story. Could it have stood to be longer? Probably. In the end, however, I got what I came for, and don't regret my purchase.

number of helpful: 0 of 6 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1
												4 hours in:Just started playing so I'll update the review once I finish, but off to a great start.Playing this toook me back to the old CRPG days of when I was back in highschool. TTON definitely feels like a solid successor to the original Torment.  The game has the same mystery, detail and story as the original and it feels so right.If you're not interested in a long literaly journey - DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.  There is a lot of reading and if you don't want to invest the time to read it through, you'll miss out on the whole point of this game.If you're a fan of CRPGs and want to expereince a great story - you MUST BUY THIS GAME.   - Every NPC so far has been a great experience.   - The items have all been interesting.   - The decisions have all given me pause, just what impact will this have down the line???The polish on the game is solid as well, very smooth feeling and it's just a goregous game.===========9 Hours inWow - this just gets better.  I ended up completing several quest chains in 2 new area maps during my next playthrough.  The NPCs continue to be very deep and engaging and boy am i sweating my decisions.  I actually failed at a quest I really wanted to succeed at, however I recall Colin McComb saying that failing in this game has sometimes more interesting consequences, so I'm letting my failures ride!Also, ended up at a bar for psycics and spent probably 2 housrs in there alone.  Ran into an NPC from Torment, very cool, and also had to do a few very interesting things with the NPCs in there.  I have to tell you, this bar, so far, is my favorite part of the game.   The folks in here were so amazing and the detail written for each made me care and worry about each one of them.  So great.===========18 Hours inMain Quest: Alright, so i'm making headway on the main quests now.  I have to say that i'm finding it quite interesting but also i'm getting very curious to see what role my character is going to play here.  The sheer amount of castoffs i'm running into is making me feel far  "less special' that I did at the start.  I think it's interesting to talk to the others but we seem to be a dime a dozen - which could be the point - The Changing God apparently changed bodies every 10-20 years.  Just not sure if i totally dig this aspect of the main story.  I wanna be SPECIAL DAMNIT!Bugs: As for bugs, I've noticed that long conversations bog down the game.  Some conversations with so many responses are the problem.  But this is easily fixed by stoppiong the dialog and starting again.Environments: They continue to be quite engaging and some of the NPCs are seriously funny.Items and quests:  So great.  Everything is interesting and the quests have lots of depth.  They definiteyl spent a lot of time making these both meaningful.Consequences: Definitely continue to feel i'm making an impact and i'm leaving a trail of broken situations i will need to see the counter-conclusions to in my NEXT play through.===========25 Hours inMain Story: Progressing through the main story - still quite interesting.  Making little progress on it though, so many fun side quests!  I have made some seriously f'd up decisions but that's how it goes in a Torment game : )  next play through I'll switch things up and see how things turn out on the flipside.Environments: I'm in the bloom now - what a great environment.  It's like a mix between the alien nest in Aliens and The Thing.  It's truely unique and the quests and the items and the interations that are possible in such a wild blend of environemtns make for such a great experience.  My favorite zone so far - just so much depth it's great.Special call out to the Doctors in the bloom - very funny dialog.Items and quests: The items i'm obtaining and the things I've been able to do with dropped items have been so fun.  So many unique itemts to use and figure out.  Dependant on your skills, you're able to use unique items by fiddling with them.  Hope I keep finding them, they're so interesting.Bugs: No bugsNext up - the Ascention!Highly recommended so far, more to come.

content:
Posted: March 19
												Amazing story!  If you like Planescape Torment you will like this too.  They have gotten a lot of critizism for the lack of character "descriptors"  or alternate classes basically.  However I believe that to be a poor critizism becase if they had encluded all these alternative descriptors, it wouldn't have changed the end product much at all.  It's a story driven CRPG and the story and your choices are what matter.  People are mad they don't get a word next to their name and a bonus percentage to another skill.  Which would change little to nothing, you might use less intellect points here or there but the story would remain.  Do you critize PS:T for having a lack of classes?  No, you don't because it's about the story, which is why the two games are so similar.  The stories and quests in both games can be very interesting.  I found Tides of Numenera's combat system to my liking.  It would have been nice to have the ability to increase the difficulty as I found the combat a bit easy, though I haven't finished the game.  This is because I've completed every quest I started; because they are so ineresting.  So I guess I out leveled most the content.This game was very nostalgic of Baulders Gate and PS:T.  I loved it and it deserver a better rating than it currently has on Steam.  I've aready addressed why there complaint about descriptors is irrevelant, such contect would change little.

number of helpful: 5 of 17 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												This may have the Grand Daddy most RPGs would love, it simply falls way short of the new generation of kick-started Classic RPGS.Firstly the class design is odd and takes a while to actually know how when you'll get new active abilities.  Most games offer new active abilities every level, and TON gives them every 5, in their hybrid system.I was getting into the odd system during the game, and when I finally felt the system was going somewhere, I hit the level cap at for all but in name Level 4.So the class design is very poor, as it simply doesn't have time to grow over the game as my second point is the game is way too short.It may boast 1 million words, but frankly when a world is so small you wonder where the dev time has gone?Add to that the confusion sometimes in conversation between multiple people on the screen, when you only get the name of the person talking, in a wall of text.  Simply we have come to expect character portraits of speaking characters in the game, and even the dev teams Wasteland 2 did it, so what where the artists actually doing?So all in all, a disappointment.- Class system not given time to develop (small cap)- Small World- No clear path for expansion (Story opens and closes fully)And would not recommend only for the die hard CRPG fans like myself hungry for the next one to drop!Better choices:  the excellent "Shadow Run Returns" (Sci-fi) or "Wastleland 2" (Post-Apoc)

content:
Posted: March 4
												Truelly the spiritual heir to Planescape Torment, and in a number of areas significantly better. Rather than stat thresholds the use of chance, edge and effort create a great and engaging game mechanic. The use of death and failure to open up alternate developments in plot is fantastic. So many items and associated mechanics with items such as cyphers, oddities and artifacts, each giving so much more in gameplay possibility whilst painting an ever richer lore. Skills, Foci and items make charachter development far more meaningful than just unlocking extra dialouge options. Turn based combat that allows you to use elements of the battlefield, interaction with items and persons in handcrafted scenarios known as crises make both dispute resolution and combat enthralling. 10/10 Extremely pleased I kickstarted this great game.

number of helpful: 0 of 7 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3
												This game has provided me a hefty amount of nostalgia dude to its cRPG style and graphics, and the setting is extremely thought-provoking. I come from a background of 20+ years of playing many different kinds of RPGs and I am a huge D&D fan as well. This game did an excellent job at its depth of story and lore, its playability, and its respect to the core of what this type of RPG is. What drew me to T:ToN was an opportunity to visit and engage in a fascinating new world, full of excitement, adventure, and wonder. Torment: Tides of Numenara does have a lot of dialogue and reading text is a huge part of the game. So if you have ever enjoyed reading fantasy and sci-fi novels, than this game is right up your alley. Combat isn't the forefront means of handling conflict in this game, so it can seem like it doesn't happen often enough. The combat system does provide something more fresh than the old D&D controls as well, which could feel clunky and burdensome at times. I have put in around 12 hours (already good value) and I've only focused on my one character.Needless to say, I am a huge supporter of this game. In terms of raw utility, this will provide me many hours of good fun.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Currently buggy as Hell. Seems to be only partly complete despite having been in development for 3 years way back when some of us decided to kick start it.Very wordy. Unnecessarily so - there's a lot of boring dialogue. The story could be interesting.For now wait and see what the next few builds bring up.I expect most people now playing it have already paid for it so I've just put this initial review out here and now for those who haven't and are thinking about it and to counter all the people who say it's the most amazing thing ever when it's a very unfinished article.Edit. Ok. Finished it now and have had some time to think about it. It's disappointing, in a word. Not as long as I'd hoped for, not as developed as I'd hoped for, not as interesting, not as fun, not as immersive and the characters ultimately all sound the same. Overall a big let down compared to POE which I kickstarted at the same time and which delivered much more.Double edit. And the time spent on the game includes about 22 hours playing the Alpha: really short game that many have indicated was cut due to one constraint or another (can't be budget, they went way over with their kickstarter and can't be time as they're 3 years late in delivery so can only assume they got crowded out by pizza boxes).Buy it on sale or better still, buy PST and enjoy a damn fine game.

number of helpful: 0 of 7 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31
												I backed the kickstarter and waited patiently for the release, I didn't actually realise how much it was delayed but well, here it is and now I've completed it. Others have spoken about InExile and the kickstarter promises and so on, I will just speak about the game.This game is all about the lore and world-building, and everywhere you go in the game there is something to poke and prod at and uncover secrets and memories. Even the loot is mostly unique, giving you little snippets of lost cultures and mysteries to ponder. I love that, and I spent a lot of time pouring over every bit of text I could find. The characters are varied and interesting, pulling from the lore to create a fascinating cast of original characters, which was definitely remiscent of Planescape: Torment. I found the companions a little lacking, though they each stand out they perhaps didn't have as much to say as I would have hoped, and they didn't react to events very often and didn't have much of a part in the final scenes as the companions did in PS:T.The story is obviously the main focus and I'd say it's interesting enough to recommend. It's very much a personal journey and while you do have an effect on the world, it's not your generic world-in-peril kind of stuff which is refreshing. There are some twists and turns and in the end your choices feel meaningful, and present a moral challenge that makes you think beyond "what is the right choice?"The combat is garbage, what else can I say. Planescape: Torment is probably my favourite game and I feel like it was a massive departure from the spirit of the original game to go with turn-based. In PS:T, the combat was criticised for being too simple and chaotic, but I liked that, and even where it failed to impress it at least went by quickly. The same cannot be said of T:ToN. There is no hurry-up or skip turn button for AI characters, and so in big fights you have to sit and watch them derpily stagger around turn by turn, and if they all decide to gang up on the main character, then too bad load a save or start again with less items. In PS:T you could pause the combat and use a healing item, but in T:ToN if it isn't your turn, too bad you can't do anything. There are at least a couple of fights in the game with an enemy that can one-shot anyone on the screen and if it targets the main character... yeah you guessed it. There are non-combat options to get out of crises or have them not start at all, but due to the turn based nature it can often be frustrating to achieve them when your character is standing right next to the thing but can't interract with it because they have to let themselves get wailed on for ten more turns because that makes sense. In case it isn't obvious I don't like turn based combat, I'll stop ranting about it now. It's not the draw of the game, and I only point out how bad it is so that people don't have any expectations that this game has any kind of decent tactical combat - it doesn't.All in all I think it's a decent shot at a spiritual successor to PS:T, and I'm glad I backed it and played it, and I will play it again in the future to try the different classes and companions. I don't agree with others that the game is too short, I feel the story warranted the length and it feels like value for money to me, especially as it does have some replay value. I don't think it's going to be making my favourite games of all time list, but if you want an interesting story-based RPG then I'd say this is worth your time.

A deep dark story, lore and narrative are stable concepts in the Torment universe. From the creators of 'Wasteland 2' You are born falling from orbit, a new mind in a body once occupied by the Changing God, a being who has cheated death for millennia. If you survive, your journey through the Ninth World will only get stranger… and deadlier. With a host of strange companions – whose motives and goals may help or harm you – you must escape an ancient, unstoppable creature called the Sorrow and answer the question that defines your existence: What does one life matter? Torment: Tides of Numenera is the thematic successor to Planescape: Torment, one of the most critically acclaimed and beloved role-playing games of all time. Torment: Tides of Numenera is a single-player, isometric, narrative-driven role-playing game set in Monte Cook’s Numenera universe, and brought to you by the creative team behind Planescape: Torment.  - Recommended!

A worthy successor to Planescape: TormentPlanescape: Torment is one of my favorite games of all-time. I waited for a long time for a RPG that would scratch the same itch as that game, and after more than 15 years I finally found one in Torment: Tides of Numenera. Posted: September 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								Of course it's not a finished game, but..If you were expecting the great return of PS:T, don't. It's not there and signs are it will never get there. The design IQ is not of the same level. * Graphics are unsettling and annoyingly cluttered. They totally went way overboard in depicting the "whacky" setting, that a normal area would probably have a few ancient robots made of banana cake, floating eyes with tree shaped black holes above them and a giant tuba encircled by moons of multicolored cheese balls. Basically it's nausea inducing rather than being fantastic or even interesting.* Writing is bad on many levels. It's... it's really bad guys. Sorry.You have these half hour long text-adventures that are grossly over-written, you have writers trying to be ego-tripping-writers to the point where you got characters being written so over the top that they're retard-funny.For example, here's a guy threatening you in TTON: "Two things are more dangerous than death in this world".. "Asking impolite questions of strangers and playing with numenera you don't fully understand".Who the hell wrote this crap? What the hell could be more dangerous than f*** DEATH?!I mean props for trying to be "dramatic" but "2 things are more dangerous than death" ?? Why not 3 things? Why not chocolate bunnies? I mean, "being impolite"?? What?!?!Or why not "2 things are more dangerous than drinking and driving" for example? "2 things are more dangerous than boarding an overloaded elevator"? Maybe "going outside with wet hair", But DEATH? srsly??At times it feels like the writers of the game were told to "write really damn good!" and overdid it to hilarious effect. It is nothing like the gritty and compelling writing of PS:T, where characters are characters and your guy is a character also.The devs. explained at some point that the dialogue is so godawful because they didn't want to describe your character too much, and so dialogue is mostly "information".  I guess that's what you get when you try to make a torment game without feargus urquhart and chris avellone both on the teamAnd there you go. The more I played it the more the comparison to PS:T made the experience a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ one for me. So I stopped. Maybe when it's released somewhere in 2065 (it's been delayed like 3 years already)

Posted: March 30
												After finishing the game my impression of this game is a very positive one albeit i feel that inXile did themselves a disservice by closely associating this game with Planescape:Torment as I have seen many try to compare every aspect of the game to PS:T. If they would have created the game without mentioning it being a spiriutal successor peoples expectations would have been different and maybe the reception would have been more positive.If you are a fan of strange and fantastical settings, lore heavy isometric rpgs with more focus on dialogue than on combat i believe you will enjoy this game. The combat is not something to celebrate, but the writing more than compensate for this deficiency.As the combat was not an issue for me and I did not base my expectation on how it compared to PS:T I must say inXile created a good and exciting game. The theme of torment also resonated nicely troughout the game as all the NPCs you can recruit all are tormented by their past.As a last word, if PS:T was a 9/10 this game would be an 8/10. Recommended for all isometric RPG fans.

												I'm not the best at writing up reviews, so I'll try to keep this fairly basic.The combat system is simple but fair.  There's a lot more of it than most reviews would have you believe if you don't build your character to just talk past everything, however.The setting...I love the setting.  It's the deranged aftermath of multiple apocalypses and ascensions, where the line between science and magic has worn so thin it's almost impossible to tell the difference anymore.And it's very much a proper successor to Planescape: Torment.  More concerned with philosophy than action.Finally...this makes me want more Numenera games.  The system has some very interesting possibilities.

												There are some shortcomings, but overall I liked it a lot. I don't know what else people expected from Planescape's "spiritual successor". The game focuses on story and writing above all else, it has a huge amount of text, it raises questions about immortality and consciousness, it's full of weird characters, items and locations, and it favors intellect-based characters so much that it's totally unfair. Yep, sounds totally like Planescape to me. It's not AS good, but still good.The only problem for me are companions, their stories just aren't that interesting, except for one or maybe two.Also, why people who have like 60 hours on record complain that the game is short? Seriously. I have 50, that's one playthrough with all sidequests and some save loads to see different outcomes. Even without all that, I think just the main story would be at least 15-20 hours. What the hell, guys.

number of helpful: 1 of 11 people (9%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14
												I wasn't a kickstarter and though I've been looking forward to this game as someone who loved Planescape: Torment, I subjected myself to as little hype or foreknowledge as possible.THE SETTING: It's a bit like a cross between Fallout and Planescape. The premise of a Sci-Fi/Fantasy world filled with gadgets that might do something cool or blow your face off is very appealing and could possibly lend itself to all sorts of great stories. Absolutely loved it, I hope they'll make more games that use it in the future. GAMEPLAY: I really like the Crisis system and the idea that you can, and indeed sometimes have to, resolve them without combat. In fact, I experienced so little combat I can't even properly comment on it. STORY: WARNING, SLIGHT SPOILERS. This is where the game lets itself down a bit for me. Of course, I still compare it to Planescape: Torment (which I rate as the best video game of all time, storywise), so it's still not BAD. Just, could be better. I liked the party characters, none of them felt flat or one-dimensional (with the exception of Erritis but perhaps that was intentional). I just wish game developers stopped enforcing arbitrary headcount limits. The foreshadowing you can get with Anamnesis gets a bit spoiler-y at times; I guessed several major plot twists (like the importance of the Ghostly Woman) before I even left the first city.The abrupt ending feels more than a bit rushed and the central question "What does one life matter?" gets a bit flimsy at times, where Planescape: Torment's "What can change the nature of a man?" never dropped out of focus.Also the final end sequence I hated, for the same reasons I hated Mass Effect 3's ending. Throughout the game, the primary antagonist (The Sorrow) is represented as a hateful force that tries to kill you through no fault of your own and cannot be reasoned with. At the last moment it basically goes "Turns out trying to kill was really hard, maybe I should just talk to you instead" and offers the same insane troll logic the Reapers in ME3 used as justification for trying to kill you. And then the game forces you to agree to play along with the Sorrow's one-sided offers for compromise; The only ending where you don't is shown to be a bad one.

Don't let the crying babies keep you away from this gem.

content:

Product received for free
												Like Planescape: Torment, this game tells its stories through reams and reams of text. Unlike Planescape, it's horribly overwritten. The writers have used 50 words where 5 would do. As this is pretty much a massive choose-your-own adventure novel, the tortured prose made it tiresome and unplayable for me. Also, the game doesn't seem to have a connection with the original Torment game, other than the main character being an amnesiac who's recovering their memories - an RPG cliche that should be killed with fire.

								I'm not the demographic for this game.I didn't play the previous Torment, but I was excited due to the positive feedback from the kickstarter and the overwhelming response from nearly every review online.That being said, my objective observation is that this story is not a game. The "combat" is so sparse that you could even argue that it isn't necssary, and that the whole "game" could be ported to a kindle with the same value. I'd rather have read this as an adventure book. It would have not brought forth expectations of 21st century animation and probably wouldn't have cost $45.

number of helpful: 29 of 89 people (33%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Contains spoilers. You were warned.To those who think im being unreasonable or just hating on the game: please go back to your fallouts 4, wastelands 2 and other garbage hailed as universal masterpiece. If however you played things like Consortium, Age of Decadence, Silent Storm Sentinels, Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines or had an irl roleplaying adventure with a competent DM, and enjoyed them, - you are likely to agree with me here. The game is at best a 7/10, despite all the promises and hollow boasts at how incredible its gonna be, it doesnt deliver. It hasnt delivered the experienced it strived and promised to. If you disagree with that, hey im happy you are happy with the game, because i am not.I have concearns about this game. I absolutely love the concept, how its realised however... i played just one hour got annoyed with some things to be honest. A lot of people are giving this a 10/10 straight up, talking about how great it is, and for the most part its pretty solid, however: there is room for doubt. During my 1st launch i died before spawning, *spoilers* you are ejected from a sort of cocoon down the planet, so i figured might aswell get there faster. Dead. But if you sit around in midair pondering existance you dont die despite falling god knows the distance. Now ingame the reason for why you die in one condition and dont in another : Terminal velocity, nevermind the distance its the speed that kills you. Great. Moving on: the tutorial is a cluster♥♥♥♥ and in theory as you see memories of others it could be incredible, what it fails to do however is give any sort of direction or motivation. Oh hey its another faceless husk i never seen before and i get to decide what happens... oh boy, where you pretty much select what stat you want to increase, which is probably far from what you would have done if you gave 2 ♥♥♥♥♥ about the characters involved.Writing is top notch with a few bumps here and there but its all too ♥♥♥♥ing convenient. Oh hey check it out! There are 5 tanks and consoles, oh gee and 5 enemies 1 per console who could have guessed. Oh and the radiant light vanquishes yeh yeh great tides n stuff.I sat there for an hour (or less i might have went to cook something) being bored out of my mind and i love rpgs. I had no empathy to anyone involved for all i care the characters should have all died. It wasnt some intense situation there is no sense of urgency or impact or pretty much anything other then tedium forced upon you. QUICK THERE IS NO TIME TO EXPLAIN GET THIS DONE! OH YOU WANT TO KNOW MORE? WELL LET ME TALK TO YOU ABOUT IT FOR 20 MINUTES WE GOT TIME! You just proceed at your own convenience, where is the monsters starting attack midsentese because you are ♥♥♥♥ing too slow? Where is need to survive? Why should i care for a hundred characters im gonna see for just 20 seconds of screen time? Its 2d and yet it lags like no other. There is no optimisation whatsowhever. And on top of all that, they hired Mitsoda to help them sink this boat. The game has a great potential, it can be amazing, hell i ONLY saw tutorial, nothing more but it was enough for me to be dissuaded from exploring any more at least till they release this. Its a no for me atm, only people i can recommend this to are avid RPG fans, game has some interesting things to offer, but not too many and are outweighted by all the negatives.Update11/06/2016: Well, they made an update, removing the horrid starting battle/introduction to tides, replacing it with no introduction, random spam of TIDE INCREASED with no explantion on why or what. Sometimes it just keeps spamming same one aswell GOLDEN INCREASED, so after about 20 blips of it i thought ok i might have it up in the sky with that value by now, - turns out it didnt even move. Battles! The famous "we'll have about a dozen crisises" yeh no wonder, with a fighting system where you cant attack or cast anything, no ♥♥♥♥ing wonder you dont want any more of that. So right now, tides is a talking simulator. So i decided to give it a go after people said 'its just tutorial" and went out there, talked to people a bit - 1st area there was some orc in stasis, weird looking semiconstruct, cultists and quantum clock, in a bar next to it - a psychic cafe in which a few ghosts, an alien and an otherworldly creature preside, all like 5 minutes of walk, not to mention talking digging insects that were brought from another plane, yet EVERYONE is losing their♥♥♥♥♥♥that you are just another body used up and discarded, which apparently were plenty before. Half the npcs ♥♥♥♥ing met you before anyway, others know who you are just because, some are psychics, some have spies that you cant ever see, others just deduce or heard rumors. Everyone is so ♥♥♥♥ing well informed, its a wonder peasants havent rebelled by now, since everyone is so incredibly observant, they see corruption, some can even see into the ♥♥♥♥ing future and whatnot yet no one does nothing. Thats another thing, so you got an npc who can see the future, but she doesnt know hers. Makes sense, just like so many other things. There are A LOT of problems in the writing. Some things are done right, i loved some of the npcs, those were brilliant like that girl who kept yelling that she is CHAMPION OF LAND YOU'LL NEVER SEE, or the dude who crashed and burned, the digging insects were done well, the scummy negotiator, - a lot of things are done really well, not impressive, but fun and enjoyable. Point being, good thing you are gonna delay this till 2017 there is A LOT of work ahead of you. Get to fixing.

								I'm not liking this game at all and certainly don't recommend it. I paid full price and can't get past 2.5 hours. This is that bad. Character generation is needlessly long. Combat is wonky and unintuitive. The only attraction is the artwork. If you like this perspective and Baldur's Gate feel, get Pillars of Eternity. It's out of 'beta'.
